headline: Inflammatory Bowel Disease Tied to Increased Dementia Risk
abstract: Those with Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis had higher rates of Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia.
lead_paragraph: People with inflammatory bowel disease — either Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis — may be at increased risk for dementia, a new study has found.

headline: How Do You Define Rosé?
abstract: These very different bottles raised questions about whether to group by color or by how the wines are made.
lead_paragraph: Certain categories of wine must be approached on tiptoe, as opinions surrounding them will be tenaciously defended, even if their champions are ill-informed. Arguments will ensue.

headline: Verdicchio di Matelica, to Discover or Revisit
abstract: Italian whites have long been derided, but many, particularly verdicchios, have the potential to make very good wines.
lead_paragraph: As some of you might have noticed, I’ve been on an Italian white wine kick. I’ve been particularly interested in wines made from the verdicchio grape.

headline: Think of Kimchi as a Verb
abstract: You can make these quick versions out of just about anything, including tomatoes and fennel.
lead_paragraph: In 1904, the Japanese military authorities arrested the American novelist Jack London. Three times. He was covering the Russo-Japanese War for the San Francisco Examiner as a war correspondent in Korea, and drew from his time overseas in a 1915 novel, “The Star Rover.”

headline: N.F.L. to Shorten Its Preseason, Pending Players’ Approval
abstract: The league proposed halving the preseason, going from four games per team to two, citing coronavirus concerns and players’ need for more time to get in shape for the regular season.
lead_paragraph: One consequence of the coronavirus may turn out to be a positive for players and other critics of meaningless football games. The N.F.L. wants to halve its preseason schedule to two games per team, from four.

headline: Introducing ‘Father Soldier Son,’ a Film From The Times and Netflix
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Ten years in the making, this documentary traces one veteran’s experience to create an intimate portrait of an American family.
lead_paragraph: War enlists generations.

headline: ‘Liberty Bell’ Tolls for Sites Where History Is Alive and Kicking
abstract: Nancy Baker Cahill uses augmented reality to explore the meaning of historical sites from the Rockaways in New York to Selma, Ala. Is public art embellishing our heritage, or defacing it?
lead_paragraph: Little did she know.

headline: The Gallery Where Stevie Wonder Was a Regular
abstract: Linda Goode Bryant discusses her career — from art dealer to urban farmer — with the artist Senga Nengudi.
lead_paragraph: This summer, Linda Goode Bryant, the pioneering art dealer, received the 2020 Berresford Prize from the nonprofit United States Artists, which is awarded annually to “a cultural practitioner who has contributed significantly to the advancement, well-being and care of artists in society.” In 1974 Bryant founded the gallery Just Above Midtown on 57th Street, which became one of New York City’s first dedicated art spaces for Black artists. Bryant now runs the urban farming initiative Project EATS, based in New York. This conversation, between Bryant and Senga Nengudi, one of the artists who got her start at JAM, took place over Zoom, and touches on JAM’s history and its legacy.

headline: 8 Things to Do This Fourth of July Weekend
keywords: ['Art', 'United States National Anthem Protests (2016- )', 'Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'Dancing', 'Classical Music', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Fireworks', 'Museums', 'Children and Childhood', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Television', 'Theater', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Our culture writers offer suggestions for celebrating Independence Day, and what to watch or listen to without leaving your home.
lead_paragraph: Judging by the sharp increase in complaints about illegal amateur firework displays this year, many New Yorkers might have already had their fill. The city’s aerial pyrotechnics typically reach a climax with its official spectacle, Macy’s 4th of July Fireworks. But this year, New York’s annual Independence Day celebration has been split up into a series of five-minute shows at locations across the five boroughs in order to discourage large crowds from gathering. The highlights from these displays, which began on Monday, will be broadcast on NBC on Saturday at 8 p.m. Eastern and Pacific time, along with a live finale. The telecast will also feature musical performances by John Legend, Lady A, the Black Eyed Peas and others.PETER LIBBEY

headline: New ‘TV’ Is a Lot Like TV
abstract: Home entertainment today isn’t all that different from the time of VHS tapes.

headline: Two Confederate Statues Removed in Richmond
abstract: Richmond, Va., removed a statue of the Confederate general Stonewall Jackson and one of Matthew Fontaine Maury, a Confederate naval officer.
lead_paragraph: Richmond, Va., removed a statue of the Confederate general Stonewall Jackson and one of Matthew Fontaine Maury, a Confederate naval officer.

headline: ‘The Truth’ Review: Being Catherine Deneuve
abstract: Following his Palme d’Or-winning “Shoplifters,” the Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda visits some of the glories of France.
lead_paragraph: When Catherine Deneuve appears in “The Truth” she isn’t simply in character. She comes in accompanied by a multiplicity of other roles and previous performances, by former directors and co-stars, old loves and scandals and triumphs, all crowding around her like phantoms. That’s often the case now with Deneuve, who, like any enduring star, has become a living testament to her own glory. Even when she’s playing relatively down-to-earth characters, she transcends their ordinary constraints.

headline: Deutsche Bank May Offer Wirecard a Lifeline
abstract: Deutsche Bank said it was considering offering emergency financing to the hobbled German fintech giant, which has filed for insolvency.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Two weeks after the spectacular crash of the German fintech giant Wirecard, Deutsche Bank said Thursday that it was open to provide emergency financing to help keep the company functioning, even as its former chief executive is out on bail and his top aide is hiding from the authorities.

headline: Review: Apple-Picking Time Again, in ‘And So We Come Forth’
abstract: Richard Nelson’s fictional family returns, but for the first time this drama of connection in the age of American bewilderment feels smaller than life.
lead_paragraph: Are the Apples becoming must-see TV?

headline: This Is the Secret to the Crunchiest Fruit Crumble
abstract: Double-baking the crumb topping keeps it wonderfully crisp over its jammy fruit filling.
lead_paragraph: I learned the secret to making the best, crunchiest fruit crumble over two decades ago. And I subsequently ignored it.

headline: Hugh Downs, Perennial Small-Screen Fixture, Is Dead at 99
abstract: A longtime host of both “Today” and “20/20,” for many years he held the Guinness-certified record for most total hours on commercial network television.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Downs, whose honeyed delivery and low-key but erudite manner helped make him a familiar face and voice on television for half a century, and whose career included long stints as host of both “Today” on NBC and “20/20” on ABC, died on Wednesday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 99.

headline: Berkshires Museums Announce Reopening Plans Under Phase 3
abstract: Mass MoCA, the Norman Rockwell Museum and the Clark Art Institute will reopen this month, with programming changes and social-distancing measures.
lead_paragraph: Three major cultural institutions in the Berkshires will reopen this month, following the greenlight from Charlie Baker, the governor of Massachusetts, who said on Thursday that the state would move into Phase 3 of its reopening plans.

headline: Coldcut + Tony Allen and African Artists = Studio Electricity
abstract: Keleketla! is a studio assemblage of musicians from four continents, creating thoroughly hybridized music with African voices up front.
lead_paragraph: Keleketla! isn’t a group. It’s a studio assemblage of British, South African, Nigerian, American and more musicians that recorded mostly in South Africa and England, produced by the English electronic-music duo Coldcut.

headline: Lester Grinspoon, Influential Marijuana Scholar, Dies at 92
abstract: He believed pot was dangerous until his research convinced him otherwise. He then became a leading proponent of legalization.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lester Grinspoon, a Harvard psychiatry professor who became a leading proponent of legalizing marijuana after his research found it was less toxic or addictive than alcohol or tobacco, died on June 25 at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 92.

headline: For Interracial Couples, Advocacy Is a Love Language
abstract: Having tough conversations about racism, police brutality and current events aren’t an option for Black and white couples — they’re essential.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, people all over the world have taken to social media and to the streets to reject police brutality and injustice toward Black people.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday unanimously passed legislation to impose sanctions on Chinese officials trying to stamp out political dissent in Hong Kong, sending the measure to President Trump’s desk for his signature.

lead_paragraph: Ghislaine Maxwell, the former girlfriend of Jeffrey Epstein, was arrested and accused of helping Mr. Epstein sexually abuse girls.

lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Tatayanna Mitchell, 21, will fly from Michigan to Newark, N.J., to spend two days with a boy she met on TikTok.

headline: Mysterious Explosion and Fire Damage Iranian Nuclear Enrichment Facility
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Sabotage (Crime)', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Iran released a photograph showing evidence of what appeared to be a major explosion at the site. Early evidence suggests it was most likely an act of sabotage.
lead_paragraph: A fire ripped through a building at Iran’s main nuclear-fuel production site early Thursday, causing extensive damage to what appeared to be a factory where the country has boasted of producing a new generation of centrifuges. The United States has repeatedly warned that such machinery could speed Tehran’s path to building nuclear weapons.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Coronavirus, a New Drug and Bedbugs
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Florida, America’s Pandemic Playground
abstract: Need a venue for a large indoor gathering — a national political convention, say? The state’s got you covered.
lead_paragraph: By now, Americans have come to expect a certain level of quirkiness from Florida. All that heat and humidity does something to people — not to mention the invading hordes of Northern and Midwestern retirees in search of bountiful sunshine and friendly tax laws. In recent years, “Florida Man” has become mocking shorthand for state denizens caught in acts of flamboyant idiocy, often involving some mix of drugs, guns, cops and predatory reptiles.

headline: How ‘365 Days’ Became One of Netflix’s Worst-Reviewed Big Hits
abstract: Critically panned, the steamy Polish flick is a streaming success thanks to TikTok teenagers and curious fans. But there’s also a growing backlash from those who say it glorifies rape culture.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Michele Morrone was working as a gardener in a tiny northern Italian village. Newly divorced, broke and severely depressed, he had given up on his TV acting career after being repeatedly told that he was too attractive for the roles on offer. “In Italy, if you’re a good-looking guy, you’re not an actor,” he said matter-of-factly. “You’re just someone good-looking.”

headline: Four Restorative Facials to Try at Home
abstract: The products, tools and tips from the professionals that you need to be your own facialist.
lead_paragraph: The New York-based aesthetician Isabelle Bellis, who is accustomed to using her hands for much of the day — lifting, sculpting and massaging the facial muscles of her clients — has felt a noticeable loss lately. Since deciding to permanently close her Manhattan studio after the pandemic hit, Bellis has turned to gardening, at her home in rural Connecticut, as a way to keep her fingers nimble and active — and, she says, to “fill the void.”

headline: Hong Kong, Australia Outbreak, Hagia Sophia: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: San Francisco Police Department to Limit the Release of Mug Shots
abstract: San Francisco’s police chief announced that the department won’t release mug shots of people who have been arrested unless they posed a public safety threat.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco’s police chief announced that the department won’t release mug shots of people who have been arrested unless they posed a public safety threat.

headline: French Open, Unlike U.S. Open, to Allow Fans at its Tournament
abstract: The French Open, played on red-clay courts, is known generally for being the most crowded Grand Slam tournament. Organizers say they are planning for as many as 20,000 fans daily.
lead_paragraph: Despite the coronavirus pandemic, two more Grand Slam tennis tournaments are still scheduled to be played in 2020: the United States Open and the French Open.

headline: How to Keep Good Habits Post-Lockdown
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Exercise', 'Content Type: Service', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: You’ll technically have to ‘relearn’ to cook each meal, or to exercise regularly or to read a book a week. But there are some shortcuts.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has brought with it a global economic downturn; unemployment in the United States has reached its highest level since the Great Depression, and many people whose jobs have not been outright eliminated have seen their work, and lives, radically transformed. But as old daily rituals are leveled, for better or worse, new ones have emerged and taken their places.

headline: Teetering Independence of Ukraine’s Central Bank Tests a Key I.M.F. Demand
abstract: The International Monetary Fund agreed to lend Ukraine $5 billion over 18 months while stressing the importance of central bank independence. Three weeks later, the central banker quit, citing political pressure.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Ukrainian government plunged into another round of turmoil over foreign aid and anti-corruption policy when the director of the nation’s central bank resigned this week, citing political pressure in violation of International Monetary Fund guidelines.

headline: Florida State University Child Care Policy Draws Backlash
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Telecommuting', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The university sent an email to its employees last week saying they would no longer be able to care for children while working remotely. After a backlash, the university clarified its policy.
lead_paragraph: Florida State University appears to be walking back an announcement that suggested it would not allow employees to care for children while working from home during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Freddy Cole, Performer Who Emerged From Nat’s Shadow, Dies at 88
abstract: Like his famous older sibling, he played the piano and sang. But he used his music to insist, “I’m Not My Brother, I’m Me.”
lead_paragraph: Freddy Cole, a pianist and vocalist who spent much of his musical life in the shadow of his brother Nat King Cole, but whose durable talents carried him through a triumphant late-career resurgence, died on Saturday in Atlanta. He was 88.

headline: Goodbye to the Wild Wild Web
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Discrimination', 'Cyberharassment', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: The internet is changing, and the freewheeling, anything-goes culture of social media is being replaced by something more accountable.
lead_paragraph: It felt like a dam breaking, or the changing of a guard.

headline: Moderate Drinking May Be Good for the Brain
abstract: A study found that older men and women who drank in moderation had slower rates of cognitive decline.
lead_paragraph: Moderate alcohol consumption may lead to slower mental decline in middle-age and older people, a new study found.

headline: Herman Cain Hospitalized With Coronavirus
abstract: The former presidential candidate attended the president’s indoor rally in Oklahoma last month. He was hospitalized on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Update: Herman Cain has died at 74. Read the obituary here.

headline: Trump’s Virus Is Spreading, and His Economy Is Stalling
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Disease Rates']
abstract: The president leads a transition to sickness.
lead_paragraph: Just over two weeks ago The Wall Street Journal published an opinion piece by Vice President Mike Pence titled “There Isn’t a Coronavirus ‘Second Wave.’” The article was supposed to reassure the nation.

headline: Gay Culverhouse,Who Helped Injured Football Players, Dies at 73
abstract: She navigated the league’s male-dominated world as a team president, then devoted her energy to fighting on behalf of players with brain disorders.
lead_paragraph: Gay Culverhouse, who put aside her career focusing on special education and child psychiatry to join the family business, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers of the N.F.L., and who went on to champion the cause of former professional football players debilitated by dementia and other health issues, died on Wednesday at her home in Fernandina Beach, Fla. She was 73.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: We’re heading into the Fourth of July weekend, and if that means beach reading for you (whether or not it involves an actual beach), then we’ve got lots of fiction to recommend. You might like Debra Jo Immergut’s eerie thriller of midlife regret, “You Again,” or Joseph O’Connor’s historical novel “Shadowplay,” about Bram Stoker and the creation of “Dracula.” You might like Gene Luen Yang’s graphic novel updating of a classic superhero story, “Superman Smashes the Klan.” If you miss sports the way I do, then Katherine Hill’s football novel “A Short Move” will scratch that itch at the same time it challenges you to consider the physical and emotional toll of competition, especially for men. There’s also a new Ottessa Moshfegh novel — it’s a mystery, sort of — and a poetry book taking on the crimes of imperialism, and two different novels set in Japan, one of them about a murderous divorce scheme and the other about a ghost in a Tokyo park. In nonfiction, we recommend Diane Johnson’s classic biography “The True History of the First Mrs. Meredith,” along with Joe Meno’s poignant odyssey of two Ghanaian men seeking refuge in the United States. It’s not a happy story, but it’s an appropriate one to read on a holiday when the nature of America itself is in the spotlight.

abstract: In ongoing discussions, team owners and the players’ union are considering how to spread out reductions in the salary cap if few or no fans attend games this fall.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. team owners and the players’ union, chastened by the spread of the coronavirus and mindful of other professional leagues’ struggles to return to play, are considering playing the 2020 regular season with few or no fans in attendance and are actively discussing how to absorb lost revenue potentially worth billions, according to three people briefed on the discussions who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not allowed to discuss the matter publicly.

headline: Federal Loan Saved a Soccer Season Nearly Lost to the Pandemic
abstract: The N.W.S.L. was one of millions of businesses that took Paycheck Protection Program loans this year. The money got the league and its players through eight uncertain weeks.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic spread early this year, shutting down large portions of the United States economy, the federal government handed out more than $520 billion in forgivable loans to more than five million small businesses. Called the Paycheck Protection Program, the money was to be used to replace the incomes of employees suddenly unable to work as cities and states entered lockdowns to reduce infection rates.

With no new blockbusters to enjoy (or endure), we invited readers to revisit Steven Spielberg’s popular park, where a T. rex and velociraptors develop a taste for human prey.

Since then, Essence has installed Caroline A. Wanga, a former Target executive, as its interim leader and has also pledged to hire law firms to conduct a review of workplace issues.

The point when hospitals reach 70 percent capacity is a red flag, for instance; so are upticks in coronavirus case counts and deaths.

headline: A Difficult Independence Day
abstract: The virus has feasted on a compromised body.
lead_paragraph: MONTROSE, Colo. — Around here, on Colorado’s Western Slope, the virus is known as “the Rona.” As in, “the Rona” is back. Montrose voted for Donald Trump in 2016, and he still has enough support to make masks rare. Up the way, in liberal Telluride, everyone wears them. Even disease is tribal now.

Berman, the former top federal prosecutor in Manhattan who was abruptly dismissed last month, has agreed to testify in a closed-door hearing before lawmakers next week as part of an inquiry into potential politicization at the Justice Department, according to a House Judiciary Committee notice reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: A Long Road to Hope
abstract: Acknowledging years of oppression and then suggesting we simply move on is as offensive as remaining silently complicit.
lead_paragraph: NARROWSBURG, N.Y. — I’ve made the trip from the North to the South and back again many times over the past five decades, first in the back of a bus in the ’60s and then by car. Whenever I traveled north, I felt that the weight of the yoke of my undeniable Blackness lessened with each mile.

It was a benefit for the Southern Foodways Alliance and included a dinner at the James Beard Foundation; it was not sponsored by the alliance and the James Beard Foundation.

headline: Severe Floods in China Leave Over 106 Dead or Missing
abstract: Unusually intense rainfall has swept away buildings and ruined homes in southern China, affecting about 15 million residents. More downpours are forecast for Saturday.
lead_paragraph: In the inland Chinese city of Yichang, the murky water ran waist-high, stranding people in their cars and turning streets into canals. Near the metropolis of Chongqing, angry torrents of water swept away country roads. The tourist town of Yangshuo experienced a cloudburst that an official called a once-in-two-centuries event.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Young Ahmed’ and ‘Hamilton’
abstract: The latest movie from Jean-Pierre Dardenne and Luc Dardenne is on Criterion Channel. And a film of the Broadway musical “Hamilton” debuts on Disney+.
lead_paragraph: YOUNG AHMED (2020) Stream on Criterion Channel; rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. A bespectacled Belgian teenager gets swept up by radicalism in this most recent film from the brothers Jean-Pierre Dardenne and Luc Dardenne. The teenager, a 13-year-old named Ahmed (Idir Ben Addi), falls under the influence of an extremist imam (Othmane Moumen). As Ahmed grows apart from his family, his attention falls on his math tutor, Inès (Myriem Akheddiou) — a fixation that leads to catastrophe. “The plot may hinge on Ahmed’s actions and motivations,” A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times, “but the film’s real drama revolves around a central moral and political conflict, between religious extremism and a humanist ethos that is more behavioral than doctrinal.”

headline: Australia Faces Its Own Reckoning Over Diversity in Media
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Indigenous Australians', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The Black Lives Matter movement has inspired Australians to examine issues of race in our own country.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, my mother was a reporter in Melbourne, where much of her work focused on the Indigenous communities in Victoria. She recently told me about a time when she went to her editors at The Age and suggested that they actively seek out and recruit young Indigenous reporters because — while she felt she had earned the trust of her sources — their stories would be better told by people from that community. Hiring a more diverse staff, she explained, would be better for journalism and better for the newspaper.

headline: Colleges Face Rising Revolt by Professors
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'E-Learning', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Most universities plan to bring students back to campus. But many of their teachers are concerned about joining them.
lead_paragraph: College students across the country have been warned that campus life will look drastically different in the fall, with temperature checks at academic buildings, masks in half-empty lecture halls and maybe no football games.

headline: The #Vanlife Business Is Booming
abstract: Coronavirus is just a distant memory while zipping around in a several-hundred-thousand-dollar custom van on the open road.
lead_paragraph: I do not own a car or a house or even a bicycle. Nor am I prone to following Instagram trends. Yet for weeks I have had an obsession: getting rid of all my possessions, breaking the apartment lease, and moving with my dog and my girlfriend into a tricked-out van.

abstract: Recent polls suggest that about 15 million to 26 million people in the U.S. have participated in recent protests.

headline: A Connection Rooted in the Land
abstract: When Benjamin Litwin spotted Madigan Beck arriving at the Colorado ashram where he then lived, he sprinted to the entryway to greet her.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, when Madigan Beck was just a girl, one of the interns on her family’s community-supported agriculture farm in Osceola, Wis., made a big impression on her.

headline: Reflecting on Summer Camp in Our Campless Summer
keywords: ['Letters', 'Camps and Camping', 'Luggage and Packing', 'Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting']
abstract: The letters my children and I used to send to and from camp were little shots of treasure, containing everything we would use to put our family back together at the end of summer.
lead_paragraph: During the normal school year, before my three children and I were confined to distance learning and lockdown measures, I structured my time faithfully, maintaining a life with a purpose entirely my own. My children worked hard to carve out that kind of space for themselves too, the way children should.

headline: She Felt Special by the Nikes He Wore
abstract: Lana Price had taken to approaching dating as a duty — one point for every date — and then she met Mel Wallace.
lead_paragraph: Lana Price was living in New York in 2015 and losing enthusiasm for dating when it struck her that she and her friends, who also reported lackluster attempts at romance, should try a new approach.

headline: Our Supreme Court Correspondent on This Week’s Abortion Ruling
abstract: A Louisiana law that could have reduced the number of abortion clinics in the state to one was struck down on Monday. In an interview, Adam Liptak, who covers the court, provided context to the decision.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Donkeys, Elephants and a Samoyed Puppy
abstract: They might differ politically, but agreed on getting a Samoyed puppy after they got married.
lead_paragraph: Paul Ryan Dorsey noticed Ariel Holy Gordon in August 2015 as soon as she walked into the University of Michigan Alumni Club bar in Washington and then they stood next to each other glancing up now and then to watch the first football game of the season.

headline: Now Showing: A First Love That Stuck
abstract: Ariella Segal and Eli Shapiro met in 2009 when both were freshmen at N.Y.U.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus forced Ariella Segal and Eli Shapiro to move their May 24 wedding to July 5, a rehearsal dinner was no longer necessary. But they did need an oil change.

headline: They Started With a First Kiss. The First Date Came Later.
abstract: Jess Seok and Gifford Brooks had a first date a few months after sharing a kiss. Many months later, he asked her to be his girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: While most couples have a first date, followed at some point by a first kiss, Jess Seok and Gifford Brooks did not. But they didn’t skip the kissing part.

headline: Meeting at Just the Right Time
abstract: Mallory Traughber and Jessica Matthews had their first date over ramen, and just a few months later, they were facing Stage 4 metastatic breast cancer together.
lead_paragraph: Mallory Traughber had been out planting trees as a volunteer all morning on the day that she and Jessica Matthews were to have their first date, in February 2018. So when she arrived at the ramen shop, she was ready for a beer.

headline: Their Book Club for Two
abstract: Sigrid Gabler and Manly Romero read to each other every night, even for five minutes.
lead_paragraph: Every time Sigrid Carrie Gabler sees a full moon it reminds her of her first date with Manly Lin Romero in January 2019 at the Quarter, a restaurant in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

headline: A Cheap, Simple Way to Control the Coronavirus
abstract: With easy-to-use tests, everyone can check themselves every day.
lead_paragraph: Simple at-home tests for the coronavirus, some that involve spitting into a small tube of solution, could be the key to expanding testing and impeding the spread of the pandemic. The Food and Drug Administration should encourage their development and then fast track approval.

headline: Playing Beethoven’s Piano Sonatas Changed How I Hear Them
abstract: Our chief classical critic took on the daunting Opus 110 in college, and now relishes risky recordings.
lead_paragraph: For my senior piano recital in college, encouraged by my teacher, I took on an ambitious program. I opened with an elaborate Haydn sonata and ended by pairing a Chopin nocturne with his teeming Ballade in G minor. I also played the first three of Schoenberg’s Five Piano Pieces — intensely complex, atonal works that hooked me.

headline: Let’s Finish the American Revolution
keywords: ['Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Oglala Sioux Indians']
abstract: Our nation’s founding was a mess of contradictions. We must push America closer to its ideals.
lead_paragraph: As baffling as it is to find statues of traitors, slaveholders and killers of Union soldiers ensconced in many a prominent square, consider the historical discordance of Custer County, S.D.

headline: Don’t Call Him Machine Gun Kelly
abstract: The rapper and actor has a real name: Colson Baker. And he’s finding his voice during the lockdown.
lead_paragraph: A few days before Los Angeles announced a shelter-in-place order in March, Colson Baker, who raps under the name Machine Gun Kelly, sat down on a sofa with an acoustic guitar. His tattoos peeked through a white tank top. Tousled blond hair poked out of a Cleveland Cavaliers cap.

headline: WNYC Employees Demanded Diversity. They Got Another White Boss.
keywords: ['Radio', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Public Broadcasting', 'News and News Media', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Minorities']
abstract: The public radio stalwart vowed to fix what its journalists said was a toxic work culture. But the latest changes have led to a newsroom revolt.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, when the American workplace at long last began to clean house, sweeping away the vestiges of “Mad Men” habits, WNYC, the most popular public-radio station in the country, pushed three of its leading on-air personalities into the dust heap where so many bad men were piling up. A long period of turmoil and self-reflection followed, one that staff members referred to internally as the Troubles (“troubles with a capital T” as one producer put it to me, borrowing the phrase from the violent conflicts in Northern Ireland).

headline: The Shaman of Instagram
abstract: Durek Verrett, friend of Gwyneth Paltrow and consort of the Princess of Norway, wants to bring spiritual healing to the masses.
lead_paragraph: Shaman Durek was singing in an ancient language into his computer screen. His voice was deep and soothing.

headline: The Mystery of High Stock Prices
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Why is the market doing so well when the economy is doing so poorly?
lead_paragraph: From the Department of Curiosities: On Tuesday, as the number of new coronavirus cases continued to spike to record levels, the stock market closed out its strongest quarter in more than two decades.

headline: One Brother Got DACA, One Didn’t. It Made All the Difference.
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled that DACA was improperly terminated, but will new applicants be allowed to enroll in the life-changing immigration program?
lead_paragraph: Jack Miralrio and his younger brother, Owen, were born in Mexico and brought to the United States illegally by their mother when they were little. Growing up, both enjoyed video games, soccer and building toy cars. Both excelled at school.

headline: Mass Transit, and Cities, Could Grind to a Halt Without Federal Aid
keywords: ['Transit Systems', 'Commuting', 'Subways', 'Buses', 'Urban Areas', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Reviving subway and bus services helped bring back cities before. It can do so again.
lead_paragraph: As Congress plans another round of economic rescue, it will have to take a step that lawmakers from both parties have found distasteful for four decades: federal operating aid for mass transit.

headline: How a Covid-19 Contact Tracer Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Kimberly Jocelyn is at her computer on the weekends, but she forces herself to take breaks for fresh air and video calls with friends.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Jocelyn is a contact tracing supervisor with New York City Health and Hospitals Test & Trace Corps, which has, since May, employed more than 3,000 researchers, callers and field workers in an attempt to stop the spread of Covid-19.

headline: Symone Sanders Bet on Biden, and Herself
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: No one is telling her to wait her turn now.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Growing up in Omaha, Symone Sanders would sometimes assume the identity of an alter-ego character named “Donna Burns,” an imaginary TV personality who would repurpose hairbrushes or forks or pens (or whatever) to use as her microphone.

headline: Latinos Back Black Lives Matter Protests. They Want Change for Themselves, Too.
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Reform', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Criminal Justice']
abstract: Many Latinos are pushing for an acknowledgment of the systemic racism they face, and a conversation about over-policing in their own communities.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — “Tu lucha es mi lucha,” several signs declared at a recent Black Lives Matter protest near the Arizona State Capitol. Your struggle is my struggle. The sea of faces included young Latinos who had marched before, during the immigrant rights movement in the state a decade ago, when Joe Arpaio championed draconian policies as the sheriff of Maricopa County. There was no doubt in these protesters’ minds: Their fights against racism are bound up together.

headline: A Beverly Hills Hotel, Bought With Looted Money, Goes on Sale
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Auctions', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Fugitives', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: The Viceroy L’Ermitage Beverly Hills was owned by a fugitive financier involved in a $2.5 billion fraud. Interested? It’ll cost north of $100 million.
lead_paragraph: For sale: Boutique hotel, convenient to Hollywood. 116 rooms, rooftop pool, jet-setting clientele. Previous owner spent $40 million on renovations before becoming an international fugitive. Asking price: $100+ million.

headline: Some Unexpected Survey Results
abstract: “I was enchanted by her writing,” said Clifford Peterson, who met Carol Ryan during planning for Ramapo College’s 50th anniversary celebration, “by the incredible life she lived, simply enchanted.”
lead_paragraph: The symphony of power tools conducted by men in hard hats still echoed in the foothills of the Ramapo Mountains when Carol Ryan first arrived at the brand-new liberal arts college in Mahwah, N.J.

headline: What Hong Kong’s Pandemic Experience Taught Uber About Other Cities
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Masks']
abstract: The city was among the first to close and among the first to reopen. But Uber’s lessons there could be difficult to duplicate elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — In late February, Uber executives were set to gather in San Francisco to form business plans for the year as the coronavirus steadily spread beyond China. While some executives who were initially invited had been told to stay home, the remaining few huddled at Uber’s headquarters to make plans for the inevitable pandemic.

headline: Biden Supporters Are More Worried About the Health Risks of Voting
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Absentee Voting', 'Minorities']
abstract: Could this tilt turnout in Trump’s direction and affect the election result?
lead_paragraph: Identifying likely voters is a challenge for pollsters in every election. This year, the coronavirus, mail voting and a surge in political engagement may make it even harder than usual.

headline: Could New York Finally Become a Bike City?
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Shortages', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Transit Systems', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantines']
abstract: A 102-year-old bicycle shop in Queens did big business during the Spanish flu, the Depression and the oil crisis of the 1970s. But the pandemic poses a new challenge for a new age.
lead_paragraph: It was an hour before closing on a Monday afternoon in May, and a crowd had formed outside a bike store, in Jamaica, Queens. The shop was letting in only a few customers at a time. A 9-year-old boy with glasses waited expectantly at the door. Three teenagers sat on their bikes to keep their friend, Chanel Burton, company while she bought one.

headline: For Maine Lobstermen, a Perfect Storm Threatens the Summer Season
keywords: ['Lobsters', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Summer (Season)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Quarantines', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The state’s lobster industry, already struggling before the virus, could be crippled as tourism dries up, leaving boatloads of crustaceans and no one to eat them.
lead_paragraph: OFF THE COAST OF MAINE — As he pulled alongside one of his lobster pots, marked by a red and yellow buoy on the Penobscot Bay, Mike Hutchings extracted and measured several of the crustaceans that would contribute to his 130-pound catch that day. It was a decent haul but his assessment of the fishing season was grim: “The worst it’s ever been.”

headline: When a Farewell Season Was Wiped Out, the Outfield Became a Diner
abstract: This was supposed to be the Pawtucket Red Sox’s final season in Rhode Island before moving to Massachusetts. Without any games for fans to attend, the team got creative.
lead_paragraph: PAWTUCKET, R.I. — The long goodbye to McCoy Stadium began in August 2018, when the Class AAA Pawtucket Red Sox of the International League announced the franchise would be moving 50 minutes up Route 146 to Worcester, Mass., starting with the 2021 season.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Building (Construction)', 'Condominiums', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Building (Construction)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Condominiums', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: The pandemic paused residential construction and stalled sales. Now developers in Long Island City and Greenpoint are scrambling to bounce back.
lead_paragraph: Skyline Tower, the 778-foot luxury condo building in Long Island City that looms over western Queens, was built to break records.

headline: A Hard Conversation for the Latino Community
abstract: Racism is deeply rooted in America’s social system, putting Afro-Latinos at a constant disadvantage.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Every weeknight, I sit down next to my co-anchor Ilia Calderón to host the Spanish-language news program “Noticiero Univision.” Although our many viewers have come to know Ms. Calderón’s face, not many know how much she has had to overcome to sit in that chair. Her story, like that of many Latinos with African ancestry in the United States, is one of tremendous personal achievement, as well as astonishing perseverance in the face of deep-seated racism.

headline: The Mug Shot, a Crime Story Staple, Is Dropped by Some Newsrooms and Police
keywords: ['Police', 'Mug Shots', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The San Francisco Police Department said it would no longer release mug shots because they reinforce racial biases, joining a growing movement by newspapers and broadcasters to curtail their use.
lead_paragraph: For more than a century, police departments and news organizations have worked together to disseminate photos of people after their arrest, often bleary-eyed and despondent, sometimes defiant and smiling.

headline: Coronavirus Cases in U.S. Are Rising, Even as Death Rates Trend Down
abstract: At least five U.S. states set single-day records on Friday as the country’s daily infection report passed 50,000 again. President Trump, in a speech at Mount Rushmore, barely mentioned the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Click here for the latest updates.

headline: Boris Johnson’s ‘Global Britain’: Inspired Vision or Wishful Thinking?
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Post-Brexit Britain is going it alone at a time when globalization is in retreat. But a clash with China over Hong Kong has shown the limits of what it can do.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his pro-Brexit allies have long promised that once Britain broke free of the European Union, it could play a bold new role on the world stage — one they dubbed Global Britain. For a few days this week, it looked as if they were actually making good on that promise.

headline: Trial of 20 Saudis in Jamal Khashoggi Killing Opens in Turkey
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Supporters of the slain journalist expressed hope that the proceedings would offer a chance for justice. The defendants are to be tried in absentia.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey opened a trial into the death of the Saudi columnist Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul on Friday, accusing 20 Saudi citizens in absentia, in a case that friends and human rights officials welcomed as an important step in advancing the search for justice in his killing.

headline: After Fighting Plastic in ‘Paradise Lost,’ Sisters Take On Climate Change
abstract: Melati and Isabel Wijsen began campaigning to reduce plastic waste in Bali seven years ago. Now 19 and 17, they say the pandemic shows that stark measures to protect the planet are possible.
lead_paragraph: SEMINYAK, Indonesia — It was trash season on Bali, the time of year when monsoon storms wash up tons of plastic debris onto the island’s beaches. It was also the time for two teenage sisters, Melati and Isabel Wijsen, to organize their annual island cleanup.

headline: Have Americans Warmed to Calls to ‘Defund the Police’?
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: As they learn more about it, voters have shown some receptiveness to the phrase, polling suggests. But they largely want to reinvest resources, not eliminate departments.
lead_paragraph: Just over a month ago, the term “defund the police” was almost entirely the domain of activists and academics. Now it’s a household phrase, with a huge majority of Americans telling pollsters they recognize it.

headline: Gentlemen, Take Control of That Beard
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Beards and Mustaches', 'Content Type: Service', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Sure, the unkempt mountain-man look was easy to rationalize under lockdown, but now it’s time for a trim — at least.
lead_paragraph: If you’re one of many men who grew a pandemic beard because it seemed like less effort than shaving, it’s time to rethink that. Unless the look you’re going for is unkempt mountain man — which, OK, anything goes these days — beard care takes time and effort.

abstract: The Mississippi flag is finally coming down.

lead_paragraph: Socially responsible investing has been putting billions of dollars to work for social change for decades.

headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Grand Designs’
abstract: It’s a bit like “The Great British Baking Show,” but in this series, the goal is to build dream homes, not frangipane and iced buns. It’s also deeply human.
lead_paragraph: These days, it’s easy to assume the internet will eventually put every TV show and movie worth watching in front of my eyes somehow. Even if it’s made very far away. All TV worth gorging works that way, I thought, right?

headline: Students May Qualify for Special Jobless Benefits
abstract: While traditional unemployment insurance usually leaves out students, they may be eligible for federal pandemic aid. But some states don’t make it easy to get.
lead_paragraph: High school and college students whose summer jobs fell through because of the pandemic may qualify for jobless benefits under a special federal program. But getting the funds is harder in some states than in others.

headline: In June, Slower Sales and Price Reductions in New York City
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']

headline: Coronavirus Leads Some Athletes to Opt Out, if They Can Afford It
abstract: The decision on whether to participate in restarting seasons is exposing the haves and have-nots of the sports world.
lead_paragraph: The resurging coronavirus has in many places exposed fault lines of class and privilege that allow those with means to escape high-risk environments, to put off work and to elide financial concerns in the interest of staying safe.

headline: I Watched My War Story Become a Movie
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Movies']
abstract: I witnessed the making of “The Outpost,” a film about the day my unit fought off 300 Taliban fighters who tried to overrun our camp in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: When I learned that my U.S. Army cavalry troop’s war story was being made into a major motion picture, I worried that a Hollywood account of the battle would be inaccurate. My soldiers and I had been sharing stories since Oct. 3, 2009, when our 53 cavalry scouts fought off more than 300 Taliban fighters bent on overrunning Combat Outpost Keating in Nuristan, Afghanistan. By all quantifiable metrics, my unit won the fight, but at a devastating cost: Eight soldiers died, 22 were wounded and our camp burned to the ground.

headline: Why Are Fireworks Going Off Every Night in California?
abstract: It’s unclear if the problem is worse this year but complaints are on the rise in parts of California.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘I Thought I Would Die’: Inside Myanmar’s Risky Pursuit of Jade
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Landslides and Mudslides', 'Jade', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: A survivor was swept away by a wave of mud and water after the wall of a mine collapsed on Thursday, killing at least 200 people.
lead_paragraph: MANDALAY, Myanmar — An ominous rumbling was the only warning the young jade miner had that something was wrong.

headline: ‘Free Again’: New Yorkers, Virus in Mind, Head Back to Their Beaches
abstract: Shorelines are finally open for swimming, but outbreaks across the country have given officials pause about the city’s wider reopening.
lead_paragraph: After more than a month of closed beaches — and pitched battles over access to the ocean — Rachel Thompson, a schoolteacher, finally frolicked in the surf at Rockaway Beach in Queens.

headline: What to Say When People Tell You Their Coronavirus Fears
keywords: ['Fear (Emotion)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'internal-essential', 'Content Type: Service', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Empathy over dismissive positivity.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus won’t be going anywhere for a long time — and neither will our fears about it. Some states have begun to roll back plans to reopen their economies, and as infections increase, the United States is consistently setting daily records for confirmed cases.

headline: Frederick Douglass, Seen Up Close
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Archives and Records', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Yale has acquired a renowned private collection relating to the abolitionist and orator, including rarely seen family scrapbooks that offer a window onto his complicated private life.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, the historian David Blight had just given a talk about Frederick Douglass in Savannah, Ga., when he was introduced to Walter Evans, a retired surgeon and collector. Dr. Evans invited him to stop by the house and see his Douglass collection. Dr. Blight was cautiously intrigued.

headline: How the Coronavirus Is Transforming July 4 in Los Angeles
abstract: While the camaraderie that comes from attending fireworks and tailgates will be absent, technology may help new traditions take hold.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Fireworks have been lighting up night skies across America, despite normally being set off almost exclusively on July 4. Red, white, blue and bright, these low-impact pyrotechnics are to “America’s birthday” as quickly melting candles on a cake are to yours or mine.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda and Disney: Timeline of a Collaboration
abstract: Disney+ is streaming a live-capture film of “Hamilton.” It’s just the latest chapter in a deepening relationship between the company and the musical’s creator.
lead_paragraph: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s relationship with Disney started inauspiciously. He wrote a song on spec for a holiday show. The company rejected it.

headline: He Drove 3,000 Miles to Find a Pool and Ended Up in the Ocean
abstract: Rudy Garcia-Tolson is determined to make a fifth Paralympic team, even if he has to start at the bottom. Or on a surfboard.
lead_paragraph: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Garcia-Tolson’s first installment here.

headline: Duterte Signs Antiterrorism Bill in Philippines Despite Widespread Criticism
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Torture', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Human rights groups say the new law will give the police and military forces more powers to stifle dissent.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Rodrigo Duterte signed a contentious antiterrorism bill Friday aimed at combating Islamic militancy in the south, a measure that critics warned could lead to more widespread human rights abuses.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Brighten your weekend morning with Joanne Chang’s blueberry scones.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There’s a little convenience store attached to the gas station down the street from where I stay and, if you get there early enough, just after the sun makes its appearance in the eastern sky, it’s possible to obtain one of the six or seven egg sandwiches the cashier makes every morning before unlocking the door. They sit on a shelf by the register, in front of a new plexiglass shield, hot in their foil jackets, soft and salty within, a $4 treat on a day that won’t yield many of them.

headline: England Drops Its Quarantine for Most Visitors, but Not Those From the U.S.
abstract: In a bid to salvage the summer tourist season, travelers from France, Italy, Spain and dozens of other nations no longer have to isolate for 14 days after arriving.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — England will drop its mandatory 14-day quarantine for visitors from more than 50 countries but leave the restrictions in place for travelers coming from the United States, deepening the isolation of America and delivering another rebuke to President Trump for his handling of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Streams Today. Here’s How it Happened.
abstract: If you never got to see Lin-Manuel Miranda portray Alexander Hamilton on Broadway, this might be the next best thing.
lead_paragraph: If you never got to see Lin-Manuel Miranda portray Alexander Hamilton on Broadway, this might be the next best thing.

headline: It’s Not a Snake, but Beware of Its Venomous Bite
abstract: Animals called caecilians may have been among the first vertebrates on land to lace their bites with venom.
lead_paragraph: If a worm and a snake had a slimy, scandalous love child, it might look something like a caecilian: a legless creature that’s actually neither worm nor snake, but a soil-dwelling amphibian found in tropics across the globe.

headline: Kanye West Dips a Toe in the Moment, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Blackpink, Jorja Smith, Washed Out and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Critics Fear Amtrak Is Using Pandemic to Cut Service That Won’t Return
abstract: Members of Congress are angry that the rail agency is asking for more money while planning to lay off staff and reduce services. Smaller communities that rely on rail service could be badly hurt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Amtrak has long wanted to cut back on long-distance train routes that span America’s heartland, but political pressure from Congress made it next to impossible.

headline: Jules Feiffer on His Long, Varied Career
abstract: Feiffer talks about his new picture book and more, and Steve Inskeep discusses “Imperfect Union.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Washington Redskins’ Name Review Follows Years of Protest
abstract: Many find the name offensive, yet there has always been defiance from the team’s owners.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Redskins’ announcement Friday that they would begin “a thorough review of the team’s name” is a potential culmination to years of protest and defiance over a nickname that many Native Americans and other advocates for change consider deeply offensive.

headline: James Sherwood, Who Revived the Orient Express, Dies at 86
abstract: A multimillionaire by 36, he also bought Cipriani in Venice, the “21” Club in New York, Harry’s Bar in London and dozens of grand hotels.
lead_paragraph: Over his long, colorful life, the peripatetic James Sherwood seeded many businesses — container leasing, a London guidebook, ferries and riverboats, hotels and restaurants (like the “21” Club in New York and Harry’s Bar in London), an ice cream company, a magazine, fruit farms and a vineyard.

headline: Margaret Morton, Photographer at Home With the Homeless, Dies at 71
abstract: For nearly two decades, she chronicled communities on the edge of society in elegant photographs that drew comparisons to the work of Jacob Riis.
lead_paragraph: From her apartment on East 10th Street in Manhattan, Margaret Morton had a front row view of the homeless encampments that engulfed Tompkins Square Park in the late 1980s. As she walked to work at Cooper Union, where she was a professor, she began to photograph these improvised structures, showing the ways people were moved to make themselves at home even when they had so little.

headline: George Floyd’s Killing Prompts Africans to Call for Police Reform at Home
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police Reform', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: Africans are increasingly pushing to hold police agencies to account and “decolonize” the repressive institutions they inherited from colonial rulers.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenyan and American protesters knelt outside the United States Embassy in Nairobi one morning last month, outraged at George Floyd’s killing and the racism and brutality they saw across the Atlantic. But they were also furious about police abuses at home, in Kenya.

headline: Trump’s Niece Presses Case Against Effort to Bar Publication of Her Book
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Wills and Estates', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Mary Trump and her lawyer filed documents questioning the validity of the nondisclosure agreement she signed, saying it was based on fraud and was too broad to be enforced.
lead_paragraph: Mary L. Trump, whose pending tell-all memoir about her uncle President Trump has incited a court fight on the eve of publication, spoke out for the first time publicly about the battle, saying that her book has “deep national relevance” and that the legal contract the family has sought to use this month to stop its release was based on fraud.

abstract: Ms. Garfinkel thrived in a field dominated by men, juggling a career while raising five children. She died of the coronavirus.

headline: We Got ‘Hamilton.’ Why Can’t We Stream Every Broadway Show?
abstract: Even in lockdown, it’s still hard to cut a streaming deal for a professional show. Here’s what viewers can expect, for now.

headline: Lifting the Cone of Silence From Black Composers
abstract: Listen to how artists have explored what it means — and could mean — to be American.
lead_paragraph: A cone of silence hangs over the work of Black composers from Africa and its diaspora. It is not that Black men and women have not written music, but too often it has been ignored — and thus assumed not to exist at all.

headline: Turkey Convicts Human Rights Activists on Terror Charges
abstract: The cases are part of a widespread effort to quash dissent in the country, which has seen dozens of activists put on trial after a failed 2016 coup attempt.

The tragic deaths of George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor and countless others has led many interracial couples to prioritize open and honest conversations about how society treats them differently and why allyship and advocacy are essential.

If you’re in Britain, you might finally be able to have a pint at the pub. Whatever you are doing, take care and make some time for some fantastic journalism.

headline: Saroj Khan, Choreographer Who Made Bollywood Sparkle, Dies at 71

keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Hospitals', 'Disease Rates', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Ventilators (Medical)', 'Elderly']
abstract: This seemingly counterintuitive trend might not last, experts said. But the nation can still learn from the decline.

States like Arizona, Florida and Texas are seeing some of their highest numbers to date, and as the nation hurtles further into summer, the surge shows few signs of stopping.

It was the middle of March, and the coronavirus pandemic was nearing peak lethality. As the government barred gatherings like music festivals, his revenue disappeared, forcing him to consider laying off his four full-time workers.

headline: Rudolfo Anaya, a Father of Chicano Literature, Dies at 82

lead_paragraph: Rudolfo Anaya, a writer whose trailblazing explorations of the folkways of the Southwest helped define the Latino experience in the United States, died on Sunday at his home in Albuquerque. He was 82.

headline: Trump Uses Mount Rushmore Speech to Deliver Divisive Culture War Message

headline: Lonnie Wheeler, 68, Dies; Helped Ballplayers Tell Their Stories
abstract: A longtime sportswriter, he collaborated with Hank Aaron, Bob Gibson and Mike Piazza on their autobiographies. “I was there,” he once said, “to make the subject more literary.”
lead_paragraph: Lonnie Wheeler, a sportswriter and columnist who collaborated with the Baseball Hall of Famers Hank Aaron, Bob Gibson and Mike Piazza on their autobiographies, died on June 9 in Cincinnati. He was 68.

headline: A Supreme Court Win for Gay Rights, but Not in My Church
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Ministers (Protestant)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: It still refuses to ordain me because of my sexuality. So why do I stay?
lead_paragraph: The greatest joys in life might be the unexpected ones. I’d put the Supreme Court’s recent decision in Bostock v. Clayton County in that category. Who expected the high court to affirm that Title VII protected L.G.B.T.Q. people from employment discrimination? And who expected Justice Neil Gorsuch to author such an opinion? It was a tremendous, surprising win for equality — and it was one that I instantly knew would barely matter for many of us who are pursuing work in Christian ministry.

headline: Reading Orwell for the Fourth of July
abstract: As we celebrate freedom, speaking freely is in danger.

headline: Unwavering

I was semi-convinced of the presence of multiple, unrelated rebuses in the northeast corner, because none of my best guesses quite fit. Elsewhere, a few of my more confident shots, made at the beginning of the endeavor, turned out to be misfires.

Berman, the former top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to his role at the time of his dismissal. headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Family Romance, LLC’ and Fireworks
abstract: Werner Herzog’s documentary explores Japan’s rent-a-family industry. And fireworks displays will be broadcast from New York and Washington.
lead_paragraph: FAMILY ROMANCE, LLC (2019) Stream on Mubi. You may not be able to choose your family, but a thriving rental industry in Japan allows you to get pretty close. In his latest film, a hybrid work of fiction and documentary, Werner Herzog goes inside the country’s rent-a-family industry, which pairs actors with those in need of a replacement relative, spouse or friend — for a fee. The film follows Ishii Yuichi, the founder of the rental company Family Romance, and the various roles he plays to fill the voids in his clients’ lives. Things get complicated when Yuichi takes a job portraying a young girl’s missing father.

headline: Tennis Tours Debate Ranking Systems Frozen by the Coronavirus

headline: If a Zoom Wedding Isn’t for You, Here’s How to Plan For Later
abstract: Just got engaged? Here are a few tips from industry experts on how to plan an in-person wedding celebration next year.
lead_paragraph: After spending the last several months canceling, downsizing and postponing weddings, event planners remain cautiously optimistic about forging ahead now that some event restrictions are being lifted. While many couples have resorted to virtual wedding celebrations on Zoom, recently engaged couples who are planning their weddings for next year are hoping to celebrate with friends and family in person. Even as many states begin to gradually lift the restrictions aimed at slowing the spread of the coronavirus, events of all types will have to adjust to new health and safety practices. We asked industry experts to share some of their planning recommendations for recently engaged couples who are looking to celebrate their union, without Zoom, next year.

Those singular displays of fashion art — handmade clothes custom-ordered by the very few — represent equal parts creative laboratory, artisanal expertise and visual extravaganza.
