lead_paragraph: I DREAM OF A JOURNEY

headline: What’s the Best Way to Make a Noise Complaint Against My Neighbor?
abstract: Noise complaints are often difficult to win, but there are some avenues to pursue that can work.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a Harlem condo. The owner of the neighboring unit rents out her apartment to a tenant who runs her air-conditioner all day and night. The unit is directly outside my bedroom window. During the day I don’t mind the hum, but at night the noise is unbearable if I open my window. I reached out to the owner of the apartment, who claimed the tenants agreed to put the air-conditioner on a low setting at night. But they haven’t done so. What should I do?

headline: Pick Your Tofu: Crispy or Baked
abstract: Yewande Komolafe’s tofu recipes, Melissa Clark’s grilled chicken thighs, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include Yewande Komolafe’s crispy tofu with cashews and blistered snap peas (above), her recipe for baked tofu with peanut sauce and coconut-lime rice and Melissa Clark’s gingery grilled chicken thighs. Find more recipes in this collection for the weekend.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon create a tenuous work environment.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s excerpt involves a subject close to my heart! It’s from a recent work of fiction called “Temporary” by the writer Hilary Leichter, whom I’d never heard of. I looked her up on my library app, borrowed the book in a couple of clicks and read most of it the same evening I solved this. It’s fun and kind of experimental — if you’re intrigued by the passage, give it a try.

headline: Visit the Louvre and Christina Tosi’s Kitchen
abstract: See the Mona Lisa, up your baking skills and get some answers to your salacious questions about dinosaurs.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: I Miss My Father’s Mind
abstract: Was he one of the hidden victims of the coronavirus pandemic?
lead_paragraph: The day after my father died unexpectedly at a rehabilitation center in May, I went searching through my microcassettes for the tapes he’d sent me many years ago.

headline: Women Ask Themselves, ‘How Can I Do This for One More Day?’
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Child Care', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Portraits of those who are making it work.
lead_paragraph: The value of women’s work, both paid and unpaid, has never been more apparent than during the coronavirus crisis. As Diane Coyle recently noted in The Times, women’s shift into paid employment was one of the great economic transformations in recent history, but it did not free women from their myriad unpaid roles as caregivers, homemakers and community volunteers. These six women talked to The Times about what it’s like to straddle that divide. Their quotes have been edited and condensed for clarity.

headline: This July 4th, Consider Switching To Glow Sticks
abstract: Maybe don’t give a toddler a sparkler.
lead_paragraph: Last summer we were celebrating the Fourth of July with our closest friends. I’m sorry to report that this anecdote is going to get real gendered, so strap in. The moms were inside talking over the remnants of dessert, while the dads were outside with the kids lighting sparklers. A dad who will remain nameless handed my 2-year-old a sparkler. You know where this is going: Cue her running back inside the apartment crying because her tiny fingers were burned.

headline: The Pandemic’s Big Mystery: How Deadly Is the Coronavirus?
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Even with more than 500,000 dead worldwide, scientists are struggling to learn how often the virus kills. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: More than six months into the pandemic, the coronavirus has infected more than 11 million people worldwide, killing more than 525,000. But despite the increasing toll, scientists still do not have a definitive answer to one of the most fundamental questions about the virus: How deadly is it?

headline: In West Texas, Lingering Distrust in Public Health Measures as Virus Spreads
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Masks', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Early in the pandemic, much of rural Texas had low case counts and few worries. Now, conservative areas are seeing a surge in cases, but distrust in government mandates endures.
lead_paragraph: LUBBOCK, Texas — For a while, it seemed that the coronavirus had spared West Texas. Cases were low. Few had died. Concern through the spring was focused on getting businesses running again.

headline: Black in America, Through a Camera
abstract: In a photography show and auction Jamel Shabazz and others take an up-close look at Black culture and community.
lead_paragraph: It would look like an improvised family gathering, children in the foreground, elders stalwart at the rear, were it not for the masks and kaleidoscopically colorful costumes. Those are central to a group portrait by Joshua Kissi, the image captured last winter at Mardi Gras, its subjects draped in a raucous mélange of Native and Afro-American ceremonial garb.

headline: ‘I Can Barely Keep Track’: Texas Hospital Battles Coronavirus Surge
abstract: Our correspondent Sheri Fink goes behind the scenes at Houston Methodist Hospital as coronavirus cases rise.
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent Sheri Fink goes behind the scenes at Houston Methodist Hospital as coronavirus cases rise.

headline: As Coronavirus Slams Houston Hospitals, It’s Like New York ‘All Over Again’
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Hospitals', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Dexamethasone (Drug)', 'Remdesivir (Drug)', 'Masks', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Shortages', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: The death toll is lower, but there are echoes of March as cases spike, doctors fall ill and supplies run short. Now, Texas is trying to adapt hard-won lessons while addressing a new set of challenges.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Over the past week, Dr. Aric Bakshy, an emergency physician at Houston Methodist, had to decide which coronavirus patients he should admit to the increasingly busy hospital and which he could safely send home.

headline: With Plexiglass and Piles of Hot Dogs, a Fourth of July Tradition Lives On
keywords: ['Contests and Prizes', 'Hot Dogs and Frankfurters', 'Records and Achievements', 'Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'Quarantines', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: “They’re going to be burping and groaning, and I’m just going to have to focus on my hot dogs,” the 2020 Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog Eating Contest champion mused ahead of the quieter, crowd-free competition.
lead_paragraph: With Independence Day celebrations canceled around the country, one distinctly American tradition continued on Saturday despite the pandemic: the annual pilgrimage of competitive eaters to Coney Island for the Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog Eating Contest. But with cheering crowds turned away to promote social distancing, contestants instead chowed down amid a chorus of gulping and chewing from their competitors.

headline: A Teacher Held a Famous Racism Exercise in 1968. She’s Still at It.
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: The day after Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, Jane Elliott carried out the “Blue Eyes, Brown Eyes” exercise in her classroom. Now, people are returning to her work.
lead_paragraph: — Jane Elliott, a schoolteacher turned anti-racism educator

headline: 3 Officers Fired Over Photos Taken Near Elijah McClain Memorial
abstract: The Aurora, Colo., police chief said the officers mocked the death of Mr. McClain, a 23-year-old massage therapist who died several days after officers put him in a chokehold last summer.
lead_paragraph: Three Aurora, Colo., police officers have been fired over photos that show two of them grinning and mocking the death of Elijah McClain, a 23-year-old massage therapist who was arrested and placed in a chokehold last August. Mr. McClain died several days later.

headline: At Mt. Rushmore and the White House, Trump Updates ‘American Carnage’ Message for 2020
keywords: ['Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'Speeches and Statements', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: His ominous remarks were a reflection of his political standing: trailing in the polls, lacking a booming economy or a positive message to campaign on, and leaning on culture wars to buoy his loyalists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump used the spotlight of the Fourth of July weekend to sow division during a national crisis, denying his failings in containing the worsening coronavirus pandemic while delivering a harsh diatribe against what he branded the “new far-left fascism.”

headline: Trump Says He Will Create a Statuary Park Honoring ‘American Heroes’
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The executive order includes John Adams, Harriet Tubman and Martin Luther King Jr. among those who would be honored. So would Billy Graham, Antonin Scalia and Ronald Reagan.
lead_paragraph: President Trump ordered the federal government late Friday to design and construct a statuary park honoring “American heroes,” his latest embrace of American heritage in opposition to what he has described as a revolutionary leftist movement that would “erase our values.”

headline: With Beijing’s Military Nearby, U.S. Sends 2 Aircraft Carriers to South China Sea
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Aircraft Carriers', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The deployment of an American aircraft carrier and its strike force is often used as a signal to deter adversaries. Deploying two at once is recognized as a significant show of force.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two American aircraft carriers sailed to the South China Sea on Saturday for what Navy officials described as a freedom-of-navigation operation while China’s military conducts exercises nearby.

headline: Marc Fumaroli, Defender of French Culture, Is Dead at 88
abstract: A leading historian, he wrote and taught in defense of the French language and its heritage and against “globish English.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Marc Fumaroli, a leading French historian, public intellectual and defender of the French language and culture against American influence and what he called “globish English,” died on June 24 in Paris. He was 88.

headline: To-Do List
abstract: Laura Taylor Kinnel’s puzzle makes us multitask.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We have a number of constructors who work in academia, and it makes sense that their puzzles might have some scholarly flair. Laura Taylor Kinnel teaches math and is the director of studies at a Friends boarding school in Pennsylvania, and was recently featured in a local news segment about how constructing and solving gives the brain a nice boost.

headline: Nikolai Fadeyechev, Elegant Bolshoi Dancer, Is Dead at 87
abstract: Acclaimed for his noble style, he was also praised as a “self-deprecating” partner who showed off his ballerinas and did not compete with them.
lead_paragraph: Nikolai Fadeyechev, one of the Bolshoi Ballet’s greatest dancers, who was hailed for his distinctively noble style and his chivalry as a partner to the company’s leading ballerinas from the 1950s to the ’70s, died on June 23 in Moscow. He was 87.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Struck by Ball as Yankees Take Health Hit
abstract: In a harrowing first workout of the summer, the Yankees starting pitcher was struck on Saturday. Later, the team announced that All-Star infielder D.J. LaMahieu and pitcher Luis Cessa tested positive for Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: Saturday was the Yankees’ first official summer workout, a routine bit of preparation to start their coronavirus-shortened 2020 season. Instead of an ordinary practice at Yankee Stadium, the team witnessed a frightening incident in which a key pitcher was hit on the head with a line drive. And later in the day, it announced that two other players were absent from practice because they had tested positive for Covid-19.

headline: To Be Hungry in the Middle of the Pandemic
abstract: In the neighborhoods most devastated by the coronavirus, food insecurity has emerged as a major concern.
lead_paragraph: In the best of times, life in New York City can be unforgiving. It was hard enough, working full tilt, to cover rent, child care and food before the pandemic. Now, in the neighborhoods most devastated by the coronavirus, life has become more precarious. And the most elemental human need — food — has become a pressing, urgent concern.

headline: Fourth of July Celebrations Dulled by Soaring Coronavirus Cases
keywords: ['Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Fireworks', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Beaches', 'Parades']
abstract: Many Americans, fearful of the virus, stayed at home and held muted celebrations, although some went on undeterred.
lead_paragraph: Fear hung over the Fourth of July holiday this year as the worsening coronavirus pandemic caused many Americans to pull back from their usual celebrations.

headline: DNA Inherited From Neanderthals May Increase Risk of Covid-19
abstract: The stretch of six genes seems to increase the risk of severe illness from the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: A stretch of DNA linked to Covid-19 was passed down from Neanderthals 60,000 years ago, according to a new study.

headline: 239 Experts With One Big Claim: The Coronavirus Is Airborne
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Masks', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Disease Rates', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: The W.H.O. has resisted mounting evidence that viral particles floating indoors are infectious, some scientists say. The agency maintains the research is still inconclusive.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus is finding new victims worldwide, in bars and restaurants, offices, markets and casinos, giving rise to frightening clusters of infection that increasingly confirm what many scientists have been saying for months: The virus lingers in the air indoors, infecting those nearby.

headline: Kansas G.O.P. Official Removes Cartoon Comparing Mask Order to Holocaust
abstract: The cartoon, which showed Gov. Laura Kelly wearing a Star of David mask as people are loaded into a cattle car, was posted Friday on the Facebook page of a newspaper owned by a Republican county chairman.
lead_paragraph: A Republican county chairman in Kansas has apologized for posting a cartoon on his newspaper’s Facebook page that invoked the Holocaust to criticize the governor’s order requiring Kansans to wear masks to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Chilling Words for Renters: ‘Be Out by Tomorrow’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 5, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “The tenant explained the new laws. The landlord acknowledged the new laws and was like, ‘I don’t care, you have to leave.’”

headline: Corrections: July 5, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 5, 2020.
lead_paragraph: The Big City column on Page 3 misstates the number of people of color in the newsroom at WNYC with direct reports. There are five people, not one.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Ganja & Hess’ and ‘Outcry’
abstract: Revisit Bill Gunn’s low-budget vampire horror film, and catch Showtime’s new investigative mini-series.
lead_paragraph: GANJA & HESS (1973) Stream on Amazon Prime, Kanopy, Mubi and Shudder. Horror as a vehicle for deeper societal commentary may be having a moment with the success of films like “Get Out” and “Parasite,” but it’s not a new phenomenon. During the Black independent film movement of the 1970s and ’80s, the actor, playwright and filmmaker Bill Gunn made this low-budget vampire flick about an anthropologist who develops an unquenchable thirst for blood after being stabbed with a cursed dagger. But it is “less a horror film than a sensual, scholarly, magic-realist exploration of Black history and Black desire,” A.O. Scott wrote of the film for The New York Times. Spike Lee added his take to a remake with “Da Sweet Blood of Jesus” in 2014.

headline: ‘We Both Wound Up at a Corner Waiting for the Light to Change’
abstract: An awkward offer to help, pets in a tree and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.

headline: With Department Stores Disappearing, Malls Could Be Next
keywords: ['Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Bankruptcies', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Brick-and-mortar retail was in the midst of seismic changes even before the pandemic. Analysts say as much as a quarter of America’s malls may close in the next five years.
lead_paragraph: The directory map for the Northfield Square Mall in Bourbonnais, Ill., has three glaring spaces where large department stores once stood. Soon there will be a fourth vacancy, now that J.C. Penney is liquidating stores after filing for bankruptcy.

headline: Why We’re Capitalizing Black
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'News and News Media', 'English Language', 'Newspapers']
abstract: The Times has changed its style on the term’s usage to better reflect a shared cultural identity. Here’s what led to that decision.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Mexico’s President Is All In for Trump
abstract: Mexican democrats will not forget Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s reverence to the man who has maligned us.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s visit with President Trump in Washington this week will no doubt embarrass many Mexicans and outrage many Americans. The meeting, intended to bolster Mr. Trump’s campaign, is an opportunity for Mr. López Obrador to return a favor.

headline: How You Get Your Berries: Migrant Workers Who Fear Virus, but Toil On
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Blueberries', 'Fruit', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Disease Rates', 'Illegal Immigration']

headline: We Now Interrupt Your Regularly Scheduled Convention Programming
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'News and News Media', 'Television', 'Cable Television', 'Republican National Convention', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Democratic National Convention']
abstract: Instead of the usual media circus, this summer’s made-for-TV political confabs will have a whole lot less TV.
lead_paragraph: Forget the luxury-suite studios soaring above the convention stage. Or the morning-show stars flown in for an on-scene dispatch. Or the armies of television crews and correspondents trawling the arena floor for rebellious delegates.

headline: Hong Kong, Changed Overnight, Navigates Its New Reality
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Politics and Government', 'Secession and Independence Movements']
abstract: In a city where China has made some ideas suddenly dangerous, people are trying to figure out where the boundaries lie, and how their lives have changed.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A barge draped with enormous red banners celebrating China’s new security law was sailing across Hong Kong’s famed Victoria Harbor only hours after the legislation passed. The police now hoist a purple sign warning protesters that their chants could be criminal. Along major roads throughout the city, neon-colored flags hailing a new era of stability and prosperity stand erect as soldiers.

headline: China Dominates Medical Supplies, in This Outbreak and the Next
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Masks', 'Medical Devices', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Government Contracts and Procurement']
abstract: Government support and protectionism have built a low-cost industry making masks, testing kits and other health gear. Other countries will find it tough to compete.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Alarmed at China’s stranglehold over supplies of masks, gowns, test kits and other front-line weapons for battling the coronavirus, countries around the world have set up their own factories to cope with this pandemic and outbreaks of the future.

keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Water', 'Hydroelectric Power', 'Rivers', 'Levees and Dams', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Environment', 'Reservoirs', 'Kurds']
abstract: In his push for economic development, Turkey’s president has flooded the archaeological gem of Hasankeyf and displaced thousands of families.
lead_paragraph: HASANKEYF, Turkey — There was something exceptional about Hasankeyf that made visitors fall in love with the town on first sight.

headline: The Week in Business: Shut It Back Down
abstract: The latest jobs report looked optimistic — but the numbers are from before the new spike in cases.
lead_paragraph: Hope you all are having a safe Fourth of July weekend, even if it has been weird and quiet. Here’s what you need to know for the week ahead in business and tech, including a new development in the Jeffrey Epstein scandal, cameras that take your temperature in public and what’s going on in Hong Kong. — Charlotte Cowles

headline: Tokyo’s First Female Governor Sails to Re-Election Even as Virus Cases Rise
abstract: Yuriko Koike has received high marks for her visible presence during the pandemic, but the coronavirus’s resurgence has raised anxiety in the Japanese capital.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In rewarding Tokyo’s first female governor, Yuriko Koike, with a second term on Sunday, voters endorsed her highly visible leadership as the sprawling metropolis has avoided the kind of spiraling death toll from the coronavirus seen in other world capitals.

headline: Phoenix Mayor Says FEMA Refused to Help With Testing
abstract: Assessing the virus’s real death rate could offer clues on what to expect next. Data shows how much harder the pandemic is hitting Black and Latino Americans.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $500,000 or Less
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: ‘Bébé’s Kids’ Shared a Lesson About Racial Injustice
abstract: This 1992 animated movie about Black children running into trouble at a theme park is meant to be a comedy. But for one viewer, it no longer seems so funny.
lead_paragraph: “The Boondocks,” “Atlanta,” “black-ish,” “Dear White People,” “Sorry to Bother You” — there are a few shows and movies that have dared to use comedy to address the grim state of Black people in America. But lately, I’ve been thinking about a movie I hadn’t seen in more than 20 years: “Bébé’s Kids.” This animated Black comedy explicitly spoke about police brutality and our broken judicial system years before the first utterance of “Black Lives Matter.”

headline: 2 Dead and 8 Wounded in Shooting at South Carolina Nightclub
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: The club, in Greenville, was hosting a concert on Saturday night despite state orders that nightclubs remain closed because of the coronavirus pandemic, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A shooting at a nightclub in Greenville, S.C., early on Sunday morning left two people dead and eight wounded, the authorities said.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Set yourself up to eat well, with Mike Solomonov and Steven Cook’s Jerusalem grill, David Tanis’s simple pasta with tomato sauce, one-pot rice and beans.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I was thinking about these dinner parties I used to attend sometimes, what seems like decades ago, in a different world, everyone crowded tight around a table covered in damask, in candlelight, an open bottle of brown liquor sitting next to uncleared plates at the end, everyone talking at once: art and politics, fishing and poetry, trips recalled and trips to be planned, bad jokes, good music, the whole beautiful tapestry.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Couture (Fashion)', 'Couture Fashion Week', 'your-feed-fashion', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: Presentations for Paris couture, in one place.
lead_paragraph: Couture fashion — exquisite handmade clothes, meant for the very few — is usually displayed in exclusive shows in Paris. Now, because of a coronavirus pandemic and global financial crisis that has stressed the industry to the core, all of us are invited to see digital presentations up close and very personal. Here are some of the shows.

headline: Italy’s Outdoor Summer Movies See Threat From Ailing Film Industry

headline: To Buy a Drink in This Border Town, Make Sure You’re in England
abstract: Pubs are open in England, but coronavirus restrictions have not yet eased that far in Wales. So the owner of one village bar went to a rival establishment for a pint.
lead_paragraph: LLANYMYNECH — In normal times, no one takes much notice of the invisible border between England and Wales that runs through Llanymynech, a village with a post office, a church and no fewer than three pubs.

headline: Review: ‘Les Blancs’ Is an Anguished Play for an Anguished Moment
abstract: This Lorraine Hansberry play, set in the 1960s in a fictional African country, speaks incisively to the American present.
lead_paragraph: When New York theaters reopen — in January, or next spring, or when some epidemiological genius figures out how to make enclosed spaces with cramped seating even passably hygienic — I have a suggestion: Revive Lorraine Hansberry’s “Les Blancs.” This drama, unfinished at her death in 1965, and completed by her former husband, had a monthlong run on Broadway in 1970. In 2016, the South African director Yaël Farber, the dramaturge Drew Lichtenberg and Joi Gresham, the literary executor of Hansberry’s estate, collaborated on a revised version of the script, which then ran at London’s National Theater.

headline: The Fullest Look Yet at the Racial Inequity of Coronavirus

But his aides wanted to better understand the man they expected to assume power, Xi Jinping. It seemed like a job for Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Trump Falsely Claims ‘99 Percent’ of Virus Cases Are ‘Totally Harmless’
abstract: The president dismissed the severity of the pandemic, downplaying the effect of the disease even as infections surge across the Sunbelt and rebound in California.

headline: Atlantic Coast Pipeline Canceled as Delays and Costs Mount
abstract: The natural gas project would have crossed the Appalachian Trail. Dominion Energy, one of the pipeline’s two partners, also announced the sale of its gas transmission and storage assets.
lead_paragraph: Two of the nation’s largest utility companies announced on Sunday that they had canceled the Atlantic Coast Pipeline, which would have carried natural gas across the Appalachian Trail, as delays and rising costs threatened the viability of the project.

headline: Baseball Is Showing Some Early Optimism. How Long Can It Last?
abstract: As players return for workouts amid the coronavirus pandemic, cities with clubs have seen recent increases in cases.
lead_paragraph: As Major League Baseball teams began their summer workouts, players over the weekend started giving their first impressions of the procedures put in place to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, including testing, social distancing and spreading activities throughout the stadium.

headline: At the Plaza Hotel
abstract: Lynn Lempel has mercy on our brains after the Fourth of July weekend. This one is smooth and (relatively) simple.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — The constructor Lynn Lempel — she of the smooth Monday grids — is back with a theme that might seem familiar to some but is a good, gentle start to our solving week. And you really can’t ask for much more than that.

headline: Iran Admits Serious Damage to Natanz Nuclear Site, Setting Back Program
abstract: A Middle Eastern intelligence official said Israel planted a bomb in a building where advanced centrifuges were being developed.
lead_paragraph: A fire at Iran’s main nuclear fuel enrichment site caused significant damage, setting back the country’s nuclear program by months, the government acknowledged on Sunday, after initially saying the destruction was minor.

headline: Croatian Prime Minister’s Gamble on Early Elections Pays Off.
abstract: Prime Minister Andrej Plenkovic ran a risky campaign based on his government’s response to the coronavirus pandemic. It paid off, with his party’s best showing in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: ZADAR, Croatia — Croatia’s ruling party finished first in a general election on Sunday despite ongoing criticism over the country’s recent handling of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: How to Give Workers a Raise Without Employers Paying for It
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'United States Economy', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: There’s a solution that can appeal to laid-off workers, their previous employers and perhaps Senate Republicans too.
lead_paragraph: For decades, American workers have seen their power erode and their wages stagnate. The current crises have only made things worse. But Congress has a chance to begin the reversal of these trends and to accelerate the economic recovery by enacting a fair wage guarantee, which makes sense economically and could be a win for both major parties. Such a guarantee would function by turning the recently increased unemployment insurance benefits, which expire later this month, into a permanent wage increase for millions of Americans.

headline: How to Keep Music (and One Another) Alive
keywords: ['Music', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: If we want to experience concerts again, we need to support the artists we love until the pandemic passes. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — On June 27, as Covid-19 cases were rising to a crisis level in Tennessee, the country music artist Chase Rice held a concert outside the Historic Brushy Mountain State Penitentiary in Petros, Tenn. Packed tightly together and wearing no masks — at least none that were visible in the video Mr. Rice posted on Instagram — fans seemed unconcerned that a deadly pandemic was unfolding around them. And probably among them, too.

headline: ‘Tell the Truth and Shame the Devil’
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Whites', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For Trump, the truth about patriarchal white supremacy defiles the American heroes who practiced it.
lead_paragraph: As Donald Trump gave his race-baiting speeches over the Fourth of July weekend, hoping to rile his base and jump-start his flagging campaign for re-election, I was forced to recall the ranting of a Columbia University sophomore that caught the nation’s attention in 2018.

headline: Police Seek 2 White People Who Were Seen Vandalizing Black Lives Matter Mural
abstract: “I’m not so surprised that it happened,” said the mural’s organizer, Justin Gomez. “I’m surprised at how bold they chose to be.”
lead_paragraph: [Update: Two people were charged with a hate crime in connection with the vandalism.]

headline: How Netflix Beat Hollywood to a Generation of Black Content
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Movies', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Television']
abstract: The company didn’t set out to build a big library of Black programming, but now it’s the envy of its rivals.
lead_paragraph: The Black documentarian Stanley Nelson says his phone has been “ringing off the hook” as America is looking again at racism and the Black experience. Justin Simien, the creator of “Dear White People,” says the reactions to his pitches have grown warmer. And the director Ava DuVernay reports a flood of calls to “me and every other Black person that’s ever picked up a camera.”

headline: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 1, Episode 3 Recap: If the Teeth Fit …
abstract: For all its brooding and disfigured corpses, the series is also showing it has a lighter side.
lead_paragraph: Sister Alice is out to sea. Literally. In the shot that ends this week’s episode of “Perry Mason,” the charismatic preacher is shown blissfully adrift in her tiny ship, figuratively kept afloat by her conviction that God has spoken to her.

headline: Nick Cordero, Nominated for Tony as Tap-Dancing Tough Guy, Dies at 41
abstract: The Broadway actor’s battle with the coronavirus was followed closely by many as his wife chronicled his experience on social media.
lead_paragraph: Nick Cordero, a musical theater actor whose imposing height — 6 feet 5 inches — and effortless charm brought him a series of tough-guy roles on Broadway, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 41.

headline: Uber Buys Postmates for $2.65 Billion
keywords: ['Delivery Services', 'Venture Capital', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Start-ups', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Food']
abstract: The ride-hailing company’s core business has struggled in the pandemic, so it is betting on the growth of its Uber Eats division.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber has agreed to acquire the food delivery start-up Postmates for $2.65 billion as it aims to expand its presence in on-demand food delivery while its core ride-hailing business struggles.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Scientists Insist Airborne Spread Is a Threat as the W.H.O. Wavers
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 6, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “At the moment we have to make a decision in the face of uncertainty, and my goodness, it’s going to be a disastrous decision if we get it wrong. So why not just mask up for a few weeks, just in case?”

headline: 8 People Believed Dead After Planes Collide and Crash Into Idaho Lake
abstract: All 8 passengers and crew members on both planes are believed to have died, according to a statement from the Sheriff’s Office in Kootenai County.
lead_paragraph: Six people were confirmed dead and two others were believed to have died after two planes collided in midair and crashed into a lake in Idaho on Sunday afternoon, the authorities said.

headline: Catalonia Lockdown, Croatia Election, Prince Andrew: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The God of High School’ and ‘Personal Problems’
abstract: The Crunchyroll original anime series makes its debut. And the final film by the director Bill Gunn arrives on Mubi.
lead_paragraph: THE GOD OF HIGH SCHOOL Stream on Crunchyroll. In East Asian animation, educational institutions are more than just common settings. They’re often portrayed as crucibles within which the transformation from childhood to adult life occurs. The main character in this new series from Crunchyroll, an adaptation of the online comic by Yongje Park, is a high school student and taekwondo practitioner named Jin Mo-Ri who is invited to participate in a fighting tournament along with others in his age group. The competitors use their cultivated skill as well as power borrowed from the gods to try to advance. But gods aren’t the only supernatural entities that exist within this world: Demons are real, too, and they’ve clashed with humans in the past.

headline: Bubonic Plague Found in a Herder in Inner Mongolia, China Says
abstract: A city put control measures in place after one confirmed case of the disease, which caused the Black Death in the Middle Ages.
lead_paragraph: A herdsman in the Chinese region of Inner Mongolia was confirmed to be infected with bubonic plague, health officials said, a reminder of how even as the world battles a pandemic caused by a novel virus, old threats remain.

headline: South Korea Denies U.S. Request to Extradite Operator of Child Pornography Site
abstract: The Justice Department had sought to try Son Jong-woo after he was indicted by a federal grand jury in the District of Columbia on money-laundering and other charges.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean court on Monday rejected an extradition request by the United States for a South Korean citizen convicted of running one of the world’s biggest child pornography websites on the dark web.

headline: Seized by the Police, an Outspoken Chinese Professor Sees Fears Come True
abstract: Xu Zhangrun, who has long taught law at the prestigious Tsinghua University, is one of the few academics in China who have harshly criticized the ruling Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese law professor had stored a few pairs of underwear and a toothbrush in a small bag, close at hand for the day when the police detained him for his unsparing criticism of the Communist Party under Xi Jinping.

headline: Trump Vowed to ‘Drain the Swamp,’ but Lobbyists Are Helping Run His Campaign

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief executive of the arms maker Raytheon, under pressure to overcome a congressional hold on major sales in the fall of 2018, wanted to sit down with one of the few people who could solve the problem — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

headline: A Kennedy and a Professor Compete to Run Against a Trump Backer
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Marijuana', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Stakes are high in the Democratic primary for a New Jersey congressional seat: The winner will face a candidate who defected from the party to support Trump.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Van Drew’s defection from the Democratic Party began with a vote against impeaching President Trump and ended with a handshake in the Oval Office.

headline: Can Cam Newton Be Superman Again?
abstract: Newton went from paradigm-shifting M.V.P. to discarded free agent. Joining the New England Patriots could give him the perfect relaunch.
lead_paragraph: Third-and-10 is traditionally a passing situation, but just outside the red zone on that down, Cam Newton took the shotgun snap, glanced left, tucked the ball and charged forward. Evading a thicket of bodies, he cut right and accelerated toward the sideline.

headline: An Unlikely Source of Catharsis for a Black M.L.B. Player: Social Media

lead_paragraph: Tony Kemp felt, in his words, depressed.

headline: Ennio Morricone, Oscar-Winning Composer of Film Scores, Dies at 91
abstract: His vast output included atmospheric music for spaghetti westerns in his native Italy and scores for some 500 movies by a Who’s Who of directors.
lead_paragraph: Ennio Morricone, the Italian composer whose atmospheric scores for spaghetti westerns and some 500 films by a Who’s Who of international directors made him one of the world’s most versatile and influential creators of music for the modern cinema, died on Monday in Rome. He was 91.

headline: These Radical Black Thrillers Fantasized About Dismantling the Police
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties']
abstract: In the late 1960s and early 1970s, a series of novels by Black authors married revolutionary politics with pulp fiction. Their plotlines remain distressingly relevant.
lead_paragraph: You could almost say these novels predicted their own fates. A telling bit of dialogue appears midway through “Operation Burning Candle,” Blyden Jackson’s 1973 thriller about a Black disciple of Jungian psychoanalysis who fakes his death in Vietnam and returns to America with a group of other veterans to take down the white establishment.

headline: (Let Us Out of This Clause)
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Diving and Divers', 'Writing and Writers', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines']
abstract: At last, I had seen the true absurd hopelessness of things, laid out in flawless prose.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago I got a note from a reader (written in the tone of patient disappointment with which you might discuss pants-wearing with a naked toddler) about parentheses. I used altogether too many of them, apparently. I tried to make them hold more than their listed storage capacity. I may as well have stamped the page with coffee rings.

headline: How a Covid-19 Vaccine Could Cost Americans Dearly
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare']
abstract: The United States is the only developed nation unable to balance cost, efficacy and social good in setting prices.
lead_paragraph: Yes, of course, Americans’ health is priceless, and reining in a deadly virus that has trashed the economy would be invaluable.

headline: Easing Arm and Shoulder Pain From a Rotator Cuff Injury
abstract: Rotator cuff injuries are extremely common, especially as we age. The right exercises can speed healing and recovery.
lead_paragraph: Few of us think about our joints until one starts to hurt when we try to use it in the way nature intended. Then the most frequent response seems to be the proverbial “take two aspirin and call me in the morning.”

headline: How to Sell Your Rape Story
abstract: There’s nothing special about my story. That’s the point.
lead_paragraph: 1. Know that, to rise to the attention of media gatekeepers, your rape story must clear a bar that love and murder and adventure and dragon stories don’t have to clear and be either horrible (gang rape, deep lacerations) or gilded (see No. 2).

headline: I’m a Direct Descendant of Thomas Jefferson. Take Down His Memorial.
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'National Mall (Washington, DC)', 'Declaration of Independence (US)']
abstract: Monticello is shrine enough for a man who wrote that “all men are created equal” and yet never did much to make those words come true.
lead_paragraph: When my brother Frank and I were boys visiting our grandparents at their home in Virginia, just outside of Washington, we used to heckle our grandmother until she would drive us into town so we could visit the Smithsonian museum on the Mall.

headline: Living With Your Desk Mates
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Quarantines', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Telecommuting']
abstract: Five work colleagues, living alone during the pandemic, decide to rent a house in the country and quarantine together.
lead_paragraph: This spring, as the months of quarantine dragged on and Taylor Mecham’s three roommates left their Lower East Side apartment to stay with family outside the city, she found herself longing for some non-remote companionship.

headline: ‘I Am Going to Physically Explode’: Mom Rage in a Pandemic
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Quarantines', 'Women and Girls', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: With coronavirus concerns, stay-at-home orders, financial instability and mounting civil unrest, it is no surprise that mothers are experiencing intensified anger.
lead_paragraph: After I wrote a personal essay on mom rage in 2019, strangers on Twitter declared me an unfit mother. But I expected Twitter-hate. What I did not expect were the many emails I received from mothers around the world, saying they too struggle with mom rage and my story made them feel less alone.

headline: As the Virus Surged, Florida Partied. Tracking the Revelers Has Been Tough.
abstract: With the coronavirus exploding, trying to trace the contacts of every positive case has become unrealistic in Florida, especially among elusive partygoers.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Miami’s flashy nightclubs closed in March, but the parties have raged on in the waterfront manse tucked in the lush residential neighborhood of Belle Meade Island. Revelers arrive in sports cars and ride-shares several nights a week, say neighbors who have spied professional bouncers at the door and bought earplugs to try to sleep through the thumping dance beats.

headline: Everyone’s an Antiracist. Now What?

abstract: Recognizing that Black people deserve dignity isn’t progress.

headline: Could We Fight Misinformation With Blockchain Technology?
abstract: The Times’s Research and Development team conducted an experiment in surfacing news photos’ metadata to help ensure they would be used to advance the truth.

headline: Jarvis Cocker Keeps Hearing That Voice
abstract: Returning with a new band, Jarv Is …, the onetime Pulp leader explains how David Bowie saved his life and why he can’t give up songwriting — yet.
lead_paragraph: “Here’s one of the most exciting things that’s happened to me recently,” said Jarvis Cocker, British rock’s foremost chronicler of hedonistic urges among the educated classes. One leaned in, expecting a rollicking anecdote. “I was given a membership to the London Library,” he revealed. “It’s a private library, in London, surprisingly, that’s been there for about 300 years.” (He was only off by 122 years; it was founded in 1841.)

headline: Our Cash-Free Future Is Getting Closer
keywords: ['Credit Cards', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'E-Commerce', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Currency']

lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a typical Sunday, patrons at Julien Cornu’s cheese shop used to load up on Camembert and chèvre for the week, with about half the customers digging into their pockets for euro notes and coins.

keywords: ['Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Veterans', 'War and Revolution', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Defense and Military Forces']

headline: Biden’s Big Climate Decision: Will He Embrace His Task Force’s Goals?
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Green New Deal', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: The former vice president’s allies and some of the Democratic Party’s leading progressives have quietly started to forge common ground to shape a climate plan before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the earliest days of his presidential campaign, progressive climate advocates viewed Joseph R. Biden Jr. with deep skepticism. He declined to fully endorse the Green New Deal. He opposed a total ban on fracking. Young activists were scathing in their criticism of him, and he was at times openly dismissive of their concerns.

headline: Why New York Buses Are on the Rise in a Subway City
abstract: During the coronavirus pandemic, daily ridership on buses has surpassed the subway for the first time in over half a century.

This week, Chloë Ellingson shares a collection of photos from a remote railway in Canada.

headline: Borders Won’t Protect Your Country From Coronavirus
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Rich nations need to help poor ones now. It’s morally right — and in everyone’s self-interest.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has hit the poorest the hardest, but until recently, they have mostly been in wealthy countries. Now, even as the pandemic continues to claim lives in high-income countries — and especially the United States — it’s spreading with ferocity in lower- and middle-income countries. The virus has infected at least 1.5 million people in Brazil and claimed more than 60,000 lives there. India ended June with around 600,000 cases; it started the month with just under 200,000.

Putin as president for life, a Russian military court on Monday convicted a freelance journalist on charges of “justifying terrorism” in a 2018 text critical of the security services.

headline: ‘An Empty Presence in My Chest’: Vanessa Guillen’s Family Calls for Change in the Military
abstract: Remains found in Texas were confirmed to belong to Specialist Vanessa Guillen, who went missing at Fort Hood more than two months ago. Her family said she had dreamed of being in the military since childhood.
lead_paragraph: While the country erupted in fireworks last week to celebrate America’s independence, one family spent the week leading to the holiday driving between Houston and Washington to demand justice for their daughter and sister, a Fort Hood soldier who had been missing for months.

headline: What You Get for $1.5 Million in California
abstract: A Craftsman house in Los Angeles, a chalet-style home in Tahoe City and a 1924 bungalow in San Anselmo.
lead_paragraph: A Craftsman house in Los Angeles, a chalet-style home in Tahoe City and a 1924 bungalow in San Anselmo.

headline: $1.5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Craftsman house in Los Angeles, a chalet-style home in Tahoe City and a 1924 bungalow in San Anselmo.
lead_paragraph: This house is in the West Adams section of Los Angeles, one of several examples of Craftsman-style architecture on its block. Built in 1906 for an executive of a lumber company, it is within the boundaries of the West Adams Terrace Historic Preservation Overlay Zone. The current owner bought the property in 2010 and has spent a decade restoring it, updating the HVAC, electrical and plumbing systems, while preserving the charm of its original details. Many of the fixtures came from the going-out-of-business sale of a popular salvage store.

headline: Rituals Keep These Athletes Grounded. They Can Help Parents, Too.
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Parenting', 'Content Type: Service', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: With stress levels high during the pandemic, every day can feel like overtime. Here’s how to take back control.
lead_paragraph: Each time my dad, a third-degree black belt in taekwondo, put on his dobok, he would stop and kiss his belt before tying it around his waist. As a kid, I thought it was just a superstition, like tossing a penny into a fountain. But he recently told me kissing the belt was actually to honor it, set an intention and to say, “I will do my best today while wearing this, no matter what comes my way.”

headline: Virus Revives Italy’s Age-Old Shadow Safety Net: The Pawnshop
keywords: ['Pawnbroking', 'Politics and Government', 'Gold', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Credit and Debt', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Italians have put up valuables as collateral for loans for centuries, through plagues and sieges. Today they do it as part of the formal banking system. And business is booming.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The economic repercussions of Italy’s lockdown to contain the coronavirus nearly wiped Anita Paris out. Her son, a car mechanic whom she depended on for financial support, couldn’t work. Her small pension didn’t suffice. The welfare checks she had hoped would pour in from the government didn’t materialize.

headline: Meet the Gleaners, Combing Farm Fields to Feed the Newly Hungry
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Food Insecurity', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Food Banks and Pantries', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: An age-old tradition suddenly has fresh urgency in the pandemic, delivering surplus produce to Americans who can’t feed their families.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD TOWNSHIP, N.J. — Armed with a cheap steak knife and a plastic basket lined with a garbage bag, a high-school sophomore named Alicia Garlic sat cross-legged in the dirt at Specca Farms, a pick-your-own operation here in South Jersey. As the sun burned through the early morning clouds, she harvested curly-leaf spinach as fast as she could, lopping the sweet green tops off yellowing plants, trimming away thickening stems.

headline: Pilots Were Once in Short Supply. Now They’re Losing Their Jobs.
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Pilots', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Seniority Systems', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Before the pandemic, airlines worried about not being able to replace retiring baby boomers. Eager recruits expect to bear the brunt of layoffs.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Weinstein always wanted to be an airline pilot, but the industry was in crisis when he started college in 2002, so he became a middle school teacher instead.

headline: States May Curb ‘Faithless Electors,’ Supreme Court Rules
keywords: ['Electoral College', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Constitution (US)', 'States (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The court said states may require members of the Electoral College to vote for the presidential candidates they had promised to support.
lead_paragraph: [Read our 2020 presidential election electoral college explainer.]

headline: Trump Adds to Playbook of Stoking White Fear and Resentment
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Automobile Racing']
abstract: With a defense of Confederate flags and a false accusation against a Black NASCAR driver, Bubba Wallace, President Trump is focusing on racial and cultural flash points to appeal to his base.
lead_paragraph: President Trump mounted an explicit defense of the Confederate flag on Monday, suggesting that NASCAR had made a mistake in banning it from its auto racing events, while falsely accusing a top Black driver, Darrell Wallace Jr., of perpetrating a hoax involving a noose found in his garage.

headline: Welcome to Sandwich City
abstract: Make a tuna salad soon, especially if it’s been a while, to celebrate summer.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Craig Claiborne put red bell pepper in his tuna salad sandwiches, and called for homemade mayonnaise to bind the ingredients. I do neither, preferring scallions, hot sauce and jarred mayonnaise of the sort called Hellmann’s east of the Rockies, and Best Foods to the west. You might add curry powder, or white balsamic vinegar, or grated carrots. You might waffle the sandwich with cheese, for a pockmarked tuna melt. You might add dill.

headline: Lobbyists, Law Firms and Trade Groups Took Small-Business Loans
keywords: ['Small Business', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Legal Profession', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: The Trump administration began releasing details of which businesses received Paycheck Protection Program aid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration, under pressure to reveal which companies received loans from a $660 billion program intended to keep small businesses afloat, on Monday released data showing that restaurants, medical offices and car dealerships ranked high among the top loan recipients.

headline: Hair From Ghostly Bears Reveals New Genetic Secrets
abstract: First Nations peoples along British Columbia’s Central Coast led research to help preserve the area’s white-furred Spirit bears.
lead_paragraph: Douglas Neasloss was skeptical that Spirit bears existed. A member of the Kitasoo/Xai’xais First Nation in Canada, he had heard the stories of white-furred bears that roamed British Columbia’s rainforest. But Mr. Neasloss, a former tour leader and cultural interpreter, had never seen one until 2005, when he experienced “one of the most magical moments” of his guiding career. During a hike, he caught sight of a cinnamon-tinged white bear as it walked out ahead of him, then lay down 50 feet away to munch on a freshly caught salmon.

headline: TikTok to Withdraw From Hong Kong as Tech Giants Halt Data Requests
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Politics and Government', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Social Media', 'Computer Security', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Google, Facebook and Twitter said they were reviewing China’s punitive new national security law for the city, a rare public questioning of Chinese policy by major American tech companies.
lead_paragraph: Google, Facebook and Twitter said on Monday that they would temporarily stop processing Hong Kong government requests for user data as the companies reviewed a sweeping national security law that has chilled political expression in the city.

headline: What the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: The entry that stumped most solvers in last week’s crossword puzzles was DECKLE, which made its third New York Times Crossword appearance in the Sat., July 4 puzzle by Peter Wentz.

headline: Europe’s Roma Already Faced Discrimination. The Pandemic Made It Worse.
abstract: Roma people in a Bulgarian town are barred from leaving their neighborhood. Officials cite a medical risk, but residents and advocates say it’s yet another form of bigotry.
lead_paragraph: KYUSTENDIL, Bulgaria — At a checkpoint on the edge of a Roma neighborhood, a police officer held up his hand, stopping Angel Iliev from leaving.

headline: Phoenix Police Kill Man in Parked Car, Igniting New Protests
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: The fatal shooting, captured on video, comes at a time when cities around the United States are grappling with anger over deaths at the hands of the police.
lead_paragraph: The fatal shooting of a man in a parked car by Phoenix police officers over the weekend, captured on video in gruesome detail, is fueling a new round of protests against violent policing tactics.

headline: Hip-Hop’s Deluxe Editions Rule the Billboard Album Chart
abstract: The Atlanta rapper Lil Baby notched a fifth week at No. 1 and Lil Durk returned to No. 2 with recently refreshed releases.
lead_paragraph: During a slow summer for the music industry, the 25-year-old Atlanta rapper Lil Baby has been a consistent bright spot. This week, in its 18th go-round on the Billboard chart, his album “My Turn” logged its fourth consecutive — and fifth overall — stay at No. 1, adding another 70,000 units, according to Nielsen.

headline: Students’ Calls to Remove a Mural Were Answered. Now Comes a Lawsuit.
keywords: ['Art', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Murals', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Censorship', 'Native Americans']
abstract: An alumnus has filed a suit to save a fresco at the University of Kentucky that depicts enslaved people; a Black artist whose work is shown with it also wants the mural to stay.
lead_paragraph: For years, there has been a simmering debate over what to do with a New Deal-era mural at the University of Kentucky that students have denounced as a racist sanitizing of history and a painful reminder of slavery in a public setting.

headline: Dakota Access Pipeline to Shut Down Pending Review, Federal Judge Rules
abstract: The ruling, a victory for the Native American and environmentalist groups who oppose the pipeline, said that it must be emptied of oil by Aug. 5.
lead_paragraph: The Dakota Access Pipeline, an oil route from North Dakota to Illinois that has inspired intense protests and legal battles, must shut down pending an environmental review and be emptied of oil by Aug. 5, a district court ruled on Monday.

headline: YouTube’s Power of the Purse
abstract: YouTube shows that some constructions of digital spaces can help combat online nastiness.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Charlie Daniels, Fiddling Force in Country and Rock, Dies at 83
abstract: He was a singer, songwriter, bandleader and a blazing fiddle player on hits like “The Devil Went Down to Georgia.” His politics swung, too, from left to right.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Charlie Daniels, the singer, songwriter and bandleader who was a force in both country and rock for decades, bringing a brash, down-home persona and blazing fiddle work to hits like “The Devil Went Down to Georgia,” died on Monday in Nashville. He was 83.

headline: Laid Off and Locked Up: Virus Traps Domestic Workers in Arab States
keywords: ['Foreign Workers', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Women and Girls', 'Migrant Labor (Non-Agriculture)', 'Domestic Service', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: The pandemic and economic crises have caused many workers to lose their jobs. Some have been detained, abused, deprived of wages and stranded far from home with nowhere to turn for help.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — When the nine African women lost their jobs as domestic workers in Saudi Arabia because of the coronavirus lockdown, the agency that had recruited them stuffed them in a bare room with a few thin mattresses and locked the door.

headline: N.Y.C. Reopening: Dog Runs and Manicures, but Still No Indoor Dining
abstract: The city took its narrowest reopening step yet as it welcomed the return of personal-care services and outdoor recreation spaces.
lead_paragraph: In the five years that Alyson Araque had been getting her nails done at a salon in Manhattan, she had never before been required to do what a receptionist asked on Monday: to wear a face mask. To wash her hands. To wear gloves during her pedicure.

headline: Cherokee Women Aim for a Better Life in ‘Crooked Hallelujah’
abstract: In her debut novel, Kelli Jo Ford summons the details of minimum-wage existence in the last quarter of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: Cans of Aqua Net. Screen doors that flap. Ford Pintos. Wood-grained contact paper on toilet lids. Cheap Zebco fishing reels. Sinead O’Connor cassette tapes. Establishments with names like Padlock Pizza and DoRight Donuts.

headline: 356 Elephants Died Suddenly. The Cause Is a Mystery.
abstract: Some conservationists say the recent die-off in Botswana could be natural, but others expressed more concern.
lead_paragraph: On May 25, conservationists were flying over Botswana’s Okavango Panhandle when they counted something disturbing: 169 dead elephants. A second flight in June revealed more carcasses, bringing the total to 356. Some of the animals appeared to have died suddenly, collapsing chest-first while walking or running. No tusks were removed, suggesting that poaching for ivory may not be to blame.

headline: PGA Tour Nixes Plan to Have Fans at the Memorial Tournament
abstract: The event had the approval of state and local officials to host a limited capacity of spectators when it opens in Dublin, Ohio, on July 16, but scrapped those plans citing rising Covid-19 cases.
lead_paragraph: The PGA Tour’s Memorial Tournament, scheduled next week in central Ohio, had hoped to pave the way for spectators to return to golf events during the coronavirus pandemic, and in turn perhaps provide a blueprint for how fans could safely attend other major American sports competitions.

headline: ‘He’s Buying Up Brixton’: Beloved Grocer’s Eviction Sparks Gentrification Fight
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Gentrification', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Evictions']
abstract: In south London, people rebelled when a developer, backed by an American hedge fund, tried to evict Nour Cash & Carry.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Saja Shaheen is walking the aisles of Nour Cash & Carry, explaining the eclectic inventory of the popular grocery store her family has owned inside Brixton Market for more than 20 years. As new immigrant communities arrive in the diverse area of south London, she said, foods are added to match their tastes.

headline: A New Generation of Fast Coronavirus Tests Is Coming
abstract: New technologies, like the gene-editing tool Crispr, can spot the virus in less than an hour. But it will likely be months before these tests hit clinics.
lead_paragraph: Researchers around the world are working on the next generation of coronavirus tests that give answers in less than an hour, without onerous equipment or highly trained personnel.

headline: In Her Words: 7 Issues, 7 Days
abstract: Learn about seven next-to-invisible inequities that women in the U.S. face every day.
lead_paragraph: Learn about seven next-to-invisible inequities that women in the U.S. face every day.

headline: Amy Cooper Faces Charges After Calling Police on Black Bird-Watcher
abstract: Ms. Cooper was captured on video calling the police after Christian Cooper asked her to keep her dog on a leash in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: When Amy Cooper, a white woman, called 911 from an isolated patch in Central Park where she was standing with her unleashed dog on Memorial Day, she said an “African-American man” was threatening her, emphasizing his race to the operator.

headline: 7 Inequities: A Weeklong Look at the Biases Women Face
abstract: Double standards abound from the salary she earns to the unpaid hours she works.
lead_paragraph: Women are living in a world that’s made for men.

headline: Trump’s Fiery Attack at Mount Rushmore
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers discuss the president’s call for a defense of U.S. monuments, his portrayal of the left as fascists and his comment that Covid-19 was almost always “totally harmless.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Simon & Schuster Advances Publication Date of Trump Tell-All
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The release of “Too Much and Never Enough: How My Family Created the World’s Most Dangerous Man,” by Mary Trump, is now scheduled for July 14.
lead_paragraph: Responding to an increase in publicity and advance orders, Simon & Schuster announced on Monday that it was planning to release a tell-all book by Mary L. Trump, President Trump’s niece, on July 14, two weeks earlier than originally scheduled.

headline: How a Brooklyn Artist Is Making Black Women Her Focus
abstract: Through her Essential Workers series, Aya Brown, 24, has shined a spotlight on the Black women in New York who work in hospitals, schools and retail.
lead_paragraph: The faces of the women in her portraits are often partly covered by a mask tied behind their heads, tugging at braids, low buns or tufts of curls. They are dressed in uniforms that show their essential jobs, but their style and charisma shine through their everyday armor.

headline: There Are Ways to Avoid Layoffs
abstract: A human resources association offers suggestions. Also: Remote learning works.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Facebook, Israel’s outbreak, Uighurs: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Pandemic First: Actors’ Union Will Allow Two Shows, With Testing
abstract: Theaters in the Berkshires are planning live shows, “Godspell” and “Harry Clarke,” with limited audiences and virus-related protocols in place. One will be indoors, and one outdoors.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since the coronavirus pandemic erupted, Actors’ Equity is agreeing to allow a few of its members to perform onstage.

headline: Two Top New York City Culinary Schools Join Forces
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vocational Training', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: The International Culinary Center will become part of the Institute of Culinary Education by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: By the end of the year the International Culinary Center, formerly the French Culinary Institute, will close its doors in SoHo and will become part of the Institute of Culinary Education in the Brookfield Place complex in Battery Park City.

headline: Britain, Charting Its Own Course on Human Rights, Imposes New Sanctions
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab announced that dozens of people from Russia and Saudi Arabia would be added to a blacklist, but China was notably absent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain, seeking to carve out a post-Brexit role as a human-rights defender, said on Monday it had blacklisted dozens of people from Russia, Saudi Arabia and Myanmar for abuses ranging from a carefully-plotted execution to jailhouse beatings and the persecution of Rohingya refugees.

headline: Can We Please Pick the President by Popular Vote Now?
keywords: ['Electoral College', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The Supreme Court’s unanimous decision in the “faithless electors” case is another reminder of how antiquated and undemocratic the Electoral College is.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court clearly got it right on Monday when it ruled that the Electoral College can keep working the way it has worked for the last 200 years.

headline: Airborne Coronavirus: What You Should Do Now
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Masks', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Education (K-12)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coughs', 'Disease Rates', 'Epidemics', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: How to protect yourself from a virus that may be floating indoors? Better ventilation, for starters. And keep wearing those masks.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus can stay aloft for hours in tiny droplets in stagnant air, infecting people as they inhale, mounting scientific evidence suggests.

headline: Trump Supports Washington Team Name. Retailers Pull Merchandise.
abstract: Walmart and Target removed the N.F.L. team’s products from their websites as pressure intensified to change the name, a consideration the president said was motivated by political correctness.
lead_paragraph: The battle over the name of the Washington, D.C., N.F.L. team deepened on Monday as President Trump defended it even as more retailers said they would pull the team’s gear off their shelves.

headline: ‘It’s Got to Stop’: Atlanta’s Mayor Decries a Surge of Violence as a Girl Is Killed
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Secoriea Turner, 8, was one of several children killed across the country over the holiday weekend. Her death has roiled Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Activists with Black Lives Matter had a vision for what the scorched remains of a Wendy’s restaurant could become: the Rayshard Brooks Peace Center, a gathering place in Atlanta with job training, counseling and youth programs that would be a living memorial named for the man whose fatal encounter with the police transformed the fast-food eatery into the heart of the city’s turmoil.

headline: Two Horses Trained by Baffert Test Positive for Banned Substances
abstract: The horses failed tests of a second sample, confirming the presence of an unauthorized local numbing agent.
lead_paragraph: Two undefeated horses trained by the Hall of Famer Bob Baffert indeed tested positive for a banned substance in Arkansas, a person familiar with the results of the split-sample test said Monday.

headline: Kwame Onwuachi Is Leaving Kith and Kin in Washington
abstract: The chef said that he would seek a restaurant of his own. Paola Velez, the restaurant’s executive pastry chef, has also left, to work with two Washington restaurants.
lead_paragraph: A month ago, the chef Kwame Onwuachi reopened Kith and Kin, the restaurant on the Potomac River in Washington where he established himself as a national talent and a leading voice for Black workers in the culinary profession.

headline: Patrick Mahomes Gets 10-Year Deal With Kansas City Chiefs
abstract: Mahomes, 24, signed an extension worth $503 million on the heels of a Super Bowl win.
lead_paragraph: Quarterback Patrick Mahomes, one of the N.F.L.’s biggest stars, has signed a 10-year contract extension with the Kansas City Chiefs, according to a person familiar with the terms of the deal who was not authorized to speak for the team.

headline: Dulce Nunes, Bossa Nova Star of the 1960s, Dies at 90
abstract: She was best-known for the 1964 album “Poor Little Rich Girl.” She died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: In Nick Cordero’s Death, a Reminder of Covid-19’s Unknowns
abstract: The Broadway star died from the coronavirus, despite being just 41 and in apparent good health. Cases like his, experts said, are growing.
lead_paragraph: The death of the Broadway actor Nick Cordero from Covid-19 has shaken people far beyond the theater world, in large part because he was just 41 and reportedly had no underlying health conditions.

headline: As M.L.B. Stumbles Out of the Gate, Player Pushback Gets Louder
abstract: Several teams had to cancel their workouts because of delays in virus testing results, and even some club executives had pointed words for the league’s handling of the process.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball triumphantly declared on Monday morning that it would announce a 60-game schedule on its cable network that evening. Around the same time, the two teams from last year’s World Series, the Washington Nationals and the Houston Astros, were canceling their Monday workouts for safety reasons — and blaming M.L.B.

headline: Breonna Taylor’s Family Claims She Was Alive After Shooting but Given No Aid
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Search and Seizure', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A new court filing says Ms. Taylor, whose death set off protests, received no medical help after she was shot by the police. The coroner asserts that her injuries were so severe she could not have been saved.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — For up to six minutes after she was shot by police officers during a drug raid, Breonna Taylor, an emergency room technician, lay dying in her apartment but received no medical aid, her family claims in a new court filing.

headline: British Foreign Secretary Announces New Human Rights Sanctions
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The British foreign secretary, Dominic Raab, said the new sanctions were part of an effort to carve out a post-Brexit role as a human-rights defender.
lead_paragraph: The British foreign secretary, Dominic Raab, said the new sanctions were part of an effort to carve out a post-Brexit role as a human-rights defender.

keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
