headline: Appeals Court Strikes Down Trump Administration’s Asylum Ban
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The ruling is a legal setback for one of the government’s most important policies aimed at slowing immigration.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A federal appeals court on Monday struck down President Trump’s policy that barred most migrants from seeking asylum in the United States if they had passed through another country, concluding that the government did “virtually nothing” to make sure that another country is “a safe option” for those fleeing persecution.

headline: F.C. Dallas Withdraws from M.L.S. Tournament Because of Virus Cases
abstract: League officials said 10 players and one member of the team’s technical staff tested positive for the virus.
lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer pulled F.C. Dallas out of its tournament near Orlando, Fla., after 10 players and a staff member tested positive for the coronavirus, M.L.S. officials announced on Monday.

headline: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau Won’t Cross the Border for Washington Summit
abstract: Mr. Trudeau was invited to the meeting this week to celebrate the official start of a new trade deal. But as Canada’s coronavirus preventer-in-chief, he hardly could go, experts said.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — He sent his regrets.

headline: How America Lost the War on Covid-19
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Disease Rates']
abstract: It wasn’t because of our culture, it was because of our leadership.
lead_paragraph: When did America start losing its war against the coronavirus? How did we find ourselves international pariahs, not even allowed to travel to Europe?

headline: New York City’s Biggest Decision: How to Safely Reopen Schools
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'E-Learning', 'Politics and Government', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: The plan now emerging could have an enormous impact because the local economy may not fully recover until working parents can send children to school.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio plans to reopen New York’s public schools in September, but students will almost certainly not return to classrooms five days a week, and they will probably have staggered schedules to fulfill social-distancing requirements.

headline: 64 Shot, 10 Dead: Spike in Gun Violence Alarms an On-Edge N.Y.C.
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The victims included a young father who was shot while holding hands with his 6-year-old daughter in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: A young father crossing a Bronx street, holding hands with his 6-year-old daughter. A 15-year-old who refused to talk to the police in Manhattan. A man in a Staten Island public housing complex, found prone in his apartment.

headline: N.H.L. and Players Agree to Start Postseason Tournament on Aug. 1
abstract: The two sides agreed to extend the current collective bargaining agreement, setting the stage for a resumption of play that will reportedly be hosted in Edmonton and Toronto.
lead_paragraph: The National Hockey League and its players’ union announced on Monday that the two groups agreed on a four-year extension to the current collective bargaining agreement, a pivotal decision that paves the way for hockey to resume play amid the coronavirus pandemic.

‘Hamilton’ and the Historical Record: Frequently Asked Questions
abstract: The Disney+ filmed version has fans wondering what’s accurate. Historians are fans, too, and they have answers, along with caveats.
lead_paragraph: When “Hamilton” premiered onstage in 2015, the musical attracted a big following among historians, who were delighted by Lin-Manuel Miranda’s unabashedly nerdy attention to primary documents and the scholarly literature.

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Block Ruling to Halt Work on Keystone XL Pipeline
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Pipelines', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: But the justices stayed the rest of a federal trial judge’s ruling striking down a permit program, allowing construction of other pipelines around the nation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday rejected a request from the Trump administration to allow construction of parts of the Keystone XL oil pipeline that had been blocked by a federal judge in Montana. But the court temporarily revived a permit program that would let other oil and gas pipelines cross waterways after only modest scrutiny from regulators.

headline: McClatchy, a Family Newspaper Business, Heads Toward Hedge-Fund Ownership
abstract: In keeping with a nationwide industry trend, a finance firm seems poised to take control of the publisher of The Miami Herald and The Sacramento Bee.
lead_paragraph: The McClatchy family has been in journalism since 1857, when its flagship publication, The Daily Bee, chronicled the latest for residents of Sacramento in the wake of the gold rush. Now, in keeping with a trend that has placed hundreds of American news outlets in the hands of the finance industry, the McClatchy Company and its 30 newspapers are likely to end up the property of a hedge fund.

headline: A Wine Getaway
abstract: New York Wine Events now offers winery tours, transportation included, for small groups of up to 12.
lead_paragraph: For a way to get out of the house, you can now gather friends and family from your quarantine bubble and take a personal wine tour of the North Fork of Long Island or the Hudson Valley led by New York Wine Events. Open to groups of two to 12, the tour hits the road from Manhattan with private tours and tastings at two wineries as well as a stop at a farm stand. Transportation is provided, and lunch is optional. Health protocols are observed, and the excursion lasts about nine hours.

headline: ‘We Are Still Knee-Deep in the First Wave,’ Fauci Warns
abstract: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said on Monday that he did not consider the increase in U.S. coronavirus cases a wave, but rather a resurgence of infections.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said on Monday that he did not consider the increase in U.S. coronavirus cases a wave, but rather a resurgence of infections.

headline: Slurp Oysters From the Eastern Seaboard
abstract: Need oysters for the raw bar at home? Many producers will ship them fresh to your door.
lead_paragraph: Like cheese makers, those who cultivate oysters along America’s coastlines have also felt the loss of restaurant business during the pandemic. Though it’s long been possible to order fresh oysters, shipped to your door, from some of these oyster farms, there are more to choose from now. (Oysters keep in the refrigerator, unopened, for more than a week.) Then you can either plan on roasting or steaming them open or arm yourself with a proper knife and protective glove — some of the farms also sell the gear. Here are some sources: Peeko Oysters, New Suffolk, N.Y., peekooysters.com; Montauk Pearls, Montauk Shellfish, 631-902-7829 for local delivery; Stella Mar Oyster Company, Stamford, Conn., stellamaroysters.com; Island Creek Oysters, Duxbury, Mass., islandcreekoysters.com; and goldbelly.com supplies oysters nationwide directly from Mook Sea Farms in Maine, Wellfleet Shellfish Company in Massachusetts, and White Stone Oyster Company and Rappahannock River Oysters in Virginia.

headline: Wooden Cutting Boards Arrive From Australia
abstract: These camphor laurel boards are handsome, antibacterial and available in a range of sizes.
lead_paragraph: In 1993, a study was published showing that wooden cutting boards had antibacterial qualities that caused them to be them safer than plastic. An Australian company that makes handsome cutting boards from sustainable camphor laurel trees is hailing its product’s antibacterial quality, which it says was confirmed by the Australian National Association of Testing Authorities. The richly grained boards come in a wardrobe of sizes.

headline: Spencer Cox Wins Utah’s G.O.P. Primary for Governor, Beating Jon Huntsman
abstract: Mr. Cox, the state’s lieutenant governor, is expected to win the general election as well. He had the endorsement of Gov. Gary Herbert, who rose to his office after Mr. Huntsman left it.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Spencer Cox of Utah won last week’s Republican primary for governor, according to results released on Monday.

headline: A Quince Paste by Request
abstract: An American food importer provided the inspiration for this spicy pâte de fruits from Provence, France.
lead_paragraph: Kitty Keller, the founder of the importer KL Keller Foodways, has a favorite French maker of pâte de fruits in Provence, François Doucet. Over a dinner at King, she persuaded him to make a paste she had been thinking of for years: quince (like the Spanish membrillo, often served with cheese) seasoned with espelette, a spice she adores from the Basque Country. The result is a small ruddy block of a densely fruity yet tart confection, with a kick. Serve it with cheese or gently melt it to make a glaze for pork. Use a slice of it instead of jelly in your PB&J, and that sandwich will never be the same.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Evidence continues to build around the risks of transmission at places like bars, restaurants and parties.
lead_paragraph: Elected officials in the United States are beginning to acknowledge that the rush to reopen was a mistake, as many of the hardest-hit areas in recent weeks have been places that lifted lockdown restrictions fastest. And one factor seems to be playing an outsize role in the uptick: indoor transmission from businesses like bars and restaurants.

headline: Colleges Plan to Reopen Campuses, but for Just Some Students at a Time
abstract: To provide some semblance of the campus experience during a pandemic, colleges say large chunks of the student body will have to stay away and study remotely for all or part of the year.
lead_paragraph: With the coronavirus still raging and the fall semester approaching, colleges and universities are telling large segments of their student populations to stay home. Those who are allowed on campus, they say, will be living in a world where parties are banned, where everyone is frequently tested for the coronavirus and — perhaps most draconian of all — where students attend many if not all their courses remotely, from their dorm rooms.

headline: Let the Ramen Come to You
abstract: The chef Yohei Ishida is now shipping ramen kits, with two varieties, from his restaurant Ramen Ishida.
lead_paragraph: Yohei Ishida is not simply packing up his various ramens for pickup and delivery from his restaurant on the Lower East Side. He’s organized them into special kits designed for reheating at home. He offers two varieties, a black truffle shoyu ramen — with a soup base made with locally raised Bo Bo chickens — and fish tonkotsu ramen in a creamy pork broth. Each component comes in a separate container ready to assemble. Mr. Ishida worked at Ippudo NY for many years, then opened this restaurant specializing in Tokyo-style ramen.

headline: Where Italian and Slovene Cuisine Meet
abstract: “Friuli Food and Wine,” a new book from two Colorado restaurateurs, puts a northern Italian regional cuisine in focus.
lead_paragraph: Travel is tamped down for the time being, but I’m daydreaming in my kitchen — Spain, and especially Italy, tempt me. So off I go with a raft of unfamiliar recipes to try, thanks to “Friuli Food and Wine: Frasca Cooking from Northern Italy’s Mountains, Vineyards and Seaside.” Frasca cooking? Frasca is a restaurant in Boulder, Colo., that features Friulian fare, and the book’s authors — Bobby Stuckey and Lachlan Mackinnon-Patterson — are its owners, working with the writer Meredith Erickson. Friuli, or Friuli-Venezia Giulia, the region of Italy east of Venice that nudges Slovenia, is flourishing wine country with a particularly rustic cuisine that has some Eastern European touches. Horseradish in a radicchio salad is one example. For tagliolini al Portonat, a simple restaurant dish, the authors insist on the region’s San Daniele prosciutto, which is sold in the United States. They are keenly aware and helpful when it comes to finding ingredients. The text transported me back to the underappreciated area that I loved visiting not long ago.

headline: Did the Popular Vote Just Get a Win at the Supreme Court?
keywords: ['Electoral College', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The justices’ ruling on faithless electors could indirectly help those who want to circumvent the Electoral College entirely.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Months Into Virus Crisis, U.S. Cities Still Lack Testing Capacity
abstract: With cases surging, some cities are seeing long testing lines and slow results.
lead_paragraph: Lines for coronavirus tests have stretched around city blocks and tests ran out altogether in at least one site on Monday, new evidence that the country is still struggling to create a sufficient testing system months into its battle with Covid-19.

headline: Bolsonaro Takes New Coronavirus Test After Attending Lunch Without Mask
abstract: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil said he would take another test for the coronavirus after a news report indicated he had developed symptoms of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil said Monday night that he went to the hospital for a lung scan and would take a new test for the novel coronavirus.

headline: Paapa Essiedu Knows ‘I May Destroy You’ Is Hard to Watch
abstract: The actor, who plays Kwame on the HBO show, discusses assumptions about sexual assault, his character’s survival mechanisms and why the show needs room to breathe.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the fourth and fifth episodes of “I May Destroy You.”

lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — If you’re going to make a splash of a debut, you might as well emulate the G.O.A.T. (Greatest of All Time), Patrick Berry.

headline: Palantir Technologies Files to Go Public
abstract: The data start-up, which has a valuation of $20 billion, would be the largest Silicon Valley tech listing since Uber made its debut last year.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Palantir Technologies, a Silicon Valley data start-up, said on Monday that it had filed to go public, setting up one of the largest public listings of a technology start-up since Uber made its debut last year.

headline: Solar Deal Would Create a New Industry Giant
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Solar Energy']
abstract: Sunrun is acquiring Vivint in an all-stock deal, valued at $3.2 billion, leaving Tesla further behind as a provider of residential solar panels and batteries.
lead_paragraph: Sunrun, the nation’s largest residential solar company, said on Monday that it was acquiring a leading competitor, Vivint Solar, to form one of the world’s largest providers of solar equipment.

lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about professional athletes who are also social justice activists misstated the kind of school LeBron James is financially supporting in Akron, Ohio. It is a public school, not a charter school.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘The Truth’ and Jim Jefferies
abstract: Watch a family drama starring Catherine Deneuve and Juliette Binoche, or stream a new Netflix special by the Australian comic Jim Jefferies.
lead_paragraph: THE TRUTH (2020) Rent or buy on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu or YouTube. Lovers of French cinema will delight in this new drama by the writer and filmmaker Hirokazu Kore-eda (“Shoplifters”). Catherine Deneuve plays Fabienne, an acclaimed French movie star who publishes a memoir titled “The Truth.” To celebrate its release, Fabienne’s daughter Lumir (Juliette Binoche), a screenwriter, visits from New York with her husband (Ethan Hawke) and their young daughter. What ensues is a thoughtful, comedic portrait of mother-daughter dynamics. Fabienne is wrapped up in her own image and is in denial over her fading legacy, while Lumir claims her mother’s confessional book is riddled with lies. In her review for The New York Times, Manohla Dargis named the movie a Critic’s Pick and wrote, “The drama is measured out in sips, in gazes, gestures, silences, off-handed humor and shocks of brutality.”

headline: How Germany Fell Back in Love With Angela Merkel
abstract: The pandemic has burnished the chancellor’s reputation as one of the country’s best leaders.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is on her way out. After almost 15 years in office, the pandemic is likely to be her last great challenge. It could also be the one that seals her legacy: The virus has reconciled Germany to its chancellor.

headline: Could You Make a Snowball of Neutrinos?
abstract: You’ll need more than a few — say, 300 decillion. And good luck trying to throw it.
lead_paragraph: “How many neutrinos would you need to make a snowball? Would it feel cold and squishy if you were hit in the face, or would it just pass through?”

keywords: ['Rare and Orphan Diseases', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Research', "Rett's Syndrome", 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Clinical Trials', 'Parenting', 'Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker Syndrome', "Jansen's Metaphyseal Chondrodysplasia (JMC)"]

lead_paragraph: 22 MINUTES OF UNCONDITIONAL LOVEBy Daphne Merkin

headline: In ‘The Golden Cage,’ a Kept Woman Grabs the Keys to the Kingdom
abstract: Camilla Lackberg shows how stifled ambition never really goes away. It just bides its time.
lead_paragraph: “Like I said, a doctor needs to reach a verdict based on the evidence at the crime scene. But as things stand, everything points toward the same explanation: that your ex-husband, Jack, has killed your daughter.” So begins “The Golden Cage,” similar in name to two early-20th-century paintings: one of a shackled female, another of a high society woman confined to the household, a prisoner of the patriarchy. In the latter, the woman stares longingly at partygoers outside, envious of their freedom. The title of Camilla Lackberg’s latest novel could not be more apt.

headline: Grandparents, Kin and Play Cousins: The Soul and Survival of Black Families
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Foster Care']
abstract: In households where relationships break down, Black families often turn to relatives or friends to keep children close.
lead_paragraph: I knew my parents, and saw them somewhat regularly, but I was raised by my maternal grandparents. Relative caregiving is ingrained in Black households and a main reason for the low number of formal adoptions. In fact, only 13 percent of formally adopted children live with a Black parent, according to the U.S. census.

headline: The Wilderness of Rare Genetic Diseases and the Parents Navigating It
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Rare and Orphan Diseases', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting']
abstract: “Rare parents” are often left charting a world of unknowns. But their persistence has paid off with more advanced treatment options.
lead_paragraph: Anne and Jerry Van Wyk didn’t notice anything unusual about their son, Reid, in the days after his birth in June 2001. But on his 10th day, when Anne Van Wyk tried to wake her  newborn, she thought his breathing was irregular.

keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Minimum Wage', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Domestic Service', 'Cooperatives', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Can a sophisticated platform cooperative help minimize exploitive working conditions in the gig economy, even during the pandemic?
lead_paragraph: Maria Carmen Tapia has learned a host of new skills in the last few months. The 42-year-old housekeeper and all her colleagues at the housekeeping app Up & Go were trained by Occupational Safety and Health Administration-authorized trainers, learning to put on protective gear correctly and establish safety protocols to keep themselves and their clients safe during the pandemic.

headline: The Confederate Monuments We Shouldn’t Tear Down
abstract: Removing statues that glorify the Confederacy from public spaces is one thing. Our history is another.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, after the violent clashes in Charlottesville, Va., President Trump said of white supremacists defending a statue of Robert E. Lee: “I wonder, is it George Washington next week? And is it Thomas Jefferson the week after? You know, you really do have to ask yourself, where does it stop?”

headline: ‘P-Valley’ Dances to a Different Tune
abstract: This new Starz drama is set in a strip club but “pulses with the female gaze,” said the creator, Katori Hall. Its premise is that sex work is as worthy of exploration as any other kind of work.
lead_paragraph: When Mercedes takes the stage in thigh-high vinyl boots and a matching red G-string, dollars rain down. She struts, she writhes, she flies around the pole, whipping her hair in time to the music. Then the music fades and the crowd quiets and all you can hear are Mercedes’s groans and hard breaths and the creak of vinyl against the pole, chafing the legs beneath.

headline: Help! I’m Owed a Refund, But the Hotel Owner Refuses to Budge
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Rebates and Refunds', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: Here we are, wondering aloud about the oversight capabilities of hotel franchises, and what powers they can exert over their thousands of individual owners. Thanks Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I were supposed to attend a wedding in Sonoma this spring, but the affair was obviously canceled. I canceled our Best Western reservation well before the 24 hours required by the company’s new coronavirus cancellation policy, but was told that the only option is to postpone our stay for a year — as if I jet-set out to wine country every year for a wedding (and besides, I’m more of a beer guy). I’ve been messaging back and forth with Best Western on Facebook; the customer-service people said the hitch lies with the hotel owner, who is refusing to issue the refund. What’s the point of flexible corporate cancellation policies if individual hotels aren’t required to adhere to them? George

headline: Maybe This Isn’t Such a Good Time to Prosecute a Culture War
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Trump has gone to the well one time too many.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump made his name in Republican Party politics as a “birther,” a true believer in — and an evangelist for — the racist conspiracy theory that Barack Obama was a foreign-born, illegitimate president. Having stoked a wave of white grievance and resentment, Trump rode it, first to influence — let’s not forget that Mitt Romney came to receive Trump’s endorsement in person during the 2012 presidential race — and then to the summit of power as president himself.

headline: Nurses Who Battled Virus in New York Confront Friends Back Home Who Say It’s a Hoax
keywords: ['Nursing and Nurses', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Social Media', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: After aiding coronavirus patients in New York City, nurses face relatives and friends who refuse to wear masks or don’t believe the virus is real.
lead_paragraph: Nurses who traveled from across the country to work in New York City hospitals saw the horrors of the coronavirus up close. They rushed patients to overcrowded intensive care units, monitored oxygen levels and held the hands of the sickest ones as they slipped away.

keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Constitution (US)', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: What is up with Chief Justice John Roberts? Has he been cowed by political pressure to move left? Is there a method to his apparent maddening pattern of trading off conservative opinions with liberal ones?

headline: A Survivor of Sexual Assault Speaks Out
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Lacy Crawford told her story when she was a student at St. Paul’s School. Few people listened. Now she’s telling it again.
lead_paragraph: NOTES ON A SILENCINGA MemoirBy Lacy Crawford

headline: How Mexico’s Drug Cartels Are Profiting From the Pandemic
abstract: Lockdown exacerbated addiction in the U.S., while in Mexico, cartels dig into their turfs with charity and curfews, and put violent pressure on a vulnerable government.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The CCTV footage taken just after dawn on June 26 shows a dozen armed men crowded in the back of a truck blocking a road in Mexico City’s wealthy Lomas de Chapultepec district. Minutes later, the gunmen fired over 150 rounds at the armored car of the city’s police chief, Omar García Harfuch. Three people died in the attack, including two bodyguards; Chief García Harfuch survived gunshot wounds in the clavicle, shoulder and knee. “Our Nation has to continue confronting cowardly organized crime,” he tweeted from his hospital bed.

headline: Hemmed In by the Pandemic, Collins Battles for Survival in Maine
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The fourth-term Republican is staring down a better-funded challenger and national headwinds, all while campaigning amid coronavirus restrictions.
lead_paragraph: LUBEC, Maine — It was quiet when the tiny plane carrying Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, landed in Eastport just before noon on the Fourth of July. No blueberry-pie-eating contest, no parade and no Navy ship waiting in the harbor, its traditional place taken by a hulking cruise liner, docked amid the pandemic and yet to set sail.

headline: Hostels Try to Adapt for the Covid-19 Era
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Budget Travel', 'Travel Warnings', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Millennial Generation', 'Generation Z']
abstract: Hostels are built on the idea of community and sharing, can they survive in a time of social distancing? As European hostels reopen, they are confronting new challenges.
lead_paragraph: On any given night at The MadHouse hostel in Prague, as many as 30 guests and staff would sit together for a family meal. Songs from English and Australian musicians like Arctic Monkeys, Rufus Du Sol and Gang of Youths would stream from the speakers. Playing rounds of beer pong or Devil’s Dice — a twist on Kings, the cards-based drinking game — was the pregame tradition before outings to the city’s bars and clubs.

headline: “The Beauty in Breaking,” by Michele Harper: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “The Beauty in Breaking,” by Michele Harper
lead_paragraph: Once, in my early teenage years, I flung myself into an argument that my father and my brother were having in an effort to protect John, but as I was just five feet tall and weighed not even one hundred pounds, I grossly misgauged my strength. When a punch careened against my arm, I was thrown back onto the floor. My mother screamed for me to move out of the way and for my father to stop. John then flipped atop my father to wrestle him into submission, every muscle in his young body pinning the madman to the floor. I scooted back and ran to my room for some type of weapon. Could I use a book or one of my larger troll dolls to pummel my father? What if I missed him and hit my brother? What if that gave the monster the advantage and then none of us would be safe? Yes, I thought about calling the police, but in that neighborhood, you didn’t call the police on your own family.

headline: ‘Burning Down the House,’ by Julian E. Zelizer: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Burning Down the House,” by Julian E. Zelizer
lead_paragraph: On the evening of July 13, 2016, the former Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich marched through the hallways of an Indianapolis television studio as he prepared to appear live on Fox News.

headline: ‘Want,’ by Lynn Steger Strong: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Want,” by Lynn Steger Strong
lead_paragraph: My alarm goes off at 4:30 every weekday morning, and I keep my phone lodged between the slatted stairs that lead up to the lofted bed my husband built us in the closet we use as a bedroom, so that I’m not able to press Snooze. I climb down in the dark and find the phone, which has often fallen. I turn off the alarm and put on my bra and tights and shirt and shoes and gloves and headband, grab my keys and phone, and lock the door behind me; I run miles and miles before anyone wakes up.

headline: ‘Notes on a Silencing,’ by Lacy Crawford: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Notes on a Silencing,” by Lacy Crawford
lead_paragraph: One evening around eleven o’clock, a young man called a girl on the phone. This was a few decades ago, and they were students at a boarding school, so he called the pay phone in her dorm from the pay phone in his. Someone answered and pounded up three flights of stairs to knock on the girl’s door. She was not expecting the call. He was a senior—a grade ahead, but a couple of years older—and he was upset. Crying, she thought, but it was hard to tell, because she barely knew him. He said something about his mom, swallowing his words. He wanted the girl’s help. Please.

headline: Park Slope, Brooklyn, Gets a Beer Garden Built Into a Garage
abstract: A new spot from the owners of Kosaka, outdoor dining at La Mercerie and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Marina Charny, the owner of Wild, a gluten-free Italian restaurant, planned to use a former garage she acquired next to her Park Slope location as a party room. But then she had another idea: a beer hall. She kept one roll-up door, and, for now, this spot is open with outdoor seating at socially distant high-top tables for about a dozen drinkers. She and her partner in this venture, Oleg Kaziev, offer 13 local craft beers on tap, and they’ll fill growlers. Wine, sangria and Prosecco are also poured. A raw bar and finger foods, like wings, fried calamari, guacamole, smoked ribs and pizza, are available. Once indoor dining is approved, there will be space for 50 at full capacity, about 25 well spaced.

headline: Women’s British Open Will Proceed Without Fans
abstract: The event, held Aug. 20 to 23 at the Royal Troon in Scotland, will be the first women’s major tournament of 2020.

The event will be the first women’s major golf championship of 2020. Last month, another women’s major, the Evian Championship, which had been scheduled for early August, was canceled for this year because of the coronavirus pandemic.

lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Murray was represented by Pace Gallery for more than two decades. For Barbara Gladstone, the gallery’s owner, including Murray’s work in group shows with more contemporary artists to expand her audience is one of her top priorities. Bolstering Murrays’ international profile is another.

headline: Can Anything Match ‘Peaky Blinders’?
abstract: Our television critic answers your questions and offers guidance on what to watch next.

abstract: Soaring unemployment will take years to control, and Europe’s recession looks deeper than it did in May, two reports find.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It will take years for the global economy to recover from the jobs taken away by the pandemic, and in Europe the recession will be significantly deeper than forecast just two months ago.

headline: Review: In ‘Stateless’ on Netflix, Cate Blanchett (and Immigration)
abstract: The A-lister plays a supporting role as a dancing scam artist in a mini-series she helped create, set at an Australian immigrant detention center.
lead_paragraph: Cate Blanchett was an executive producer as well as the star of Hulu’s “Mrs. America,” but the multi-Oscared actor actually made her debut as a television producer when the mini-series “Stateless” premiered in Australia in March. She also created the six-part drama, with the Australian writers Elise McCredie (a longtime friend) and Tony Ayres, and appears in a supporting role as a torch-singing hustler who runs a cultlike self-help racket out of her dance school.

headline: When Washington Helped Small Business, Washington Was Helped
keywords: ['Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Small Business', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Consultants', 'Political Action Committees', 'Think Tanks', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The loan program to help firms keep paying their workers had many beneficiaries. Among them was the capital’s permanent political class.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Car dealers and private schools, restaurants and doctors, hotels and contractors all got money from the program established to help small businesses survive the coronavirus. But a subset of the list of recipients reads like a guide to a professional political class that thrives in the nation’s capital no matter what is happening elsewhere in the country.

headline: Everybody Dance Now: 20 Songs to Get the Party Started
abstract: Wedding D.J.’s share their top tunes that are guaranteed to get all of your guests dancing.
lead_paragraph: It may be a while before dance floors are packed again. But music remains a priority for couples, even when hosting intimate socially distanced weddings and celebrations in person or via video conferencing apps and platforms. Hiring a D.J. for your reception — even a virtual one — offers several advantages.

headline: Hoping for a Theater Bailout? Better Head to London

headline: The ‘Surreal’ Moment After Release From Prison
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Probation and Parole', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: For these former inmates in Texas, the rush of emotions that accompany freedom play out at a Greyhound bus station.
lead_paragraph: When inmates are released from Huntsville Unit, the oldest state prison in Texas, the first destination for many is the nearby Greyhound bus station. Every weekday, the bus station becomes a site of reflection for men who’ve spent months, or decades, imprisoned. The short documentary above was filmed before the pandemic but captures the precarious period experienced by the estimated 600,000 people released annually from federal and state prisons across the country. With nothing much more than the clothes on their backs, a bus voucher and a $100 release check, these formerly incarcerated men grapple with the excitement and uncertainty that come with freedom.

headline: Three Confederate Statues Removed in Richmond
abstract: Crews removed a statue of J.E.B. Stuart in Richmond, Va., the latest Confederate monument the city has taken down in recent days.
lead_paragraph: Crews removed a statue of J.E.B. Stuart in Richmond, Va., the latest Confederate monument the city has taken down in recent days.

headline: Ennio Morricone in Eight Moments
abstract: The spaghetti westerns were only the beginning. His scores turned horror, romance and more into transcendent works of art.
lead_paragraph: A composer who thought in terms of molten-guitar melodrama and wailing choral grandeur, Ennio Morricone, who died on Monday at 91, scored movies the way their biggest fans heard them in their heads. He believed in the films no matter how ridiculous, celebrating and amplifying their feelings into something transcendent. (Morricone was often more successful at doing this than their directors or screenwriters.)

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘She Wanted to Save the World’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: The night I met my best friend, Bhavya, we clashed over feminism and plastic surgery. I would go on to describe her as “a more annoying version of myself.” A year later, we argued about the apartment we would move into. We worked our way through medical school, and all the while, we argued: Medical specialties. Netflix shows. Politics. Ice cream. Men. Impostor syndrome. Despite the fights, she would always say, “Stop underestimating yourself; you’re brilliant.” Someday, she will ask me, “How did you meet him?” But for now, let me tell how lucky I am to have met her. — Areej Ali

headline: What Is Your True ‘Character’? And Who’s to Judge It?
abstract: Marjorie Garber’s new book prods at the cloud of confusion surrounding the word — its philosophical roots, literary history, political uses and inadvertent comedy.
lead_paragraph: In the ungainly, interminable pageant of public apologies of late, one statement about misbehavior is proving strangely popular.

headline: ‘Greyhound’ Review: At Sea in World War II, With Tom Hanks in Command
abstract: Based on a 1955 novel, the film follows a Navy captain who must shepherd men and ships across the perilous Atlantic Ocean to join the war.
lead_paragraph: When the United States entered World War II in 1941, a huge challenge for its military was getting to where the fighting was, safely. Troops and equipment had to be moved over the water, even when protection from airborne forces was sporadic. In the Atlantic, this left Allied convoys vulnerable, for harrowingly long periods, to attack by the advanced German submarines known as U-boats.

If the film tends toward convention, it is saved from cliché by the bejeweled and beguiling presence of Walter Mercado himself.

headline: New List of Unproduced Plays Tallies Those Disrupted by Pandemic

headline: A Designer Who Makes Rugs Based on Screenshots
abstract: Tom Atton Moore’s vibrant floor coverings are indebted to centuries-old craft techniques — and to the more contemporary art of trawling through one’s phone.
lead_paragraph: “It’s almost a distasteful color,” says the British rug-maker Tom Atton Moore of the vivid chile-pepper red that appears in many of his handmade wool and acrylic creations. The fiery, cautionary shade, little seen within living rooms, is characteristic of his work as a whole, which often has an almost defiantly undomestic feel. Emblazoned with amorphous shapes in bold colors that include electric blue, a corrosive chemical green and rust red, his designs don’t immediately evoke a sense of coziness. Only upon closer inspection do the dense, lush textures, subtly uneven surfaces and satisfying thickness of the pieces reveal themselves, encouraging a childlike impulse to sprawl across them.

headline: Who Tore Down This Frederick Douglass Statue?
abstract: President Trump and others have speculated about why vandals destroyed a Rochester, N.Y., statue of the prominent Black abolitionist even as protests against systemic racism continue.
lead_paragraph: The authorities know that a statue of the renowned Black abolitionist Frederick Douglass was torn from its base in a park in Rochester, N.Y., and then dumped some 50 feet away, where it was discovered near a river gorge.

headline: Years After 43 Mexican Students Vanished, a Victim’s Remains Are Found

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: The Dire State of Testing
abstract: Scenes from the early days of the pandemic are being replayed, as Americans wait for hours in snaking lines to get a test.

With cases rising in 37 states, scenes from the early days of the pandemic — when people waited for hours in snaking lines to get a test — are being replayed in many parts of the country. Though the U.S. has greatly ramped up its testing capability, performing nearly three times as many tests in June as in April, a surge of infections has ushered in a new crisis.

headline: Corrections: July 8, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 8, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the lack of coronavirus testing capacity in U.S. cities described incorrectly the details of recent testing in Wuhan, China. The rapid testing of 6.5 million people was part of a campaign to screen the city’s entire population, not in response to a new outbreak. And the testing took place in May, not June.

headline: CBS Fires Producer of ‘Magnum P.I.’ After Workplace Complaints
keywords: ['Television', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: The longtime showrunner Peter Lenkov apologized, saying “It’s difficult to hear that the working environment I ran was not the working environment my colleagues deserved.”
lead_paragraph: CBS announced on Tuesday that it had fired Peter M. Lenkov, one of its most prolific producers, after a human resources investigation concluded that he had created a toxic workplace environment on his shows.

headline: Scrabble Tournaments Move Toward Banning Racial and Ethnic Slurs
keywords: ['Scrabble (Game)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'Dictionaries']

lead_paragraph: Josephine Flowers became a ranked, competitive Scrabble player more than a dozen years ago, and to commemorate the moment, she inscribed her custom-built game board with one of her favorite sayings: “Never underestimate the power of words.”

headline: Artists and Writers Warn of an ‘Intolerant Climate.’ Reaction Is Swift.
abstract: An open letter published by Harper’s, signed by luminaries including Margaret Atwood and Wynton Marsalis, argued for openness to “opposing views.” The debate began immediately.
lead_paragraph: The killing of George Floyd has brought an intense moment of racial reckoning in the United States. As protests spread across the country, they have been accompanied by open letters calling for — and promising — change at white-dominated institutions across the arts and academia.

abstract: New fiction: “At the exact moment of the death of time, if I remember correctly, I was lying in the hammock staring out over nothing but empty streets.” From the magazine’s Decameron Project.

headline: The Decameron Project: New Fiction
abstract: Twenty-nine short stories to help us try to understand this moment. Fiction by Margaret Atwood, Tommy Orange, Edwidge Danticat, Charles Yu, David Mitchell, Rachel Kushner and more.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-nine short stories to help us try to understand this moment. Fiction by Margaret Atwood, Tommy Orange, Edwidge Danticat, Charles Yu, David Mitchell, Rachel Kushner and more.

headline: Over 180 Bodies Found Dumped in Burkina Faso Town, Report Says
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: For months, terrified residents of Djibo, a town in the West African nation, kept discovering corpses of men who had been shot, blindfolded and bound. They blame the military.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The bodies of at least 180 men thought to have been killed by security forces have been found dumped in fields, by roadsides and under bridges in a town in the West African country of Burkina Faso over the past eight months, witnesses told human rights researchers.

headline: Downward Dog
abstract: Chase Dittrich makes his New York Times Crossword debut by messing with his keyboard.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Another debut this week! Chase Dittrich joins the club with a puzzle that made me smile and really appreciate computer keyboard shortcuts.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Though Statues in Russia Fell, the Ideas They Embodied Persist
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 8, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Waging war on bronze men doesn’t make your life any more moral or just. It does nothing really.”

headline: An Introduction to ‘The Decameron’
abstract: The magazine’s fiction issue was inspired by Giovanni Boccaccio’s book of tales, written as the plague swept Florence in the 14th century.
lead_paragraph: The magazine’s fiction issue was inspired by Giovanni Boccaccio’s book of tales, written as the plague swept Florence in the 14th century.

headline: Amid Pressure, Chicago N.H.L. Team Says It Won’t Change Its Name
abstract: After teams in other leagues said they would reconsider their names, the club defended its name by saying it was meant to honor a historic figure.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Blackhawks will not change their name, the N.H.L. club announced on Tuesday, despite mounting pressure from Native American advocacy groups and others who say the team’s name and logo are racist.

headline: Chief Justice Roberts Was Hospitalized Last Month With a Head Injury
abstract: A court spokeswoman said the chief justice had fallen while walking for exercise and blamed dehydration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. sustained a head injury last month that required a night at the hospital, a spokeswoman for the Supreme Court said on Tuesday.

headline: Missouri Man Surrenders After ‘Unprovoked Attack’ on 12-Year-Old Performer, Police Say
abstract: The boy’s mother said she wondered what had provoked the attacker “to lash out at a child.”
lead_paragraph: A Missouri man turned himself in to the authorities on Wednesday to face charges that he hit a 12-year-old hip-hop dancer on Friday in what the police called a “violent and completely unprovoked attack” that was captured on video and viewed widely.

headline: Mary Kay Letourneau, Teacher Who Raped Student and Then Married Him, Dies at 58
abstract: A tabloid fixture in the 1990s, she defended the relationship as consensual, as did he.
lead_paragraph: Mary Kay Letourneau, a onetime teacher who became a tabloid fixture in the late 1990s after she raped a 13-year-old student and later married him after serving a prison sentence, died on Monday at her home in Des Moines, Wash., a suburb of Seattle. She was 58.

headline: Tammy Duckworth Confronts Nativist Smears From Tucker Carlson
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Television', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ms. Duckworth, an Illinois senator who is Thai-American and lost both legs fighting in Iraq, has been the target of two nights of attacks from the Fox News host; some were amplified by President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tammy Duckworth of Illinois, a Thai-American Democrat who lost both of her legs fighting in the Iraq war and is now a potential vice-presidential nominee, was targeted with nativist smears for the second night in a row on Tuesday by Fox News’s Tucker Carlson.

headline: Jair Bolsonaro, Global Warming, Sweden’s Economy: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Mad Max: Fury Road’ and ‘Scary Stories’
abstract: “Mad Max: Fury Road” airs on Syfy. And the recent movie adaptation of “Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark” is on Showtime.
lead_paragraph: MAD MAX: FURY ROAD (2015) 9 p.m. on Syfy. In a recent interview with The New York Times, Charlize Theron looked back on her experience shooting this “Mad Max” sequel. “I feel a mixture of extreme joy that we achieved what we did, and I also get a little bit of a hole in my stomach,” she said. Anyone who’s seen the movie will have a sense that shooting it would have been arduous: It revolves around a high-speed desert chase, with characters vaulting between enormous, rusty vehicles cobbled together from spare parts. The main players — the driver Furiosa (Theron) and the warrior Max (Tom Hardy) — are in perpetual motion, threatened by a crazed leader, Immortan Joe (Hugh Keays-Byrne), and an army of his underlings. “The biggest thing that was driving that entire production was fear,” Theron said. “I was incredibly scared, because I’d never done anything like it.”

headline: Does Zuckerberg Understand How the Right to Free Speech Works?
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Hate Speech']
abstract: A new audit warns that Facebook may be “driving people toward self-reinforcing echo chambers of extremism.”
lead_paragraph: It’s time for Mark Zuckerberg to really start listening.

headline: Japan Flooding Deaths Rise to 58, With More Rain on Horizon
abstract: Tens of thousands of troops, police officers and other rescue workers have worked their way through mud and debris in the hardest-hit riverside towns to evacuate residents.
lead_paragraph: For more than a week, Japan has been battered by floods driven by torrential rains, spurring widespread evacuations and the deaths of at least 58 people by Wednesday. Many people remained missing.

headline: Mexican Leader Vows ‘Dignity’ at Trump’s Side; Critics Fear Humiliation
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Illegal Immigration', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, visiting the White House Wednesday, has avoided fighting the Trump administration. Critics say he is too willing to bend to the American president’s will.
lead_paragraph: Before heading out for his first state visit to the United States, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, the firebrand president of Mexico known for excoriating his foes in long-winded tirades, made a surprising promise to his people.

headline: Facebook’s Decisions Were ‘Setbacks for Civil Rights,’ Audit Finds
keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Online Advertising', 'Political Advertising', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Hate Speech']
abstract: An independent audit faulted the social network for allowing hate speech and disinformation to thrive — potentially posing a threat to the November elections.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Auditors handpicked by Facebook to examine its policies said that the company had not done enough to protect people on the platform from discriminatory posts and ads and that its decisions to leave up President Trump’s inflammatory posts were “significant setbacks for civil rights.”

headline: Islamists Block Construction of First Hindu Temple in Islamabad
keywords: ['Hinduism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government', 'Minorities', 'Religion and Belief', 'Vandalism']
abstract: The government hailed the temple as a sign of Pakistan’s growing tolerance under Prime Minister Imran Khan. But pressure from clerics mounted, and the government gave in.
lead_paragraph: A Hindu temple planned for Islamabad, the city’s first, was supposed to be a symbol of tolerance. Instead, violence and controversy have turned it into an emblem of Pakistan’s troubled relationship with its religious minorities.

headline: What’s the Best Exercise for You? Twins Can Provide an Answer
abstract: Almost everyone responds to the right exercise program, but the right program is not genetics-dependent.
lead_paragraph: If you start exercising and do not seem to be gaining as much endurance or strength as you had hoped, you might want to switch up your routine, according to a fascinating new study of exercise responders and non-responders.

headline: Charles Booker Says Progressives Should ‘Show Up and Listen’ to Deep Red Districts
abstract: Mr. Booker, who narrowly lost a Democratic Senate primary in Kentucky, talked about how to get rural voters on board with a progressive message, saying structural inequality affects all people who feel left behind.
lead_paragraph: For most of his Senate campaign in Kentucky, Charles Booker was considered a long shot. He was running in a Democratic primary against Amy McGrath, a former Marine fighter pilot who had the support of the party’s establishment and had raised over $40 million.

headline: Was This Ancient Taoist the First Philosopher of Disability?
abstract: Zhuangzi pushed back against the idea that “normal” is good and difference is bad 2,500 years ago.
lead_paragraph: In one of his philosophical parables, the Taoist philosopher Zhuangzi (fourth century B.C.) describes a man he calls Splay-limb Shu. This man’s “chin is sunk in his belly,” Zhuangzi writes. “His shoulders are above his head, and pinched together so they point to the sky. His five organs are on top, his thighs tight against his ribs.” In Zhuangzi’s era as in our own, most people would consider Splay-limb Shu to be unfortunate.

headline: ‘Inmate #1: The Rise of Danny Trejo’ Review: Prison, Recovery, Stardom
abstract: A man’s journey from behind bars to in front of the cameras.
lead_paragraph: The actor Danny Trejo, with more than 300 movies under his belt, doesn’t mind being what some people call “typecast.” In this engaging documentary about his should-be-legendary life, directed by Brett Harvey, he acts out a typical exchange with an interviewer: “Danny, aren’t you afraid of being typecast?”

headline: The Cafe Has Black Lives Matter Signs. The Owner Voted for Trump.
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: “I’m a liberal guy,” said Thomas Bosco, who is facing backlash after he said in an MSNBC interview that he voted for the president in 2016 and was likely to do so again.
lead_paragraph: At Indian Road Cafe in Upper Manhattan, a Black Lives Matter sign hangs in a front window. Local writers, artists, musicians and political activists are regulars. And for years, two drag queens have hosted a monthly charity bingo tournament there.

headline: College Courses Online Are Disappointing. Here’s How to Fix Them.
abstract: No one wants to pay $30,000 per semester for the current experience.
lead_paragraph: Millions of families with college-age children face a difficult choice. As school after school announces that it will welcome students back to campus this fall, many classes — perhaps most — may continue to be held online. A survey of college students in the spring found that about 75 percent were disappointed with the online learning experience during the lockdown. Is it worth paying as much as $30,000 per semester for that sort of education?

headline: Mainers Are ‘Disappointed,’ Too, Susan Collins
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Maybe we’ve been expecting too much of her all along.
lead_paragraph: As I filled out my absentee ballot for the Maine primary, I was overcome with a familiar sense of dejection.

headline: Ady Barkan Endorses Joe Biden for President
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Endorsements', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The endorsement by Mr. Barkan, an activist who supports “Medicare for all,” signaled that some progressives were increasingly willing to back Mr. Biden.
lead_paragraph: Ady Barkan, the prominent liberal activist and advocate for “Medicare for all,” is endorsing Joseph R. Biden Jr. for president, in a sign that some progressives who opposed Mr. Biden in the Democratic primary race are increasingly willing to actively support him against President Trump.

headline: What Counts as a Streaming Hit? A Start-Up May Have Answers
abstract: Unlike Nielsen, which measure audience size, Parrot Analytics says it can track viewer enthusiasm. That’s more important to subscription services.
lead_paragraph: Nielsen has umpired television’s winners and losers since the medium was new. Who won the West Coast? Who lost in late night? For decades, the entertainment industry has relied on the ratings giant to measure the value of everything from “All in the Family” to “Young Sheldon.”

headline: I Played in the N.F.L. It Needs Way More Than a Black Anthem.
keywords: ['Football', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Coaches and Managers', 'United States National Anthem Protests (2016- )']
abstract: If the league wants to show its commitment to its players, it should hire and promote more Black coaches and executives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In response to the Black Lives Matter protests, the N.F.L. has decided to play “Lift Every Voice and Sing,” known as the Black national anthem, in Week 1 of its coming season.

headline: A Fashion Model For the Moment
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Dresses', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Fashion Shows']
abstract: How a digital avatar helped the fashion designer Hanifa go viral during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: How to have a fashion show during a pandemic is one of the immediate questions facing designers this week, as what would have been the couture runway season is replaced with three days of digital mini-films. Can video ever replace the runway experience?

headline: I No Longer Believe in a Jewish State
abstract: For decades I argued for separation between Israelis and Palestinians. Now, I can imagine a Jewish home in an equal state.
lead_paragraph: I was 22 in 1993 when Yitzhak Rabin and Yasir Arafat shook hands on the White House lawn to officially begin the peace process that many hoped would create a Palestinian state alongside Israel. I’ve been arguing for a two-state solution — first in late-night bull sessions, then in articles and speeches — ever since.

headline: How United Are Democrats? A 96-0 Data Point Offers a Hint
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Polling shows Biden is not facing any serious defections from his left flank.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden has emerged from a contested Democratic primary with surprising party unity and without any serious threat on his left flank, according to New York Times/Siena College polls of the six battleground states likeliest to decide the presidency.

headline: Erdogan Talks of Making Hagia Sophia a Mosque Again, to International Dismay
keywords: ['Mosques', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Byzantine Civilization', 'Ottoman Empire', 'Museums', 'World Heritage Sites', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: The World Heritage site was once a potent symbol of Christian-Muslim rivalry, and it could become one once more.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Since it was built in the sixth century, changing hands from empire to empire, Hagia Sophia has been a Byzantine cathedral, a mosque under the Ottomans and finally a museum, making it one of the world’s most potent symbols of Christian-Muslim rivalry and of Turkey’s more recent devotion to secularism.

headline: Is This the End of New Pipelines?
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Natural Gas', 'Pipelines', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Energy and Power', 'Shale', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Defeats at three projects reflect increasingly sophisticated legal challenges, shifting economics and growing demands by states to fight climate change.
lead_paragraph: They are among the nation’s most significant infrastructure projects: More than 9,000 miles of oil and gas pipelines in the United States are currently being built or expanded, and another 12,500 miles have been approved or announced — together, almost enough to circle the Earth.

headline: The Chicks Are Done Caring What People Think
abstract: The trio formerly known as the Dixie Chicks is returning with its first album in 14 years, at peace with an industry that’s never made nice.
lead_paragraph: The women formerly known as the Dixie Chicks have survived the good old boys of country music, a legal battle with their record label, a feud with a president and arguably the first attempted cancellation of the internet era. As they plotted their comeback — writing their first album together in 14 years — they decided to have a little bit of fun with their reputation. So they called up restaurants across America with menu items named after the band.

headline: Visa Waivers, Vouchers, Flight Discounts and Other Travel Lures
abstract: Desperate to revive tourism, countries around the globe are offering incentives to visit — but Americans, barred from most of these destinations, won’t be able to take advantage of them.
lead_paragraph: In some countries where Covid-19 cases are receding, governments are attempting to entice travelers to help save battered tourism industries with offers of discounted flights, vouchers for local attractions and free entry to tourist sites. A few are even offering to pay travelers’ medical expenses if they are infected with the virus.

headline: As Virus Spreads, States Face a Truth: ‘We Cannot Test Our Way Out of This’
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Disease Rates', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'States (US)', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Tennessee’s governor said anyone in his state could be tested for the coronavirus, and the state would pay. That did not stop the virus from roaring back.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the United States struggled with coronavirus testing this spring, Tennessee was the rare state that lived up to President Trump’s promise that “anybody that wants a test can get a test.” Gov. Bill Lee announced in mid-April that any Tennessean could get tested — regardless of symptoms — and that the state would pay for it.

headline: They Splurged on Fancy Clothes Before Quarantine. Now What?
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Fashion purchases innocently made before the spread of coronavirus are poignant markers of canceled activities.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks before the pandemic, Anthony Longhi, 28, a self-described shopaholic who’s a sales associate at Celine in Paris, found himself smitten with a pair of black leather Yves Saint Laurent pants. Their four-figure price felt indulgent, and he hesitated to buy them. Then came the news that France was about to go into shutdown.

headline: Stop Building More Roads
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: There’s a right way to do infrastructure. Why does America get it wrong?
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden and Donald Trump may not agree on much, but one thing unites them, and it’s no small matter: Both support investing trillions of dollars in a nationwide infrastructure campaign. Both recognize, in their own way, the power of such spending to create jobs and revitalize communities, and invest in the future.

headline: On Some Planes, Empty Rows While Passengers Crowd Together
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: Airlines vowed to bring social distancing to the air. In practice, some are and some aren’t.
lead_paragraph: On a June 30 flight on American Airlines from Dallas to Newark, Joy Gonzalez, an aviation engineer based in Seattle, found herself seated at a window with two older passengers beside her in the middle and aisle seats. In order to gain more social distance, she and the aisle passenger both moved to seats behind them where two rows were empty. But before takeoff, a flight attendant ordered them back to their assigned seats, telling them they had not paid for those exit row seats, which are more expensive.

headline: Pandemic Plunges Puerto Rico Into Yet Another Dire Emergency
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Politics and Government', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantines']
abstract: The island has had to weather a hurricane, a political crisis and earthquakes, but those crises did not lead to the widespread unemployment caused by the response to the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: What Was the Problem With ‘Wyatt Cenac’s Problem Areas’?
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'Television', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Two years ago, his HBO series tried to take on police reform in a thoughtful, comedic way. But being ahead of its time didn’t help keep it on the air.
lead_paragraph: In the debut season of his topical HBO comedy series, Wyatt Cenac resolved to tackle the challenging issue of police reform in America. The show, “Wyatt Cenac’s Problem Areas,” drew on its host’s experience as a former correspondent for “The Daily Show,” allowing him to meet with activists, law enforcement officials and elected leaders across the country. Using a mixture of journalism and comedy, Cenac sought to educate viewers on subjects like community policing, consent decrees, defunding and abolition.

headline: Brooks Brothers, Founded in 1818, Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The retailer, which has dressed all but four U.S. presidents, will close 51 U.S. stores as it looks for a buyer.
lead_paragraph: Brooks Brothers, the retailer known for dressing the great and good of the United States since 1818, filed for bankruptcy on Wednesday, buckling under the pressure from the coronavirus pandemic after years of faltering sales as customers embraced more casual apparel and sales shifted online.

headline: 8 Questions From a Disease Detective on the Pandemic’s Origins
keywords: ['Epidemics', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Ferrets', 'Research', 'Wildlife Trade and Poaching', 'your-feed-health', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Dr. Daniel R. Lucey wants answers to pointed questions that bear on how the coronavirus leapt from bats to humans.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Dr. Daniel R. Lucey, an infectious disease specialist at Georgetown University, has crisscrossed the globe to study epidemics and their origins. His attention now is on the Covid-19 pandemic, which first came to public notice late last year in Wuhan, China. Its exact beginnings are sufficiently clouded that the World Health Organization has begun a wide inquiry into its roots. The advance team is to leave for China this weekend, and Dr. Lucey has publicly encouraged the health agency to address what he considers eight top questions.

headline: Ryder Cup Postponed Until 2021 to Accommodate Fans
abstract: Many of the world’s top golfers had objected to holding the tournament without fans, threatening to drop out of the biennial event if it was not postponed.
lead_paragraph: The 2020 Ryder Cup, a biennial international men’s golf competition that dates to the 1920s, was postponed until next year on Wednesday because of the coronavirus pandemic. The P.G.A. of America, which conducts the team event contested between players from the United States and Europe, said the competition, scheduled for Sept. 25 to 27, would instead be held on Sept. 24 to Sept. 26, 2021, at Whistling Straits in Kohler, Wis., which was slated to host this year’s competition.

headline: Some Polynesians Carry DNA of Ancient Native Americans, New Study Finds
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Research', 'Genealogy', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Native Americans', 'Canoes and Canoeing', 'your-feed-science']

lead_paragraph: About 3,000 years ago, people on the eastern edge of Asia began sailing east, crossing thousands of miles of ocean to reach uninhabited islands. Their descendants, some 2,000 years later, invented the double-hulled canoe to travel even farther east, reaching places like Hawaii and Rapa Nui.

headline: ‘Ai Weiwei: Yours Truly’ Review: On the Irony of Personal Freedom

headline: The Dangers of the N.B.A.’s Short Run-Up to the Restart
abstract: Players have about three weeks to re-acclimate their bodies to full five-on-five speed and physicality. But if they push too hard, injuries could become a serious problem.

headline: Ennio Morricone Was More Than Just a Great Film Composer
abstract: He was one of the great composers, period.
lead_paragraph: Ennio Morricone was more than one of the world’s great soundtrack composers — he was one of the world’s great composers, period. For me, his work stands with Bach, Mozart, Debussy, Ellington and Stravinsky in achieving that rare fusion of heart and mind. Dare we compare the five notes of his famous “coyote call” in “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly” with the four opening notes of Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony? Morricone’s music is just as timeless.

lead_paragraph: When her hospital stopped doing elective surgeries to treat coronavirus patients in El Mirage, Ariz., Trudy Lard went from working full-time with overtime hours to working two days a week.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be ‘At Home’ These Days?
abstract: People are experiencing the reopening of the country in different ways in different regions. They are responding to it differently, too.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. I write from home because home is where I work, but I’m not always at home any longer. I’ve been to a hardware store this week, a pizzeria, a convenience store and the chandlery for a length of rope, which for someone who’s only been to the supermarket like five times since March seems like a lot of progress. This weekend I’m going to a bookstore. I want to read “Crooked Hallelujah,” by Kelli Jo Ford. I might hit the beach to do it.

headline: The Decision to Capitalize ‘Black’
abstract: Readers offer differing opinions about the move by many news organizations, including The Times.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Class Action Park’ Documentary Coming to HBO Max
abstract: The movie looks back on a water park in Vernon, N.J., that became notorious for injuries and even deaths after it opened in 1978.
lead_paragraph: Action Park, an amusement park in Vernon, N.J., that opened in 1978, was notorious for bruises, scars, broken bones and even death — in a single week in 1982, two people died on extreme water rides. Starting next month, HBO Max will stream a documentary about it, “Class Action Park,” that was produced and directed by Chris Charles Scott and Seth Porges.

headline: What We Know About Aerosols and Coronavirus
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Masks', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness']
abstract: In a crowded indoor space, one infected person can release enough aerosolized virus over time to infect many people.
lead_paragraph: In a crowded indoor space, one infected person can release enough aerosolized virus over time to infect many people.

keywords: ['Foreign Students (in US)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
