headline: F.B.I. to Investigate Case of Black Man Pinned by White Man in Indiana
abstract: Vauhxx Booker said a group of white men surrounded him, pinned him against a tree and threatened to “get a noose” after he and his friends had gathered near Lake Monroe.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. is investigating a confrontation between a Black man and a group of white men who pinned him against a tree at an Indiana lake over the Fourth of July weekend, after video of the episode drew broad condemnation.

headline: The Tech Giants’ Invisible Helpers
abstract: Why we should all care who controls the invisible infrastructure of the global internet.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: ‘Far Side’ Cartoonist Gary Larson Shares First New Work in 25 Years
abstract: In a note on his website, Mr. Larson thanked a clogged pen for pushing him to create digital cartoons on a tablet. “I’m just exploring, experimenting, and trying stuff,” he said. “New Stuff.”
lead_paragraph: The “Far Side” cartoonist Gary Larson surprised fans this week with three new cartoons, 25 years after his retirement and months after he teased his return.

headline: Bolsonaro Hails Anti-Malaria Pill Even as He Fights Coronavirus
abstract: He is infected and has Covid-19 symptoms, but Brazil’s president still endorses hydroxychloroquine, an unproven treatment. He projects optimism amid a pandemic that kills over 1,000 Brazilians a day.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil has been presenting an image of resilience and vigor as he fights the coronavirus, flashing smiles and thumbs-up, posting on social media — and enthusiastically promoting the drug hydroxychloroquine.

headline: Ava DuVernay’s Fight for Change, Onscreen and Off
keywords: ['Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Movies', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Violence (Media and Entertainment)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The award-winning film director on the role of artists in a time of widespread unrest, and how film can help hold police to account.
lead_paragraph: — Ava DuVernay, award-winning writer, producer and film director

headline: Robinhood Has Lured Young Traders, Sometimes With Devastating Results
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Financial Brokers', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading']
abstract: Its users buy and sell the riskiest financial products and do so more frequently than customers at other retail brokerage firms, but their inexperience can lead to staggering losses.
lead_paragraph: Richard Dobatse, a Navy medic in San Diego, dabbled infrequently in stock trading. But his behavior changed in 2017 when he signed up for Robinhood, a trading app that made buying and selling stocks simple and seemingly free.

headline: Stanford Permanently Cuts 11 Sports Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
abstract: The university said in a statement that it faced a $70 million shortfall over the next three years.
lead_paragraph: Stanford University, which has built the most successful broad-based athletic department in the country, said on Wednesday that its model was financially unsustainable in part because of the coronavirus pandemic and that it would permanently drop 11 sports to help offset what it projected would be at least a $70 million deficit over the next three years.

headline: The Jewish Week Pauses Its Print Edition
abstract: Pummeled by the impact of the pandemic, the New York newspaper will try to attract a younger readership online.
lead_paragraph: The Jewish Week, a 45-year-old newspaper serving New York’s large Jewish community, announced Tuesday that it would put its print edition “on hiatus” as it moved to emphasize its website amid a steep decline in advertising related to the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Review: ‘Little Voice’ Is a Twee Musical Fairy Tale
abstract: If you’re looking for something earnest and coronavirus-free, the Apple TV+ series from Sara Bareilles and Jessie Nelson may be perfectly timed.
lead_paragraph: If you’re particularly hungry to escape current realities, and have a susceptibility to industrial-strength sentimentality wrapped in tastefully autumnal lighting, then “Little Voice” on Apple TV+ might appeal to you. A half-hour dramedy premiering Friday about an aspiring singer-songwriter who tends bar, teaches music and walks dogs on the suspiciously clean streets of New York, it’s coronavirus-free.

headline: Does Cuomo Share Blame for 6,200 Virus Deaths in N.Y. Nursing Homes?
abstract: A state directive sent thousands of Covid-19 patients into nursing homes, but the Cuomo administration has given other reasons for the virus’s spread.
lead_paragraph: The death toll inside New York’s nursing homes is perhaps one of the most tragic facets of the coronavirus pandemic: More than 6,400 residents have died in the state’s nursing homes and long-term care facilities, representing more than one-tenth of the reported deaths in such facilities across the country.

headline: Trump Welcomes Mexico’s President in Surprisingly Warm Terms
keywords: ['United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: President Trump hosted Andrés Manuel López Obrador at the White House to spotlight a North American trade deal.
lead_paragraph: President Trump welcomed Mexico’s president to the White House on Wednesday for a feel-good meeting between unlikely partners that was meant to celebrate a revised North American Free Trade Agreement that Mr. Trump hailed as historic but that is expected to have only modest economic effects.

headline: Harvard and M.I.T. Sue to Stop Trump Visa Rules for Foreign Students
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'International Study and Teaching', 'Visas', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: Universities opposed a policy that would require students to take at least one in-person class or be denied permission to study in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology sued the Trump administration in federal court on Wednesday, seeking to block a directive that would strip foreign college students of their visas if the courses they take this fall are entirely online.

headline: All in the Family Dynamics: Donald Trump’s Niece on the President’s Clan
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In “Too Much and Never Enough,” Mary L. Trump says her uncle is turning this country “into a macro version of my malignantly dysfunctional family.”
lead_paragraph: Robert Trump, baby brother of Donald Trump, has had a curious turn in the spotlight these last couple of weeks, as he has repeatedly tried to prevent the publication of “Too Much and Never Enough,” a new memoir by his and the president’s niece, Mary L. Trump. In the book, it turns out that Uncle Rob has only a bit part to play — the youngest child of five who took the path of least resistance, sliding into the executive chair of his father’s business, a mostly passive bystander to the central drama between Donald and Mary’s father, Freddy. Still, Mary doesn’t strip Rob of all personality. She remembers him as a teenager, not much older than she was, leaning against the refrigerator as he peeled back the foil on a block of Philadelphia cream cheese and ate it “as if it were a candy bar.”

headline: Britain Plans Incentives to Bring Its Workers Back
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Fearing layoffs as a furlough program expires, the government is prodding businesses to coax their staff members to return — and consumers to eat out.
lead_paragraph: The British government, facing a potential avalanche of layoffs in the fall, announced a host of tax and spending measures on Wednesday to preserve and create jobs in Britain as the nation reopens its economy.

headline: United Airlines Could Furlough 36,000 Workers as Virus Cases Soar
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Flight Attendants', 'Pilots', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The airline warned workers that they could lose their jobs because demand for travel remains weak and appears to be falling again as infections rise.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines said on Wednesday that it could furlough as many as 36,000 employees, or nearly 40 percent of its global work force, this fall if travel remained weak and more workers did not accept concessions like reduced hours or buyout and early retirement packages.

headline: Grave Shortages of Protective Gear Flare Again as Covid Cases Surge
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hospitals', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Masks', 'Shortages', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Five months into the pandemic, the U.S. still hasn’t solved the problem. The dearth of supplies is affecting a broad array of health facilities, renewing pleas for White House intervention.
lead_paragraph: As coronavirus cases surge across the country, hospitals, nursing homes and private medical practices are facing a problem many had hoped would be resolved by now: a dire shortage of respirator masks, isolation gowns and disposable gloves that protect front-line medical workers from infection.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Hong Kong, U.S. schools, Hagia Sophia: here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Radio Television Hong Kong, the territory’s public broadcaster, has fearlessly reported on police misconduct and China’s crackdown on the Uighurs, asking tough questions to top officials. But under the new national security law, its journalists have been feeling the pressure.

headline: Shepard Smith, Formerly of Fox News, Joins CNBC as a Nightly Anchor
abstract: Mr. Smith abruptly left Fox News last year after tensions over coverage. He was hired as CNBC is rethinking its evening lineup.
lead_paragraph: Shepard Smith, the former Fox News anchor who abruptly left his longtime network last year after tensions with colleagues over coverage, is set to join CNBC, the cable station known for Wall Street and business news, as the host of a new nightly newscast.

headline: How Democrats Can Win the Youth Vote in November
abstract: Youth organizers have the answers. When will party elites invest in them?
lead_paragraph: Yaniliz Rosario, 19, was making Snapchat playlists for a watch party for an event that some may assume teenagers don’t typically get excited about — a school board meeting. High schoolers logged on, flooding the chat box on Zoom with questions, as Ms. Rosario curated song suggestions and gave them shout-outs.

headline: New Transcripts Detail Last Moments for George Floyd
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: “They’ll kill me. They’ll kill me,” Mr. Floyd pleaded, according to a body camera transcript in court filings by a former officer who wants the charges against him dismissed.
lead_paragraph: George Floyd’s dying moments have played on an endless loop, horrifying the world and prompting a spasm of street protests, but newly released evidence reveals an even more desperate scene than previously known in the moments before an officer pressed his knee into Mr. Floyd’s neck.

headline: Facebook Removes Roger Stone for Ties to Fake Accounts
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The social network said the fake accounts were active around the 2016 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on Roger Stone’s sentence being commuted by President Trump.]

headline: 7 Takeaways From Mary Trump’s Book About Her Uncle Donald
abstract: Growing up Trump wasn’t easy. There were feuds, grudges and spanking with a wooden spoon. Now, there’s the burden of the name.
lead_paragraph: In the prologue of “Too Much and Never Enough,” Mary Trump writes: “The media failed to notice that not one member of Donald’s family, apart from his children, his son-in-law and his current wife, said a word in support of him during the entire campaign.” That doesn’t mean they had no opinions. The daughter of the president’s older brother, Freddy, who died in 1981, now shares some of hers — not just by airing the family’s dirty laundry, but by washing and folding it, too. (Mary Trump is a clinical psychologist whose diagnoses for her uncle are as varied and extensive as the fast food buffet he offered the Clemson Tigers when they visited the White House in 2019.)

headline: Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders Deepen Their Cooperation
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Tuition', 'Student Loans']
abstract: Allies of the onetime presidential rivals revealed a long list of policy proposals. Most were widely acceptable to liberals, and some were broader than Mr. Biden’s plans during the primary campaign.
lead_paragraph: Allies of Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Bernie Sanders unveiled a sweeping set of joint policy recommendations on Wednesday, a significant if tentative sign of cooperation among Democrats as Mr. Biden’s campaign continues its appeals to the progressive left.

headline: Court Ruling in Monaco Ends One Piece of a $2 Billion Art Dispute
abstract: The case against Yves Bouvier, a Swiss businessman who helped the Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev buy 38 artworks, was dismissed.
lead_paragraph: A long-running dispute, between Yves Bouvier, a Swiss businessman who sold $2 billion worth of artworks, and Dmitry Rybolovlev, the Russian billionaire who bought them, took a decisive step in Mr. Bouvier’s favor Wednesday when a Monaco court upheld a lower court’s ruling to dismiss the criminal investigation against him because the prosecution of him had been unfair.

headline: A Black Republican Feels the Sting of Racism but Is Silent on Trump
abstract: John James, a candidate for Senate in Michigan, is grappling with heavy and complicated questions as he tries to lead in President Trump’s Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — John James still feels the sting from the harrowing encounters and indignities he has experienced as a young Black man crossing paths with the police.

headline: Santiago Manuin, Indigenous Leader in Peru, Dies at 63
abstract: Mr. Manuin fought for the rights of Indigenous people and the protection of the Amazon. He survived a gunshot wound from a 2009 police crackdown, but died last week of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: ‘Hamilton,’ ‘The Simpsons’ and the Problem With Colorblind Casting
abstract: Egalitarian in theory, the practice is more often used to exclude performers of color. But even well-intentioned efforts at increasing diversity create complications.
lead_paragraph: Late June brought news that the animated shows “The Simpsons,” “Family Guy,” “Big Mouth” and “Central Park” would recast characters of color who have been played by white actors.

headline: Overlooked No More: Brad Lomax, a Bridge Between Civil Rights Movements
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Disabilities', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT']
abstract: A member of the Black Panthers, he helped lead a historic, and successful, sit-in in San Francisco as part of a nationwide anti-discrimination campaign on behalf of people with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. This latest installment is part of a series exploring how the Americans With Disabilities Act has shaped modern life for disabled people. Share your stories or email us at ada@nytimes.com.

headline: Macron’s New Cabinet Stirs Ire of French Feminists
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', "Women's Rights", 'Sex Crimes', '#MeToo Movement']

headline: Ivy League Places All Sports on Hold Until January
abstract: The league’s decision could be influential for other university presidents as they consider how to handle the coronavirus pandemic. It is the first Division I conference to suspend football for the fall.
lead_paragraph: The Ivy League presidents placed all sports on hold Wednesday until at least January, making it the first Division I conference that will not play football as scheduled in the fall because of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Couples Separated by Europe’s Travel Bans Fight to Be Reunited
keywords: ['Travel Warnings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Dating and Relationships']

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Local outcry had grown for weeks over plans by the Texas Republican Party to hold its convention in Houston in the middle of one of the nation’s worst coronavirus outbreaks.

headline: What Will Trump’s Rally in New Hampshire Be Like? It’s Anyone’s Guess
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines']
abstract: The governor, a Republican, isn’t attending. It isn’t clear how many other G.O.P. elected officials will come. The turnout could be low, or expansive. And fears of the virus hang over the event.
lead_paragraph: Three days before President Trump’s latest rally, in a state that Hillary Clinton narrowly won in 2016, the only thing that seems clear is that the president’s team has no idea what to expect.

headline: Schools, Supreme Court, Summer Gardens: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing

headline: Ida Haendel, Violin Virtuoso With ‘Fire and Ice’ in Her Playing, Dies
abstract: A link to the early-20th-century school of violin playing, Ms. Haendel was a noted champion of the concertos of Britten, Walton and Sibelius.
lead_paragraph: Ida Haendel, the Polish-born prodigy with a fiery sound and unassailable technique who became one of the foremost violinists of her generation,  died on July 1 in Pembroke Park, Fla.

headline: Study of 17 Million Identifies Crucial Risk Factors for Coronavirus Deaths
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Elderly', 'Gender', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'your-feed-health', 'Research', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Age, Chronological', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: The largest study yet confirms that race, ethnicity, age and sex can raise a person’s chances of dying from Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: An analysis of more than 17 million people in England — the largest study of its kind, according to its authors — has pinpointed a bevy of factors that can raise a person’s chances of dying from Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: A Push to Reopen Schools
abstract: The Trump administration is putting pressure on school districts to resume in-person learning by the fall.
lead_paragraph: In an ideal world, schools would reopen in the fall.

keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'E-Sports', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']

headline: Driver Charged With Vehicular Homicide in Death of Seattle Protester
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']

keywords: ['Names, Organizational', 'Names, Personal', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Country Music', 'Blues Music', 'Trademarks and Trade Names']
abstract: The platinum-selling country group’s new name was already being used by a blues singer. Now they’re asking a court to affirm “a trademark we have held for many years.”
lead_paragraph: When the country trio Lady Antebellum announced last month that it would change its Civil War-referencing band name to Lady A out of respect for Black people, the group credited the widespread protests against police brutality for revealing “blind spots we didn’t even know existed.”

headline: Some Republicans Have Grown Wary of Protests Against Racism, Poll Shows
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Police Reform', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: A month ago, polls reflected a new consensus around the need for racial justice. But after weeks of attacks by President Trump, some Republicans’ views have shifted.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans continue to support the nationwide protests against racial injustice, but with President Trump issuing an ever-more-combative barrage of attacks, new polling shows that some Republicans have grown wary of demonstrators’ demands and retreated toward saying that racism is not in fact a big problem in the United States.

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Dr. Bruce Dart, the director of the Tulsa Health Department, said Tulsa County had reported nearly 500 new cases of Covid-19 in the past two days.

keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: President Trump and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico marked the start of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement on Wednesday. It replaced the North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: The Next Big Campaign Issue: Reopening Schools
abstract: Right as the presidential campaign enters the final stretch, the nation’s schools will be plunged into a huge experiment during a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host, back with you after a break.

headline: State Attorney General Calls for Stripping N.Y.P.D. Control From Mayor
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Citing police misconduct at protests, the attorney general said an independent panel should oversee the city police and hire the commissioner.
lead_paragraph: One officer in Brooklyn pulled down a protester’s mask and pepper-sprayed him. Another officer shoved a young woman to the ground, knocking her head against the pavement and giving her a concussion. An officer in Manhattan pulled a gun and waved it at protesters after one of his colleagues was hit in the head with an thrown object.

headline: Newsom Says California Has the Capacity to Treat 50,000 Virus Patients
abstract: On Wednesday, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said he had been working with healthcare officials to ensure the state did not get overwhelmed with the increase in coronavirus hospitalizations over the past few weeks.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said he had been working with healthcare officials to ensure the state did not get overwhelmed with the increase in coronavirus hospitalizations over the past few weeks.

headline: Serbia Protests Meet Violent Response in Europe’s 1st Major Virus Unrest
abstract: To counter a second coronavirus wave, President Aleksandar Vucic announced a new lockdown. Protesters reacted with fury at his inconsistency, amid wider anger over his strongman leadership.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Serbs demonstrated for a second consecutive night on Wednesday in response to President Aleksandar Vucic’s management of the coronavirus crisis and wider concerns over the state of democracy in Serbia.

headline: Sex, Sisters and Dr. Donald
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'ABORTION']
abstract: Who wants to trust their reproductive life to Trump?
lead_paragraph: Let’s pretend there was an order of nuns with a particular devotion to the Sacred Heart of Jesus. So much so that the order had, over the years, decided that any human heart was a holy symbol, and it was immoral to mess with it, even if you were a physician doing cardiac surgery.

headline: Corrections: July 9, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 9, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about Mary L. Trump’s reasons for writing a memoir about President Trump, her uncle, misstated the birth order of Ms. Trump and her brother, Fred Trump III. She is younger than him, not older. The article also misidentified a member of the Trump family who sued over an estate. The quote referred to Fred Trump III, not Fred Trump Jr.

headline: Where’s Trump’s Financial Disclosure? The White House Blames the Pandemic
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Trump Tax Returns']
abstract: The annual report was due last week under federal ethics rules, but the White House says it needs more time. The president was already given a 45-day extension.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s annual financial disclosure report was due to be released more than a week ago. But the filing, the only official public document detailing his personal finances, was not published, and neither the White House nor federal ethics officials offered a public explanation.

headline: Call a Thing a Thing
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Whites', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Language and Languages', 'News and News Media']
abstract: White supremacy is the biggest racial problem this country faces, and has faced.
lead_paragraph: Now that we are deep into protests over racism, inequality and police brutality — protests that I’ve come to see as a revisiting of Freedom Summer —  it is clear that Donald Trump sees the activation of white nationalism and anti-otherness as his path to re-election. We are engaged in yet another national conversation about race and racism, privilege and oppression.

headline: 5 Guards and a Nurse Face Charges in Death of Inmate Who Pleaded, ‘I Can’t Breathe’
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers']
abstract: Five former detention officers and a nurse at a North Carolina jail were charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of a Black man, John Neville, 56.
lead_paragraph: Five former detention officers and a nurse at a North Carolina jail have been charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of a Black man who repeatedly exclaimed, “I can’t breathe,” as the officers tried unsuccessfully to remove his handcuffs, a prosecutor said on Wednesday.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Churches Open Doors, and the Virus Sweeps In
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 9, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Our churches have followed protocols — masks, go in one door and out the other, social distancing. And still people have tested positive.”

abstract: The return of Joe Kidd.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Thousands of New York renters left the city because of the coronavirus, and rents have finally started to go down.

headline: Australia Halts Hong Kong Extradition Agreement and Extends Visas
abstract: Prime Minister Scott Morrison said visas for Hong Kongers already in Australia would be lengthened by five years, and suggested businesses should move from the city to his country.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Australia will suspend its extradition agreement with Hong Kong because of the new national security law imposed by China and extend temporary visas for Hong Kongers in the country, Prime Minister Scott Morrison said on Thursday.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Once Upon a Time in America’ and ‘Stateless’
abstract: Rent a Sergio Leone classic with music by Ennio Morricone, or stream a new mini-series about an immigrant detention center in Australia.
lead_paragraph: ONCE UPON A TIME IN AMERICA (1984) Rent on Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. In the 1960s, the Italian filmmaker Sergio Leone and the Italian composer Ennio Morricone created a distinctive, sweeping vision of the Old West in movies like “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly” and “Once Upon a Time in the West,” where brass horns blew over desert sand. A couple decades later, they captured outlaws in more claustrophobic surroundings with “Once Upon a Time in America,” a mob movie set in New York’s Lower East Side. The plot tracks the growth of two gangsters (played as adults by Robert De Niro and James Woods) and a budding Broadway dancer (Elizabeth McGovern). It stretches over several decades — parts of the story take place in 1922, 1933 and 1968 — an epic expanse that was infamously cut to under two and a half hours when the film was shown in North American theaters. (“This version seems to have been edited with a roulette wheel,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times in 1984.) Thankfully, a longer, 229-minute version that was shown in European cinemas and is widely considered superior is available from the streaming services listed above.

headline: In the Absence of Live Theater, TV Takes, Well, Center Stage
abstract: “Staged,” a six-episode sitcom, and “Talking Heads,” a remake of a group of vaunted monologues, show what good can come of a bereft theatrical scene in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Can we add Michael Sheen and David Tennant to the list of defining double-acts of our time? That’s one response to the giddy pleasures of “Staged,” a delicious comedy series made for the BBC that owes its existence to the theatrical desolation of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Naya Rivera, ‘Glee’ Actress, Is Missing at California Lake
abstract: There was “no indication” the 33-year-old actress made it to shore after going missing Wednesday, the authorities said. They were focusing the search on the waters of Lake Piru.
lead_paragraph: The search for Naya Rivera, 33, who starred in six seasons of the Fox series “Glee” as the sharp-witted cheerleader Santana Lopez, resumed Thursday morning after she was reported missing on Wednesday at Lake Piru in California, the authorities said.

headline: Six Feet? Try Seven Separate Tracks
abstract: Call it extreme social distancing. Track and field athletes will compete in eight disciplines at seven different tracks in Europe and the United States.
lead_paragraph: At the last summer Olympics, Allyson Felix and Shaunae Miller-Uibo dueled down the final stretch of the 400 meters. In a photo finish, Miller sprawled across the finish line to win the gold medal by seven-hundredths of a second.

keywords: ['Triathlon', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Athletics and Sports']

headline: The True Story of My Marriage to a Pot
abstract: How did it come to this? My stars were not aligned.

headline: How Everclear Became a Pandemic Favorite
abstract: Long the stuff of fraternity parties, the 190-proof grain alcohol wants to go from D.I.Y. germ killer to cocktail ingredient.

To date, she has signed copies of “28 Summers” at four independent stores — Bethany Beach Books and Browseabout Books on the Delaware coast, Books & Greetings in Northvale, N.J., and Warwick’s in La Jolla, Calif.

headline: When a Critic Met Facebook: ‘What They’re Doing Is Gaslighting’
abstract: “I think Facebook’s heart is in the right place sometimes. But their heart doesn’t make decisions inside the corporation."
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s long-awaited civil rights audit is now public and it isn’t flattering. The 100-plus-page report laid bare many of the issues facing the platform — that Facebook does not fully understand how its algorithms drive hate, that anti-Muslim speech is “rampant,” that Facebook’s reforms never fix the problem — and warned the company may be “driving people toward self-reinforcing echo chambers of extremism.”

headline: Supreme Court to Decide if Trump Can Block Release of Tax Records
abstract: Around 10 a.m. Thursday, the justices are set to issue highly anticipated decisions on whether the president’s accountants and bankers must disclose information about his financial affairs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Around 10 a.m. Thursday, the Supreme Court is set to decide whether President Trump can block the release of his financial records. The ruling, concerning tax returns and other information the president has fought hard to protect, is likely to yield a major statement on the power of presidents to resist demands for information from Congress and prosecutors.

headline: 68% Have Antibodies in This Clinic. Can a Neighborhood Beat a Next Wave?
abstract: Data from those tested at a storefront medical office in Queens is leading to a deeper understanding of the outbreak’s scope in New York.
lead_paragraph: At a clinic in Corona, a working-class neighborhood in Queens, more than 68 percent of people tested positive for antibodies to the new coronavirus. At another clinic in Jackson Heights, Queens, that number was 56 percent. But at a clinic in Cobble Hill, a mostly white and wealthy neighborhood in Brooklyn, only 13 percent of people tested positive for antibodies.

headline: Stocks That Could Thrive in a Post-Pandemic World
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Medical Devices', 'Politics and Government', 'Quarantines', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Telecommuting', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']

headline: How a Saber-Tooth Marsupial Blinded Us With Its Bite
abstract: The extinct South American animal made us believe it was as fierce as a saber-tooth cat, but a new study suggests it was a mere scavenger.
lead_paragraph: Smilodon fatalis has its name for a reason. With swordlike canines, the saber-tooth cat is widely thought to have waited in silence before lunging and dealing devastating wounds to the soft throats of the large animals that it preyed upon. But paleontologists have long believed that this super-ambush predator was not alone in its way of life. A predatory marsupial known as Thylacosmilus also had long blades projecting from its mouth. But new research suggests that this notion is wrong.

headline: Warehouse Workers in a Bind as Virus Spikes in Southern California

lead_paragraph: BLOOMINGTON, Calif. — When Thomas and Kim Rocha bought their house in 2006 in this unincorporated swath of San Bernardino County about 50 miles east of Los Angeles, they looked out on a view of snow-capped mountains and blue sky.

headline: Cairo Badly Needed a Detox. Lockdown Supplied One, at a Steep Price.
abstract: Three months of lockdown slowed its pulse, stripped its grit and exposed a new side to a weary city. But without the noise, bustle and grind, was it really Cairo?
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — If ever a city needed a good detox, it was Cairo.

headline: Republican Senators in Arizona and Georgia Have a Problem: The Base
abstract: This November, the uneasy relationship between the most right-wing voters in the Republican Party and the statewide lawmakers who rely on their votes will burst into the open.
lead_paragraph: DILLARD, Ga. — As Representative Doug Collins went booth to booth at a recent Republican jamboree in northeast Georgia’s Rabun County, he was a hero, not an insurgent. No one knocked him for splitting the party with his bid against the state’s junior senator, Kelly Loeffler, who is also a Republican. For many voters in the deeply conservative region, Mr. Collins was the candidate who most represented the values of their political icon: President Trump.

headline: United Airlines says it could furlough up to 36,000 workers.

headline: Should Schools Reopen?

lead_paragraph: An Iowa school district suspended its in-person summer school program this week after an outbreak of fevers. Fort Benning, an Army base in Georgia, had a coronavirus outbreak shortly after new recruits arrived. And multiple sports teams have had to halt practices after athletes or other employees got sick.

headline: I’ve Seen a Future Without Cars, and It’s Amazing
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Buses', 'Transit Systems', 'Urban Areas', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Parking', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Air Pollution', 'Land Use Policies', 'Pedestrian Malls']
abstract: Why do American cities waste so much space on cars?
lead_paragraph: As coronavirus lockdowns crept across the globe this winter and spring, an unusual sound fell over the world’s metropolises: the hush of streets that were suddenly, blessedly free of cars. City dwellers reported hearing bird song, wind and the rustling of leaves. (Along with, in New York City, the intermittent screams of sirens.)

headline: Seoul Mayor Is Found Dead After Harassment Complaint Is Filed
abstract: Mayor Park Won-soon, who vanished after leaving a cryptic message for his daughter, had faced a newly filed complaint from his secretary.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The mayor of Seoul, the country’s second-most powerful official and a potential presidential candidate, was found dead just days after a secretary in his office told the police that he had sexually harassed her since 2017, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Thailand Moves to Legalize Same-Sex Unions, a Rare Step in Asia
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The bill avoids the term “marriage,” but allows for couples to adopt children and jointly own property. Though approved by the country’s cabinet, the plan has to get through Parliament to become law.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — In a country that has long been a rare bastion in Asia for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people, Thailand said on Wednesday that it had approved a draft bill that would give same-sex unions many of the same benefits as those of heterosexual marriages.

headline: Exclusive — Venture Fund for Women Raises More Than Expected
abstract: Rethink Impact invests solely in tech start-ups founded by women, which accounted for just 4 percent of all venture deals in the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: Want this delivered to your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: ‘Guest of Honour’ Review: Burying a Father, Unburying Secrets
abstract: Atom Egoyan indulges his obsessions in his newest drama, but the core revelations are pretty silly.
lead_paragraph: “Guest of Honour” provides new evidence in the perplexing case of Atom Egoyan, the gifted Canadian writer-director best known for “Exotica” (1995) and “The Sweet Hereafter” (which earned him two Oscar nominations in 1998) — both prismatic ruminations on unfathomable loss. In recent years, Egoyan has hit something of a rut, often directing others’ scripts and taking on material of questionable quality. (The latter would include “Remember,” from 2015, starring Christopher Plummer as a Nazi hunter with “Memento”-like recall lapses.)

headline: ‘Bloody Nose, Empty Pockets’ Review: Over Drinks, a Blurry Line Between Truth and Fiction
abstract: Bill and Turner Ross’s portrayal of a group of barflies tests the boundaries of documentary filmmaking.
lead_paragraph: Early in “Bloody Nose, Empty Pockets,” one of the barflies who populates the film talks about working as an actor. “I wanted the truth of every line,” he says. But when he realized that truth was elusive, he says, “I started going after beauty.”

headline: ‘Relic’ Review: A Haunted House and a Clouded Mind
abstract: Natalie Erika James’s arresting debut deftly merges a classic horror genre with an allegory of dementia.
lead_paragraph: The final image of the three generations of women who share the center of “Relic,” Natalie Erika James’s arresting horror debut, isn’t particularly scary. But it’s easily one of the most unsettling, ambiguous and unusual movie tableaus I’ve seen in some time.

headline: ‘Widow of Silence’ Review: Burden of Proof
abstract: Praveen Morchhale’s newest drama explores a Kashmiri woman’s desperate quest for freedom and agency.
lead_paragraph: “The government is very powerful,” a corrupt registrar (Ajay Chourey) tells Aasiya (Shilpi Marwaha) when she arrives for the umpteenth time to beg for a death certificate for her long-missing husband. To illustrate his point, the registrar will happily issue the certificate; all Aasiya has to do is sell him her land or lend him her body.

headline: ‘Never Too Late’ Review: The Vietnam Vet as Lovable Codger
abstract: Former soldiers known as “The Chain Breakers” take on a romantic mission involving nursing homes in this movie from Mark Lamprell.
lead_paragraph: While 1970s dramatic and genre cinema overindulged the insensitive “psychotic Vietnam vet” trope, there’s still time, if we petition studios or maybe just pray, to head off a slew of “lovable old codger Vietnam vet” movies. “Never Too Late,” an Australian production directed by Mark Lamprell, is a sometimes dire portent of what we might be in for if we don’t do something.

headline: ‘We Are Little Zombies’ Review: Rocking Away the Pain
abstract: Wry humor, absurd dialogue and unflagging energy propel this dazzling, manic debut from Makoto Nagahisa.
lead_paragraph: When four suddenly orphaned Japanese 13-year-olds meet at a crematory, they instantly connect over their shared inability to cry — and the likely commingled remains of their parents.

headline: ‘Olympia’ Review: When the Moon Hits a Documentarian’s Eye
abstract: In his fawning documentary about Olympia Dukakis, Harry Mavromichalis doesn’t distinguish the disarming from the banal.
lead_paragraph: Actors aren’t always as interesting as their performances. Whatever you think of Olympia Dukakis, she is not so splendid a raconteur that she can carry “Olympia,” a feature-length profile directed with grating obsequiousness by Harry Mavromichalis.

headline: ‘Tito’ Review: An Oddball Character Study
abstract: The filmmaker and actor Grace Glowicki steps into a gender-bending role in an experimental indie that muddles its moral lesson on sexual predation.
lead_paragraph: Looking like a cross between Crispin Glover and PJ Harvey, the perpetually hunched-over, often furrow-browed Tito skulks around in fear with a red emergency whistle around his neck. His employment and source of trauma both remain vague. The Canadian director-actor-writer Grace Glowicki plays the title role in her debut feature, gender-bending as a male character with sideburns and baggy clothes. Tito’s reclusive, reticent mannerisms probably would have been a bizarre protrusion during its festival run; now, they feel like universally recognizable quarantine behavior.

headline: ‘The Tobacconist’ Review: Playing Dress-Up in 1930s Vienna
abstract: A coming-of-age drama with attractive cinematography and production design, but no political or philosophical weight.
lead_paragraph: The coming-of-age costume drama “The Tobacconist” is set in Vienna during the rise of Nazism, leading up to the German occupation of Austria. But despite taking place during one of the most traumatic periods of modern civilization, the movie itself feels like little more than an amusing trifle, a chance to play dress up with some of history’s most famous figures.

headline: Once You’re Out of the Market, It’s Tricky Getting Back In
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Credit and Debt', 'Quarantines', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Money Market Accounts', 'Financial Planners', 'Mutual Funds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)']
abstract: Abandoning stocks when they are sinking may be tempting. But how and when will you get back on board?
lead_paragraph: The standard wisdom says investors should hang tough and ride out market declines. But a big plunge always drives plenty of people to the sidelines.

headline: Biden and Bernie, United (at Least Briefly)
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Democratic unity materializes in a long set of policy proposals: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Dems strike a deal on policy, Trump rejects the C.D.C. guidelines for schools, and SCOTUS gives the green light to religious groups refusing birth-control coverage. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: 6 Takeaways From the Biden-Sanders Joint Task Force Proposals
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Income Inequality', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Education (K-12)', 'Green New Deal', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Border Barriers', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Global Warming', 'Criminal Justice']
abstract: Signature progressive programs like “Medicare for all” and the Green New Deal did not make it into the recommendations. But Senator Bernie Sanders’s allies pushed some policies to the left.
lead_paragraph: The new policy recommendations for Joseph R. Biden Jr., crafted jointly by allies of Mr. Biden and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, are the clearest sign yet that the moderate and progressive wings of the Democratic Party are trying to unite far more than they did in 2016.

headline: Hedge Funds Duel in Bankruptcy Court Over McClatchy Newspapers
abstract: Alden Global Capital faced off against a pair of rivals trying to win the publisher of The Sacramento Bee and more than two dozen other papers.
lead_paragraph: A battle of the hedge funds is brewing in the bankruptcy auction of the McClatchy Company, one of the nation’s largest and most decorated newspaper chains, pitting Chatham Asset Management and Brigade Capital Management, both debt holders in the chain, against a newcomer to the proceedings, Alden Global Capital.

headline: Digital Dior. Remote Chanel. What’s Couture With No Runway?
abstract: The first streamed couture shows were more like mini-movies, music videos, trailers and perfume commercials. There were some clothes, too.
lead_paragraph: Is this a front row anyone really wants to join?

headline: Outdoor Dining Offers Fresh Air and Fantasy to a City That Needs Both
abstract: New York City’s sidewalks and streets have sprouted oases that evoke destinations from the Greek isles to the New Jersey Turnpike.
lead_paragraph: A new design genre was born last month when New York City began allowing restaurants, which had been closed for on-premises dining since March, to take over miles of sidewalks and streets for outdoor seating. Traditionally, the city’s sidewalk cafes tended to be dull to look at, crowded rows of tables hemmed in by plain metal railings. The new ones are more expressive. Governed by two emergency programs meant to let restaurants earn some money until indoor dining can resume, these structures follow a set of rules for keeping the public safe from the coronavirus and, when the seating is placed in parking spaces, from passing cars. Within and around these rules, however, creativity blossomed.

headline: How Berkeley Could Remove the Police From Traffic Stops
abstract: Thursday: The city’s proposal appears to be the first of its kind in the country. Also: A coronavirus update.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Shoppers Should Wear Masks. Shouldn’t Protesters, Too?
abstract: A reader believes there’s a “double standard” for cooperation with public safety measures.
lead_paragraph: I have a question that I hope you won’t take the wrong way. I am 72 years old and have been isolating for months. I take Covid-19 very seriously. But I’ve noticed a double standard about safety measures: People who refuse to wear face masks on principle, as a statement of their personal freedom, are shamed about it (often on the internet). But protesters in the Black Lives Matter movement seem to get a free pass on not wearing them. People get agitated when I bring this up. Am I wrong to?

headline: Review: ‘P-Valley’ Has All the Right Moves
abstract: Sex may sell this Starz strip-club drama, but at heart it’s a potent, lyrical story about hard work.
lead_paragraph: In the first episode of “P-Valley,” Mercedes (Brandee Evans), a dancer at the Pynk, a strip club somewhere in the Mississippi Delta, takes the stage for her headlining act. She struts, she swings, she grinds, she climbs the pole. The audience roars. Then it disappears.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Handblown glass, sparkly shoes, Scottish jewelry — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: At Home, With a Long List of Needed Repairs
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Interest Rates', 'Home Equity Loans']
abstract: How are people paying for the renovations that they can’t ignore any longer? Often, by borrowing.
lead_paragraph: While we’re stuck inside during the pandemic, it’s easy to find things that need improvement at home — from emergency repairs to ugly kitchens. So it’s little surprise that many Americans are taking on renovation projects. First quarter 2020 sales were up 7.1 percent at Home Depot and 11.2 percent at Lowe’s compared with the first quarter of 2019. Interest in our own articles about organizing, D.I.Y. renovation and interior design also attests to the trend.

abstract: This week’s properties are in Windsor Terrace, Hudson Heights and in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Windsor Terrace, Hudson Heights and in the East Village.

headline: Northern Right Whales Are on the Brink, and Trump Could Be Their Last Hope
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Lobsters', 'Whales and Whaling', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: The species was declared critically endangered on Thursday, with fewer than 450 left.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When boaters spotted a dead North Atlantic right whale off Elberon, N.J., on June 25, marine biologists quickly established the identity of the hulking gray carcass.

headline: A Melania Trump Statue Is Set on Fire. Its Patron Gets Inspired.
abstract: The American artist who commissioned the work near the first lady’s Slovenian hometown said he wanted to interview the arsonists. “There’s a lot of buzz around the destruction of monuments,” he noted.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After a wooden statue of Melania Trump was burned near her birthplace in Slovenia over the weekend, the American artist who commissioned it said that he now wants to interview the arsonist as part of a new project.

headline: ‘The Old Guard’ Review: Fighting to the Death, and Beyond
abstract: Charlize Theron leads a group of immortal warriors in Gina Prince-Bythewood’s fresh take on the superhero genre.
lead_paragraph: “The Old Guard” could just as well have been called “The New Blood,” since that’s what it tries to pump into the weary superhero genre, with a reasonable degree of success and quite a lot of, well, blood. With the familiar movie-studio franchises in lockdown, Netflix has the opportunity to introduce a new squad of specially empowered warriors, drawn from the pages of Greg Rucka’s graphic novel series, brought to life by the director Gina Prince-Bythewood and set loose against an evil tech-bro big pharma C.E.O. and his heavily armed minions.

headline: The Timely Agitation of Run the Jewels
abstract: Killer Mike and El-P’s anti-government and pro-justice hip-hop feels like it anticipated the current moment.
lead_paragraph: The racial justice protests that have spread across the United States (and the world) in recent weeks have had many soundtracks. But what’s striking about Run the Jewels’ music is how it can feel like it anticipated the current moment.

headline: James Harrison, Music Professor and Piano Lover, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Harrison was a longtime teacher of music theory and a dean of fine arts and humanities at Hunter College in Manhattan. He has died of complications of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Carl Reiner, Perfect
abstract: The director and funnyman taught Steve Martin about film and comedy, but it’s Reiner’s advice on a completely different subject that he cherishes.
lead_paragraph: I’ve known only two perfect people in my life. One is that son of a bitch Martin Short; the other is Carl Reiner.

headline: Exit Arias: What Opera Can Teach Us About Dying
abstract: In opera, death is an art — one that might light the way to a more mindful conversation about the end of life.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, I heard the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato sing the great final lament from Purcell’s “Dido and Aeneas” in Hamburg. Its text consists of just two sentences:

headline: The Dance on Camera Festival, When Dance Is Only on Camera
abstract: Many dance films of recent months have been films by necessity, but the ones in this festival are films by design, for better and worse.
lead_paragraph: “We’re all becoming filmmakers,” Annie-B Parson told me in May. She was speaking for her fellow choreographers, and in the months since, her generalization has proved prophetic. With theaters closed, dance companies and dance makers accustomed to stage performance have been rushing to channel their work into a form you can stream. Live dance is dormant, but filmed dance has been busting out all over.

headline: ‘Maybe I Shouldn’t Have Come’: U.S. Visa Changes Leave Students in Limbo
keywords: ['Foreign Students (in US)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Colleges and Universities', 'E-Learning', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Visas', 'International Study and Teaching']
abstract: The return to studying at an American institution has been thrown into question for an estimated one million international students.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Oliver Philcox was nearing the end of his first year of graduate studies in astrophysics at Princeton University when the coronavirus outbreak began. Classes were halted in March, and then moved online. By May, he had decided to travel home to Britain.

headline: NASA Scientist Jailed in Turkey for 3 Years Recounts His Ordeal
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Terrorism', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Turkish-Americans']
abstract: Finally home in Houston, Serkan Golge is still dismayed by the “garbage” evidence linking him to a failed coup and says the country is missing a chance to build its democracy.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — When Turkish police officers stopped him as he set out for the airport to return to the United States after a family vacation in Turkey, the country of his birth, Serkan Golge, a NASA scientist and American citizen, was in disbelief.

headline: Landmark Supreme Court Ruling Affirms Native American Rights in Oklahoma
abstract: A 5-4 decision declaring that much of eastern Oklahoma is an Indian reservation could reshape criminal justice in the area by preventing state authorities from prosecuting Native Americans.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that much of eastern Oklahoma falls within an Indian reservation, a decision that could reshape the criminal justice system by preventing state authorities from prosecuting offenses there that involve Native Americans.

headline: Supreme Court Rules Trump Cannot Block Release of Financial Records
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Trump Tax Returns', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Two rulings clear the way for prosecutors in New York to seek President Trump’s financial records, but the justices stopped Congress for now.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court cleared the way on Thursday for prosecutors in New York to seek President Trump’s financial records in a stunning defeat for Mr. Trump and a major statement on the scope and limits of presidential power.

headline: 2 Art Gallery Shows to Explore From Home
abstract: Galleries and museums are getting creative about presenting work online during the coronavirus crisis. Here are two shows worth viewing virtually.
lead_paragraph: Some of New York’s now-shuttered museum exhibitions — the Museum of Modern Art’s precise Donald Judd retrospective, the Whitney Museum of American Art’s grand survey of Mexican painting — will go back on view later this summer, but one of the best will not re-emerge. “Gerhard Richter: Painting After All,” the final exhibition at the Met Breuer, took years to organize and yet closed after just nine days; since the Metropolitan Museum of Art is now turning over the Breuer building to the Frick Collection, the German artist’s terse photo paintings and doubt-wracked abstractions are being crated up and shipped home.

headline: How the Coronavirus Has Changed Air Travel: A Visual Diary of a Flight
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'AIRPORTS', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Airport Security', 'Masks', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: In late June, a photographer flew from Seattle to Boston. This is a step-by-step visual account of the flight.
lead_paragraph: In late June, a photographer flew from Seattle to Boston. This is a step-by-step visual account of the flight.

headline: Redman, Mehldau, McBride and Blade Take Another Spin, 26 Years Later
abstract: A quartet of jazz all-stars returns with its players — and its philosophy — in a different phase of life.
lead_paragraph: When the saxophonist Joshua Redman released “MoodSwing” in 1994, his name was becoming synonymous with a kind of renewed purpose in jazz after a decade of Neo-Classicism: a drive to freshen, to expand, to nudge past the bounds of traditionalism while holding on to its code of standards. History was still the foundation, but it was no longer the main guide.

headline: N.Y.C. Paints ‘Black Lives Matter’ in Front of Trump Tower
keywords: ['Black Lives Matter Movement', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murals']
abstract: The public art project is the latest battle in a feud between President Trump and Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: New York City painted “Black Lives Matter” in large yellow letters on the street outside Trump Tower on Thursday, the latest flare-up in a yearslong feud between President Trump, who rose to fame as a Manhattan real estate developer, and Mayor Bill de Blasio, who once sought to replace him.

headline: First Woman Joins Green Berets After Graduating From Special Forces Training
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The soldier’s graduation is a landmark moment for the Army, as the Special Forces were one of the branch’s last assignments without any women.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A female National Guard soldier graduated from Army Special Forces training on Thursday and earned the title of Green Beret, the first woman to do so since the Pentagon opened all combat jobs, including those in the Special Operations community, to women in 2016.

headline: ‘Whac-a-Mole’ Against Virus Sounds Reasonable, Unless You’re the Mole
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantines', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: When the city of Leicester was shocked with a second lockdown, it lashed back with anger and recriminations.
lead_paragraph: LEICESTER, England — Fresh buttercream wastes away in an empty cake shop. Young men slip past the lockdown border to reopened pubs in nearby towns. And neighbors blame neighbors for a new outbreak of the coronavirus that has stalled their return to something resembling normal life.

headline: ‘Big Mess’ Looms if Schools Don’t Get Billions to Reopen Safely
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: As President Trump and others push to get students back in the classroom this fall, educators say they need more support and clearer guidelines.
lead_paragraph: Bus monitors to screen students for symptoms in Marietta, Ga.: $640,000. Protective gear and classroom cleaning equipment for a small district in rural Michigan: $100,000. Disinfecting school buildings and hiring extra nurses and educators in San Diego: $90 million.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: It’s probably no coincidence that the same subjects we’re taught to avoid in polite conversation — politics, religion, money — are so irresistible to read about. We’ll save religion for another time, but this week we invite you to think about money by way of Stefano Massini’s epic novel of the Lehman Brothers company, and about politics by way of the other books we recommend, from Robert M. Gates’s treatise on foreign policy to DW Gibson’s tour of President Trump’s border wall. We won’t even discourage you from discussing them, politely, when you’re done.

headline: Can Facebook Ever Stop the Drama?
abstract: How Facebook’s most recent crisis started, and what it says about the company’s role in our lives.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: 7 Things to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Music', 'Theater', 'Dancing', 'Jazz', 'Harry Potter (Fictional Character)', 'Classical Music', 'Children and Childhood', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: How can you get your cultural fix when many arts institutions remain closed? Our writers offer suggestions for what to listen to and watch.
lead_paragraph: Not even Harry Potter has a spell to defeat the coronavirus, but that boy wizard’s charms — the literary ones, at least — can often cure cabin fever. To enhance that power, Wizarding World Digital is presenting the free online hub Harry Potter at Home, which offers themed activities along with videos of celebrities reading aloud, chapter by chapter, the series’ first book, “Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone.” (The title in Britain uses the term “Philosopher’s Stone.”)

headline: A Swiss Dada Pioneer Finally Gets Her Spotlight
abstract: Sophie Taeuber-Arp did it all: Installations, textiles, costumes, abstract art. Nearly 80 years after her death, an online gallery show commemorates her talent (and a major museum exhibition is coming).
lead_paragraph: In 1937, the Swiss artist Sophie Taeuber-Arp wrote a letter to a friend, noting her exclusion from an avant-garde exhibition in Paris. While a male Belgian artist in her circle was refused entry too, “as a woman it is ten times harder to hold your position in this caldron.”

headline: ‘Palm Springs’ Review: Déjà Vu All Over Again
abstract: Andy Samberg and Cristin Milioti star in a fresh and funny comedy that might remind you of something you saw before.
lead_paragraph: Another wedding. The tight smiles of parents and stepparents. The awkward toasts and embarrassing dance-floor moves. The squabbles and hookups. The open bar. You’ve probably been to a hundred like it, if not in real life then at least in romantic comedies. In this one, called “Palm Springs,” we’re not here to pay attention to the bride and groom — their names are Tala and Abe, by the way, a fact you’ll be reminded of from time to time — but to observe two of the guests.

headline: These Scientists Raced to Find a Covid-19 Drug. Then the Virus Found Them.
abstract: This spring, researchers at Regeneron’s Westchester headquarters found themselves in one of the country’s first coronavirus hot spots.
lead_paragraph: In January, as a frightening new virus filled hospital wards in Wuhan, China, Stephanie Giordano, a 25-year-old researcher at the drugmaker Regeneron, in a suburb of New York City, began working on a treatment for the disease.

headline: Top Manhattan Prosecutor Ousted by Trump Details Firing
keywords: ['United States Attorneys', 'Attorneys General', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Geoffrey S. Berman told House investigators about a tense meeting in a luxury hotel room in which Attorney General William P. Barr pressured him to resign and he refused.
lead_paragraph: Geoffrey S. Berman, whom President Trump abruptly dismissed last month as the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, told lawmakers on Thursday that Attorney General William P. Barr tried unsuccessfully to pressure him to resign voluntarily, warning that being fired could ruin his career.

headline: How Does Anything Go Viral?
abstract: In “The Rules of Contagion” the scientist Adam Kucharski turns to the nonbiological to understand the common features of a virus, whether physical or virtual.
lead_paragraph: THE RULES OF CONTAGIONWhy Things Spread — and Why They StopBy Adam Kucharski

headline: Sur La Table joins a growing list of bankrupt retailers.
abstract: Sur La Table, the upscale cookware company, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Wednesday, dealing another blow to brick-and-mortar retail. The company has started liquidating 51 of its 121 U.S. stores, according to court filings, which it said were in shopping centers and traditional shopping malls or as stand-alone storefronts.
lead_paragraph: Sur La Table, the upscale cookware company, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Wednesday, dealing another blow to brick-and-mortar retail. The company has started liquidating 51 of its 121 U.S. stores, according to court filings, which it said were in shopping centers and traditional shopping malls or as stand-alone storefronts.

headline: 5 Arrested in Connection With Pop Smoke Killing
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The Los Angeles Police Department said it had taken three adult men and two minors into custody on Thursday, following the February shooting of the rising rap star in the Hollywood Hills.
lead_paragraph: Five people, including three adult men and two minors, were arrested early Thursday in connection with the February killing of Pop Smoke, a rising New York rapper, the Los Angeles Police Department announced.

headline: Ziwe Fumudoh Asks: ‘How Many Black People Do You Know?’
abstract: The comedian performs a kind of racial high wire act on her Instagram Live show, but she really just wants to heal.
lead_paragraph: How many Black friends do you have? Is it “between four and five?” If so, then you have something in common with several guests on Ziwe Fumudoh’s Instagram Live show.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: July 2020
abstract: At least 282 pro-government forces and 109 civilians were killed in Afghanistan the past month.
lead_paragraph: At least 28 pro-government forces and 26 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week. An additional 15 people were killed in Logar on July 30 after a car bomb exploded near the Ghazi roundabout in Pul-e-Alam, the provincial capital, though officials did not have a breakdown of military and civilian casualties. An additional 30 people were wounded in that attack. In Ghor Province, where the Taliban attacked security outposts in the village of Kharestan in Firoz Koh, the provincial capital, killing four commandos and wounding seven security forces, including four soldiers and three members of the National Directorate of Security. Three soldiers were taken prisoner by insurgents after the attack and two Humvees were seized. One day earlier, in Baghlan Province, a minibus hit a roadside bomb in the Chashma-e-Shir area of Pul-i-Kumri, the provincial capital, killing four civilians and wounding another.

headline: It Looks Like a Reality Show. Why Not Just Make It One?
abstract: The drama among influencers at Hype House and Sway House seems like a natural fit for TV. Will the industry bite?
lead_paragraph: Late Monday night, a group of male TikTok stars who belong to the Gen Z influencer collective known as the Sway House charged up the streets of the Hollywood Hills. They were on their way to the Hype House to confront a fellow TikTok star, Chase Hudson, 18, about comments he had made earlier online.

headline: ‘I Just Cost Myself 250 Grand.’
abstract: Missing a short putt worth hundreds of thousands of dollars is a golfer’s nightmare, but PGA Tour veterans have ways of psyching themselves up to try anyway.
lead_paragraph: On the final green of virtually every PGA Tour event, a golfer will stand over a routine short putt worth between $200,000 and $500,000. It might take one second for the ball to roll toward the hole, but if the result is a costly four-foot miss, it usually takes another minute for the enormity of the loss to sink in.

headline: How Coronavirus Cases Have Risen Since States Reopened
abstract: Reported cases are rising fast in many states that opened early, while those that stayed shut down longer are largely seeing declines.
lead_paragraph: Reported cases are rising fast in many states that opened early, while those that stayed shut down longer are largely seeing declines.

headline: This Ancient Sea Creature Builds Its Body With a Whisper, Not a Scream
keywords: ['Reproduction (Biological)', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'ANIMALS', 'Research', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: Unlike vertebrate embryo cells, which signal to each other over long distances, sea squirt embryo cells talk only to those they’re closest to.
lead_paragraph: Building a body from scratch is a daunting task, one that requires careful coordination among all those involved. That’s why nature’s starting stuff — cells — have learned to be remarkably chatty to get the job done right.

headline: How André Holland and Company Brought ‘Richard II’ to Radio
abstract: What was meant to have opened Shakespeare in the Park’s season has found new life as a four-part audio play with resonance in the wake of Black Lives Matter.
lead_paragraph: On the list of questions you’ve probably never considered is how to describe what spitting sounds like.

headline: Don’t Be Fooled, Trump Is a Winner in the Supreme Court Tax Case
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Subpoenas', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: His taxes will probably not become public before the election. And that is what he most cares about.
lead_paragraph: The first reports on Thursday’s Supreme Court decisions dealing with the subpoenas for President Trump’s financial records sounded like bad news for the president in his effort to keep them hidden. But don’t be fooled. There were actually two winners, and you wouldn’t know that from the headlines: the president and Chief Justice John Roberts.

headline: Review: Covid Responders Have Their Harrowing Say in ‘The Line’
abstract: A documentary play based on interviews with New York doctors, nurses and paramedics underlines the inequities of a medical system “flawed from its root.”
lead_paragraph: In his many years as a paramedic, Ed (Jamey Sheridan) has delivered emergency care to soldiers and citizens in Kashmir, Haiti, Afghanistan and Iraq. At a makeshift hospital 250 yards from the front line in Mosul, as sniper fire flew through the blown-out windows, he and his team made curtains out of body bags.

headline: Michael Cohen Returned to Jail in Dispute Over Trump Book
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Quarantines', 'Books and Literature', 'Probation and Parole', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: President Trump’s former personal lawyer balked at signing an agreement not to publish a book while serving his sentence at home, his legal adviser said.
lead_paragraph: Michael D. Cohen, President Trump’s onetime lawyer and fixer, was in good spirits on Thursday when he arrived at a Manhattan federal courthouse, where he expected to complete routine paperwork related to his home confinement amid the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Is Sex Dead for Parents?
abstract: Finding the time and energy for intimacy was hard enough pre-pandemic; now wanting to be closer to someone feels almost impossible.
lead_paragraph: While in domestic confinement, the most comforting thing I can say to my female friends, near and far, is not “This too shall pass.” Nor is it “We can do hard things.” It is my own pearl of wisdom, and it goes something like this: “Don’t worry, no one actually wants to have sex with their husband.”

headline: The Supreme Court’s Decision on Releasing Trump’s Records
abstract: Readers discuss who should claim victory and the significance of the ruling in the short and long term.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In a Death, Details of More Russian Murder-for-Hire Plots
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Informers', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: A Chechen man shot near Vienna last weekend had spoken publicly of giving Austrian and Ukrainian authorities information about contract killings. He also said there was a price on his head.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Earlier this year, a heavyset man living in Vienna and known as Martin Beck said during a TV interview that he was assisting an investigation of a complicated murder-for-hire plot, in which three people were to be killed in exchange for $2 million.

headline: The Coronavirus Can Be Airborne Indoors, W.H.O. Says
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'your-feed-science', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: The agency also explained more directly that people without symptoms may spread the virus. The acknowledgments should have come sooner, some experts said.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus may linger in the air in crowded indoor spaces, spreading from one person to the next, the World Health Organization acknowledged on Thursday.

headline: India’s Outbreak, Seoul Mayor, Short Stories: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Melania Trump Statue Removed After Being Set on Fire
abstract: A structure made of wood resembling Melania Trump was set on fire near her hometown in Slovenia last weekend.

headline: Milley Calls for ‘Hard Look’ at Renaming Bases Honoring Confederates
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Names, Organizational', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a House hearing that “there is no place in our armed forces for manifestations or symbols of racism, bias or discrimination.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top military official in the United States called on Thursday for taking “a hard look” at changing the names of Army bases honoring Confederate officers who had fought against the Union during the Civil War, disagreeing with President Trump and further exposing a divide between the military and the president.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Politics and Government', 'Republican National Convention', 'Campaign Finance']

headline: NOAA Officials Feared Firings After Trump’s Hurricane Claims, Inspector General Says
abstract: The report found White House pressure led to NOAA’s rebuke of forecasters who contradicted Mr. Trump’s inaccurate claim that Hurricane Dorian would hit Alabama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration felt that his job and the jobs of others would be in jeopardy if the agency did not rebuke forecasters who contradicted President Trump’s inaccurate claim last year about the path of Hurricane Dorian, a government report found.

headline: Drug Giants Create Fund to Bolster Struggling Antibiotic Start-Ups
abstract: New medicines are desperately needed to treat a growing number of drug-resistant infections, but many companies developing the drugs are short on cash and investments.
lead_paragraph: Twenty of the world’s largest pharmaceutical companies on Thursday announced the creation of a $1 billion fund to buoy financially strapped biotech start-ups that are developing new antibiotics to treat the mounting number of drug-resistant infections responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths each year.

headline: A Coffee Chain Reveals Flaws in the Fed’s Plan to Save Main Street
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: Businesses that want to use the Federal Reserve’s Main Street program cannot, and many that can use it have better options in the private market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — La Colombe, a Philadelphia-based purveyor of fancy coffee and canned draft lattes, has seen its business fall off sharply in 2020 as the coronavirus pandemic shuttered its cafes and closed the upscale restaurants that serve its brew. But the company has fallen through the cracks when it comes to government relief.

headline: With Stores Closed, Barnes & Noble Does Some Redecorating
abstract: Retail locations shuttered during lockdowns, so the company spruced up hundreds of its stores as the first step in a bigger plan.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Barnes & Noble, James Daunt, who took over last summer, thought the company’s stores were badly in need of some sprucing up. His plan, over the next two years or so, was to close locations on a rotating basis for a few weeks at a time to refurnish and refurbish.
