headline: My Favorite Summer Blockbuster
abstract: Popcorn movies are among the many pleasures of the season. Since we can’t go to the movies, we asked six critics to bring the hits to us.
lead_paragraph: There’s a kind of movie where not even five minutes have passed yet you know you’re in love. I had just started seriously dating somebody and by the time “Wall-E” was over, I contemplated opening up the relationship. The movies tend to overdo the end of the world. The demise matters less than the resulting spectacle or mounting suspense. And the aftermath is always a dirge. But certain filmmakers have a knack for the womp and cadence of doom. The “Mad Max” movies, for instance, turned apocalypse into heavy metal. “Wall-E” turns catastrophe into waltz.

headline: Occupy City Hall Struggles as Homeless Move In
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: Organizers said they were helping vulnerable people. But nearby residents said the camp had turned into an unruly — and at times violent — shantytown.
lead_paragraph: When it first kicked off last month, the activist encampment that billed itself as Occupy City Hall was viewed as the latest wave of the city’s George Floyd protests — an innovative political space that, under summer skies, attracted peaceful crowds to speeches and teach-ins focused on a narrow goal: cutting $1 billion from the New York Police Department’s budget.

headline: Big Ten Will Play Fall Sports Only Within Conference, if at All
abstract: The league’s football teams had been scheduled to participate in some of the most highly anticipated nonconference games of the 2020 season.
lead_paragraph: The Big Ten Conference’s fall sports teams will play only within the league, a decision that will affect football, men’s and women’s cross country, field hockey, men’s and women’s soccer, and women’s volleyball — assuming public health officials advise playing at all amid the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Ola Mae Spinks, Who Helped Preserve a Slave Archive, Dies at 106
abstract: In 1972, she and another librarian went to the Library of Congress to bring order to a sprawling collection of interviews with former slaves.
lead_paragraph: Ola Mae Spinks, a librarian and descendant of slaves who went to the Library of Congress in 1972 to bring order to a vast but scattered archive of interviews with former slaves, thus helping to preserve them for scholars, died on June 16 at her home in Southfield, Mich. She was 106.

headline: Like ‘a Bus Accident a Day’: Hospitals Strain Under New Flood of Covid-19 Patients
abstract: I.C.U. units are reaching capacity. Nurses are falling sick, contributing to shortages. The new coronavirus spikes are challenging hospitals across the United States.

headline: Conservatives, Don’t Give Up on Your Principles or the Supreme Court
abstract: Some are turning away from a founding idea, originalism.
lead_paragraph: For decades, originalists — many of them conservatives — have argued that courts should interpret the Constitution and other law in keeping with its original meaning. And their views have gained power. Both of President Trump’s appointments to the Supreme Court — Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh — have described themselves as originalists, leading many to hope or fear that they would form a conservative majority with Chief Justice John Roberts, Justice Clarence Thomas and Justice Samuel Alito.

headline: Judge in Michael Flynn Case Asks for Full Appeals Court Review

Flynn asked a full appeals court on Thursday to review an order by a panel of its judges to end the prosecution, saying their ruling marked “a dramatic break from precedent that threatens the orderly administration of justice.”

headline: Macron Drops Idea of a Modern Spire for Notre-Dame
abstract: The French president had floated the idea of replacing the fire-ravaged cathedral’s 19th-century spire with a “contemporary architectural gesture.” Few were in favor.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Thursday dropped the unpopular idea of building a modern spire atop a restored Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris, a possibility he had floated after a devastating fire sent the previous spire crashing through the roof.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: There are signs the death rate, which had stayed relatively low during the current surge, is starting to climb.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus is reaching terrifying new levels in the United States. The country set another record for new coronavirus cases yesterday, with more than 59,400 infections — the fifth such record in nine days. As of Tuesday, the U.S. had recorded more than three million cases in total.

headline: Corrections: July 10, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 10, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about corporate lobbying in Washington misstated the timing of a meeting between Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and the chief executive of the arms maker Raytheon. David Urban, a lobbyist close to Mr. Pompeo and President Trump, requested the meeting more than two weeks before Mr. Pompeo issued an emergency waiver in May 2019 allowing Raytheon to proceed with arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, but according to the State Department the meeting took place in June, after the waiver was issued, not a few months before.

headline: A Glimpse Into My Son’s Magnificent Mind
abstract: Our house is a mess of misplaced possessions. I’m grateful for what this — and my son’s autism — has taught me.
lead_paragraph: A tiny white heart marks a five-second video on my phone as beloved, one in which my boy (age 6 at the time) proudly displays a pale pink cross-body purse. He twists his torso as he flirts with the camera, asking, “Hey girl, do you like my new purrrrrrse?”

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Expecting Amy’ and ‘Palm Springs’
abstract: A new documentary series follows Amy Schumer during a busy pregnancy. And a weird romantic comedy hits Hulu.
lead_paragraph: EXPECTING AMY Stream on HBO Max. In March of last year, the comedian Amy Schumer released a stand-up special, “Growing,” that was filmed while Schumer was pregnant. Making it, Schumer said, was the most difficult challenge of her career. “I’m ecstatic and furious,” she told The New York Times shortly before the special’s release. “And pleased and peaceful and manic and hopeless and so hopeful it’s crazy.” So viewers can expect both highs and lows in this new, three-part documentary, which follows Schumer during her pregnancy. “Expecting Amy” is woven together primarily from cellphone video footage (Alexander Hammer, who worked on Beyoncé’s “Homecoming,” is the director and editor), which adds to the intimacy.

headline: Fear and Loathing on the Bosporus
abstract: Turkish soccer, hobbled by fallen giants and rife with conspiracy theories, can no longer match Europe’s powerhouses. Fixing its problems will require the one trait no one seems to have.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The fury drew them in their hundreds to the doors of the Ulker Stadium. They pressed up against the barricades, climbed onto each other’s shoulders and chanted for change: for the manager to be fired, for the owner to step aside, for the players to be chased out of town.

headline: Dispatch from a Locked-Down Melbourne
abstract: The mood in Melbourne among family and friends and strangers on the internet is defeated and dark.
lead_paragraph: Melbourne winters are notoriously depressing. The days are short and often gray, the rain is cold and persistent. For those of us who live here, coping mechanisms are important. We sit in front of blazing fireplaces at neighborhood pubs, we take trips to the countryside or plan our annual holidays abroad during these long dark months. We gather for family dinners and make sure our exercise routines are uninterrupted.

Courtney Sullivan, cautioned, winking at the elitism of “gifted and talented,” it’s ultimately “an incisive inspection of privilege, race and class,” and its takeaway is “damning.”

headline: Stayin’ Alive: How Disco Saved Daddy
keywords: ['Defibrillators', 'Heart', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: He hated the Bee Gees, couldn’t stand platform shoes, and deplored the only pair of polyester pants he’d ever owned.
lead_paragraph: After he and Mom divorced, Dad went out some weekends with a group from church. The group, made up entirely of divorced people, was called “Singles Again,” an unfortunate name for a collection of people whose failed marriages had already caused them enough trauma. The church might as well have gone all-out “Scarlet Letter” and pinned D’s for divorced to all the Singles Again group members’ shirts and jacket lapels.

headline: Meet the Heroes Fighting on the Front Lines Against Covid-19

headline: Yeah, Let’s Not Talk About Race
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Whites', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: Unless you pay me.
lead_paragraph: To fill the void created by not being able to play basketball for months, I’ve cobbled together a daily workout. I jump rope, I do some light weight lifting, I think real long and hard about doing some push-ups, and I take walks around my neighborhood. It’s a grid and it’s relatively flat, so it’s an easy walk. I follow a path that takes me up and down each street until I’ve reached 10,000 steps, the arbitrary point where I feel accomplished enough to give myself permission to eat an ice cream bar.

headline: Awkward Timing, but the Financial Ideas Are Still Sound

headline: ‘It Was Like a Time Bomb’: How ICE Helped Spread the Coronavirus
abstract: An investigation by The New York Times and The Marshall Project reveals how Immigration and Customs Enforcement became a spreader of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Admild, an undocumented immigrant from Haiti, was feeling sick as he approached the deportation plane that was going to take him back to the country he had fled in fear. Two weeks before that day in May, while being held at an Immigration and Customs Enforcement detention facility in Louisiana, he had tested positive for the coronavirus — and he was still showing symptoms.

headline: I’m 10 Minutes Away From Becoming a U.S. Citizen
abstract: But U.S.C.I.S. is sitting on a growing backlog of would-be citizens like me.
lead_paragraph: Ten minutes and an oath. That’s all that stands between me and American citizenship. After filling out a 20-page application, paying almost a thousand dollars, organizing piles of supporting documents, planning my life around five years of residency requirements and waiting another two — as well as F.B.I. background checks, InfoPass appointments and a civics test — 10 minutes and the recitation of 140 words is all I need.

headline: Trump Would Like to See You Now
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Why does the president want to open everything up? It’s not because it’s safe to do so.
lead_paragraph: Back in March, when Congress was debating pandemic relief, Senator Rick Scott of Florida spoke out against a Democratic plan to greatly expand federal unemployment insurance. “The moment we can go back to work, we cannot create an incentive for people to say ‘I don’t need to come back to work because I can do better some place else,’ ” Scott said at a news conference in support of an amendment that would strike the program from the bill. “These employers are going to need these workers to rebuild this economy, so we cannot pay people more money on unemployment than what they would get in their jobs.”

headline: Why Is a Tech Executive Installing Security Cameras Around San Francisco?
keywords: ['Cameras', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Privacy', 'Police Reform', 'Police', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Facial Recognition Software', 'Virtual Currency']

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It sounds sinister. A soft-spoken cryptocurrency mogul is paying for a private network of high-definition security cameras around the city. Zoom in and you can see the finest details: the sticker on a cellphone, the make of a backpack, the color of someone’s eyes.

headline: Think You’ve Seen the Subway? Not Like This You Haven’t
abstract: Patrick Cashin spent two decades as the official M.T.A. photographer. From the bridges to the tunnels, he showed us some of his most stunning images.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Cashin has climbed the steep cables to the top of the Throgs Neck Bridge, where peregrine falcons circled above. The birds were a bonus. He was there to photograph electricians working on one of the towers as the staff photographer for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which operates the bridges, tunnels and transit system for New York City and several surrounding counties.

headline: What Happens When You’re Disabled but Nobody Can Tell
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Autism', 'Discrimination', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT']
abstract: The author and clinical psychologist Andrew Solomon examines the disabilities that ramps and designated parking spots don’t address.
lead_paragraph: I have depression and anxiety. These conditions are well-controlled most of the time, but when I have a significant dip, no one makes anything easier for me unless I explain it all to them — an unpleasant effort at the best of times and beyond my ken at the worst. When my depression mushrooms, I shun visibility; I walk so close to buildings that my shoulder becomes dirty. Because my intermittent disability is invisible, in the thick of it I have often felt compelled to make myself invisible. I neither anticipate nor receive public compassion.

headline: The Last Reporter in Town Had One Big Question for His Rich Boss
abstract: His newspaper has withered under a hedge fund. His industry was in turmoil even before a pandemic. But Evan Brandt won’t stop chronicling his town.
lead_paragraph: POTTSTOWN, Pa. — An essential worker drove his cluttered Toyota Corolla through the early spring emptiness, past a sign outside a closed parochial school asking people to pray. Time to bear witness in a pandemic.

headline: They Passed the Long-Distance Test
abstract: Dr. Erika Alejandro Crespo Martínez and Victor Gabriel Santiago Hernandez built a relationship on patience and pacing. Then the coronavirus came and they had to act quickly.
lead_paragraph: The Zoom wedding of Victor Gabriel Santiago Hernandez and Dr. Erika Alejandro Crespo Martínez, held on June 27 in their West Harlem studio apartment, was beamed to more than 75 households across Puerto Rico and planned in less than a month. It was the result of a question each had asked the other when New York City was in lockdown and chances of catching the coronavirus seemed higher than average: Why waste time?

headline: How the Creator of Domino Park’s Social Distancing Circles Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mike Lampariello, director of the park, slathers on sunscreen and makes his masked rounds.
lead_paragraph: In Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Domino Park’s 30 or so white social distancing circles on artificial grass quickly became a go-to visual for describing the city mid-pandemic. They are the brainchild of Mike Lampariello, the park’s director.

headline: In South Africa, Burial Traditions Upended by Coronavirus
abstract: Restrictions on travel have disrupted a deeply important cultural practice for many Black residents in Cape Town: returning the body for burial hundreds of miles home in the Eastern Cape province.
lead_paragraph: KHAYELITSHA, South Africa — In ordinary times, there would have been no question where Zinzile Mweli would be buried: alongside his ancestors in the village where he was born.

headline: An Unexpected Struggle for Trump: Defining an Elusive Biden
abstract: With only six weeks to the Republican National Convention, President Trump has yet to find a framework for attacking his opponent.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Biden vs. Trump 2020 election coverage.]

headline: Riots Long Ago, Luxury Living Today
keywords: ['Gentrification', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: High-end development has transformed some Black neighborhoods decades after they were scarred by unrest. And not by coincidence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the corner of 14th and U Streets Northwest, where the anger first simmered in what became Washington’s devastating 1968 riots, the going rent for a one-bedroom today is about $2,500 a month. That sum buys concierge services, rooftop terrace access and proximity to any number of niche fitness studios.

headline: David Mitchell Brings His Novelistic High Jinks to the Swinging ’60s
abstract: “Utopia Avenue,” by the British master of intricate literary puzzles, features a band on the make, lots of inside jokes and references to the author’s previous works.
lead_paragraph: In a psychedelic moment toward the end of David Mitchell’s new novel, “Utopia Avenue,” which is about the birth, rise and demise of a British rock band in the 1960s, the long and lurid family history of one of the band members — a preternaturally talented, half-British, half-Dutch guitarist named Jasper de Zoet — unspools, filmlike, before his astonished eyes, all the way back to the late 18th century; as it does so, another character murmurs that “the chain of events would fill a hefty novel.” Indeed. We see Jasper’s boarding school days in the 1950s melting into his infancy; his father’s wedding in the 1930s segueing into the elder de Zoet’s childhood adventures with a kite; scenes from the Boer War (“a bloody, stupid mess”) dissolving into images of horse-drawn carriages; then colonial plantations in Java, Dutch East India Company ships sailing into Japanese waters; finally a trading post, a monastery, a room filled with corpses. Nagasaki, 1800.

abstract: Early hopes for a quick rebound from the pandemic have yielded to worries about its long-term impact on state finances and the governor’s ambitious agenda.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — When California shut down its economy in March, it became a model for painful but aggressive action to counter the new coronavirus. The implicit trade-off was that a lot of upfront pain would help slow the spread, allowing the state to reopen sooner and more triumphantly than places that failed to act as decisively.

abstract: And by the way, it’s “suffragist” not “suffragette.”
lead_paragraph: As the story is often told, the path to women’s suffrage began ​in Seneca Falls, N.Y.,​ in 1848 and ended with the ratification of the 19th Amendment in 1920. Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton​ were the leaders of the movement. It granted all women in America the right to vote.

headline: Newark Artists, Thriving Amid Crisis and Catharsis
abstract: Laid low by the coronavirus crisis, the city’s artists were then raised on the energy of protests. They have been on the front lines all the while.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — This city prides itself on its resilience, and its artists share in that spirit. Ever since the coronavirus arrived, Newark’s creative community has been on the front lines, responding to the crisis and, now, the catharsis.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: This weekend, get into a cooking project like buttermilk banana pudding or beef empanadas.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. If I could, I’d load up my vehicle and drive to Southern California right now, sleep in the truck bed in national parks and Walmart parking lots along the way, cook on a camp fire or a little propane stove, take some hikes, make an adventure out of it, give the children something to remember from this summer that isn’t masks, boredom and “Avatar: The Last Airbender.”

headline: ‘I’m Sorry to Everyone’: In Death, South Korean Mayor Is Tainted by Scandal
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Sexual Harassment', '#MeToo Movement', "Women's Rights", 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']

headline: The Best Drinks in Life Are Frozen
keywords: ['Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Ice', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: Slushy, boozy cocktails are perfect year-round. You may not even need to pull out a blender.
lead_paragraph: While evocations of sun, sand and rosé don’t hurt — hey, wear a mask out there — not all icy beverages require heat waves or pink wine. Drink good, well-made frozen drinks because they’re good, and well made. And sure, drink them barefoot in the summer grass, but also boot-clad in winter, or any other time that you’d drink an ice-cold martini or a shaken margarita.

headline: Americans Must Know if Their President Is a Crook
keywords: ['Trump Tax Returns', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The public’s interest in access to Donald Trump’s or any president’s tax filings depends on strong reform legislation from Congress.
lead_paragraph: When Richard Nixon declared, “People have got to know whether or not their president is a crook,” we often forget that he wasn’t talking about Watergate. He was speaking about compliance with tax law. The public had a “right to know,” in this case, what was in his returns and if he had followed the law.

headline: KFC Birthday Party Costs $18,000 in Covid-19 Fines in Australia
abstract: “That’s a heck of a birthday party to recall,” said Chief Commissioner Shane Patton of the Victoria police. Officers were led to a house where they found people hiding in the backyard, garage and under beds.
lead_paragraph: A large takeout order from a KFC in Australia led the police to more than a dozen people hiding at a house party and more than 26,000 Australian dollars in Covid-19 fines, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Debating ‘Hamilton’ as It Shifts From Stage to Screen
abstract: Five critics wade into the controversies (like its treatment of slavery) and examine the performances (especially Lin-Manuel Miranda’s) five years after the show debuted.
lead_paragraph: “Hamilton,” Lin-Manuel Miranda’s revisionist take on our founding fathers, was the subject of conversation, debate and argument at The Times when the musical premiered Off Broadway in 2015 and again when it moved to Broadway. Why should the filmed version, which started streaming on Disney+ over the Fourth of July holiday weekend, be any different? I asked the critics at large Wesley Morris and A.O. Scott, the co-chief theater critic Jesse Green, the chief pop music critic Jon Pareles and the arts critic fellow Maya Phillips to discuss the show in changing contexts: onscreen not onstage, and as protests over racism and police reform are forcing the country to face up to its history. Here are excerpts from their round table.

The trove of medieval religious art was sold just before the stock market crash in 1929, sent to the United States and back, then split up and sold. All 82 pieces have changed hands at least twice.

Sipping coffee and surveying plexiglass dividers, Ms. Sturgeon, the leader of Scotland’s government, warned customers not to expect the jolly, sweaty intimacy of nightlife before the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: When ‘Keep Your Distance’ Has Been a Way of Life
keywords: ['Graphic Novels', 'Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Quarantine life puts a son’s relationship with his mother into a new light.
lead_paragraph: Long before the pandemic, I’d been distancing myself from one person in particular: my mother. Our relationship has always been distant. She was in prison for most of my childhood. Every graduation, most birthdays and holidays — she is not in the photos. Even when she was not locked up, she was struggling with addiction and mental health, and she kept her distance. My brother and I were fortunate to have a grandmother who was our caregiver and our foundation.

But apparently the “Anglos” who prevented Mexican families from becoming foster parents in 1904 Arizona never got the telegram about charity and kindness. To nobody’s surprise, racism and bigotry drove the dispute, which ended up in court.

headline: Inside an Eclectic Retreat on Shelter Island
abstract: Jonathan Adler and Simon Doonan’s art- and design-filled summer home is a place for both creativity and downtime.
lead_paragraph: Shelter Island, N.Y., a sylvan splash of land positioned between the tines of Long Island’s North and South Forks, is only a 10-minute ferry ride from Sag Harbor and the rest of the Hamptons. And yet, with its weather-beaten clapboard houses and unmanicured lawns — and its lack of tony boîtes and traffic lights — it feels much farther away. The potter and designer Jonathan Adler and the author and fashion commentator Simon Doonan have been visiting the island since they met 25 years ago, and it’s here, on the northern shore, that they built their summer house in 2011.

Jamieson, M.D., a member of the Covid-19 task force at the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and chairwoman of gynecology and obstetrics at the Emory University School of Medicine, noted in an email that it was “remarkable” how much we still do not know about Covid-19 in pregnancy.

keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Small Business', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']

headline: From Catherine Opie, a Visual Diary of the Recent Past
abstract: The celebrated photographer shares her snapshots of a time of togetherness.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Catherine Opie has always been interested in the subversively domestic. In one of her best-known early works, “Self-Portrait/Cutting” (1993), her naked back is carved with a still-bleeding childlike drawing of a home, two women stick-figures in the foreground. That image, now in the Guggenheim’s permanent collection, nods to the queer B.D.S.M. scene in which Opie found community in the ’90s, while capturing the painful longing she felt for a family of her own. Queer domesticity was a radical thing to envision at the time, but three decades later, the pandemic has confined Opie to the Los Angeles home she now shares with her wife, Julie Burleigh, and their 18-year-old son, Oliver. Their daughter, Sara, whom Julie had when she was young, and their 6-year-old grandson, Joaquin, visit often, though for the first few months of quarantine, even that was off-limits. The house has art scattered across the mantles and climbing up to the high ceilings, some of it from famous friends, and some, like the children’s drawings on the fridge, simply a reminder that once it arrives, family grows as unwieldy and resilient as the 90-year-old Aleppo pine tree in the yard.

headline: ‘Ghislaine Maxwell Is Not Jeffrey Epstein’: Maxwell Asks for Release

If you were supposed to be getting down on the dance floor at a wedding this summer, why not blast these D.J.s’ classics and dance around your home instead? And as we face months without blockbuster movie releases, watch some of our critics’ favorites from summers gone by. Whatever you end up doing, make time for some amazing journalism.

headline: Martha Rocha, 87, Dies; to Brazil, a Beauty Queen Denied a Crown

She was 87.

lead_paragraph: If you are enjoying this newsletter every Friday, we’re glad. Now please pass it on to a friend (or four or five) and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.

headline: Big New Obstacle for Economic Recovery: Child Care Crisis
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'Child Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Organized Labor', 'Parenting', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The decision to only reopen New York City’s public schools part time in September illustrates the looming threat to businesses.
lead_paragraph: When New York City decided to reopen its school system, the nation’s largest, on a part-time basis in September, it set off a new child care crisis that could seriously threaten its ability to restart the local economy and recover from the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: A Novel About 3 Generations of Cherokee Women (and No-Good Men)
abstract: “Crooked Hallelujah,” by Kelli Jo Ford, spans decades and follows hardscrabble lives in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: CROOKED HALLELUJAHBy Kelli Jo Ford

headline: Murder, Murder, Everywhere
abstract: In Marilyn Stasio’s new column, the bodies pile up so fast it’s hard to keep count.
lead_paragraph: Male authors love to send their male heroes on the road. Any excuse will do, from a gathering of crime clans to a rowdy biker rally. (For my money, “32 Cadillacs,” by Joe Gores, tops the chart on these screwball road-trip crime novels.) Female authors, not so much. Which brings us to DON’T TURN AROUND (HarperCollins, 320 pp., $27.99), a hair-raising entry in this subgenre by the pseudonymous Jessica Barry.

headline: Herman Benson, Who Fought Union Corruption, Dies at 104
abstract: A machinist and Socialist from the Bronx, he pushed trade unions to be more democratic and to depose crooked labor leaders.
lead_paragraph: Herman Benson, a former machinist who crusaded against corrupt labor leaders and introduced democratic reforms to entrenched trade unions, sometimes overcoming the resistance of fellow unionists, died on July 2 at his home in Brooklyn, a week shy of his 105th birthday.

headline: Theater Artists of Color Enumerate Demands for Change
abstract: A 29-page document released this week amounts to a call for wholesale restructuring of the system, onstage and backstage, on Broadway and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Rename half of all Broadway theaters. Impose term limits for theater industry leaders. Require that at least half the members of casts and creative teams be made up of people of color.

headline: A Rescue Plan for the Planet? Watch Our Debate Here.
abstract: A virtual event with eight speakers and one question: Has Covid-19 created a blueprint for combating climate change?
lead_paragraph: The devastation of Covid-19 has forced swift and startling change around the globe. To combat the coronavirus, governments poured money into rescue programs, companies adapted their goals and production, central banks permitted exceptional stimulus packages and many societies mobilized to shield the most vulnerable.

headline: Facebook Said to Consider Banning Political Ads
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Online Advertising', 'Hate Speech', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Social Media', 'Corporate Social Responsibility']
abstract: The social network has been under intense pressure for allowing misinformation and hate speech to spread on its site.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook is considering banning political advertising across its network before the November general election, according to two people with knowledge of the discussions, after facing intense pressure for allowing hate speech and misinformation to flourish across its site.

headline: What if the U.S. Bans TikTok?
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Generation Z', 'Millennial Generation']
abstract: Gen Z and millennial users have found community on the app, particularly during the coronavirus pandemic. And for some of them, it’s their livelihood.
lead_paragraph: Since Secretary of State Mike Pompeo told Fox News on Monday that the United States was considering banning TikTok over national security concerns, a sentiment echoed by President Donald Trump in an interview on Tuesday, TikTok users have been scrambling.

headline: Earl Cameron, Barrier-Breaking British Actor, Is Dead at 102
abstract: In the 1950s and ’60s, when Black leading men and women were virtually nonexistent on British screens, he became a star. He continued to make movies into his 90s.
lead_paragraph: Earl Cameron, a veteran film, television and theater actor who in the early 1950s became one of Britain’s first Black movie stars, died on July 3 at his home in Warwickshire, England. He was 102.

headline: Thinking of Traveling in the U.S.? Check Which States Have Travel Restrictions
abstract: Nearly half of the states have measures in place for visitors, from mandatory testing to quarantine requirements.
lead_paragraph: This list is updated weekly as states continue to announce changes to their travel advisories. Check the date above for when we added the most recent information. Are we missing any updates? Email us at travelrestrictions@nytimes.com.

headline: As a Flag Comes Down, Looking for a ‘New Mississippi’
keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Much of Mississippi galvanized around the effort to remove the state flag. Residents now want to seize on the momentum created by the triumph.
lead_paragraph: [Please sign up here to have the Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.]

headline: Wall Street Journal Staff Members Push for Big Changes in News Coverage
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'News and News Media', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: A letter from a group of Journal reporters and editors calls for “more muscular reporting about race and social inequities,” as well as skepticism toward business and government leaders.
lead_paragraph: Staff members of The Wall Street Journal have been pressing newsroom leaders to make fundamental changes in how the newspaper covers race, policing, and its primary focus, the business world, along with other matters.

headline: College Football Season Teeters on the Brink
abstract: Bit by bit, workouts, programs or seasons are canceled by conferences, throwing into question if it is worth having a season at all in a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The idea of playing college sports this fall has felt iffy all along, like assembling a massive and unwieldy Jenga tower of good intentions and questionable hopes.

headline: 6 Steps to an Efficient Pantry
abstract: A rainy weekend can be a great time to get your pantry in order. Here are a few tips to make it as well-organized as possible.
lead_paragraph: A rainy weekend can be a great time to get your pantry in order. Here are a few tips to make it as well-organized as possible.

headline: Appeals Court Sends the Case of a Pink $40 Million Diamond to Trial
abstract: The diamond, auctioned by Christie’s in 2013, is the subject of an ownership dispute that is making its way through the courts.
lead_paragraph: The legal battle over the true ownership of an exquisite pink diamond valued at $40 million is headed to trial after an appellate court in New York delivered a ruling in favor of the descendants of an Italian politician who are trying to prove that the stone is rightfully theirs.

headline: Britain Gambles on a Bankrupt Satellite Operator, OneWeb
keywords: ['Satellites', 'Bankruptcies', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Pushed by Brexit, the U.K. government will have a platform to expand into the space business.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Britain says goodbye to the European Union, the government of Prime Minister Boris Johnson is making a sudden swerve into space. On Friday, a federal bankruptcy judge in New York approved an arrangement under which Britain will become an owner of a company that wants to use satellites to connect customers in remote parts of the world to the internet.

headline: U.S. Will Impose Tariffs on French Goods in Response to Tech Tax
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Trump administration said it would impose 25 percent tariffs on some French goods but will delay collection of the levies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Friday said it would impose new tariffs on $1.3 billion worth of French goods, including cosmetics, soap and handbags, in retaliation for a French tax that largely hits American technology companies, escalating a trade dispute that threatens to further damage the global economy.

headline: An Interstellar Phone Call
abstract: Michael Barbaro speaks with Bob Behnken, Chris Cassidy and Doug Hurley, the three NASA astronauts aboard the International Space Station.
lead_paragraph: Michael Barbaro speaks with Bob Behnken, Chris Cassidy and Doug Hurley, the three NASA astronauts aboard the International Space Station.

headline: Everton Weekes, Cricket Star and Racial Pioneer, Is Dead at 95
abstract: Along with his fellow Barbados batsmen Frank Worrell and Clyde Walcott — together they were “the three Ws” — he broke the sport’s longstanding color barrier.
lead_paragraph: The West Indies cricketer Everton Weekes was the last of the “three Ws" — batsmen linked by a matchless conjunction of birth, location and alliteration.

headline: It’s Time, Dr. Fauci
abstract: A reader calls on the infectious disease expert to speak up and to resign from the president’s task force.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ Note: This letter has been updated to reflect developments.

headline: Marga Richter, Composer in a Male-Dominated Era, Dies at 93
abstract: During a career that began in the 1940s and stretched into this century, she often felt she and other women were slighted.
lead_paragraph: Marga Richter, a prolific composer whose determination to be heard in a male-dominated field once led her to rent Merkin Concert Hall to stage a program of her own works, died on June 25 at her home in Barnegat, N.J. She was 93.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Disney World reopens this weekend despite a surge of cases in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Despite Florida’s sharp rise in cases over the past month, Walt Disney World in Orlando is preparing to welcome guests starting this weekend.

headline: A Dispatch From Outer Space
abstract: A producer reflects on his childhood dream coming true on The Daily’s interstellar phone call.
lead_paragraph: Space, for the most part, is silent. The airless voids between galaxies are scattered with star dust — tiny molecules incapable of carrying sound waves through the dark.

headline: FedEx Made a Demand Dan Snyder Couldn’t Afford to Dismiss
keywords: ['Names, Organizational', 'Football', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Native Americans', 'Discrimination', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Mascots']
abstract: Long a defiant defender of his team’s name, the owner of the Washington football team changed course in short order after FedEx sent a letter threatening to withdraw its sponsorship.
lead_paragraph: After decades of controversy, it took a serious threat to Dan Snyder’s team’s finances, and those of the rest of the N.F.L., to get the owner of the Washington Redskins to consider changing the team’s name, which Native Americans (and many dictionaries) consider to be a slur.

headline: Officers Shot Latino Man Five Times in the Back, Autopsy Says
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Autopsies', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police']
abstract: Andres Guardado was killed in Southern California last month. His family said he was working as a security guard for an auto body shop the day he was shot.
lead_paragraph: An 18-year-old Latino man who was killed in a confrontation with Los Angeles County sheriff’s deputies last month was fatally shot five times in the back, according to an autopsy released Friday in a killing the man’s family contends was unjustified.

headline: Christie’s New Auction Technique: The Global Gavel
abstract: The sale on Friday, which started in Hong Kong and included Paris, London and New York, raised $420.9 million.
lead_paragraph: It started in Hong Kong at 9:25 in the evening, moved back eight time zones to Paris and London in the afternoon, and then finished in New York at 11:15 Friday morning. In just under four hours, $420.9 million had been spent.

headline: Coronavirus, Hagia Sofia, Frozen Drinks: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Zuckerberg Never Fails to Disappoint
abstract: He cannot hold on to such enormous power and avoid responsibility when things get tough.
lead_paragraph: I had hoped to write about electric bikes this week, as part of my ongoing effort to live without a car. I was also considering weighing in on Uber’s purchase of the Postmates food delivery service and its implications for the already beleaguered restaurant industry. Or, perhaps the rumors that Twitter is considering a subscription service. Or, and this is interesting, the spectacular I.P.O. of the insurance industry disrupter Lemonade.

headline: Trump Calls Biden a ‘Puppet’ of Bernie Sanders and A.O.C.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump criticized former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., calling him a “puppet” of Senator Bernie Sanders and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, and falsely claiming the Obama administration was “pro-Communist.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump criticized former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., calling him a “puppet” of Senator Bernie Sanders and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, and falsely claiming the Obama administration was “pro-Communist.”

headline: After Trump’s Supreme Court Loss, D.A. Moves Closer to Getting Tax Records
keywords: ['Trump Tax Returns', 'ADULTERY', 'Campaign Finance', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A lower-court judge swiftly scheduled a hearing for next week on the Manhattan prosecutor’s demand to see President Trump’s financial records.
lead_paragraph: A day after winning a Supreme Court victory over President Trump, the Manhattan district attorney moved one step closer to obtaining some of the president’s financial records when a lower-court judge acted quickly to hear any final arguments from the president’s lawyers.

headline: Leading Homeland Security Under a President Who Embraces ‘Hate-Filled’ Talk
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Elaine Duke, a lifelong Republican, was acting secretary of homeland security for four months in 2017.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Elaine C. Duke, then President Trump’s acting secretary of homeland security, arrived at the Roosevelt Room, down the hall from the Oval Office, on a steamy August afternoon in 2017 expecting a discussion about President Trump’s pledge to terminate DACA, the Obama-era protections for young immigrants. Instead, she said, it was “an ambush.”

headline: An Open Letter on Free Expression Draws a Counterblast
keywords: ['Letters', 'News and News Media', 'Writing and Writers', 'Social Media', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A few days after more than 150 cultural luminaries warned of a growing “intolerant climate,” another group responded with a pointed letter of its own.
lead_paragraph: Three days after an open letter signed by more than 150 cultural luminaires darkly warning of a growing “intolerant climate” stirred intense response on the internet, another group issued a counterblast on Friday accusing them of elitism, hypocrisy and complicity in the bullying they decry.

headline: In a Term Full of Major Cases, the Supreme Court Tacked to the Center
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Native Americans', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'ABORTION', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: Doling out victories to both sides, the court led by Chief Justice John Roberts seemed to strive to avoid charges of partisanship.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an era of stark partisan polarization, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. steered the Supreme Court toward the middle, doling out victories to both left and right in the most consequential term in recent memory.

headline: Study of Coronavirus in Pregnant Women Finds Striking Racial Differences
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Research', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Antibodies', 'Disease Rates']
abstract: About 10 percent of Black and Latino participants in a Philadelphia study of pregnant women had been exposed to the coronavirus, compared with 2 percent of white participants.
lead_paragraph: Black and Latino pregnant women in Philadelphia are five times as likely as their white counterparts to have been exposed to the coronavirus, according to data collected from nearly 1,300 women between April and June.

headline: Running Past an Olympic Dream
abstract: When Kyle Merber’s plans to reach the Tokyo Games were derailed by the pandemic, he realized how much the singular pursuit had been holding him back.
lead_paragraph: On an overcast morning in late March, a few days after the International Olympic Committee announced it was postponing the 2020 Tokyo Games because of the coronavirus pandemic, Kyle Merber made the short drive from his home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., to the Dutchess Rail Trail, one of his favorite running routes.

headline: In Singapore, an Orderly Election and a (Somewhat) Surprising Result
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Foreign Workers', 'Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The People’s Action Party, which has never been out of power, won yet again, but by a narrower margin than usual. The opposition had sought to deny it “a blank check.”
lead_paragraph: Face-masked citizens lined up to vote in Singapore on Friday, with plenty of space separating them from each other. Their temperatures had been checked. Before receiving their ballots, they spritzed their hands with sanitizer, and many put on disposable gloves.

headline: The Most Dangerous Phase of Trump’s Rule
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: His threat to democracy is nothing to laugh at.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Think of postwar European institutions as an elaborate shield against fascism. The European Union diluting nationalist identity; the welfare state cushioning the social divisions dictators may exploit; NATO transforming the United States into a European power and the ultimate protector of democracy against totalitarian ideologies.

headline: No Foul Play in Robert Fuller’s Death, Private Inquiry Finds
abstract: A lawyer for the family of Robert Fuller, who was found hanging from a tree in California last month, said there was no evidence to suggest that anything was “racially motivated.”
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for the family of Robert Fuller, who was found hanging from a tree in California last month, said there was no evidence to suggest that anything was “racially motivated.”

headline: Auctions get creative as the pandemic forces them online
abstract: Just about every area of personal finance has been affected by the coronavirus pandemic. That economic shock reaches all the way to some of the most aspirational purchases on the planet: art, cars, watches and wine.
lead_paragraph: Just about every area of personal finance has been affected by the coronavirus pandemic. That economic shock reaches all the way to some of the most aspirational purchases on the planet: art, cars, watches and wine.

headline: I Have Cancer. Now My Facebook Feed Is Full of ‘Alternative Care’ Ads.
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Online Advertising', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Alternative and Complementary Medicine', 'Cancer']
abstract: Being targeted by those who traffic in false promises feels like a “slap in the face” to patients like me.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I posted about my breast cancer diagnosis on Facebook. Since then, my Facebook feed has featured ads for “alternative cancer care.” The ads, which were new to my timeline, promote everything from cumin seeds to colloidal silver as cancer treatments. Some ads promise luxury clinics — or even “nontoxic cancer therapies” on a beach in Mexico.

headline: An End to Empty Seats on Canada’s Airlines
abstract: Air Canada and WestJet are no longer putting empty seats between passengers to physically distance them. Some health experts are concerned.
lead_paragraph: Photos of empty airports have come to symbolize the head-spinning drop in air travel during the pandemic. But the more surprising illustration for me involves a now-crowded space.

headline: Testing, Testing
abstract: You want a coronavirus test? How about next month?
lead_paragraph: Q: I think I have it.

headline: Trump Commutes Sentence of Roger Stone in Case He Long Denounced
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president’s friend had been convicted of impeding a congressional inquiry that threatened Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump commuted the sentence of his longtime friend Roger J. Stone Jr. on seven felony crimes on Friday, using the power of his office to spare a former campaign adviser days before Mr. Stone was to report to a federal prison to serve a 40-month term.

headline: Edward Kleinbard, Tax Lawyer Turned Reformer, Dies at 68
keywords: ['Tax Shelters', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Income Inequality', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: After advising multinationals for 30 years, he began teaching and writing, criticizing corporate tax dodging and pressing for higher taxes to combat inequality.
lead_paragraph: Edward Kleinbard, a prominent tax lawyer who helped global corporations find creative ways to cut their taxes before he moved to academia and shined a light on the practices of the types of companies he had once advised, died on June 28 in Los Angeles. He was 68.

headline: As Trump Demanded Schools Reopen, His Experts Warned of ‘Highest Risk’
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'States (US)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A briefing packet for federal emergency response teams details the steps schools should take to reopen safely.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal materials for reopening schools, shared the week President Trump demanded weaker guidelines to do so, said fully reopening schools and universities remained the “highest risk” for the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Trump, in Florida, Seeks to Quell Doubts About His Opposition to Maduro
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: In his recent book, John Bolton, the president’s former national security adviser, recounted how Mr. Trump disparaged Venezuela’s opposition leader, Juan Guaidó, and was impressed by Mr. Maduro’s resilience.
lead_paragraph: President Trump renewed his opposition on Friday to Venezuela’s socialist dictator, Nicolás Maduro, showcasing a hard-line position popular with Florida’s Latino voters and accusing his presumptive Democratic rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., of supporting “pro-Communist policies” across Latin America.

headline: Reopening Schools Will Be a Huge Undertaking. It Must Be Done.
abstract: Officials need to think outside the school building.
lead_paragraph: American children need public schools to reopen in the fall. Reading, writing and arithmetic are not even the half of it. Kids need to learn to compete and to cooperate. They need food and friendships; books and basketball courts; time away from family and a safe place to spend it.

headline: Judge Orders Delay of First Federal Execution in 17 Years
abstract: The Justice Department immediately appealed the injunction, issued after family members of the victims of the crime argued that the coronavirus made it unsafe for them to travel to witness the execution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the Justice Department scheduled on Monday to carry out the death penalty for the first time in 17 years, a federal judge in Indiana temporarily suspended the plan on Friday after family members of the victims sought a delay, saying they could not safely travel to witness the execution because of the coronavirus.

headline: Grizzly Bears Around Yellowstone Can Stay on Endangered Species List, Court Rules
keywords: ['Bears', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Environment']
abstract: The decision by a federal appeals court protects about 700 bears in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem from being hunted.
lead_paragraph: Those 700 or so grizzly bears around Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks are safe — at least for now.

headline: Bulk of an Experiment
abstract: Kameron Austin Collins pushes us to our limits.
lead_paragraph: A note on 58D, which is incorrectly clued. The crossword editors write: “While Wall-E pronounces the name “EE-vuh,” it’s actually spelled EVE, which stands for Extraterrestrial Vegetation Evaluator.” The clue has been changed to ___ Air (carrier to Taiwan) in electronic formats.

headline: By Praising Trump, Goya President Angers His Core Latino Market
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Food', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Boycotts', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Robert Unanue said the country was “blessed” to have the president’s leadership. Now, amid calls for a boycott, the largest Hispanic-owned food company in the U.S. is facing dismay from chefs and home cooks.
lead_paragraph: When Lina Baez-Rosario moved to the United States as a young girl, she missed her home in the Dominican Republic. Her parents made sure to cook with familiar flavors, to keep memories alive.

headline: Corrections: June 11, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 11, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about rising coronavirus infections misidentified the state where Chris Sununu is the governor. It is New Hampshire, not Vermont.

headline: Quotation of the Day: As Paper Withers, a Reporter Dares to Ask Why
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 11, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Evan is the voice of the voiceless. He speaks for the little people. If we lose him, we’re in trouble.”

headline: Trump Adds Roger Stone to His List of Pardons and Commutations
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Ex-Convicts']
abstract: The president’s decision to commute Mr. Stone’s sentence continues a pattern of his presidency: granting clemency to friends whose cases resonate with him personally.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Friday commuted the sentence of Roger J. Stone Jr., a longtime friend and former campaign adviser who had openly expressed loyalty to him throughout a congressional investigation into ties between Mr. Trump’s 2016 campaign and Russia.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Bloody Nose, Empty Pockets’ and ‘Unidentified’
abstract: Watch an experimental film about bar regulars, and Tom DeLonge’s U.F.O. series returns.
lead_paragraph: BLOODY NOSE, EMPTY POCKETS (2020) Watch through virtual cinemas. This film is neither a documentary nor fiction, but rather an experimental combination of the two. Without giving too much away, it centers on a dive bar called the Roaring ’20s, and the last night of debauchery there before it closes its doors for good (or does it?). As barflies waft in and out of the establishment to bid farewell, the filmmakers — brothers Bill and Turner Ross — turn their attention to the conversations and connections the patrons make inside, celebrating the makeshift community that drinking establishments tend to provide.

headline: Hindu God in a Music Video? A K-Pop Band Runs Afoul of Fans
abstract: A tempest over the band Blackpink’s use of a Hindu god in a video was the latest example of K-pop fans holding artists to account — while staying fiercely loyal.
lead_paragraph: The statue of the Hindu god Ganesha flashed onscreen for just seconds in the music video by Blackpink, an all-female K-pop band. The elephant-headed deity was shown on the floor, near a bejeweled Aladdin lamp, as a member of the band preened and rapped on a golden throne.

headline: 10 Steps to Take to Try to Prevent Your Own Eviction
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Evictions', 'Landlords', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'internal-essential']
abstract: Some federal relief is about to expire. Local assistance is spotty. Congress may not act quickly. Here’s how to get help, or help yourself.
lead_paragraph: If you have a mortgage and can’t afford to pay it because of fallout from the coronavirus, you may be able to push off your payments for several months, or even into next year. But if you’re struggling to pay your rent, your options are probably much more limited.

headline: The Bryan Brothers Were Ready to Call It Quits. Now They Might Need One Last Hug.
abstract: 2020 was supposed to be a farewell tour for Bob and Mike Bryan, the incomparable tennis twins, who have long been the darlings of doubles. Then coronavirus canceled it. Will they try again?
lead_paragraph: Bob and Mike Bryan had a really good plan. One last whirl around the world for this unmatched identical twin doubles team. Collect some prize money, doff their caps in Melbourne and Paris and at Wimbledon, then end in one big blanket of tennis love at the U.S. Open in New York, where they have won their home-country slam five times.

headline: For 20 Years, His Firm Called Him Antoine. Now Mohamed Is Suing.
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Names, Personal', 'Discrimination', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Mohamed Amghar, a retired software sales manager in France, has filed a discrimination complaint against his former employer, accusing the company of making him use a traditional French name at work.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Mohamed Amghar was a 40-year-old software salesman in the final stages of interviewing for a new job in November 1996 when, in his telling, his future boss made a request that left him speechless.

headline: Ethiopia Announces Arrests in Prominent Singer’s Killing
abstract: The shooting last month of Hachalu Hundessa, a hero to young Ethiopians calling for reform, was followed by unrest in which hundreds of people were killed.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Ethiopia has said that two men have been arrested in connection with the killing of Hachalu Hundessa, a well-known musician and activist whose death last month was followed by unrest in which hundreds were killed.

headline: Can These Markets Be Trusted?
abstract: After a calamitous drop in March, the stock market has had a ferocious rally, despite a cascade of awful news. How can investors cope?
lead_paragraph: The stock market is often a puzzle, but lately it has been more difficult than usual to understand.

headline: What Are the Quarantine Rules for Returning New Yorkers?
abstract: Those coming from a restricted state must isolate, but you can’t be barred from entering your own building.
lead_paragraph: Q: I have been staying in Florida during the pandemic, but am now planning to return to my Manhattan co-op. Do the quarantine restrictions apply to New York residents? If I inform my co-op that I’ve been in Florida, could they keep me from coming back to my apartment, or stop me from leaving if I need to go out to get groceries?

headline: Who Gets the Banhammer Now?
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Hate Speech', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: In a single week, some of the internet’s biggest platforms banned users and groups they had tolerated for years. What changed?
lead_paragraph: In a typical year, a good way for a company to handle an announcement it hoped to bury is to schedule it before a nice long holiday weekend. This is one way to interpret the last week of June online, when several internet giants took decisive action against mostly far-right communities and users, many of whom who had been sources of controversy for years.

headline: For Oklahoma Tribe, Vindication at Long Last
abstract: After decades of betrayals and broken treaties, the Supreme Court ruled that much of Oklahoma is their land, after all.
lead_paragraph: The sorrow and death of the Trail of Tears were still fresh when a band of Muscogee (Creek) people gathered by an oak tree in 1836 to deposit the ashes of the ceremonial fires they had carried across America and begin a new home in the West. It was called Tulasi, or “Old Town.” Tulsa.

headline: What’s the Value of Harvard Without a Campus?
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Colleges and Universities', 'E-Learning', 'Dormitories', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Many first-generation, low-income Harvard students feel that the elite institution has failed them.
lead_paragraph: Dumebi Adigwe, a rising sophomore studying mathematics at Harvard University, has no idea where she is going to live. This week, Harvard announced it would allow only up to 40 percent of its nearly 6,800 undergraduates on campus in the fall, the vast majority of them freshmen, and that all classes would be held online.

headline: After an Arrest at a Black Lives Matter Protest: Deportation Proceedings
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Police Reform', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: A Phoenix activist was supporting one cause, and caught up in the unresolved fight of another.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Máxima Guerrero had seen it before: young people gathering in anger and frustration, not waiting for the guidance of major organizations or longtime political leaders.

headline: Fact-Checking Biden on the Coronavirus and His Own Record
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Small Business', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: The presumptive Democratic nominee has assailed President Trump’s pandemic response and sought to shore up his left flank.
lead_paragraph: Since effectively securing the Democratic nomination in April, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has focused his low-profile campaign on hammering President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus epidemic. We rounded up some inaccurate claims in his recent remarks.

headline: At a Time of Financial Stress, 401(k) Fees Matter More Than Ever
keywords: ['401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Retirement', 'Personal Finances', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Calculators', 'Mutual Funds']
abstract: These expenses always eat away at savings balances, but as the pandemic drags on, savers should be especially aware of how to keep them down.
lead_paragraph: John C. Bogle, founder of the Vanguard Group, had a mantra throughout his long career in the mutual fund industry: “Costs matter.” The amount of fees you pay to a third party to manage your money eats into your retirement savings. That has never been more important, although it is probably not foremost on your mind right now.

headline: Scientists Say You Can Cancel the Noise but Keep Your Window Open
abstract: Researchers in Singapore developed a system that’s sort of like noise-canceling headphones for your whole apartment.
lead_paragraph: Car alarms, jackhammers, a drunken argument and the rumble of the No. 7 train passing overhead. It is the glorious urban symphony that pours into a typical New York City apartment building day and night.

headline: Hunger Is Worsening. Here Are 7 Ways New Yorkers Are Addressing It.
keywords: ['Food Insecurity', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Food Banks and Pantries', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: Pastors, theater technicians and nonprofit leaders are repurposing their organizations to create and distribute meals.
lead_paragraph: The number of food-insecure New York City residents has doubled to about two million since the onset of the pandemic. But just as quickly as the need escalated, so, too, did new solutions.

headline: Georgia. Ohio. Texas. Democrats Tell Biden to Go Big (He’s Being Cautious).
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: This election, some Democrats argue, offers the party the provocative possibility of a new path to the presidency, even as others warn against overconfidence.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2020 election between Joe Biden and President Trump.

headline: Caught Between Indian and Chinese Troops, at 15,000 Feet
abstract: Ladakh is a place of high-altitude pastures, lonely herders and desolate moonscapes — and a byword for intractable geopolitical disputes.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — First it was cellphone towers, new roads and surveillance cameras, popping up on the Chinese side of the disputed Himalayan border with India.Then it was more run-ins between troops on each side, pushing, shoving and eventually getting into fistfights.Then, about three years ago, Indian soldiers spotted their Chinese foes carrying iron bars with little numbers written on them — a weapon apparently issued as standard gear, and a sign that the Chinese were gearing up for hand-to-hand combat.“This is how China operates,” said J.P. Yadav, a recently retired official with the Indo-Tibetan Border Police, on the Indian side. “These are very planned things.”Now, weeks after a deadly brawl erupted along the border, thousands of Chinese and Indian troops are amassed over a contentious, jagged line in one of the most remote places on earth. Satellite photos reveal a major Chinese buildup, including a blizzard of new tents, new storage sheds, artillery pieces and even tanks.

headline: ‘I Couldn’t Do Anything’: The Virus and an E.R. Doctor’s Suicide
keywords: ['Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hospitals', 'Quarantines', 'Shortages', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Doctors', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Dr. Lorna Breen was unflappable — until she faced a new enemy.
lead_paragraph: On an afternoon in early April, while New York City was in the throes of what would be the deadliest days of the coronavirus pandemic, Dr. Lorna M. Breen found herself alone in the still of her apartment in Manhattan.

headline: In Latin America, the Pandemic Threatens Equality Like Never Before
abstract: Over the past two decades, inequality in Latin America had fallen to the lowest point in its recorded history. The pandemic threatens to reverse that. We traveled 1,000 miles across Colombia to document this critical moment.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Sandra Abello grew up poor, left school at 11 and spent her teenage years scrubbing floors as a live-in maid. But by this year, something remarkable had happened.

headline: ‘Not a Welcoming Name’: Calls to Drop ‘Plantation’ Gain Steam Nationwide
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'City Councils']
abstract: Across the country, people are pushing to change the names of cities, neighborhoods and gated communities that include the word “plantation.”
lead_paragraph: When Dharyl Auguste was 3 years old, he and his parents packed all of their belongings and left their home in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, to immigrate to the United States.

headline: Jack Charlton, Soccer Hero in England and Ireland, Dies at 85
abstract: A towering defender, he won the World Cup with his home country in 1966 and went on to coach the Irish national team to memorable runs in 1990 and 1994.
lead_paragraph: LEEDS, England — Jack Charlton, a soccer star who was a central part of the England team that lifted the World Cup on home soil in 1966 and who would later go on to transform Ireland’s national team as a manager, died on Friday at his home in Northumberland, in northern England. He was 85.

headline: ‘I Don’t Want to Go Back’: Many Teachers Are Fearful and Angry Over Pressure to Return
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)', 'E-Learning', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Organized Labor', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: Teachers say crucial questions about how schools will stay clean, keep students physically distanced and prevent further spread of the virus have not been answered.
lead_paragraph: Many of the nation’s 3.5 million teachers found themselves feeling under siege this week as pressure from the White House, pediatricians and some parents to get back to physical classrooms intensified — even as the coronavirus rages across much of the country.

headline: Louisiana Orders Bars Closed and Masks for Most
abstract: Trump wears a mask publicly for the first time. Disney World reopened, despite a surge in Florida. Thousands of Israelis protested the government’s handling of the economy.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow the latest news on the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Even as Covid-19 Looms, an M.L.B. Rookie Is Ready to Play
abstract: Seattle Mariners outfielder Kyle Lewis never wavered in his decision to play in baseball’s truncated season. Now he’s just got to get used to wearing a mask and not spitting.
lead_paragraph: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Lewis’s first installment here.

headline: A Perfect Peach Poundcake
abstract: Make Jerrelle Guy’s recipe, Ali Slagle’s shrimp scampi, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include Jerrelle Guy’s peach poundcake (above), Ali Slagle’s summer shrimp scampi and Eric Kim’s cucumber “quick kimchi.” Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: To ‘Protect Young Minds,’ Hong Kong Moves to Overhaul Schools
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Education', 'Education (K-12)', 'ACADEMIC FREEDOM', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: China’s leaders have pushed the territory to revamp an education system they see as having bred young rebels who have helped drive pro-democracy protests.
lead_paragraph: Starting this fall, schools in Hong Kong will display colorful new government-issued posters declaring that “freedom comes with responsibilities.” Administrators may now call the police if anyone insults the Chinese national anthem on campus.

headline: How to Reopen Schools: What Science and Other Countries Teach Us
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Education (K-12)', 'E-Learning', 'Children and Childhood', 'Disease Rates', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Masks', 'Quarantines', 'Research', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Content Type: Service', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: The pressure to bring American students back to classrooms is intense, but the calculus is tricky with infections still out of control in many communities.
lead_paragraph: As school districts across the United States consider whether and how to restart in-person classes, their challenge is complicated by a pair of fundamental uncertainties: No nation has tried to send children back to school with the virus raging at levels like America’s, and the scientific research about transmission in classrooms is limited.

headline: Business Leaders Urge Trump to Leave DACA Alone After Court Ruling
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Executives with companies including Target, Apple, Google and Facebook warned the president that any actions related to DACA would disrupt the economy and affect the battle against the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: A group of prominent business leaders urged President Trump on Saturday to leave in place a program affecting roughly 800,000 young immigrants who are shielded from deportation, saying it would disrupt the economy and impact the battle against the coronavirus.

headline: Variety: Diagramless Crossword
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners presents us with an uphill battle.
lead_paragraph: DIAGRAMLESS CROSSWORD — I hope people look forward to the diagramless puzzle, especially when it’s — drumroll — asymmetrical. That indicates a picture puzzle, because the entries have been freed from their usual mirror-image or bilateral lockdown for a good reason, to make a pattern that the solver comes upon or ferrets out. We’ve recently had a house with a chimney from Alex Eaton-Salners, a René Magritte pipe and a number three (which happens to be a hint to getting started today).

headline: America Needs an Emergency Meeting of the Baby-Sitters Club
abstract: Schools and day cares are still closed. Luckily, I have an eager 9-year-old neighbor.
lead_paragraph: LOUDONVILLE, N.Y. — A few weeks back, our 9-year-old neighbor, Nealy, cornered me in the driveway. Since summer camp was canceled, she said, and because she is technically too young to babysit (though fully capable of doing so), she wanted to offer her services as a mother’s helper. She would come over and watch my children — ages 20 months and just-turned-3 — so that I could get things done around the house.

headline: Metropolitan Opera Will Livestream Its Biggest Stars
abstract: Starting on July 18, 12 professionally shot recitals will be broadcast from idyllic locations around the world. The price of admission: $20.
lead_paragraph: For months, the Metropolitan Opera has been streaming operas from its extensive video archive each night, a program that has helped it attract tens of thousands of new donors. The At-Home Gala the company broadcast in April, with live performances filmed on smartphones by singers around the world, was watched by 750,000 people.

headline: The Left Is Remaking the World
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Green New Deal']
abstract: “Defund the police” and “cancel rent” aren’t reforms, but paths to revolution.
lead_paragraph: The uprisings in response to the killing of George Floyd are far different from anything that has come before. Not just because they may be the largest in our history, or that seven weeks in, people are still in the streets (even if the news media has largely moved on). But also because, for the last few years, organizers have been thinking boldly.

headline: Trump Says He ‘Aced’ a Cognition Test. What Does That Tell Us?
abstract: If the president wants to impress us with his intellect, he should take the SAT.
lead_paragraph: President Trump said on Thursday that he “aced” a cognitive test administered at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.

headline: In Texas Beach City, Out-of-Towners Drove In an Outbreak
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Beaches', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Quarantines', 'Masks', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: A month ago, Corpus Christi had hardly any cases of coronavirus and business was booming. Now it is struggling to contain one of the state’s fastest growing outbreaks. What happened?
lead_paragraph: CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — As recently as early June, days went by with hardly anyone testing positive for the coronavirus. A single case one day. Three the next. Then zero. Zero. Zero.

headline: In Commuting Stone’s Sentence, Trump Goes Where Nixon Would Not
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Senator Mitt Romney called the commutation an act of “unprecedented, historic corruption.” Attorney General William P. Barr privately argued against clemency for the president’s friend.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has said he learned lessons from President Richard M. Nixon’s fall from grace, but in using the power of his office to keep his friend and adviser Roger J. Stone Jr. out of prison he has now crossed a line that even Mr. Nixon in the depths of Watergate dared not cross.

headline: ​Paik Sun-yup, Lightning Rod General in South Korea, Dies at 99
abstract: The country’s first four-star general, he was a war hero to the U.S. and South Korean militaries. But many saw him as a traitor who had collaborated with the Japanese.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Paik Sun-yup, South Korea’s first four-star general, who was lionized as a Korean War hero by the South Korean and United States militaries but dismissed by many in his country as a traitor, died here on Friday. He was 99.

headline: Ragaa el-Gedawy, Cherished Star of Egyptian Cinema, Dies at 85
abstract: She endeared herself to audiences with her grace, naturalism and comic skill. She fell ill after filming a TV series in May and died from Covid-19 in July.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: A #MeToo Moment Emerges for Military Women After Soldier’s Killing
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', '#MeToo Movement', 'Hispanic-Americans']
