lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the #MeToo movement gained ground, propelled by stories of women in Hollywood, the news media, restaurants and other industries, women in the military have remained in the shadows.

headline: Yacht Rock Revue Kicks Off First Night of Drive-In Concerts in Indiana
abstract: Live Nation’s outdoor music series attracted many captain hats, but few masks (which weren’t required).
lead_paragraph: NOBLESVILLE, Ind. — On a breezy, 80-degree summer night, more than a thousand, mostly middle-age smooth rock fans, many of them sporting cargo shorts and captain’s hats, danced for two hours to tunes from the 1970s and ’80s by Yacht Rock Revue, who were performing in an Indiana parking lot.

headline: Valentina Sampaio Is the First Transgender Model for Sports Illustrated
keywords: ['Models (Professional)', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Bathing Suits and Swimwear']

headline: The Mistakes That Will Haunt Our Legacy
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Factory Farming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Global Warming', 'Vegetarianism']
abstract: As we topple statues, let’s also search for our own moral blind spots.
lead_paragraph: As we pull down controversial statues and reassess historical figures, I’ve been wondering what our great-grandchildren will find bewilderingly immoral about our own times — and about us.

headline: The Republicans Who Want to Destroy Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: Their party’s a lost cause. America isn’t.
lead_paragraph: Should you have any doubt about how passionately George Conway and the other Never Trumpers at the Lincoln Project want to defeat the president, check out their ads.

headline: The Chinese Decade
abstract: The coronavirus has given Beijing a strategic opportunity — but one that might not last.
lead_paragraph: It is quite extraordinary that a pandemic originating in a Chinese province, a disease whose initial cover-up briefly seemed likely to deal a grave blow to the Communist regime, has instead given China a geopolitical opportunity unlike any enjoyed by an American rival since at least the Vietnam War.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Masks', 'Plagiarism', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Lying', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']

headline: Putting Heroes, and Traitors, Where They Belong
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Names, Organizational']
abstract: The military should rechristen bases named for Confederates. Better options are not hard to find.
lead_paragraph: African-Americans were nonpersons in the eyes of the state when the federal government started to name U.S. Army installations for Confederate officers. Black people in the South were being lynched with impunity for such offenses as seeking the vote, competing with white people in business or simply failing to give way on the sidewalk.

headline: Protests Rock Russian Far East With Calls for Putin to Resign
keywords: ['Term Limits (Political Office)', 'Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Tens of thousands took to the streets in Russia’s usually somnolent hinterland after the arrest of a popular regional governor.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Tens of thousands of people protested in Russia’s Far East on Saturday in a rare display of opposition to President Vladimir V. Putin in the country’s vast hinterland, chanting “Putin Resign” and demanding the release of a regional governor arrested this past week on suspicion of multiple murders.

headline: 3 Picture Books: How to Hike, Camp, Relax in the Great Outdoors
abstract: For families ready to roam free, these visually-driven stories celebrate the physical joys of wide-open spaces.
lead_paragraph: On limited outings in my Brooklyn neighborhood, children I see riding atop their dads’ shoulders or lounging in strollers are all wearing masks. Without having much to compare it to, their sci-fi pandemic version of life is, simply, life. No telling what sort of impact all this will have on their tender psyches.

headline: Lucius Barker, Expert on Race in American Politics, Dies at 92
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: He was a passionate Jesse Jackson delegate at the 1984 Democratic National Convention and, later, a mentor to future politicians like Senator Cory Booker.
lead_paragraph: Lucius J. Barker, a revered political scientist and professor whose professional expertise in race in American politics informed his personal role as a delegate for Jesse Jackson at the 1984 Democratic National Convention, died on June 21 at his home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Fire Badly Damages San Gabriel Mission in California
keywords: ['Churches (Buildings)', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Native Americans']
abstract: The fire broke out one day after $200,000 in renovations had been completed at the church, which is more than 200 years old.
lead_paragraph: A fire early on Saturday morning destroyed the roof and badly damaged the interior of San Gabriel Mission, a Catholic church in California that is more than 200 years old and considered to be the “birthplace” of the Los Angeles region.

headline: Defying U.S., China and Iran Near Trade and Military Partnership
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The investment and security pact would vastly extend China’s influence in the Middle East, throwing Iran an economic lifeline and creating new flash points with the United States.
lead_paragraph: Iran and China have quietly drafted a sweeping economic and security partnership that would clear the way for billions of dollars of Chinese investments in energy and other sectors, undercutting the Trump administration’s efforts to isolate the Iranian government because of its nuclear and military ambitions.

headline: Disney World Opens Its Gates, With Virus Numbers Rising
abstract: Thousands of giddy visitors streamed into the Florida resort, as Disney tried to prove it can safely operate at a highly dangerous time.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The Bibbidi Bobbidi Boutique, a Magic Kingdom hair salon where little girls get styled like Disney princesses, remained closed this weekend. Buzz Lightyear was only able to wave from a distance. Parades and fireworks? Scratched.

headline: N.H.L. Owners and Players Approve New C.B.A. and Return-to-Play Plan
abstract: The approval cements the league’s plan to begin an expanded playoff tournament in August, and ensures labor peace at least through 2026.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L.’s owners and players union announced on Friday that they had officially approved a new labor agreement that will last through 2026 and, more immediately, will allow them to proceed with plans to complete the 2019-20 season.

headline: Make Beads From Your Newspaper
abstract: All it takes is your trusty Times, a little glue and these templates.
lead_paragraph: For so many reasons, right now is the perfect time to start a soothing and gratifying craft project. It’s even better when you can use what you have, like the very newspaper you are holding.

headline: Explore the Red Planet and the Pool
abstract: Go on a scavenger hunt for Mars Day, muse on why we swim and boogie during a dance master class.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Tackle Reopening Choices as a Couple
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Content Type: Service', 'Marriages', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The world is reopening, and differing levels of anxiety can strain already tense relationships. Here are some strategies for getting through it together.
lead_paragraph: Around the world, couples are struggling to cope with the stress that comes with reopening cities and towns (and the pausing or rolling back that, in some places, has ensued). For some, tension has run high for months: As Eric Spiegelman, a podcasting executive based in Los Angeles, tweeted in April, “My wife and I play this fun game during quarantine, it’s called ‘Why Are You Doing It That Way?’ and there are no winners.”

headline: Coronavirus Fears Stem the Flow at Atomic Liquors, Las Vegas’s Oldest Bar
abstract: Nevada shut bars again after the virus surged. While restaurants remain open, customers find it’s not the same.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — At midnight on Friday, bars across Las Vegas and Reno shut down for a second time in six months. With the coronavirus surging, the governor of Nevada had ordered it, and Las Vegas’s oldest freestanding bar, Atomic Liquors, was no exception.

headline: Live: Louisiana Presidential Primary Election Results 2020
Chores Galore
abstract: Honey, do this Samuel A. Donaldson puzzle. Let us know if you need a hand.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This has to be intentional, right? Today’s puzzle is a sequel to last Sunday’s ticked-off boxes; maybe next week we’ll get to take summer vacation, cast off our mantles of constant responsibility and solve something with a beach theme.

headline: Trump Claims Credit for 2018 Cyberattack on Russia
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The move was intended to deter Russians from interfering in the midterm elections, and serve as a test of America’s capability to protect the 2020 elections.
lead_paragraph: President Trump took credit late last week for a cyberattack on Russia’s Internet Research Agency two years ago, citing it as evidence that he has responded strongly to Russian provocations, despite considerable evidence that he has often excused Moscow’s aggressions in cyberspace and on European territory.

headline: Writer for Tucker Carlson Resigns After ‘Abhorrent’ Online Posts Are Revealed
abstract: Fox News condemned Blake Neff, a writer for “Tucker Carlson Tonight,” after he was revealed as the pseudonymous author of racist and misogynist online messages.
lead_paragraph: A writer for the Fox News star Tucker Carlson resigned after he was revealed as the pseudonymous author of several years’ worth of racist, sexist and obscene posts on an online message board.

headline: Trump’s Clemency Came After Displays of Loyalty by Stone
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The extraordinary decision to commute the prison sentence of an embattled adviser demonstrates how the president has managed to bend America’s legal machinery to his advantage.
lead_paragraph: Months before F.B.I. agents arrived in darkness at his Florida home to take him into custody, Roger J. Stone Jr. promised that he would remain loyal to his longtime friend. “I will never roll on Donald Trump,” he said.

headline: Presidential Pardons and Commutations, From Whiskey Rebellion to Roger Stone
abstract: President Trump’s commutation of his friend Roger Stone’s prison term is part of a tradition of controversial pardons going back to George Washington.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s move on Friday to commute the 40-month prison sentence of the political operative Roger J. Stone Jr., a longtime friend of the president’s, is far from the first time the use of that presidential power has raised eyebrows.

headline: California Parents Agree to Plead Guilty in College Admissions Scandal
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'College Admissions Scandal (2019)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: Prosecutors said Todd and Diane Blake paid $250,000 to fraudulently gain their daughter’s admission to the University of Southern California as a volleyball recruit.
lead_paragraph: A California couple have agreed to plead guilty to charges that they paid $250,000 to fraudulently gain their daughter’s admission to the University of Southern California as a volleyball recruit, prosecutors said.

headline: In Rare Public Comments, Mueller Defends Prosecution of Roger Stone
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons']
abstract: Breaking his silence, the former special counsel rebutted President Trump’s attacks on the Russia investigation and said Mr. Stone had been prosecuted “because he committed federal crimes.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The former special counsel Robert S. Mueller III broke his long silence on Saturday to defend his prosecution of Roger J. Stone Jr., forcefully rebutting President Trump’s claims that the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election was political and illegitimate.

headline: Former U.S.A. Gymnastics Coach Faces 14 Charges of Lewdness With a Minor
abstract: Terry Gray, who had been a coach for the U.S.A. Gymnastics women’s national team, was arrested on Friday, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A former coach for U.S.A. Gymnastics was arrested in Las Vegas on Friday and faces more than a dozen counts of lewdness with a minor, the authorities said.

headline: Corrections: July 12, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 12, 2020
lead_paragraph: The Big City column on Page 3 about socially conservative voters in the Bronx misspells the given name of the state director of the Working Families Party in New York. She is Sochie Nnaemeka, not Soiche.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Beach City in Texas Once Was Safe Haven but Is Now a Hot Spot
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 12, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “I never thought in my wildest dreams that I’d be telling tourists, ‘Don’t come to our beaches.’”

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Mucho Mucho Amor’ and ‘Snowpiercer’
abstract: Watch Netflix’s documentary on the astrologer Walter Mercado, and the two-part finale of “Snowpiercer.”
lead_paragraph: MUCHO MUCHO AMOR: THE LEGEND OF WALTER MERCADO (2020) Stream on Netflix. Made in the months before his death, this documentary chronicles the larger-than-life existence of the Puerto Rican television and radio astrologer, Walter Mercado. Mercado became an icon — for his elaborate costumes, focus on positivity and as a gender nonconforming entertainer — and his show was broadcast to millions of viewers every day, until he somewhat mysteriously disappeared from public view. But the directors Cristina Costantini and Kareem Tabsch were able to sit down with Mercado, as well as Lin-Manuel Miranda, the actor Eugenio Derbez and the television host Raúl de Molina to discuss the entertainer’s life and legacy.

headline: Outspoken Chinese Professor Is Said to Be Released From Detention

headline: ‘Action Park’ Looks Back in Amusement and Terror
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS']
abstract: In a new memoir, Andy Mulvihill tells the story of the notorious New Jersey adventure land founded by his father.
lead_paragraph: In 1980, when he was 16 years old, Andy Mulvihill stood at the top of a water slide called Cannonball Loop at Action Park, the beloved and notorious New Jersey amusement park founded in 1978 by his father, Gene Mulvihill. The Cannonball Loop included an “improbable” 360-degree vertical turn near the finish. Andy had been enlisted as the first living creature to test the safety of the experience. Previously, “someone had tied off the ankles and sleeves of an old janitorial jumpsuit, stuffed it with sand and fabricated a head out of a plastic grocery bag,” Mulvihill writes in his new book, “Action Park: Fast Times, Wild Rides, and the Untold Story of America’s Most Dangerous Amusement Park.” “The makeshift dummy cleared the loop but emerged decapitated.”

headline: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 1, Episode 4 Recap: A Final Verdict
abstract: Perry had it pretty easy this week, but others in his orbit were forced to follow darker paths.
lead_paragraph: There’s a new victim in the Charlie Dodson murder case: his mother’s lawyer. In a concluding scene that colors everything that’s gone before it, this episode of “Perry Mason” ends with the apparent suicide of the debonair defense attorney E.B. Jonathan. (I say “apparent” only because we haven’t yet seen a dead body; years of prestige-television watching have taught me not to count my chickens before they’ve died on-screen.)

headline: Pittsburgh Seemed Like a Virus Success Story. Now Cases Are Surging.

lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — A little more than three weeks ago, officials in Pittsburgh announced a milestone enviable for almost any major city in America: A day had gone by without a single new confirmed case of the coronavirus. It was good news for a city that had seen only a modest outbreak all along, even as the virus raged through places like Philadelphia and New York.

It was pleasurable labor, so different from the grind of the workweek, and if my inbox was any indication, it was a joy I shared with many of you.

headline: Bonnie Lucas, Still Playing With Dolls
abstract: The artist finds pleasure and healing in cutting up toys and feminine things, and reassembling the pieces.
lead_paragraph: For the past 41 years, Bonnie Lucas, a Syracuse native who graduated from Wellesley College a few years after Hillary Clinton, has been making intense, memorable collages of dolls, toys and craft implements at home in her tiny NoLIta walk-up. The collages, often bubble gum pink, are powered by a painful ambivalence toward conventional notions of sex and femininity, as well as political rage. Ms. Lucas prides herself on working without glue, instead pinning, tying, or sewing the collages together, or embedding their constituent parts in clay.

Many college students will experience only an attenuated version of campus life — if they get to experience it at all.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘CMA Best of the Fest’ and ‘Foodie Love’
abstract: The musical festival retrospective special airs on ABC. And an Isabel Coixet series arrives on HBO platforms.
lead_paragraph: FOODIE LOVE Stream on HBO platforms. In this Spanish-language series by the prolific director and screenwriter Isabel Coixet, a man and a woman, played by Guillermo Pfening and Laia Costa, meet through a dating app and bond over their shared loved of food and distaste for the culture that has sprung up around it. Across eight episodes, all of which are now available, their relationship develops against the backdrop of coffee and cocktails, ramen and sake, ice cream and croissants. But as they move further from the virtual into the realm of embodied love, by way of fine dining and frequent snacking, the stakes become higher, their intimacy becomes more intense and their deepening connection is threatened.

headline: I’m an Actor of Color. My Curls Aren’t Wanted.
abstract: I know if I want to land more roles, I need to look white.

In the video above, Dominican-American actor Christopher Rivas reflects from the barber’s chair on the hundreds of crew cuts he’s gotten over the course of his career in hopes of appeasing casting directors who have a certain unwavering vision of how a star actor looks.

keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Food', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Cafeterias', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Restaurants', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: It is still unclear how many students will return to college campuses this fall, but for those who do, mealtime will change dramatically.
lead_paragraph: By Becky Vuksta’s calculations, the new socially distanced dining-hall setup at Furman University in Greenville, S.C., will serve 12 students a minute, or 720 students per hour. Not bad, but still not fast enough to feed the school’s 2,700 students in the rush between classes.

headline: Suriname Elects a New President, Ending Bouterse’s Long Rule
abstract: Desi Bouterse has cast a long shadow over Suriname since its independence. Once a dictator, he returned as a populist, but fell in the face of the pandemic and an economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: Suriname elected a new president on Monday, ending the long rule of Desi Bouterse, who dominated the small South American nation’s politics since its independence through intimidation and charisma.

keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Labor and Jobs']

keywords: ['Classical Music', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Music']
abstract: Mr. McClain, who played the violin, died while being detained by the police in Colorado last summer.
lead_paragraph: Ashanti Floyd couldn’t sleep.

headline: Russell Westbrook Says He Tested Positive for the Coronavirus
abstract: Westbrook, the Houston Rockets guard, said he was “feeling well” in a post on social media on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Russell Westbrook of the Houston Rockets, the N.B.A.’s most valuable player in the 2016-17 season, said on Monday in a social media post that he had tested positive for the coronavirus. He said he received his test result before the team left for Walt Disney World in Florida, where the N.B.A. is attempting to restart its season.

headline: The Case Against Tickling
abstract: Laughter doesn’t always signal enjoyment, and “stop” should mean “stop.”
lead_paragraph: When she was a young child, Ashley Austrew’s father would hold her down and tickle her so hard she felt momentarily paralyzed. He thought they were having fun — the tickling made her laugh, after all — but she dreaded it. More than once, she rolled off the couch and hit her head on the coffee table.

headline: Los Angeles and San Diego Schools to Go Online-Only in the Fall
abstract: California’s two largest districts made the joint call amid a White House push to get children back into classrooms.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — California’s two largest public school districts said on Monday that instruction would be online-only in the fall, in the latest sign that school administrators are increasingly unwilling to risk crowding students back into classrooms until the coronavirus is fully under control.

headline: Ghislaine Maxwell Tried to Hide When F.B.I. Knocked, Prosecutors Say
abstract: On the day of her arrest, Ms. Maxwell, a longtime companion of Jeffrey Epstein, refused to answer the door and fled to another room, according to a new court filing.
lead_paragraph: When F.B.I. agents went to arrest Ghislaine Maxwell on the morning of July 2 on a remote property in New Hampshire, they broke through her locked gate, approached the front door and announced themselves, telling her to open the door, federal prosecutors said in newly filed court papers on Monday.

headline: A Colorful Townhouse With Nods to James Turrell
abstract: The architect Michael K. Chen brought a crumbling Brooklyn brownstone back to life by reanimating its once vibrantly painted walls.
lead_paragraph: After purchasing a majestic but dilapidated 19th-century brownstone in Brooklyn’s Clinton Hill neighborhood, a husband-and-wife couple — she a public-school art teacher and artist, he a tech venture-capital investor — set about finding an architect to revive the four-story, four-bedroom house. Built in 1899, the 3,600-square-foot landmarked building had been abandoned for over 20 years, and while its oversize backyard and sweeping Douglas fir staircase remained grand and inviting, the paint was peeling, the plaster was crumbling and the red oak floors were coated in two decades’ worth of grime. Each half of the couple independently sourced suggestions for an architect, asking their respective friends and family members for recommendations. But when they reconvened, each prepared to argue for their own incontestable pick, they found themselves blurting out the same name: Michael Chen.

headline: Naya Rivera Is Found Dead at Lake Piru, Officials Say
abstract: Ms. Rivera, a star of the show “Glee,” disappeared last week after going boating on the California lake with her young son.
lead_paragraph: Investigators on Monday were “confident” they had found the body of Naya Rivera, a star in the series “Glee,” almost a week after she was reported missing at a lake in California, the authorities said.

headline: Trump in a Mask, at Last!
abstract: A reader is stunned that it’s “world news” when the president finally yields to pleas that he wear a mask.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hong Kong Disneyland to Close Again, Days After Disney World Reopens
abstract: The park is the smallest in Disney’s portfolio and is shutting down again to comply with a government-mandated rollback of public activities because of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong Disneyland will close again on Wednesday to comply with a government-directed rollback of public activities in the region after an increase in coronavirus infections, the Walt Disney Company said on Monday. Disney called the closing of the theme park “temporary” and said its resort hotels at the Lantau Island complex would remain open.

lead_paragraph: He just won a landmark victory in the Supreme Court over President Trump that paved the way for prosecutors to obtain the president’s tax returns. In February, he won a conviction against Harvey Weinstein in perhaps the biggest criminal case to arise from the #MeToo movement.

headline: Best Guess on When Business Travel Will Recover? It Could be Years
keywords: ['Business Travel', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'AIRPORTS']

lead_paragraph: While business travel evaporated in a flash when the coronavirus hit, it may take two to three years for it to fully recover — far longer than many travel experts initially predicted.

headline: How to Help Kids Cope With Moving
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Content Type: Service', 'Children and Childhood', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Parenting', 'Moving and Moving Industry', 'Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: A move may mean a welcome change of scenery for you, but to young children it can present an insecure world.
lead_paragraph: When my husband and I decided to buy a new house at the end of last year, we spent very little time considering what the move would mean to our two daughters, who were 3 and 22 months at the time.

headline: The Massacre That Destroyed Tulsa’s ‘Black Wall Street’
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Cemeteries', 'Forensic Science', 'Tulsa Race Riot (1921)']
abstract: In 1921, the city of Tulsa erupted in a spasm of hate and fire that destroyed its prosperous Black district. A century later, excavators are uncovering a “crime scene.”
lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — Incited by a salacious and largely fabricated news story about a young Black man assaulting a white girl, a lynch mob showed up at the Tulsa city jail, where he was being held. A group of African-Americans, many of them soldiers who had returned from fighting the First World War, rushed over to help guard the young man. Fighting broke out, then shooting.

headline: Manchester City Won. Now Brace for the Losses.
abstract: City’s victory will be welcomed by rivals with deep pockets. But the demise of cost-control rules risks destabilizing teams and a sport already shaken by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Manchester City has its answer: the answer it wanted, the answer it was adamant, right from the start, was the only one possible.

headline: Women’s Rights Activists Describe Seoul Mayor’s Alleged Abuse
abstract: A women’s rights activist group in Seoul called for an investigation into abuse allegations against Mayor Park Won-soon, who committed suicide last week.
lead_paragraph: A women’s rights activist group in Seoul called for an investigation into abuse allegations against Mayor Park Won-soon, who committed suicide last week.

headline: Judy Dyble, Singer in Fairport Convention and Beyond, Dies at 71
abstract: Her crystalline soprano drew on folk tradition, but she also embraced psychedelia and progressive rock.
lead_paragraph: Judy Dyble, a singer and songwriter who was in the first recorded lineup of the British folk-rock institution Fairport Convention before going on to an extensive, though interrupted, recording career, died on Sunday in Oxfordshire, England. She was 71.

headline: Soap With a Brisket Back Story
abstract: Mighty Quinn’s Barbeque is repurposing fat from its meat into rustic bars of soap.
lead_paragraph: Making soap basically requires two ingredients: fat and lye. Micha Magid, an owner of Mighty Quinn’s Barbeque, with a number of stores in New York and New Jersey, had a lot of fat in his kitchen. “We would trim the whole briskets before smoking them and were throwing away tons and tons of fat,” he said. “I was looking for a way to repurpose it.” He started making soap with the fat, plus lye, peppermint oil and organic charcoal. “It seemed to be a really good idea now that everyone has to wash their hands all the time,” he said. The blocks of charcoal gray soap are effective, and are sold in its stores and on the company’s website. Mighty Quinn’s is donating 25 percent of sales to No Kid Hungry.

headline: Brexit Border Bureaucracy Looms for Truckers, Pet Owners and Travelers
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: Next year businesses and travelers face mounds of new paperwork (and higher cellphone bills) as Britain builds up frontier controls.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — No more seamless access to medical care. A spike in cellphone bills. And months of preparation if you are bringing the dog.

headline: Bahrain to Execute 2 Shiite Protesters After Years of Desperate Appeals
keywords: ['Shiite Muslims', 'Confessions', 'Political Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Capital Punishment']
abstract: The men were convicted of a bombing that killed a police officer in 2014. They say they were tortured into making a false confession during Bahrain’s escalating crackdown on critics.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Two Bahraini men who say they were tortured into making false confessions were sentenced to death for the fifth time on Monday in what international rights groups called another stain on Bahrain’s record of imprisoning, torturing and executing government critics.

headline: Michael Lewis, Who Forged a New Life After Prison, Dies at 65
abstract: Mr. Lewis counseled newly released inmates on how to adjust to life on the outside, using a simple orange bag to make his point. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: McEnany Plays Down Tensions Between White House and Fauci

lead_paragraph: White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany disputed reports that the Trump administration was sending “opposition research” against Dr. Anthony S. Fauci to news organizations.

headline: ‘Big Friendship,’ by Aminatou Sow and Ann Friedman: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Big Friendship,” by Aminatou Sow and Ann Friedman
lead_paragraph: We’re now a full decade into our friendship. We’ve lived apart for more than twice as long as we lived in the same city. We still see a lot of each other and talk almost daily, although the years of watching TV on the couch or lingering at happy hour every week feel very far away. The truth is that it’s harder for us to fit into each other’s lives than it once was—and we work together.

headline: Jeff Sessions Won’t Say if He’d Back Tommy Tuberville for Senate

lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — Jeff Sessions, the Alabama Republican and former attorney general who is trying to reclaim his old Senate seat, on Monday declined to answer directly whether he would support his opponent, Tommy Tuberville, in the general election in the event that Mr. Sessions does not win Tuesday’s runoff race against him.

headline: Monthly U.S. Budget Deficit Soared to Record $864 Billion in June
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: The shortfall was nearly as large as the entire 2019 deficit as spending on virus-related efforts outpaced revenues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States budget deficit grew to a record $864 billion for June as the federal government pumped huge sums of money into the economy to prop up workers and businesses affected by the coronavirus, the Treasury Department said on Monday, an amount that is expected to grow as a surge in cases portends prolonged economic pain.

abstract: She was ambassador to Denmark after years as a voice against apartheid (sometimes in poetry) alongside her parents, Nelson Mandela and Winnie Madikizela-Mandela.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Zindziswa Mandela, the youngest daughter of Nelson Mandela and Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, who found her own voice as an activist and poet, died in Johannesburg on Monday. She was 59.

headline: Florida Sheriff’s Deputy Is Fired After Pointing Gun at Unarmed Man
abstract: Sergeant Janak Amin, a 21-year veteran of the Hillsborough County Sheriff’s Office, has been charged with aggravated assault with a deadly weapon, the sheriff said.
lead_paragraph: A sergeant with the Hillsborough County Sheriff’s Office in Tampa, Fla., has been fired and charged with assault after he pointed a gun at an unarmed man for refusing to give his name, the sheriff said.

headline: These Are the Deutsche Bank Executives Responsible for Serving Jeffrey Epstein
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Sex Crimes', 'Human Trafficking', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Prostitution']

lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Epstein, the sex criminal and financier, didn’t act alone. Now we know in vivid detail who some of his financial enablers were: executives and bankers at Deutsche Bank.

headline: U.S. Says Most of China’s Claims in South China Sea Are Illegal
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Law of the Sea (UN Convention)', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The announcement by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo portends more American military operations to push back Chinese maritime activity and sanctions on Chinese companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced on Monday that China’s expansive maritime claims across most of the South China Sea were “completely unlawful,” setting up potential military confrontations with Beijing and sanctions against companies as the United States seeks to push back Chinese activity in the region.

headline: 17 States Sue to Block Student Visa Rules
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Visas', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'States (US)']
abstract: A legal battle between universities and the Trump administration over foreign students and online learning escalated on Monday, ahead of a critical federal court hearing.
lead_paragraph: A Trump administration effort to force foreign college students to take in-person classes in the fall or lose their visas has prompted a high-stakes legal battle between the White House and some of America’s top universities, with 17 states and the District of Columbia joining the fray on Monday in a lawsuit that calls the policy “senseless and cruel.”

headline: Want to Abolish the Police? Consider Becoming an Officer Instead
abstract: If more people in law enforcement cared about the things progressives support, we’d all benefit.
lead_paragraph: For the past few years, I’ve taught a seminar on the sociology of the police at Colby College in Maine. My students, mostly progressive, ask me whether there’s anything they can do to help solve some of the serious problems that exist in policing, such as racial inequities in the use of force, the overpolicing of minority neighborhoods and rogue officers who lie to justify arrests. Today, young people all over the country are asking the same question.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: California and its schools roll back reopenings.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles and San Diego Counties said schools would be online-only in the fall, citing a surge in infections that pose too much risk for students and teachers. The unified school districts, with around 825,000 students, are the largest so far in the U.S. to abandon plans for even a partial physical return.

headline: Trump Continues Criticism of Movement to Defund the Police
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The president is embracing law enforcement, a tactic that won him support in the 2016 campaign, while ignoring calls for reform.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Monday assailed a broad movement to defund police departments, invoking the kind of pro-police language that won him support with the law enforcement community in 2016 and ignoring the calls for reform that have helped shape this election.

headline: For Native American Activists, Washington Name Change Was ‘a Long Time Coming’
abstract: The Washington N.F.L. team has long been a target of protests but now that its owner has budged, activists are pushing for other teams to follow suit.
lead_paragraph: Activists have spent decades pressuring professional sports leagues, college programs and high schools to abandon Native American names and imagery for their teams.

headline: Body of Naya Rivera Is Found at California Lake, Sheriff Says
abstract: Ventura County Sheriff Bill Ayub said search teams recovered Ms. Rivera’s body on Monday, almost a week after she was reported missing.
lead_paragraph: Ventura County Sheriff Bill Ayub said search teams recovered Ms. Rivera’s body on Monday, almost a week after she was reported missing.

headline: Headed to the Convention? Not I, More Republicans Are Saying
abstract: “Everybody just assumes no one is going,” said one House member wary of the virus risks. But other delegates dismissed the health threat and said it was an honor to help nominate President Trump.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Trump abruptly cancels Republican Convention in Jacksonville.]

headline: DeVos Abandons a Lifetime of Local Advocacy to Demand Schools Reopen
abstract: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has become the face of the Trump administration’s demands, a stance diametrically opposite to how she has led the department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the nation’s public schools plunged into crisis at the outset of the coronavirus outbreak, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos stuck to the message of decades of conservative education advocacy.

headline: The N.Y.P.D. Has Rejected Reform for Decades. It Can’t Anymore.
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: New York is finally giving its Police Department the scrutiny it deserves.
lead_paragraph: In New York, a 1-year-old boy was fatally shot over the weekend, one of the latest victims in a surge of violence that has rattled an already traumatized city. As of Monday, New York City had had 634 shootings this year, up from 394 at the same time last year, according to Police Department data.

headline: Fauci Back at the White House, a Day After Trump Aides Tried to Undermine Him
abstract: The visit underscored a reality for both the president and his most prominent coronavirus adviser: They are stuck with each other.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A day after President Trump’s press office tried to undermine the reputation of the nation’s top infectious disease expert with an anonymously attributed list of what it said were his misjudgments in the early days of the coronavirus, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci returned to the White House on Monday.

headline: Ted Cruz Was Seen on a Flight Without a Mask. His Office Says He Followed Airline Policy.
abstract: The senator’s office says he wears a mask when traveling and temporarily takes it off to eat or drink.
lead_paragraph: American Airlines said on Monday that it had reached out to Senator Ted Cruz after a widely shared photograph showed him not wearing a mask on one of its flights.

headline: A Reissue of John Cage’s Mushroom Book
abstract: The composer was also a forager who sold his finds to the Four Seasons. Now, you can buy a new edition of his 1972 book.
lead_paragraph: The composer John Cage was also a passionate mycologist. He even sold the fungal fruits of his foraging to the Four Seasons Restaurant in Manhattan. In 1972, he wrote a limited-edition book about mushrooms with Alexander H. Smith and Lois Long. Now the “Mushroom Book,” a reproduction with lithographic illustrations, anecdotes, poetry and even authors’ scribblings, has been reissued in a boxed set with “A Mycological Foray by Cage and others. The collectors edition, limited to 500 copies, also includes a box of postcards with Cage’s mushroom recipes; the regular edition of 4,500 omits the recipe box.

headline: New Seasoned Fonio Pilafs From Pierre Thiam
abstract: The chef, an ambassador for the West African grain, now sells preseasoned instant packs of gluten-free fonio.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Thiam, a native of Senegal, has become the American ambassador for fonio, the versatile West African grain. He’s written a book about it. Now in addition to selling plain fonio, which cooks up like fine couscous, his company, Yolélé, has introduced tasty, efficient fonio pilafs. They are preseasoned with several flavor profiles: Yassa, with onion, lime and chile; Jollof, with tomato and bell pepper; Afro-Funk, with herbs and fermented locust bean; Dakar Curry, with currants; and Greens, with moringa and spinach. Each package, with the addition of some oil and water, makes enough fine-textured light and fluffy grain for four as a main or six as a side dish.

headline: A Rare Honey for Your Table
abstract: This new honey from the Savannah Bee Company is made from the nectar of black sage.
lead_paragraph: Black sage, a spiky shrublike plant native to Southern California and Northern Mexico, flowers only about every three years. So black sage honey is a rare thing for the Savannah Bee Company, which buys it from a beekeeper who only gets three to four yields a decade. The honey is earthy and a bit rustic, with a distinctive spiciness. Drizzle it on grilled peaches.

headline: A Bakery Gets Into the Ice Cream Business
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The Good Batch in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, has opened an ice-cream parlor across the street from its bakery.
lead_paragraph: Anna Gordon’s the Good Batch Bakery has been a staple in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, for several years. In summer it even offered ice cream sandwiches made with its own cookies. On Wednesday Ms. Gordon is opening a scoop shop across the street. In addition to some new flavors like sprinkletown, coffee ganache and caramel brownie swirl (made with her bakery’s brownies), she’s serving ice cream sandwiches, sundaes, cones and cups. There will be free scoops to celebrate the opening from Wednesday through Friday.

headline: Cocktail Veterans Create a Few Canned Drinks
abstract: Social Hour, a new line of canned cocktails from Julie Reiner and Tom Macy, features classics like the gin and tonic and the whiskey mule.
lead_paragraph: A few heavy hitters from the New York cocktail scene have collaborated on a new line of canned cocktails called Social Hour. Julie Reiner and Tom Macy, two of the owners of the Brooklyn cocktail bar Clover Club, are providing the mixological inspiration, while some of the base spirits will come from the New York Distilling Company in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The gin and tonic will use the distiller’s Perry’s Tot Navy Strength Gin and a custom-made tonic water. The whiskey mule will combine the distiller’s Ragtime Rye with a handmade ginger beer. There is also an Italian aperitivo-style Pacific Spritz. Social Hour will be available in New York and New Jersey beginning Aug. 1.

headline: In Some Countries, Normal Life Is Back. Not Here.
abstract: Trump’s incompetence has wrecked us. Where are the calls for him to resign?
lead_paragraph: If you’re lucky enough to live in New Zealand, the coronavirus nightmare has been mostly over since June. After more than two weeks with no new cases, the government lifted almost all restrictions that month. The borders are still shut, but inside the country, normal life returned.

headline: Navy Warship Is Still Ablaze, and Now Tilting to One Side
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'USS Bonhomme Richard (LHD-6) (Ship)', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The U.S.S. Bonhomme Richard in San Diego is listing because of water from the fire hoses, tugboats and helicopters fighting the inferno, which has destroyed the ship’s forward mast.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Navy sailors were continuing on Monday to battle a raging fire on the U.S.S. Bonhomme Richard at a San Diego naval base, one of the worst blazes to ever engulf an American warship outside of combat.

headline: Millions Have Lost Health Insurance in Pandemic-Driven Recession
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs', 'States (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: A new study estimates that more than five million American workers lost their insurance this spring, a number higher than those in any full year of insurance losses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The coronavirus pandemic stripped an estimated 5.4 million American workers of their health insurance between February and May, a stretch in which more adults became uninsured because of job losses than have ever lost coverage in a single year, according to a new analysis.

headline: New York Judge Clears Publication of Trump Tell-All
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Nondisclosure Agreements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In his ruling, Judge Hal B. Greenwald dismissed the argument by the Trump family that a 2001 confidentiality agreement applied to the book, which goes on sale on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A New York judge ruled on Monday that Mary L. Trump, the niece of President Trump, could legally go ahead with the publication of her explosive tell-all memoir about her famous family, ending a whirlwind of last-minute litigation to try to stop the book.

headline: Inside Democrats’ 2020 Plan
abstract: Meet the two Democratic operatives battling President Trump since before he was president.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: A Mayor Committed Suicide. His Accuser Won’t Be Heard.
abstract: Allegations against a prominent liberal mayor are the latest evidence in a series of terrible wrongs against Korean women.
lead_paragraph: An elaborate public funeral was held on Monday in Seoul, South Korea, in honor of the city’s mayor, Park Won-soon, a prominent human rights lawyer and confidant of President Moon Jae-in. Mr. Park was found dead last week, by suicide, hours after a personal assistant in his office filed a claim of sexual abuse and harassment against him.

headline: Tucker Carlson to Take ‘Long-Planned’ Vacation After Writer’s Resignation
abstract: On his Monday evening show, the Fox News host said racist and sexist posts by one of his writers, Blake Neff, were “wrong,” while castigating his detractors as “ghouls.”
lead_paragraph: The Fox News star Tucker Carlson said on Monday evening that he would leave on a vacation, starting immediately, days after a writer on his program, Blake Neff, resigned over racist, sexist and misogynist messages that Mr. Neff published pseudonymously on an online message board.

headline: Speaking on Charity Scandal, Trudeau Adopts a Now-Familiar Tone of Contrition

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Roger J. Stone Jr., the political operative convicted of lying and obstructing an investigation into President Trump’s campaign, denied on Monday night that he withheld incriminating information about the president before receiving clemency keeping him out of prison.

headline: N.Y.C.’s Wave of Gun Violence Continues With 3 Drive-By Shootings
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The attacks in Brooklyn were among the latest in a recent surge that has pushed the number of shootings so far this year well above last year’s figure.
lead_paragraph: Five people were shot in Brooklyn on Monday in what the police described as three drive-by attacks within 20 minutes and about a mile of each other, continuing a wave of gun violence that has gripped New York this summer.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Dirty John’ and ‘The Business of Drugs’
abstract: The second season of “Dirty John,” which follows Dan and Betty Broderick’s unraveling marriage, comes to a close. And a new series on Netflix delves into the international drug trade.
lead_paragraph: DIRTY JOHN: THE BETTY BRODERICK STORY 10 p.m. on USA. Following the success of  its first season, which adapted the hit podcast “Dirty John” for television, this anthology series tracks the very public unraveling of a marriage. It stars Amanda Peet as Betty Broderick, and Christian Slater as her husband, Dan, who seemed to lead an idyllic life in Southern California in the ’80s until Dan, a successful medical-malpractice lawyer, hired a new legal assistant named Linda Kolkena (Rachel Keller). Dan and Betty’s marriage spats and divorce played out in La Jolla for more than five years, until Betty shot and killed Dan and Linda, who had married, while they slept. The season finale wraps up Betty’s case, which, as The New York Times reported in 1991, “divided this normally placid city and has drawn attention to the issue of domestic psychological abuse.”

headline: Jimmy Fallon Predicts Trump Will Say He Was the First to Wear a Mask
abstract: After the president finally wore a face mask in public, the “Tonight Show” host called it “a really smart move — if today were March 13th.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: As Europe’s Economies Reopen, Consumers Go on a Spending Spree
abstract: Supported by government furlough programs, people freed from lockdowns are opening their wallets at a record pace. The virus will determine how long that lasts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Clémentine Sebert buzzed through an Ikea furniture store during her lunch break, filling her cart with decorative cushions, a new nightstand, lamps and a small rug. After being cooped up for two months during France’s coronavirus quarantine, she was back to work at the firm where she is a legal counselor — and ready to spend.

headline: Grant Imahara, Engineer Who Co-Hosted ‘MythBusters,’ Dies at 49
abstract: Mr. Imahara also worked behind the scenes on the “Matrix” sequels, among other films, and operated the robot R2-D2 in the “Star Wars” prequels.
lead_paragraph: Grant Imahara, an electrical engineer who co-hosted the pop science show “MythBusters” on the Discovery Channel and operated robots in the “Star Wars” prequels and other major Hollywood films, has died. He was 49.

headline: After Months of Debate, England Requires Face Masks for Shoppers
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: Many parts of Europe and the United States already require masks in stores, but in Britain the idea has come up against the twin fears of appearing either perturbed or ridiculous.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britons, a people famously averse to seeming ruffled in times of distress, have taken slowly, if at all, to face masks during the coronavirus pandemic. Jim Williams says people in his home city, Newcastle, have even yelled at him and shot him angry looks when he wore one.

headline: How to Mend a Pair of Jeans
abstract: If threads start fraying, add stitching before the fabric tears. Patching should be your last resort.
lead_paragraph: “Cut a patch of denim bigger than your hole,” says Atsushi Futatsuya, 36, a sewing teacher who lives in Lewisburg, Pa. He grew up in Japan, a descendant of many generations of experts in a kind of decorative needlework called sashiko. Wives of rural, working-class farmers and fishermen developed the stitching technique as early as the 1600s as a means to reinforce and mend their clothing. “The idea is that one jacket would be passed down three generations or more,” Futatsuya says. Different regions developed dozens of patterns, of which Futatsuya knows more than 100; his two favorites are asanoha (six-pointed stars) and shippo (overlapping circles). Since 2017, he has spent hundreds of hours covering jeans he owns in stitched patterns to make them stronger. If, after wearing, he notices threads fraying, he’ll add stitching before the fabric tears. “Patching should be your last resort,” he says.

headline: The Housing Boom and Bust, Seen From the Front Lines

headline: New & Noteworthy, From French Pancakes to a Bipartisan Road Trip
abstract: A selection of recent books of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: SCORPIONFISH, by Natalie Bakopoulos. (Tin House, paper, $16.95.) Across a balcony in Athens, a grounded sea captain and a grieving academic spend summer nights sharing beers and stories of heartbreak in Bakopoulos’s elegant, atmospheric second novel.

headline: I Didn’t Mean to Adopt a Dozen Pet Snails
abstract: They aren’t very good companions. But the lockdowns forced us to bond.
lead_paragraph: If parcels arrived in the early weeks of the lockdown, the wariness with which we collected them off the doorstep — fingertips tented, sweat on brow — arose not only out of a fear of surfaces teeming with microbes, but because their contents belonged to a future we would not inhabit. These deliveries, sundry things we had ordered, were possessions from a different stream of time: one in which my partner, a playwright, would be staging a new show in a London festival. But now the play was canceled, the festival too, and with it the pell-mell that typically attends last rehearsals.

headline: The Pandemic Could Get Much, Much Worse. We Must Act Now.
abstract: A comprehensive shutdown may be required in much of the country.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: I Don’t Want to Spread Covid-19. Can I Sit Out the Protests?
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on balancing political progress and public health, and more.
lead_paragraph: In normal times, I would feel an obligation to take part in the recent protests against police brutality. I’m worried, however, that these gatherings could lead to a coronavirus outbreak. Black Americans are suffering from Covid-19 at a disproportionately high rate — I don’t want to endanger the very lives that this movement is seeking to protect. I have done what I can to speak out in other ways, from signing petitions to making donations and even making a Black Lives Matter sign and carrying it for a solo march around my neighborhood (which definitely attracted a lot of laughter and scorn). I feel bad for not getting out there and standing up for what’s right. Is it ethical to support these protests only from a distance? Name Withheld

headline: Why We’re Losing the Battle With Covid-19
abstract: The escalating crisis in Texas shows how the chronic underfunding of public health has put America on track for the worst coronavirus response in the developed world.

headline: Scientists Find an Earthquake’s Toll in an Organism’s DNA
abstract: Along a coastline in New Zealand, kelp seems to contain a genetic record of the planet’s geological upheaval.
lead_paragraph: Waving fronds of seaweed form a peaceful underwater scene, with dappled sunlight pouring down. Hidden in the organisms’ genes, however, may be evidence of the planet’s past geological violence.

headline: 10 Theses About Cancel Culture
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: What we talk about when we talk about “cancellation.”
lead_paragraph: Cancel culture is destroying liberalism. No, cancel culture doesn’t exist. No, it has always existed; remember when Brutus and Cassius canceled Julius Caesar? No, it exists but it’s just a bunch of rich entitled celebrities complaining that people can finally talk back to them on Twitter. No, it doesn’t exist except when it’s good and the canceled deserve it. Actually, it does exist, but — well, look, I can’t explain it to you until you’ve read at least four open letters on the subject.

headline: Flour and Toilet Paper Are Back at N.Y. Supermarkets, but There’s a Catch
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stockpiling', 'Meat', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Shoppers are accustomed to enjoying an extraordinary variety of choices, but the pandemic has changed that.
lead_paragraph: Shoppers no longer stare at aisles devoid of toilet paper. Pasta, in many shapes and sizes, is back in abundance. And eager home bakers can restart their mixers and ovens now that flour and yeast have finally reappeared.

headline: She Went to Prison for Killing Her Husband. The Pandemic Set Her Free.
abstract: Foroozan was one of nearly 20 women held in an Afghan women’s prison for murdering her spouse after years of abuse. “Thanks to coronavirus, I am given a second chance to live.”
lead_paragraph: On a Thursday morning in May, three days after Foroozan was freed from prison, she left her mother’s house to go to the market. It was the first time in six years that she had set foot on the streets of Herat, the capital city of a province of the same name in western Afghanistan. As she made her way through crowds of men wearing masks, she became lightheaded, as if “the world was revolving around her head.” It was nothing like how she had imagined it. “When I was in prison, I thought the outside world is heaven and those who are released, they’re on their way to heaven,” she said. But now, finally experiencing it for herself, she found it alienating and even frightening. “I thought everyone was staring at me,” she said. “Pointing their fingers toward me while whispering, as if they knew I was a prisoner, but of course it was all in my head.”

headline: This Year Will End Eventually. Document It While You Can.

headline: Self-Care for Black Journalists
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'News and News Media', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: In a news cycle filled with tragedy, much of it disproportionately affecting people of color, Black reporters and editors are reimagining coping strategies.
lead_paragraph: Heat flushed Natelegé Whaley’s body as she wrote a news article about the shooting by police that killed Breonna Taylor. Ms. Whaley, a journalist, figured she was tired. Then came the mental fog, digestive issues and blurred vision. When these seemingly separate issues snowballed into a panic attack and a trip to the emergency room in late May, Ms. Whaley, 31, who lives in Brooklyn, connected the dots.

headline: After a Trail of Tears, Justice for ‘Indian Country’
abstract: From my elders, I learned that justice is sometimes seven generations away or more — and inevitable.
lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — It was an ordinary July morning in the Arts District of the Muscogee Creek Nation territory here. Already hot and set to get hotter. I was inside my house fooling with some lyrics when my husband burst in. “We won!” he announced. The cellphone in his hand carried the breaking news. “We won the McGirt v. Oklahoma decision!”

headline: ‘Gotham Refuses to Get Scared’: In 1918, Theaters Stayed Open
abstract: With an influenza pandemic and a war on, New York’s health commissioner took an unorthodox stand, declining to shutter public entertainment.
lead_paragraph: War plays were big on Broadway in the fall of 1918. With the nation sending soldiers to Europe to fight in World War I, spectacles like the “Ziegfeld Follies” wrapped themselves in patriotism.

headline: G.A.O.: Trump Boosts Deregulation by Undervaluing Cost of Climate Change

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal report released on Tuesday found the Trump administration set a rock-bottom price on the damages done by greenhouse gas emissions, enabling the government to justify the costs of repealing or weakening dozens of climate change regulations.

headline: Black Behind the Wheel
abstract: On a road trip to Detroit, reflections on the car as a symbol of aspiration and adventure. But if you’re Black in America, that lovely machine isn’t always a refuge.
lead_paragraph: Driving across Woodward Avenue in Detroit a few weeks ago amid a spirited George Floyd demonstration — this one a 30-mile motorcade into the suburbs, billed as the “I Have a Dream Protest Cruise” — my mind drifted strangely to an empty two-lane highway in Arkansas near the Texas border. The memory was jarring, sweeping me away from this raucous caravan — honking horns, Black-power fists thrust from car windows, the whir of sirens — back to my youth in the spring of 1986.

headline: Famous Paintings Go on Show, Without a Canvas in Sight
abstract: The French company behind flashy digital shows of Klimt, Klee, van Gogh and others is bringing fine art to a mass audience. And it’s turning a profit.
lead_paragraph: BORDEAUX, France — On the walls inside of a former World War II submarine base, a huge Gustav Klimt tree expands its branches and a gold Paul Klee fish floats by. The bright, changing colors of these projections are reflected by four saltwater pools. Visitors walk along gangways, watching the floor-to-ceiling digital animations based on famous works by Klimt, Klee and Egon Schiele.

headline: Britain’s economic recovery disappointed in May as businesses started to reopen.
abstract: May was supposed to be the first month of Britain’s economic recovery, when some restrictions on business activity were eased after the near-total lockdown of April. Some economists predicted the economy would grow by 5.5 percent after contracting by nearly 7 percent in March and a further 20 percent in April. But the data announced Tuesday was greeted as a disappointment, showing just a 1.8 percent increase from the month before.
lead_paragraph: May was supposed to be the first month of Britain’s economic recovery, when some restrictions on business activity were eased after the near-total lockdown of April. Some economists predicted the economy would grow by 5.5 percent after contracting by nearly 7 percent in March and a further 20 percent in April. But the data announced Tuesday was greeted as a disappointment, showing just a 1.8 percent increase from the month before.

headline: U.K. Bars Huawei for 5G as Tech Battle Between China and the West Escalates
keywords: ['5G (Wireless Communications)', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense']
abstract: Banning the use of the Chinese tech giant’s equipment in high-speed wireless infrastructure is a major reversal by Prime Minister Boris Johnson — and a big victory for the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain announced on Tuesday that it would ban equipment from the Chinese technology giant Huawei from the country’s high-speed wireless network, a victory for the Trump administration that escalates the battle between Western powers and China over critical technology.

headline: He Changed His Country’s Name. Will North Macedonia Punish Him?
abstract: Zoran Zaev led North Macedonia into NATO and toward the European Union by altering its name. That could cost him in an election on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: SKOPJE, North Macedonia — Zoran Zaev, the front-runner in a general election on Wednesday in North Macedonia, got more done during his 30 months as prime minister than most Macedonian politicians did in the nearly 30 years since the country won independence from Yugoslavia.

headline: Review: Peacock’s ‘Brave New World’ Is Neither Brave Nor New
abstract: This adaptation of Aldous Huxley’s classic novel, inaugurating the NBCUniversal streaming service, is generic and tame (despite the orgies).
lead_paragraph: Aldous Huxley’s 1932 novel “Brave New World” famously imagined a future society in which people were enslaved to pleasure. The future’s diversions were so absorbing that they commanded attention over everything else.

headline: Alabama Votes for Tommy Tuberville, and Democrats Name a Challenger in Maine
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A former college football coach defeated Jeff Sessions in a Republican runoff in Alabama, and Sara Gideon will challenge Susan Collins for the Senate in Maine. Key races also took place in Texas.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow the latest Biden vs Trump 2020 live elections briefing here.

headline: Newsom Rolls Back Reopening in California
abstract: Tuesday: The governor announced that many businesses must close once again. Also: Los Angeles and San Diego schools will be online-only in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Wells Fargo reports first quarterly loss in more than a decade.
abstract: Wells Fargo on Tuesday reported its first quarterly loss since 2008, losing $2.4 billion as the pandemic’s economic shocks ravaged nearly every line of its business.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo on Tuesday reported its first quarterly loss since 2008, losing $2.4 billion as the pandemic’s economic shocks ravaged nearly every line of its business.

headline: Citigroup reports a 73 percent drop in quarterly profit.
abstract: Citigroup said Tuesday that its quarterly profit fell 73 percent as it set aside $5.6 billion to cover future loan losses triggered by the widespread unemployment caused by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup said Tuesday that its quarterly profit fell 73 percent as it set aside $5.6 billion to cover future loan losses triggered by the widespread unemployment caused by the pandemic.

headline: The Black Photographer Making History at Vanity Fair
abstract: Viola Davis appears on the cover of this month’s issue, the first by a Black photographer, in an image meant to be a protest.
lead_paragraph: Until about two weeks ago, Dario Calmese didn’t know he was the first Black photographer to shoot the cover of Vanity Fair. But he had a suspicion, so he asked the editors, who went digging.

headline: Going ‘Deep Green,’ Office Buildings Give Back to the Planet
keywords: ['Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Sustainable Living', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: As technology costs have declined, more developers are creating buildings that can benefit the Earth by tackling pollution and save money by producing their own power.
lead_paragraph: For a couple of decades, many in the real estate industry have been trying to make buildings “green,” replacing conventionally made materials with sustainable ones and installing energy-efficient systems. Buildings have a heavy environmental footprint, so the upshot of all this tinkering has been structures that are less harmful to the planet.

headline: Caught in ‘Ideological Spiral,’ U.S. and China Drift Toward Cold War
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Relations are in free fall. Lines are being drawn. As the two superpowers clash over technology, territory and clout, a new geopolitical era is dawning.
lead_paragraph: One by one, the United States has hit at the core tenets of Xi Jinping’s vision for a rising China ready to assume the mantle of superpower.

headline: Government Carries Out First Federal Execution in 17 Years
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hours after a 5-to-4 vote by the Supreme Court, Daniel Lewis Lee was put to death by lethal injection in Terre Haute, Ind., for his role in the 1996 murder of a family of three.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours after the Supreme Court rejected a last-minute legal challenge on a 5-to-4 vote, the Justice Department put a man to death for his role in the 1996 murder of a family of three, the first federal execution in more than 17 years.

headline: Automakers Are Making Cars, but Virus Surge Puts That at Risk
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Organized Labor', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Disease Rates']
abstract: Some workers are calling on the industry to shut down plants in states where virus cases have increased sharply in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: Automakers are back to building cars and trucks at full speed — at least for now. But as coronavirus cases rise across much of the country, it may become difficult for the companies to keep at it.

headline: Hannibal Buress Meets the Moment
abstract: In ways large and small, the stand-up’s new special, released free on YouTube, taps into the national mood, once again showing what a talent he is.
lead_paragraph: In his dynamite, accidentally topical new special “Miami Nights,” released for free on YouTube over the July Fourth weekend, Hannibal Buress describes himself as “medium famous,” which he says translates to: “I constantly talk people out of recognizing me.”

headline: Andy Samberg Makes Each Day Count With Thundercat and ‘Not Too Much’ Bourbon
abstract: The star of “Palm Springs,” on Hulu and at drive-in theaters, also puts A Tribe Called Quest and “Queer Eye” on his list of essentials.
lead_paragraph: As a Hollywood multihyphenate, Andy Samberg reads — and rejects — a lot of scripts. But about 30 pages into “Palm Springs,” he started thinking that the answer was going to be a rare yes.

headline: After 43 Years, Mossy Kilcher’s Folk Songs for Alaska Get a Second Life
abstract: Observing the wilderness of her home state has always been her passion. But the musician, who is Jewel’s aunt, is also ready to return to one of her original loves.
lead_paragraph: In her first memory, Mossy Kilcher, then 3 years old, is standing on a windswept Alaskan beach in 1945, holding her father’s hand as thundering waves crash at their feet. Surrounded by rugged cliffs and the seemingly endless expanse of Kachemak Bay, she realizes for the first time that any of this can kill her.

headline: Disabled Do-It-Yourselfers Lead Way to Technology Gains
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Innovation', 'Mobile Applications', 'Dyslexia', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voice and Speech', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wheelchairs', 'Blindness', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Prostheses', 'Smartphones']
abstract: So long to overhyped innovations. Hello to tech that embeds accessibility into everyday devices.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 3: On ‘NASA Names Headquarters After Its First Black Female Engineer, Mary Jackson’
abstract: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Chandini, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
lead_paragraph: Thank you to the more than 890 teenagers who participated in the third week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest, and congratulations to Chandini, our winner, as well as to our many runners-up and honorable mentions.

headline: Virgin Atlantic secures a $1.5 billion private rescue deal.
abstract: Richard Branson has reached a 1.2 billion pound ($1.5 billion) deal with two credit-card payment processing companies and an American hedge fund to rescue Virgin Atlantic from financial collapse after the British government rejected the airline’s request for a loan.
lead_paragraph: Richard Branson has reached a 1.2 billion pound ($1.5 billion) deal with two credit-card payment processing companies and an American hedge fund to rescue Virgin Atlantic from financial collapse after the British government rejected the airline’s request for a loan.

headline: Massachusetts Sues Uber and Lyft Over the Status of Drivers
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A lawsuit by the state’s attorney general adds to pressure on the companies to consider their drivers full employees.
lead_paragraph: Uber and Lyft should treat their drivers in Massachusetts as employees with the right to receive benefits, instead of misclassifying them as independent contractors, the state’s attorney general said in a lawsuit filed against the ride-hailing companies.

headline: As Training Camps Near, N.F.L. and Players Debate Protocols
abstract: The two sides are working to resolve questions about testing, opting out and revenue loss before the scheduled start of training camps in two weeks.
lead_paragraph: As sports leagues rushed to delay or cancel events in March, the N.F.L. made a bold promise to start its season on time and unaltered. Since then, the league has held most of its normal activities, including free agency, the draft and off-season workouts, on time, though remotely rather than in person.

headline: The Fight Over the Future of the Democratic Party
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
