lead_paragraph: THE PEOPLE, NOA Brief History of Anti-PopulismBy Thomas FrankECONOMIC DIGNITYBy Gene Sperling

headline: A New To-Go Window From an Uptown Fixture
abstract: Takeout from Butterfield Market, a pop-up series by Black chefs, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: The new Butterfield Market, a branch of the 105-year-old store on Lexington Avenue, is moving into the spacious storefront once occupied by Dean & DeLuca, but it won’t be ready until the fall. Evan Obsatz, one of the  owners (along with his sister, Joelle, and his father, Alan), said the neighborhood had been quiet: “I hope the Upper East Side gets busier in September.” For now, he’s offering a taste of the store’s specialty, frozen yogurt, from a window on the 85th Street side, near Madison Avenue. But the window is not just about frozen yogurt. Sandwiches, cold soups and composed salads like salmon with potatoes, haricots verts, tomatoes and arugula, are some of the options sold to take away. There are benches along the Madison Avenue side of the store, whose name recalls its telephone exchange, dating back to the days when such things existed. Remember the movie “Butterfield 8”? (Opens Wednesday)

headline: This Pickle Is a Cake
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Cakes', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Social Media', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: Welcome to the viral world of hyper-realistic cake slicing videos.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, social media has been flooded with videos of knives slicing into ordinary objects only to reveal that they are actually made of cake.

headline: Biden Announces $2 Trillion Climate Plan
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: Joe Biden’s plan connects tackling climate change with the economic recovery from the coronavirus crisis, while also addressing racism. The proposal drew praise from his onetime critics.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced on Tuesday a new plan to spend $2 trillion over four years to significantly escalate the use of clean energy in the transportation, electricity and building sectors, part of a suite of sweeping proposals designed to create economic opportunities and strengthen infrastructure while also tackling climate change.

headline: C.D.C. Employees Accuse Agency of ‘Toxic Culture of Racial Aggressions’
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Medicine and Health', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Government Employees']
abstract: More than 1,000 employees signed a letter criticizing the agency for “scant progress in addressing the very real challenges Black employees experience.”
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 employees of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have signed a letter calling for the agency to address “a pervasive and toxic culture of racial aggressions, bullying and marginalization” against Black employees.

headline: Meet This Popular Essential Worker. And Give Her a Scratch Behind the Ear.
abstract: Children in the hospital lost many of their activities during Covid-19. More than ever, they rely on the contact and comfort of therapy dogs.
lead_paragraph: In early March, Everett Gray’s transplanted heart began to fail. A couple months shy of the five-year anniversary of receiving his “miracle heart,” the 8-year-old was admitted to the cardiac I.C.U. at the Children’s Healthcare of Atlanta at Egleston, as his immune system battled with the heart that saved his life as a toddler.

headline: Frieze’s London Fairs Are Art World’s Latest Cancellations
abstract: The premiere fairs are off, and a gallery-based Frieze Week looks doubtful because of the continued challenges of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This October’s Frieze London and Frieze Masters art fairs, the double-headed centerpiece of the British capital’s busiest art market week, have been canceled “in light of continued unprecedented challenges regarding Covid-19 (coronavirus),” the organizers said Tuesday.

headline: Grappling With How to Reopen Schools Safely
abstract: Readers suggest steps to minimize the risks, including prioritizing younger grades and making use of unused commercial spaces.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: California Man Is Accused of Driving Into a Group of Black People
abstract: Prosecutors have accused Dennis Wyman of a hate crime, saying he hit an off-duty security guard with his car in Torrance, Calif., last month.
lead_paragraph: A man who the authorities say drove into a group of Black people at a Southern California hotel, injuring one person, has been accused of a hate crime, prosecutors said on Monday.

headline: ‘Hero’ Pay Raises Disappear for Many Essential Workers
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Several retailers have ended the pay raises and bonuses they gave to employees as an appreciation for their courage and commitment in showing up to work during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Many retailers across the United States have quietly stopped providing their workers with the pay raises they had dispensed at the start of the pandemic, despite surging virus numbers in many states.

headline: What to Keep in Mind on Election Day: Times Reporters on the 2020 Homestretch
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: We can’t predict the future, but members of our politics team  offer analysis of polling, early voting and everything else about this unprecedented election season.

headline: Republicans Said to Be Planning to Move Some Convention Events Outdoors
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Masks', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: With the coronavirus surging in Florida, officials are examining outdoor venues near the arena in Jacksonville, but it remains uncertain how many people will be allowed to attend.
lead_paragraph: With coronavirus cases surging in Florida, Republicans are planning to move the three nights of their national convention from an indoor arena to an outdoor venue in Jacksonville, but it’s still unclear how many people will be allowed to attend the events, people familiar with the discussions said Tuesday.

headline: How Facebook Handles Climate Disinformation
abstract: Critics say a company policy that exempts opinion articles from fact-checking amounts to a huge loophole for climate change deniers.
lead_paragraph: As Covid-19 spread across the globe early this year, Facebook went into action to combat potentially dangerous disinformation on its site. The company labeled and suppressed misleading content, removed disinformation and directed users to reputable sources, including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention website.

headline: You’d Rather Get a Coronavirus Vaccine Through Your Nose
abstract: Some experts say a vaccine puffed in the nose would be better at protecting people from infection. But nasal vaccines won’t be ready right away.
lead_paragraph: Of the 150-plus coronavirus vaccines in development around the world, the lion’s share will rely on a needle prick to make their way into the body.

headline: ‘These Are the Most Critical Investments,’ Biden Says of Climate Plan

lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. unveiled his $2 trillion climate plan for reducing fossil fuel use across the U.S. and creating jobs.

headline: Delle Donne’s Opt-Out Request Is Denied

lead_paragraph: Elena Delle Donne, the W.N.B.A.’s reigning most valuable player, said she had been denied a medical waiver for the league’s abbreviated season, which begins July 25.

headline: Three Marines, Now Focus of Russian Bounties Investigation, Show the Costs of an Endless War
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The U.S. mission in Afghanistan is now described as training, advising and assisting Afghan troops. But American forces are still patrolling areas that are as deadly as they were in 2001.
lead_paragraph: The American military convoy was almost back to Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan when a vehicle, laden with explosives, careened into it and detonated.

headline: Billboard Tweaks, but Doesn’t Repeal, a Chart Rule Over Album ‘Bundles’
abstract: The main arbiter of commercial popularity in music has struggled to adapt its methods to reflect the way listeners behave today without alienating major artists and labels.
lead_paragraph: This spring, the country singer Kenny Chesney narrowly beat the typically chart-dominating rapper Drake to a Billboard No. 1 debut using a marketing tactic that has been increasingly common in recent years — the ticket bundle, which includes an artist’s new album as a redeemable bonus when fans pony up to see them in concert.

headline: Judge, Expressing Skepticism, Upends $25 Million Harvey Weinstein Settlement
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']

lead_paragraph: Expressing deep skepticism, a federal judge on Tuesday upended a $25 million proposed civil settlement between Harvey Weinstein, his former film company, and dozens of women who have accused him of sexual harassment and abuse.

headline: Aide Posts Cartoon Mocking Fauci as White House Denies Undermining Him
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Social Media', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']

headline: How to Fight Health ‘Cures’ Online
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Junk health information that preys on people’s fears spreads online. Here’s how we can stamp it out.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Seeing Native Americans Nowhere, and Everywhere
abstract: As Washington’s professional football team retires a team name, a curator at the National Museum of the American Indian talks about our attachment to Native American imagery.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the N.F.L. team in Washington announced that it would be retiring the name “Redskins” and its feather-topped Indian head logo, abruptly reversing its staunch defense of a name long considered as a racial slur.

headline: ‘Dateline-Saigon’ Review: Challenging the Official Story
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Vietnam War', 'News and News Media']
abstract: This documentary focuses on five reporters who covered the early years of the Vietnam War.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Dateline-Saigon” reconstructs the early rumblings of the Vietnam War — mainly from 1961 through 1964 — through the eyes of five print reporters who were on assignment in Saigon.

headline: Thereza de Orléans e Bragança, Brazilian Society Doyenne, Dies at 91
abstract: Once called “the best dressed woman in Rio de Janeiro” by Life magazine, she was an “old money” style-setter in the 1950s and ’60s before marrying into Brazilian royalty.
lead_paragraph: Thereza de Orléans e Bragança, an elegant society figure in Rio de Janeiro who gained a measure of international celebrity in the 1950s and ’60s before transforming herself into a princess by marrying into Brazil’s royal family, died on June 27 in Rio. She was 91.

headline: Former V.A. Nursing Assistant Pleads Guilty in Deaths of 7 Patients
abstract: Prosecutors said Reta Mays, who worked at a hospital in West Virginia, administered fatal doses of insulin to veterans.
lead_paragraph: A former nursing assistant at a Department of Veterans Affairs hospital in West Virginia pleaded guilty on Tuesday to second-degree murder in the deaths of seven patients.

headline: The Flu May Linger in the Air, Just Like the Coronavirus
abstract: As scientists race to understand how coronavirus aerosols may spread indoors, a new study on influenza offers some clues.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus is not the flu. But the two viruses have something crucial in common: Both have been described as spreading primarily through close contact with symptomatic people or the surfaces they’ve touched.

headline: Baby Was Infected With Coronavirus in Womb, Study Reports
abstract: Researchers said the case strongly suggests that Covid-19 can be transmitted in utero. Both the mother and baby have recovered.
lead_paragraph: Researchers on Tuesday reported strong evidence that the coronavirus can be transmitted from a pregnant woman to a fetus.

headline: Why Alabama’s Senate Race Is the Most Negative in the Country
abstract: Neither candidate has aired a positive ad since February in a campaign where both candidates are trying to appeal to the brand of politics popularized by President Trump.
lead_paragraph: One candidate is “weak,” an “embarrassment,” a “Washington insider” and “not man enough.”

headline: Andrew Cuomo Ascends to the Mountaintop With His Pandemic Poster
abstract: The retro political artwork on “New York Tough” is peak Cuomo, summing up the state’s battle against the coronavirus. But is it art?
lead_paragraph: Mao Zedong wrote poetry. Bill Clinton played saxophone. Winston Churchill and George W. Bush both turned to painting. For some politicians, only art can calm the passions after a long day — and Gov. Andrew Cuomo, now steering New York to a cautious reopening after the deaths of 32,000 citizens, has lately taken solace in the discipline of graphic design.

headline: Make Your Own Printer’s Hat
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Hats and Caps', 'Content Type: Service', 'Newspapers', 'Handicrafts']
abstract: All the news that’s fit to cover your cranium.
lead_paragraph: The pressman’s hat, also known as the printer’s hat, was designed to protect its wearer from ink and grease splatters on the job — all of that 19th-century machinery could get messy — and was still commonly used until the 1990s.

headline: The Specter of Caste in Silicon Valley
keywords: ['Caste Systems', 'Indian-Americans', 'Discrimination', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Indian immigrants from Dalit backgrounds are rising up against caste discrimination at their workplaces in the United States.
lead_paragraph: On June 30, California’s Department of Fair Employment and Housing regulators sued Cisco Systems Inc., for discrimination. The cause was not, like most workplace discrimination lawsuits, based on race, gender, age or sexual orientation. It was based on caste.

headline: Turkey’s Islamist Dream Finally Becomes a Reality
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government', 'Russian Orthodox Church', 'Museums', 'Ottoman Empire']
abstract: The Hagia Sophia has been designated as a mosque again, its status as a museum viewed for decades as a seal on the country’s spirit.
lead_paragraph: IZMIR, Turkey — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Friday issued a decree ordering the Hagia Sophia, a majestic 65,000-square-foot stone structure from the sixth century in Istanbul, to be opened for Muslim prayers. The same day, a top Turkish court had revoked the 1934 decree by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of the Turkish republic, which had turned it into a museum.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We Gave Up, but Her Hair Didn’t’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: The driving rain hit her train window and streamed two rows back across mine. The depth of her grief was impossible to contain within six feet of social distance. It spilled over. Too on edge to listen to music, I overheard her story unfold through phone calls as we crossed Connecticut: Early that morning, heart attack, her father won’t walk her down the aisle. I bore silent, masked witness to the heaviest moment of her life. On Amtrak 2167, I absorbed an ounce of her pain. Now, I will carry it for her, a stranger’s burden in a strange world. — Hannah Sands

headline: The ‘Sex Talk’ Is Actually a Series of Talks
abstract: Several psychologists and sexual health experts offer ways to make conversations about sex informative and comfortable for children and parents.
lead_paragraph: Like many parents, I had hoped to delay discussing sex with my young sons as long as possible. They would ask me where babies came from on some vague day in the future, I imagined, when they were mature and I had a knowledgeable, profound answer at the ready.

headline: Ghislaine Maxwell Is Denied Bail by Judge Who Calls Her a Flight Risk
abstract: The longtime associate of Jeffrey Epstein has been charged with helping him recruit, groom and ultimately sexually abuse girls as young as 14.
lead_paragraph: Ghislaine Maxwell, the longtime associate of Jeffrey Epstein who has been charged with helping him recruit, groom and ultimately sexually abuse girls as young as 14, was denied bail on Tuesday by a judge who said she posed a high risk of fleeing before her trial.

headline: From Rep. Carolyn Maloney: Please Fill Out the Census

headline: Banks Stockpile Billions as They Prepare for Things to Get Worse
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Company Reports', 'United States Economy', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo said that as long as the economy behaved according to their forecasts, they were braced for more pandemic-induced pain.
lead_paragraph: Three of the nation’s biggest banks revealed Tuesday that they had set aside billions of dollars to cover potential losses on loans, signaling that they don’t expect consumers and corporations to be able to pay their debts in the coming months as the pandemic continues to gut employment and commerce.

headline: Tom Bergeron Is Out as ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Host After 15 Years
abstract: The longtime host and his co-host, Erin Andrews, were let go by ABC, which said it had plans to take the show in a new direction.
lead_paragraph: After spending nearly a quarter of his life as the host of “Dancing With the Stars,” Tom Bergeron, the 65-year-old host of the one-time ABC ratings juggernaut, has been dropped from the show, he announced on Twitter on Monday evening.

headline: Bari Weiss Resigns From New York Times Opinion Post

lead_paragraph: Bari Weiss, a writer and editor for the opinion department of The New York Times, has resigned from the paper, citing “bullying by colleagues” and an “illiberal environment.”

headline: A Media Critic Focuses on the Crisis in Local News
abstract: Margaret Sullivan recalls her years as public editor of The New York Times and her time as the first woman to lead The Buffalo News.
lead_paragraph: Before she became a media columnist, Margaret Sullivan saw the crisis in the American newspaper industry from within.

headline: Strains Show in Russia’s Make-Believe Politics
abstract: The nationalist Vladimir Zhirinovsky has been forced to disavow protests over the arrest of a governor from his own party, underscoring growing domestic volatility.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, Russia’s septuagenarian nationalist firebrand, long functioned as a safety valve for public discontent, corralling protest votes but then supporting President Vladimir V. Putin at key junctures.

headline: Ireland Has a New Coronavirus Fear: Americans Who Flout Quarantine
abstract: The government is under fire for not enforcing the rule that people arriving self-isolate for 14 days. With the pandemic still raging in the United States, concern has focused on Americans.
lead_paragraph: Janet Cavanagh, whose electric bike tour company offers a guided glimpse of western Ireland’s windswept landscape, saw her business come to a swift halt — along with nearly everything else — as the coronavirus pandemic forced the country into lockdown.

headline: Radio Host Loses Her Show Over English-Only Rant
abstract: The host, Dianna Ploss, filmed herself telling landscape workers to speak English. She later said she considered the criticism of her remarks “a badge of honor.”
lead_paragraph: A New Hampshire radio station has severed ties with a conservative radio host who berated landscape workers for speaking Spanish in a widely shared video.

headline: U.S. Rescinds Plan to Strip Visas From International Students in Online Classes
keywords: ['Foreign Students (in US)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'E-Learning', 'Visas']
abstract: The Trump administration said it would no longer require foreign students to attend in-person classes during the coronavirus pandemic in order to remain in the country.
lead_paragraph: In a rare and swift immigration policy reversal, the Trump administration on Tuesday bowed to snowballing opposition from universities, Silicon Valley and 20 states and abandoned a plan to strip international college students of their visas if they did not attend at least some classes in person.

headline: For a New Series, Black Artists in Dance Tell Their Stories
abstract: This week’s standout livestreams in dance: revisiting “Relations” and early Trisha Brown, and working out with Viva Soudan.
lead_paragraph: In the absence of live dance performances, interviews with artists in the field, presented online, have become a way to stay connected until it’s safe to gather again. A new series in that spirit, Black Dance Stories, favors storytelling over interviewing, while giving artists a chance to meet and chat the way they might have in a theater lobby.

headline: German Court Says Tesla Self-Driving Claims Are Misleading
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A ruling by a state court contradicts Elon Musk’s bullish view of autonomous driving technology.

headline: Global Methane Emissions Reach a Record High
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Research', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Methane', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas']

headline: University of Texas Won’t Drop Song With Racist History
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Names, Organizational', 'Discrimination']
abstract: “The Eyes of Texas,” once sung at minstrel shows, will remain a campus anthem at the University of Texas at Austin, the school announced on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The University of Texas at Austin said it would rename a building named for a racist professor, erect a statue of the school’s first Black football player and commission a monument to its first Black undergraduates. What’s not changing? “The Eyes of Texas,” a campus anthem with minstrel roots that student-athletes want abolished.

headline: Egyptian Dissident Battles Extradition in Spanish Court
abstract: Mohamed Ali made videos critical of Egypt’s government, touching off protests. Now he is a target of that government, as President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt pushes to silence critics abroad.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — An Egyptian dissident whose online videos ignited a flurry of rare antigovernment protests last year is fighting against extradition from Spain, as President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt campaigns to silence his most vocal critics abroad.

headline: Tiger Woods Returns, Without Roars
abstract: After a five-month PGA Tour layoff, Woods will try to adjust to competing without his usual throng of spectators at the Memorial Tournament this weekend. “It’s just a silent and different world.”
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — Tuesday morning, in his first appearance at a PGA Tour event in five months, Tiger Woods hit a majestic iron shot during a practice round that soared toward an elevated green 250 yards away. When the ball deftly skirted bunkers protecting the putting surface and settled eight feet from the 15th hole, one person among the handful of security officers, volunteers and media members watching Woods clapped his hands.

headline: Mondaire Jones Rides Insurgent Wave to a House Primary Win in N.Y.
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: Mr. Jones is likely to become among the first openly gay African-American members of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Mondaire Jones, a progressive candidate supported by the institutional left, was declared the victor in a crowded Democratic House primary in the suburbs north of New York City, all but ensuring that he will join Congress next year as among its first openly gay African-American members.

headline: Jay Riffe, Spearfishing King, Is Dead at 82
abstract: He became a champion in sport fishing while in his 20s and went on to found a leading company in the manufacture of spearfishing and diving gear.
lead_paragraph: Jay Riffe recalled his first spearfishing outing as a fearsome affair — not for the fish but for him. Mr. Riffe, a celebrated California speargun designer, entrepreneur and pioneer of tankless hunting and diving, was about 10 years old, stalking lobster and sea bass in 70-degree Pacific waters while wearing a sweatshirt, gardening gloves and boxer trunks.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — General Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the top choice of congressional leaders to chair a bipartisan coronavirus oversight commission, has taken himself out of the running for the post, the latest setback in Congress’s efforts to keep tabs on the distribution of hundreds of billions of dollars of federal pandemic aid.

abstract: The international scholars the administration was threatening to send home are vital to American innovation and competitiveness.
lead_paragraph: Confronted with a deadly virus, many American colleges and universities are choosing to protect their communities by teaching fall classes largely or entirely online. Last week, the federal government deliberately disrupted those plans by proposing a new rule that would have prevented potentially hundreds of thousands of foreign students from studying in the United States this fall if their classes were taught remotely.

headline: Man’s Dismembered Body Is Found in Luxury Manhattan Condo

headline: Who Bears Witness to a Hidden Epidemic?
abstract: We know domestic violence is spiking under lockdown — we just don’t know the details. Here are women who do.
lead_paragraph: Within the first few weeks of states’ going into lockdown, reports began flooding in from domestic violence hotline centers throughout the country: They were seeing spikes in calls. But as sheltering-in-place dragged on, the calls for help dropped off. To those familiar with the dynamics of intimate-partner violence, this was not a good thing.

headline: How a Velvet Ant (Which Is a Wasp) Got Its White Fluff
abstract: The thistledown velvet ant, which is actually a wasp, resembles creosote fuzz. But mimicry isn’t the reason, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: At the foot of certain shrubs in the Mojave Desert, fluffy white motes skitter like tumbleweeds across the sand. Some are fruit: harmless, fuzzy orbs dropped by the creosote bush. Others are white wasps — not that kind — of the species Dasymutilla gloriosa, which have painful stingers and luxuriously silky hair, or setae.

headline: Scientists Have Finally Calculated How Many Hot Dogs a Person Can Eat at Once
keywords: ['Contests and Prizes', 'Hot Dogs and Frankfurters', 'Animal Behavior', 'Research', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Sports Medicine']
abstract: The world’s best hot dog eaters could outeat a grizzly bear or a coyote, but would fall far behind a wolf or a Burmese python, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: Over the Fourth of July weekend, with streams of sweat pouring down his face, Joey Chestnut broke his own world record for hot dog eating, by downing 75 hot dogs (with buns) in 10 minutes at the Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog Eating Contest. It was his 13th win at the annual contest. And Miki Sudo set a women’s record, 48.5 hot dogs, to grab her seventh straight Nathan’s win.

headline: Alabama’s Mud-Slinging Senate Primary
abstract: Welcome to the most negative Senate campaign of 2020 so far.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.

headline: Blaine Kern, Architect of Lavish Mardi Gras Floats, Dies at 93
abstract: The work of Mr. Kern, known as “Mr. Mardi Gras,” has delighted visitors to Carnival in New Orleans for decades.
lead_paragraph: Blaine Kern, who helped turn Mardi Gras in New Orleans into a huge event known around the world, most notably through the innovative and spectacular parade floats he designed and built, died on June 25 at his home in the city. He was 93.

headline: Naya Rivera’s Death Ruled Accidental Drowning
abstract: No traumatic injuries or disease were found, the medical examiner said.

keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Hospitals', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Hospitals have been ordered to bypass the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and send all patient information to a central database in Washington, raising questions about transparency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has ordered hospitals to bypass the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and send all Covid-19 patient information to a central database in Washington beginning on Wednesday. The move has alarmed health experts who fear the data will be politicized or withheld from the public.

headline: Asked About Black Americans Killed by Police, Trump Says, ‘So Are White People’
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Whites', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The president rejected the fact that Black people suffer disproportionately from police brutality and made startling remarks about the Confederate flag and a recent confrontation in St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, whose re-election prospects have dimmed as Americans question his handling of the coronavirus outbreak and race relations, on Tuesday stoked racial grievances yet again with a series of startling remarks about the Confederate flag, victims of police violence and a St. Louis couple who pointed guns at protesters peacefully marching by their house.

headline: World Population Could Peak Decades Ahead of U.N. Forecast, Study Asserts
abstract: The study, published in The Lancet, said an accelerated decline in fertility rates means the global population could peak in 2064 at 9.7 billion and fall to 8.8 billion by century’s end.
lead_paragraph: United Nations demographers have been anticipating since last year that the world’s population may stop growing by 2100 as fertility rates decline, projecting a peak of 10.9 billion people by century’s end, compared with roughly 7.8 billion now.

headline: 2 Stylists Had Coronavirus, but Wore Masks. 139 Clients Didn’t Fall Sick.
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Beauty Salons']
abstract: A new study looks at what might have been a dangerous outbreak — had it not been for vigilant mask wearing.
lead_paragraph: Vigilant mask wearing might have spared nearly 140 people from catching the coronavirus at a hair salon in Missouri, according to a report published on Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In May, the people interacted with two hair stylists with confirmed coronavirus infections, but none ended up showing symptoms of Covid-19.

abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 15, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about the reluctance of public health experts to speak about the dangers of attending protests during a pandemic when the protests are against racism misstated the difference in life expectancy between Black Americans and white Americans. It is a difference of three and a half years, not two years.

headline: Most Big School Districts Aren’t Ready to Reopen. Here’s Why.
abstract: All but two of the nation’s 10 largest districts exceed a key public health threshold, according to a New York Times analysis.
lead_paragraph: As education leaders decide whether to reopen classrooms in the fall amid a raging pandemic, many are looking to a standard generally agreed upon among epidemiologists: To control community spread of the coronavirus, the average daily infection rate among those who are tested should not exceed 5 percent.

headline: First Coronavirus Vaccine Tested in Humans Shows Early Promise
abstract: The vaccine, developed by government scientists and Moderna, a biotech company, appeared safe and provoked an immune response in 45 people in a study.
lead_paragraph: An experimental coronavirus vaccine made by the biotech company Moderna provoked a promising immune response against the virus and appeared safe in the first 45 people who received it, researchers reported on Tuesday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: For Sessions, No Amount of Campaigning Could Overcome Trump in Alabama
abstract: He beat back tears. He said he let his family down. He declared of politics, “This chapter of my life is closed.” But he would not criticize his former boss, and even said President Trump could win in November.
lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — Jeff Sessions spent his final days on the campaign trail reiterating his support for President Trump’s agenda, reminding voters of his efforts to curb illegal immigration while attorney general and emphasizing how, as a senator, he had endorsed Mr. Trump’s presidential campaign at a time when few others in Washington would.

lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — As a longtime senator from Alabama, Jeff Sessions did nothing less than legitimize Donald. J. Trump as a credible Republican candidate for president, endorsing him when no other big names did and championing him to conservative voters. As Mr. Trump’s star rose, Mr. Sessions’s rose, too.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘First Cow’ and ‘The Line’
abstract: The latest film from Kelly Reichardt is available online. And the Public Theater is streaming a virtual play about the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: FIRST COW (2020) Buy on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. At a settlement in the Oregon Territory in the mid-19th century, two men set up shop on a patch of ground. Their product, fried dough with modest garnish, sells out almost instantly. The secret ingredient? Stolen milk. The buddies who cook up that clever racket are at the heart of this latest western from Kelly Reichardt. When “First Cow” introduces Cookie (John Magaro) and King-Lu (Orion Lee), they’re strangers: Cookie is working as a cook and forager for a group of trappers; King-Lu is on the run. The friendship they develop together — and their covert dairy operation — is explored against a forested frontier backdrop. A.O. Scott called the film “deceptively simple and wondrously subtle” in his review for The New York Times. “A parable of economics and politics, with shrewd insights into the workings of supply and demand, scarcity and scale and other puzzles of the marketplace, the movie is also keenly attuned to details of history, both human and natural,” he wrote.

headline: She Tested Negative for Lyme Disease. So What Was Wrong?
abstract: Her lethargy and joint pain suggested a tick-borne illness. Adding to the mystery, was a recent trip abroad a clue or a red herring?
lead_paragraph: The 50-year-old physician dropped into the leather chair in her psychiatrist’s Manhattan office. Her new normal, she announced to Dr. Deborah Cabaniss, was constant fatigue. Cabaniss noted that although her patient looked put together as usual, she could see the exhaustion in her eyes. “You don’t look like yourself,” the therapist agreed.

headline: The Wealthy Can't Stop Not Paying Their Taxes
abstract: Budget cuts have left the I.R.S. unable to chase down wealthy tax evaders.
lead_paragraph: Budget cuts have left the I.R.S. unable to chase down wealthy tax evaders.

headline: Living With Aphantasia, the Inability to Make Mental Images
abstract: When the mind’s eye cannot see, counting sheep or navigating streets with a “mental map” can be impossible.
lead_paragraph: When I was in elementary school, I occasionally had trouble falling asleep, and people would tell me to count sheep. I had seen the activity graphically depicted in cartoons, but when I tried it, I never saw anything — just black. I’ve been counting silently into the darkness for years.

headline: The Herculean Effort to Build an American Army
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Paul Dickson’s “The Rise of the G.I. Army, 1940-1941” tells the remarkable story of how the United States created an effective military from scratch.
lead_paragraph: THE RISE OF THE G.I. ARMY, 1940-1941The Forgotten Story of How America Forged a Powerful Army Before Pearl HarborBy Paul Dickson

headline: Gardening Made Me Happier. It Will Work for You Too.
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Seeds', 'Corn']
abstract: Samin Nosrat turns to her vegetable plot for solace — and flavor. Her favorite is something many farmers throw away: fresh coriander seeds.
lead_paragraph: When I’m angry — which is often these days — I pull weeds. Getting my hands in the dirt untangles the knots that form in my stomach. With the first few weeds, I feel my exasperation with those who refuse to wear masks relent. It takes a little more digging and pulling to address the rage that builds up each day while I listen to friends and colleagues who have been mistreated by the food-media organizations that are now being exposed for systemic racial injustices.

headline: Trump Isn’t the Worst Pandemic President
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Just ask Brazilians.
lead_paragraph: Who’s the world’s worst leader at handling the pandemic? Easy. Donald Trump. Right? Well, as terrible as Mr. Trump is, a Brazilian YouTube star, Felipe Neto, argues it’s actually his president, Jair Bolsonaro.

headline: How Exercise May Bolster the Brain
abstract: Exercise prompts the liver to pump out a little-known protein that appears to rejuvenate the brain, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Exercise may help change exercisers’ brains in surprising ways, according to a new study of physical activity and brain health. The study, which included both mice and people, found that exercise prompts the liver to pump out a little-known protein, and that chemically upping the levels of that protein in out-of-shape, elderly animals rejuvenates their brains and memories. The findings raise provocative questions about whether the brain benefits of exercise might someday be available in a capsule or syringe form — essentially “exercise in a pill.”

headline: It’s Long Past Time to Get That Beard Under Control
keywords: ['Hair', 'Beards and Mustaches', 'Barbers and Barbering', 'Content Type: Service', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Good thing men are warming up to some new tools.

headline: The Return of Jane Elliott

Knopf has had four publishers in its 105-year history. Farrar, Straus and Giroux has only been run by two people since John C. Farrar, Roger W. Straus and Robert Giroux.

headline: Five Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
abstract: Our critic looks at street photography that gives you a taste of global life during the lockdown, from Iran, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Hong Kong, South Korea and Ethiopia.
lead_paragraph: When things are tough at home, I sometimes search Instagram for street photographers abroad. It’s not that I’m looking for happy scenes, necessarily. It’s just reassuring to be reminded that the world is so much larger than our national news cycle. (Scrolling through digital feeds is also the safest way to travel these days, not to mention the most eco-friendly.) These are the five accounts that I’ve been turning to lately for quick little doses of our common humanity; other New York Times critics will be posting their own favorites regularly.

headline: A Plague on Your Houses: Reading Covid-19 Into Disease Onstage
abstract: Efforts like ‘The Oedipus Project’ are worthy, but in an attempt to draw contemporary parallels, they can misread drama and mislead about the present.
lead_paragraph: “The hateful plague spreads like a raging wildfire, devouring the city without mercy, emptying homes and filling the streets with moans and wailing and heaps of rotting bodies,” declares a priest in “The Oedipus Project,” Theater of War Productions’ recent reading of scenes from “Oedipus the King,” translated and directed by Bryan Doerries.

headline: Turn Your Relationship Into a Work of Art
abstract: For some couples who postponed their engagement shoots because of the coronavirus, artists have stepped in to create custom illustrations and portraits.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic upended wedding plans and industry jobs, many couples rescheduled their engagement photo shoots in order to adhere to social distancing guidelines. Others hired illustrators to commemorate their upcoming nuptials, ceremonies and other relationship milestones. Here are a few creative examples from artists.

headline: Covid-19 Risk Doesn’t Depend (Much) on Blood Type, New Studies Find
abstract: New studies show that people with Type A blood are not at greater risk of getting sick, as previous studies had suggested.
lead_paragraph: Early in the Covid-19 pandemic, researchers found preliminary evidence suggesting that people’s blood type might be an important risk factor — both for being infected by the virus and for falling dangerously ill.

headline: Your New Favorite Sandwich
abstract: The chef Brooks Headley’s crispy chicken-fried tofu sandwich is a riff on chicken-fried steak, and neither complicated nor difficult.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The chef Brooks Headley is in the spotlight today, with his recipe for the crispy chicken-fried tofu sandwich (above) served at his Superiority Burger on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. It’s a bit of a project as most restaurant recipes tend to be, but it’s neither complicated nor difficult. If you start the process this afternoon, you’ll eat a sandwich of intense deliciousness for dinner and be thankful for having done so, against the backdrop of our troubled, reeling world.

lead_paragraph: At first glance, American paddlefish and Russian sturgeon seem about as different as two fish can be.

headline: After Attacks From Trump Aides, Fauci Says ‘Let’s Stop This Nonsense’ and Focus on Virus

Bunch III, who last year became the first Black secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, said in an interview Wednesday that is he reviewing complaints in a letter sent by former employees and board members of its National Museum of African Art that described it as a bad place for Black employees.

keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks']

lead_paragraph: Steven Pinker occupies a role that is rare in American life: the celebrity intellectual. The Harvard professor pops up on outlets from PBS to the Joe Rogan podcast, translating dense subjects into accessible ideas with enthusiasm. Bill Gates called his most recent book “my new favorite book of all time.”

headline: For Paris Men’s Wear, the Next Stop Is California

headline: How Artists Are Trying to Solve the World’s Problems
keywords: ['Art', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Grants (Corporate and Foundation)']
abstract: A cohort of 30 artists have received funding to find creative solutions to 21st-century problems like surveillance, digital inequality and inherited trauma.
lead_paragraph: Janine Soleil’s passing was sudden and shocking. She died a week after her 75th birthday in May, which was spent in hospice care after contracting the novel coronavirus. And once she was gone, her son, the artist Dylan Gauthier, found her digital imprint everywhere: on the dating websites where she found love, on the insurance company listings for her old therapy practice and across the hundreds of other websites she had tacitly agreed to share personal data with.

headline: These Creamy Tomatoes Are the Ideal Lunch for One

headline: Wagner in the Parking Lot as Opera Returns to Germany
abstract: Three productions under unusual constraints show how the art form is gradually re-emerging in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The Rhinemaidens lament their lost gold on asphalt. Tristan savors doomed love in a stately 17th-century garden. A motley crew of playboys and deposed royalty are set adrift in an industrial harbor.

headline: Oklahoma Governor Tests Positive for Coronavirus
abstract: Gov. Kevin Stitt said he was “pretty shocked” to become the first governor known to have contracted the virus. Oklahoma has averaged more than 640 new cases per day over the past week.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma announced on Wednesday that he tested positive for the coronavirus, becoming the first governor in the United States known to have been infected during the pandemic.

headline: Just Collect Less Data, Period.
abstract: Every company wants the biggest data stockpile possible. We need unilateral data disarmament.

headline: How ‘I May Destroy You’ Got Its Stunning Soundtrack
abstract: The show’s 27-year-old music supervisor, Ciara Elwis, talks about matching Michaela Coel’s singular vision with songs by Nicki Minaj, Daft Punk and more.
lead_paragraph: In the world of “I May Destroy You,” the critically hailed HBO/BBC series written, co-directed by and starring Michaela Coel, few things are ever static. The show, like its central characters — young, exuberantly liberated but inherently vulnerable Black Britons navigating sex, power and friendship in a very recent London — is held together by the cumulative force of its apparent contradictions.

headline: Playwrights Horizons Details First Season Under New Leadership
keywords: ['Theater', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Women and Girls', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Podcasts', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: Though no dates are set, Adam Greenfield plans to present four plays, all directed by women, at the Off Broadway theater.
lead_paragraph: In his first season at the helm of Playwrights Horizons, Adam Greenfield is sending a message: The organization may be staging fewer shows because of the pandemic — four in its 2021 season, down from the six that were slated for the 2019-2020 season — but it is committed to showcasing work by writers of color.

headline: Theater Streams See Stars Pop Up in Unexpected Places
abstract: Most of them are available on short notice, after all. Live readings with some of the New Group’s original casts and an Ian Dury jukebox musical are among this week’s highlights.
lead_paragraph: One of theater’s great pleasures is watching actors bring characters to life. The era of online performing arts has added a remarkably democratic element by allowing high-caliber casts to pop up in everything from revisited classics to fresh-from-the-oven efforts by young playwrights. Most stars are available on short notice these days, after all, and now they can take on projects that time or financial constraints may have kept them away from. We look for whatever upside we can find, and the pleasure of fine acting in an unexpected setting has been a balm.

headline: Airlines May Learn to Love the Boeing 737 Max Again

Boeing froze production of its beleaguered plane from January through much of May as customers canceled hundreds of orders, and deals for hundreds more were put at risk by delays in the plane’s return to the skies and the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Country Music Struggles to Meet the Moment. Again.

While PGA Tour golfers ply their trade at nearby Muirfield Village Golf Club, site of the Memorial Tournament, the sports bar would welcome an overflow crowd of fans to enjoy a live band on its expansive patio outfitted with a disco ball.

headline: Teenage Suspect Charged in Fatal Shooting of 8-Year-Old Girl in Atlanta
abstract: The death of Secoriea Turner has roiled Atlanta. A lawyer for the suspect said his client, who turned himself in, witnessed the shooting but did not open fire.
lead_paragraph: A teenager was charged on Wednesday in the fatal shooting of Secoriea Turner, an 8-year-old girl who died this month in Atlanta after an armed group stopped her family’s car and opened fire, officials said.

headline: What to Do When Most Days Feel Like Wednesdays
abstract: Seek diversion from what’s happening in your head and in our world, if just for a moment of recharge and reflection. It works.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. How are you? Wednesdays were a bear even before the pandemic came to town and made most days feel like Wednesdays. Now Wednesdays are like Wednesdays squared, like Nebraska on a cross-country drive, 456 miles from Omaha in the East all the way to the Wyoming line. They’re a long way from a weekend that is hardly a weekend for many, in both directions on the calendar.

headline: TikTok Enlists Army of Lobbyists as Suspicions Over China Ties Grow
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']

headline: Comet NEOWISE: How to See It in Night Skies
abstract: Enjoy it while you can. The frozen ball of ice won’t return to the inner solar system for 6,800 years.

headline: Hermès Introduces Seasonless Staples for the Long Haul
abstract: Breaking with the standard fashion calendar, the brand has created a capsule collection inspired by its archives.
lead_paragraph: As the artistic director of women’s ready-to-wear at Hermès, Nadège Vanhée-Cybulski is deeply familiar with the fashion calendar, its shows and seasons coming at a quick but constant pace. Last spring, though, she was staring down the maternity leave she would soon take following the birth of her first child — an event that can’t help but remake one’s relationship with time — and found herself wanting to take advantage of the remaining weeks before she went. “We decided to do this capsule collection we’d always talked about,” she says of her team, which works out of the brand’s atelier in Pantin, just north of Paris. “Something special created out of season, when we can really explore.”

headline: Meet the 19-Year-Old From Kazakhstan Who Remixed ‘Roses’ Into a Hit
abstract: Imanbek was working at his local train station when he stumbled onto a Saint Jhn song ripe for a dancey redo. The result boosted both artists to a new level.
lead_paragraph: Imanbek Zeikenov is 19 years old and lives with his parents in the small village of Aksu in Kazakhstan. He studied railway engineering at school, and until last December, held a day job at his local train station. But everything changed in the summer of 2019, when he discovered a song called “Roses” by the Guyanese-American rapper and singer Saint Jhn.

headline: Can Doug Jones Fend Off Tommy Tuberville and Trump in Alabama?

In Mr. Jones’s Alabama, he said, “You don’t work for the United States of America — you spend your first three years trying to impeach the best president we’ve ever had. And he voted to impeach him!”

lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is considering a sweeping ban on travel to the United States by members of the Chinese Communist Party and their families, according to people familiar with the proposal, a move that would almost certainly prompt retaliation against Americans seeking to enter or remain in China and exacerbate tensions between the two nations.

headline: North Macedonia Election Returns No Clear Winner
abstract: Zoran Zaev changed North Macedonia’s name to allow it to join NATO and apply to the European Union. But he faces coalition talks after failing to win a majority in Wednesday’s election.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The first general election in North Macedonia since the country changed its name and resolved a longstanding dispute with neighboring Greece has ended with no clear winner, leaving the country’s future diplomatic trajectory in the balance.

headline: Why Does the N.Y.P.D. Want to Punish Journalists?
keywords: ['Police', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: The Police Department’s proposed new rules threaten press freedom.
lead_paragraph: Increased public scrutiny of American policing — through cellphone videos, social media and mass protests — has revealed in recent weeks an urgent need for sustained and systemic reform. The New York Police Department has chosen to respond by pressing ahead with new rules to grant wider latitude to bar journalists from covering official police activity.

headline: Corrections: July 16, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 16, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about oil and gas companies that are heading toward bankruptcy misidentified the scientific agency where Claus Zehner works. It is the European Space Agency, not the SRON Netherlands Institute for Space Research.

headline: Trump Replaces Brad Parscale as Campaign Manager, Elevating Bill Stepien
abstract: The replacement of Mr. Parscale with Mr. Stepien, who had served as deputy campaign manager, comes as the president has struggled in public and private polling.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Wednesday shook up his re-election team with less than four months until November’s vote, replacing his campaign manager, Brad Parscale, in an acknowledgment of the president’s diminished standing in nearly all public and private polling since the spring.

headline: George Floyd’s Family Files Lawsuit Against Officers
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A lawyer for George Floyd’s family, Benjamin Crump, filed a civil rights lawsuit on Wednesday against the city of Minneapolis and the four officers who were charged with his killing
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for George Floyd’s family, Benjamin Crump, filed a civil rights lawsuit on Wednesday against the city of Minneapolis and the four officers who were charged with his killing

headline: Airbnb Says Its I.P.O. Plans Are Back on Track
abstract: After a financial hit from the pandemic, the San Francisco company said business was starting to return from its nose-dive.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb has resumed its efforts to go public, despite significant damage to the home rental business caused by the coronavirus pandemic, Airbnb’s chief executive, Brian Chesky, told employees Wednesday.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Economic Damage of Lockdown Lingers for Minority Women in Britain
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 16, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “They phoned me one by one to say don’t come. Each call was like a bomb, blasting every bit of my livelihood until I had no work left.”

headline: Top N.Y.P.D. Chief Injured While Making Arrest at a Protest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Attacks on Police', 'Criminal Justice']
abstract: Terence A. Monahan, New York’s highest-ranking uniformed chief, was one of several officers who were attacked on the Brooklyn Bridge, officials said.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s top uniformed police officer, two lieutenants and a sergeant were injured on Wednesday in two separate incidents on the Brooklyn Bridge, including one that involved an attack with some kind of stick or pole as protesters marched nearby, officials said.

headline: Witchcraft
abstract: Evan Kalish is hiding from us.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — “By the pricking of my thumbs, / Something wicked this way comes.” So says the second witch in Act IV, Scene 1 of that Scottish play.

headline: China’s Economy Rebounds From Coronavirus, but Shares Fall
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: Heavy spending on roads and rail lines reversed the economy’s outbreak-induced nose-dive in February and March. But retail sales stayed weak, alarming investors.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Economies in Europe and the United States are still languishing as the pandemic forces cities to shut down and shoppers to stay home. But one major country is growing once again: China.

headline: It’s Been 75 Years, and America Still Won’t Admit a Nuclear Disaster
abstract: Remember when we blew radioactive ash over New Mexico? Now the Trump administration is talking about testing bombs again.
lead_paragraph: When America detonated the world’s first atomic bomb at 0529 hours on July 16, 1945, it was an attack on American soil.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: U.K. women, Philippines, Siberia fires: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Black and other ethnic minority women in Britain are being disproportionately affected by the financial and psychological toll from the coronavirus outbreak, even as the economy reopens.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Brave New World’ and ‘Little Voice’
abstract: An adaptation of “Brave New World” is on the new streaming service Peacock. And a dramedy series about a young musician is on Apple TV+.
lead_paragraph: BRAVE NEW WORLD Stream on Peacock. Aldous Huxley’s 1932 dystopian novel, “Brave New World,” has been ripped from the hands of your high school English teacher and thrown onscreen with this new TV adaptation. One of the highest-profile titles from NBCUniversal’s new streaming service, Peacock, the show brings to life the futuristic New London, a city where crime and disease are in the past, and residents spend their time popping happy pills and having orgies. At the story’s center are Bernard (Harry Lloyd) and Lenina (Jessica Brown Findlay), two New Londoners who bring a pair of outsiders, played by Alden Ehrenreich and Demi Moore, into the city. While the creators of the series make an effort to cook up a version of Huxley’s vision that feels fresh to 21st-century audiences, James Poniewozik wrote in his review for The New York Times that the show ultimately “transmutes a provocative warning into a vision of a sci-fi world that feels neither brave nor new.”

headline: A Team by Any Other Name Is Fine, It Turns Out
abstract: The Washington N.F.L. franchise is picking a new name. As other pro franchises have learned, the process of rebranding can be as unique as the result.
lead_paragraph: When team owner Abe Pollin decided to change the name of the N.B.A.’s Washington Bullets in 1995, the two-year rebranding process had the veneer of a democratic undertaking.

headline: ‘Fatal Affair’ Review: Close Stalker
abstract: Nia Long and Omar Epps ignite a dangerous obsession in this hackneyed romantic melodrama.
lead_paragraph: There is so much recycled material in “Fatal Affair” that its carbon footprint must have been zero. That’s the good news in this Netflix dance of déjà vu, one with scarcely a camera move, plot swerve or line of dialogue that hasn’t already graced myriad romantic thrillers and special-victim police procedurals.

headline: Late Night Thinks the Trumps Are Full of Beans
abstract: Ivanka Trump posed with a can of Goya beans after the company’s president praised her father. “Sadly, after Ivanka tweeted in Spanish, Trump immediately had her deported,” said Jimmy Fallon.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Bristol Removes Statue of Black Protester After Just One Day
abstract: The statue of Jen Reid, a Black Lives Matter protester, was raised on Wednesday in place of a toppled memorial to the slave trader Edward Colston.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jen Reid, the Black Lives Matter protester whose statue was erected in place of a toppled slave trader in Bristol, England, on Wednesday, said just before the unauthorized installation that she did not know whether the city’s authorities would let it stand there for a few months or a single day.

headline: E.U. Court Strikes Down Trans-Atlantic Data Transfer Pact
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The ruling is the latest twist in a campaign by privacy-rights activists in Europe to prevent personal information from being transferred to countries with looser protections.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Europe’s top court on Thursday struck down a trans-Atlantic agreement that allows scores of companies to move data between the European Union and the United States, causing uncertainty for businesses that rely on moving digital information seamlessly around the world.

headline: U.S. Wants to Bar Members of China’s Communist Party. Who Are They?
abstract: With more than 90 million members and led by Xi Jinping, the party encompasses people at the heights of Chinese power and the civil servants of everyday life.
lead_paragraph: As the Trump administration weighs a travel ban against the members of the Chinese Communist Party and their relatives, it is considering cutting off a vast sector of Chinese society — 92 million people — that often defies stereotypes, including those who walk the halls of power in Beijing, supervise China’s schools and run major companies.

headline: ‘Putin’s People’ Documents the Ruthless and Relentless Reach of Kremlin Corruption
abstract: Catherine Belton’s new book argues that Vladimir Putin has presided over the country and its resources like a czar, bolstered by a cadre of friendly oligarchs and secret service agents.
lead_paragraph: In the years that it took the journalist Catherine Belton to research and write “Putin’s People,” her voluminous yet elegant account of money and power in the Kremlin, a number of her interview subjects tried various tactics to undermine her work. One of them, “a close Putin ally” apparently alarmed by her questions about Russian President Vladimir Putin’s activities as a K.G.B. agent in Dresden in the 1980s, emphatically insisted that any rumored links between the K.G.B. and terrorist organizations had never been proved: “And you should not try to do so!” he warned.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Wilderness Camping With a 9-Month-Old
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Wilderness Areas', 'Road Trips', 'Parenting', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: Is this the beginning of a wonderful family tradition? Or a terrible idea?
lead_paragraph: Brian writes: My wife, Karen, and I are expecting. I want to bring our child to the Boundary Waters Canoe Area, a remote wilderness in Minnesota, where we go every year. Karen thinks that camping with a 9- to 12-month-old will be unenjoyable and dangerous. But how cool would it be for our child to be able to say they’ve been to the B.W.C.A. every year of their life?!

headline: He Wanted a Manhattan Bachelor Pad for Under $600,000. Which of These Would You Choose?
abstract: After failing to land a two-bedroom co-op he could share with a roommate, a young buyer scaled back his search. Here’s where he wound up.
lead_paragraph: After failing to land a two-bedroom co-op he could share with a roommate, a young buyer scaled back his search. Here’s where he wound up.

headline: Must We Make Your Stepfather’s Coronavirus Sickness a Political Issue?
abstract: My liberal-leaning son doesn’t think I’ve been taking the pandemic seriously. Now my husband is sick, and my son says it’s our fault.
lead_paragraph: My 24-year-old son and I bicker constantly over politics. He thinks I’m hypnotized by Fox News. I’m not, but I’m not impressed by his knee-jerk liberal positions either. I never doubted our love for each other. But when Covid-19 came, he began accusing his stepfather and me of not taking the virus seriously. (We’ve always followed our state’s mandates.) Now, my husband has become seriously ill with the virus. And my son has been nasty about it: blaming us and saying, “I told you so,” rather than helping me or being sympathetic. I am devastated. What can I do?

headline: Silvia Moreno-Garcia Has Crafts Covered. Bring Your Own Scissors.
abstract: The author of “Mexican Gothic” offers a downloadable book club kit including a paper doll inspired by her main character.
lead_paragraph: VALUE ADDED Spend some time lurking on websites of best-selling authors and you’ll be inspired by the clever ways they’ve found to cheer up glum fans during the pandemic. Take Hank Green, whose novel “A Beautifully Foolish Endeavor” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 4. He reminds you, “Don’t forget to be awesome,” and lets you know he’s discussing his book on Zoom, Crowdcast and YouTube. Renée Ahdieh, author of “The Damned” (No. 5 on the young adult list), not only offers advice (“Persist. Always Persist”), she also dishes about her least favorite mode of transportation (“Alpaca. Definitely alpaca”).

headline: Are We Overreacting on Climate Change?
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Books and Literature', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs']
abstract: In “False Alarm,” Bjorn Lomborg argues that the global attention on fighting climate change has been misplaced, and taken resources away from more pressing problems.
lead_paragraph: FALSE ALARMHow Climate Change Panic Costs Us Trillions, Hurts the Poor, and Fails to Fix the PlanetBy Bjorn Lomborg

headline: Poem: The Body’s Uncontested Need to Devour: An Explanation
abstract: We stayed inside so long. The moss is calling us. A poem's lush language invites us to feel close to something elemental again.
lead_paragraph: We stayed inside so long. The moss is calling us. The leaves, the little flickers — bow down. Major Jackson’s mesmerizing fifth collection, “The Absurd Man,” conveys profound physical presences: connection to earth and memory, a deepest need for embodied contact in this often ridiculously abstracted modern world. His lush language invites us into the exquisite realms here at our feet — or beyond that tree, there, in the cracks between the old stones. Take it in, be fed, feel close to something elemental again. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: Why Does America Have Old Leaders?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Age, Chronological', 'Baby Boomers', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: The age of elected leaders in other wealthy democracies is falling, not rising.
lead_paragraph: The American presidency is starting to feel like a gerontocracy.

headline: Protests Continue Daily in Louisville. Here’s a Look at 45 Days of Marches.
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Kentucky’s largest city has seen weeks of demonstrators demanding justice in the case of Breonna Taylor, who was killed by the police in her home there.
lead_paragraph: Kentucky’s largest city has seen weeks of demonstrators demanding justice in the case of Breonna Taylor, who was killed by the police in her home there.

headline: FaZe Clan President Departs: ‘It’s Time for Gaming to Clean Up Its Act’
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'E-Sports', 'Women and Girls', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Greg Selkoe is leaving the successful esports conglomerate to start a new venture that’s less “frat house” and more diverse.
lead_paragraph: FaZe Clan, an esports lifestyle conglomerate, helped turn gamers into a new class of social media influencers. Now, several top executives behind FaZe Clan are leaving to start a competing organization called XSET.

headline: What’s With All the Covid-Death Shaming?
abstract: Some Pakistanis won’t say they are losing family members to the pandemic because they don’t want to bury the bodies alone.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — I’ve made a few condolence calls during the past few months. None of the people I called to condole about had died of Covid-19. I was always given another reason.

headline: Saying Goodbye to Totokaelo
abstract: A shopping refuge for irreverent luxury.
lead_paragraph: The fashion industry is in a state of emergency. This has been made clear not only by the mounting bankruptcies of big-name retailers, but also by the closure of beloved smaller businesses. These are shops that won’t bounce back.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Parenting', 'Child Care', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
