headline: Experts warn of a gathering storm of corporate bankruptcies.
abstract: Since March, economic lockdowns have forced more and more companies — including well-known names like Hertz, J. Crew and Neiman Marcus — to file for bankruptcy protection. headline: Ending an Era, British Airways Retires Fleet of Boeing 747s

headline: Three takeaways from this week’s earnings reports.
abstract: America’s four largest consumer lenders — Bank of America, Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo — set aside $33 billion to cover potential loan losses, nearly $10 billion more than in the previous quarter and $30 billion more than the same time last year. And even the investment banks that had a better quarter thanks to rising markets — Goldman Sachs and (especially) Morgan Stanley — said their good fortune was unlikely to last.
lead_paragraph: America’s four largest consumer lenders — Bank of America, Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo — set aside $33 billion to cover potential loan losses, nearly $10 billion more than in the previous quarter and $30 billion more than the same time last year. headline: World Surf League Cancels 2020 Season and Revamps Future Tours
abstract: The championship tour had been scheduled to start in March in Australia, but never got underway because of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Surfing was poised for a monumental year in 2020 with its arrival on the Olympic stage. But the pandemic has not only caused a postponement of the Tokyo Games, it has now led the World Surf League to cancel the World Championship Tour this year and to revamp the next tour schedule.

But they started looking to move closer to their teenage son’s school when pandemic lockdowns showed they could avoid a commute across town by working from home.

abstract: As myriad activities are restricted this summer, there’s no shame in the game when it comes to creatively keeping up morale.

Now that summer is here, many of the seasonal pleasures she’d been eagerly anticipating have not come to pass. No sleepovers at her grandparents’ house. No day camp. No amusement parks.

headline: Federal Agents Unleash Militarized Crackdown on Portland
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Federal authorities said they would bring order to Portland, Ore., after weeks of protests there. Local leaders believe the federal presence is making things worse.

headline: Democrats Eye Trump’s Game Plan to Reverse Late Rule Changes
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: President Trump pioneered the use of an obscure 1996 law to quickly reverse the regulations of his predecessor. Now Democrats hope to take a page from his game plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the dawn of the Trump era, Republicans in the White House and Congress turned an old law into a potent new weapon. An obscure 1996 statute was harnessed to wipe out 14 Obama-era regulations in 16 weeks, before President Trump set out to enact the most significant deregulatory agenda in the modern presidential era.

headline: A ‘Significant Return to Normality’ by Christmas, U.K. Prime Minister Says
abstract: “Hoping for the best but planning for the worst,” Boris Johnson said as he announced a road map for reopening England, and granted local authorities extended powers to tackle regional outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Stadiums and concert venues in England may reopen in the fall, but nightclubs will remain closed. All schools will welcome students by September, but wedding receptions will be limited to 30 people. And while pubs and restaurants reopened in England earlier this month, the local authorities will be granted new powers to close them when coronavirus cases flare.

headline: A Timeless Tomato Tart
abstract: Light, custardy and flavored with a layer of pesto, this simple, flavorful dish lets juicy heirloom varieties shine.

With water, sunlight and good soil, the plants bore fruit, offering a timely reminder to us all on the importance of nourishment and care.

headline: Cave’s Clues Show It’s More Than Just Oldest Outhouse in the Americas

headline: Ginsburg Says Her Cancer Has Returned, but She’s ‘Fully Able’ to Remain on Court
abstract: The announcement touches off speculation about the possibility of a court opening as both parties seek to make the future of the Supreme Court an election issue.
lead_paragraph: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the most prominent member of the Supreme Court’s liberal minority, said Friday that she has had a recurrence of cancer, causing a wave of anxiety among Democrats that was not completely assuaged by her assurance that she was undergoing chemotherapy, with “positive results,” and would remain on the Supreme Court.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Police Reform', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Classical Music', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases']
abstract: Colin Powell. Lessons from a New Jersey city. Koalas with chlamydia. Changes in the publishing world. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. You may not have plans (I don’t have plans), but like most weeks nowadays, it’s been a busy one, with promising vaccine news and a major Twitter hack. And, there’s an election. So take some time to relax (maybe start shopping for flower bulbs to plant for fall, if that’s your thing). And be sure to make time to read some amazing journalism.

headline: Sheet-Pan Summer

headline: ‘30 Rock’ Reunion Review: A Few Laughs, a Lot of Blergh
abstract: The TV-biz satire spent a joking-not-joking night selling NBCUniversal TV, winking so hard that it injured itself.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday’s satire is today’s news. It is one of the iron laws of reality in 2020, and it was awkwardly proved by the weird, recursively ironic reunion “30 Rock: A One-Time Special” Thursday night, in which a sitcom that spent years spoofing corporate TV’s desperate salesmanship took part in the big shill seriously. But jokingly. But seriously.

headline: How One Student Chose a College During a Pandemic
abstract: Craig McFarland was accepted by all eight Ivy League schools. At first he committed to Yale, but the ongoing disruptions caused by the coronavirus caused him to change his plans.
lead_paragraph: When he was applying to colleges last year, Craig McFarland of Jacksonville, Fla., aimed high and wide. He received 17 acceptance letters in all, including one from each of the eight Ivy League universities, a remarkable feat.

headline: Inside Johnson & Johnson’s Nonstop Hunt for a Coronavirus Vaccine
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Clinical Trials', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Public-Private Sector Cooperation', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: In Boston and in the Netherlands, scientists are racing to build a vaccine against the virus strangling the world.
lead_paragraph: Each workday morning in March, Noe Mercado drove through the desolate streets of Boston to a tall glass building on Blackfan Circle, in the heart of the city’s biotech hub. Most residents had gone into hiding from the coronavirus, but Mr. Mercado had an essential job: searching for a vaccine against this new, devastating pathogen.

headline: Government Says Contract for Covid-19 Database Was Competitively Bid
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Government Contracts and Procurement']
abstract: A $10.2 million contract to run the Trump administration’s new coronavirus database continues to draw scrutiny, but the government says it had six bidders.

headline: The Pandemic Is Straining Airbnb

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: A witty guest star joins Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon and asks, “What’s so funny?”
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — The acrostic puzzle, nee “Double-Crostic,” has appeared regularly in The New York Times since 1943. It’s a bit unsung, if you will, compared with its more mainstream relative, the crossword, but its fans are passionate and the puzzle itself is smart and fun. Over all those years, there have been only five people responsible for its creation, and the most recent two work as a team. It’s remarkable for us to introduce a fresh new voice to the vaunted genre, then — let alone a voice that you may find familiar.

headline: New York City Eases Into Phase 4 of Reopening, but Indoor Limits Remain
abstract: Monday brings a new stage of activity to the city, allowing some places to reopen outdoors, while many activities inside, like restaurant dining, will still be forbidden.

headline: Love Letter: Confessions of a Hopeful Romantic
abstract: Plus: Tackling a Covid-19 scare together.
lead_paragraph: Online dating can be hard for just about anyone, but looking for love online can present different challenges for Black women. In this week’s Modern Love essay, Loré Yessuff, a writer who spends her days helping digital daters around the world find love using the dating app she works for, struggles with her own feelings of rejection from would-be suitors who have feigned interest or told her they don’t date Black women. While these encounters have often left her questioning her own desirability, she remains hopeful that she’ll find a partner who acknowledges her worth.

headline: How the Yankees Are Adapting to a Season of Distancing
abstract: M.L.B.’s protocols require it, but it’s not easy to suddenly stop spitting, high-fiving and wiping your face in a sport where doing so can be second nature.
lead_paragraph: During a recent practice game at Yankee Stadium, pitcher Jordan Montgomery occasionally wiped his nose with his hand between pitches. Behind the plate, catcher Gary Sanchez spit to his side a few times. Frequently, Manager Aaron Boone sat or stood just a couple feet away from some of his coaches or an umpire to chat. A day later, outfielder Aaron Judge smacked palms and fists with several teammates after smashing a home run.

headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Supermarket Sweep’
abstract: In an era of toilet paper shortages and lines outside of supermarkets, this vintage free-for-all, now on Netflix, feels oddly gratifying.
lead_paragraph: It was an entirely different time in life when there was very, very little to do.

headline: 2 White Men Charged After Helping Pin Black Man to a Tree in Indiana, Officials Say
abstract: The charges came after Vauhxx Booker said on Facebook that he had been assaulted by a group of men who had threatened to “get a noose.”
lead_paragraph: Two white men who the authorities say helped pin a Black man against a tree by an Indiana lake on the Fourth of July were charged on Friday with battery and other crimes.

headline: Cuomo Says N.Y.C. Museums Won’t Reopen Monday
abstract: New York City is moving to Phase 4 of its reopening plan, but indoor cultural attractions such as museums will stay shut for the time being.
lead_paragraph: Whitney Donhauser, the director of the Museum of the City of New York, had hoped that, come next Thursday, the museum’s halls would play host to its first masked, socially distanced visitors.

headline: A Portuguese Artist’s Chilled Tomato Soup
abstract: For a simple lunch or dinner, Vanessa Barragão often makes arjamolho, which is healthy, flavorful and perfect for summer.
lead_paragraph: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.

headline: How Can We Be of Service?
abstract: We know you have questions about how to manage life at home, life with family, with roommates, all alone, especially as the summer stretches onward toward September’s call.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. Here’s all any of us have been talking about these days on our calls and video calls, on Slack, in texts and in emails sent too early in the morning or way too late at night: What happens when it’s Fall?

headline: ‘Richard II’ Review: A Radio King With a Tottering Crown
abstract: Electric performances, led by André Holland, transcend didacticism in an audio rendition that replaced a Shakespeare in the Park production.
lead_paragraph: You say you want a revolution. Well, you know — we all wanna rule the world.

headline: F.T.C.’s Facebook Investigation May Stretch Past Election
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly a year ago, Joseph J. Simons, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, predicted his agency would wrap up an antitrust investigation of Facebook by the presidential election.

headline: Brandis Kemp, Character Actress and ‘Fridays’ Original, Dies at 76
abstract: Ms. Kemp told comically gruesome fortunes on “Fridays” and made doctors’ lives miserable on “AfterMASH.” She died of a brain tumor and complications of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: The Fall of ‘Terrace House’
abstract: Japan’s heartwarming reality TV hit ended in tragedy when the participant Hana Kimura killed herself after a wave of online abuse. But “Terrace House” was always more complicated than it appeared.
lead_paragraph: Hana Kimura, a professional wrestler in Japan, joined the cast of the hit reality show “Terrace House” in September because, as she said, she wanted “to find a wonderful romance.”

headline: Hackers Tell the Story of the Twitter Attack From the Inside
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Virtual Currency', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Bitcoin (Currency)']
abstract: Several people involved in the events that took down Twitter this week spoke with The Times, giving the first account of what happened as a pursuit of Bitcoin spun out of control.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — A Twitter hacking scheme that targeted political, corporate and cultural elites this week began with a teasing message between two hackers late Tuesday on the online messaging platform Discord.

headline: The Community That Covid-19 Built
abstract: On Hiawatha Road, the virus has stitched neighbors into a community that exchanges homemade food and homegrown produce.
lead_paragraph: The wagon on Jennifer Ois’s front porch is a symbol of the coronavirus’s silver lining. It’s red and wooden, with black rubber wheels that once fell off, when Ms. Ois was towing her first child and a frozen turkey home from a store many years ago.

headline: Picking Your Sunday Read
abstract: One editor wants to “take you someplace you wouldn’t otherwise go.”
lead_paragraph: What kind of story do you want to listen to on a Sunday morning?

headline: Newsom Outlines Reopening Guidelines for California Schools
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced new rules on Friday that would force many schools to start the year with virtual learning.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced new rules on Friday that would force many schools to start the year with virtual learning.

headline: Emily Howell Warner, Who Broke a Sky-High Glass Ceiling, Dies at 80
abstract: She was the first woman hired to command the cockpit for a major American airline on scheduled flights and the first woman to achieve the airline rank of captain.
lead_paragraph: Emily Howell Warner, a pilot who was credited with breaking a tropospheric glass ceiling in the 1970s as the first woman hired to command the flight deck of a commercial airliner in the United States, died on July 3 in a nursing home in Littleton, Colo. She was 80.

headline: Newsom Order Would Keep Most California Schools Online
abstract: Districts in counties with rising caseloads will be required to teach remotely until conditions improve.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Responding to soaring coronavirus infections and growing concern from teachers, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced new rules on Friday that would force many of the state’s districts to teach remotely when school starts next month.

headline: Delta tells its pilots: Take a 15 percent pay cut and keep your jobs.
abstract: Delta Air Lines has told pilots it will not furlough them for a year if they accept a 15 percent cut to guaranteed pay, according a memo sent to staff on Friday.“Our approach is to spread the work of a smaller airline among all our pilots to preserve all jobs — that would be unheard of in our history,” John Laughter, senior vice president of flight operations, said in the memo, which was reviewed by The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines has told pilots it will not furlough them for a year if they accept a 15 percent cut to guaranteed pay, according a memo sent to staff on Friday.“Our approach is to spread the work of a smaller airline among all our pilots to preserve all jobs — that would be unheard of in our history,” John Laughter, senior vice president of flight operations, said in the memo, which was reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: Prosecutors Drop Felony Charges Against 87 Breonna Taylor Protesters in Kentucky
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: The Jefferson County attorney will expunge the charge from the records of an N.F.L. player, a reality TV star and 85 others who gathered this week on the Kentucky attorney general’s lawn.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors have dropped felony charges against 87 protesters who peacefully gathered this week outside the Kentucky attorney general’s home to demand charges against the police officers responsible for the death of Breonna Taylor.

headline: Watchdog Faults Medicare Agency’s Use of Communications Contractors
keywords: ['Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Inspectors General', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Medicare']
abstract: An inspector general’s audit said the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Service used communications contractors for work that should have been performed by public servants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services violated federal contracting rules when its leaders misused communications consultants to burnish the image of the agency and its chief, Seema Verma, according to the Department of Health and Human Services’s inspector general.

headline: Portland, Masks, Captain Tom: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Flossie Wong-Staal, Who Unlocked Mystery of H.I.V., Dies at 73
abstract: A molecular biologist, she helped establish the virus as the cause of AIDS, then cloned it and took it apart to understand how it evades the immune system.
lead_paragraph: Flossie Wong-Staal, a molecular biologist who helped establish H.I.V. as the cause of AIDS, revealed the virus’s inner-workings by cloning it and then laid the foundation for treatments, died on July 8 in San Diego. She was 73.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Americans still can’t stop fighting about masks.
lead_paragraph: The United States continues to set daily infection records, with hospitalization and death rates on the rise — and Americans still can’t stop fighting about masks.

headline: Fighting Discrimination, a French Woman Becomes a Champion of Men
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Assa Traoré had long demanded justice for her half brother, Adama, who died in police custody. Now, she embodies France’s fight against discriminatory police violence.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Standing on a truck, her fist clenched high and her back turned to a row of police vans, Assa Traoré galvanized the crowd before her.

headline: Pence Attacks Biden at Wisconsin Campaign Event: ‘You Won’t Be Safe in Joe Biden’s America’
abstract: At a campaign stop in Ripon, Wis., Vice President Mike Pence on Friday suggested that a Biden presidency would fundamentally alter the fabric of the country.
lead_paragraph: At a campaign stop in Ripon, Wis., Vice President Mike Pence on Friday suggested that a Biden presidency would fundamentally alter the fabric of the country.

headline: Ex-Federal Reserve Chairs Urge More Economic Relief From Congress
abstract: Two former Federal Reserve chairs, Janet L. Yellen and Ben S. Bernanke, pushed for further economic relief from lawmakers, adding that it would take years before unemployment was back to pre-pandemic levels.
lead_paragraph: Two former Federal Reserve chairs, Janet L. Yellen and Ben S. Bernanke, pushed for further economic relief from lawmakers, adding that it would take years before unemployment was back to pre-pandemic levels.

headline: For Third Time This Week, the Federal Government Carries Out an Execution
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Dustin Lee Honken was put to death by lethal injection for the 1993 murders of five people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A 52-year-old man was put to death on Friday for the 1993 murders of five people, the third federal execution this week after a 17-year hiatus of federal capital punishment.

headline: The Justice Department’s Shameful Rush to Federal Executions
abstract: The push to impose the federal death penalty no matter the cost poses a grave threat to the rule of law.
lead_paragraph: Early on Tuesday morning, while much of the country was still asleep, the federal government executed its first death-row prisoner in 17 years. We are among the lawyers who represented the prisoner who was killed, Daniel Lee.

headline: The Tenacity of the Franco-American Ideal
abstract: Can a slave owner be celebrated for writing a liberating sentence?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Perhaps the root of the mutual fascination that binds France and the United States is that each sees itself as an idea, a model of some kind for the rest of the world. This is an immodest but tenacious notion, bound up with the founding articles and myths of both republics. No other countries make such claims for the universality of their virtue.

headline: 10 Fingers, 2 Feet and 5,000 Pipes, Breathing Life Into the Present
abstract: You don’t need to go to a jazz club to hear spontaneous riffs and exciting musical invention. You can go to church.
lead_paragraph: The last time I was in a church was the week before New York City’s coronavirus lockdown, nearly five months and a lifetime ago.

headline: Biden’s School Plan Draws Clear Contrast With Trump’s
abstract: Joseph Biden said the president’s insistence on getting students and teachers back in the classroom, despite the virus, was “just plain dangerous.” Mr. Biden also warned that Russia and China were engaged in election meddling.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2020 election between Joe Biden and President Trump.

headline: While Virus Surges, Georgia Governor Sues Atlanta Mayor to Block Mask Rules
abstract: Gov. Brian Kemp filed a lawsuit against Keisha Lance Bottoms, the mayor of Atlanta, to block the city’s mask requirement.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the season of the pandemic, governors and local leaders have bickered, at times fiercely, over the best way to safeguard the public health. But perhaps no place has seen these disputes break out into hostility quite like Georgia this week, which culminated in the governor filing a lawsuit against the mayor of the state’s capital and economic engine.

headline: The Legal System Should Not Be a Tool for Bullies
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Libel and Slander', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: A bill in New York would discourage frivolous lawsuits aimed at chilling free speech.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Legislature has before it an important bill that would discourage abusive lawsuits filed with the sole purpose of silencing critics. Known as SLAPPs, for strategic lawsuits against public participation, the suits are deliberate misuses of the legal system intended to choke off free speech.

headline: Jane Walentas, Who Planted a Carousel in Dumbo, Dies at 76
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Carousels', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: With her husband, David, Ms. Walentas helped develop the Brooklyn waterfront neighborhood into a desirable address — and gave it an unusual gift.
lead_paragraph: Jane Walentas, an artist who spent more than 20 years restoring a century-old carousel as a gift to the Brooklyn waterfront neighborhood that she helped her husband, David Walentas, develop, died on July 5 at her home in Southampton, N.Y. She was 76.

headline: Treacherous Times for Dr. Fauci in the Sacred Cow Business
abstract: As the Trump White House attacks the government’s top infectious disease expert, “What’s happening to Dr. Fauci?” has become an urgent topic in Washington and in science and medical circles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a while there, it looked possible that Dr. Anthony S. Fauci — the nation’s top infectious disease expert and a Washington sacred cow if there ever was one — might come away from the Trump White House unscathed. He was viewed as bipartisan (served six presidents!) and a savvy truth-teller able to skirt the reputational contagions that can accompany prolonged exposure to President Trump.

headline: Washington N.F.L. Harassment Report Shocked Many, but Not Women
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Women and Girls', 'Football', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Diversity and inclusion advocates said until the league fully addresses its toxic relationship with women, “those stories will keep coming.”
lead_paragraph: After news broke Thursday that there were accusations of rampant sexual harassment within the Washington N.F.L. franchise, several colleagues at women’s organizations hopped on their group chat.

headline: Gabriella Tucci, 90, Dies; Italian Soprano and Met Opera Mainstay
abstract: Ms. Tucci’s voice had luster, and she brought refinement to her singing. She sang 20 roles at the Met, where her heyday was the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Gabriella Tucci, an Italian soprano whose richly expressive voice and beguiling stage presence made her a mainstay at major international houses — including, for 13 consecutive seasons, the Metropolitan Opera — died on July 9 in Rome. She was 90.

headline: F.B.I. Agent in Russia Inquiry Saw Basis in Early 2017 to Doubt Dossier
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: Newly declassified documents added more fodder for the continuing political fight over an aspect of the Trump-Russia investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top F.B.I. agent recognized by February 2017 that a now notorious dossier of claims about purported Trump-Russia ties had credibility problems, but the Justice Department continued to rely on it as part of its basis to renew permission to wiretap a former Trump campaign adviser, documents released on Friday showed.

headline: Tiger Woods, Injured Grinder, Makes Cut at the Memorial
abstract: Woods slogged through back pain to birdie two of his final three holes on Friday, surviving the cut by one stroke.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — When he was younger, Tiger Woods looked forward to getting older.

headline: Were the Actions of Federal Agents in Portland Legal?
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Public Property']
abstract: The Department of Homeland Security can point to federal statutes protecting property to justify the arrests of protesters in Portland, Ore., but whether they stretched the law would be up to a judge.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security’s deployment of federal agents to Portland, Ore., has shown the broad legal authority an agency created to protect the United States from national security threats has to crack down on American citizens.

headline: Utility Company Gave Jobs to Allies of Top Illinois Democrat, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Illinois Speaker Michael J. Madigan has not been charged, but the governor, a fellow Democrat, said he must resign if the allegations are true.
lead_paragraph: When it came to a scheme to try to influence the speaker of the Illinois House, a politician so deft and powerful that he is known as the “Velvet Hammer,” a lobbyist had some plain advice for his client, Commonwealth Edison, the state’s largest electric utility, prosecutors say.

headline: Cheeky
abstract: John Guzzetta and Michael Hawkins present a puzzle with sass.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I blame the dog days for dulling my senses, but this collaboration between John Guzzetta and Michael Hawkins (their seventh for The Times, by my count) required me to take a second, closer look to fully appreciate the nuances. It’s not extremely hard for a Saturday, and there’s a breezy quality about it that made my brain coast a little bit, but there’s a lot of riffing going on throughout that makes for a really cool and clever grid.

headline: American Crime and the Baltimore Model
abstract: Cities across the country are in danger of making the same mistakes.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, there were 211 homicides in the city of Baltimore. The following year, there were 342, an astonishing increase of 62 percent. The murder rate has barely budged since.

headline: 50 Nights of Unrest in Portland
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Robert Evans of Bellingcat says the city “is being used as a bellwether to see what this administration can get away with.”
lead_paragraph: Thursday night marked the 50th consecutive night of demonstrations in Portland, Ore. The protests began after the killing of George Floyd — tens of thousands of people took to the streets to protest police violence and racial injustice. Since then, the protests have grown smaller, but clashes between law enforcement officers and protesters have escalated — on July 12, videos circulated of a federal officer shooting a protester in the head with a nonlethal munition, resulting in a skull fracture. Coverage of the unrest has caught the attention of President Trump, who vowed to “dominate” the protesters with federal law enforcement officers.

headline: John Lewis, Towering Figure of Civil Rights Era, Dies at 80
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Images of his beating at Selma shocked the nation and led to swift passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act. He was later called the conscience of the Congress.
lead_paragraph: Representative John Lewis, a son of sharecroppers and an apostle of nonviolence who was bloodied at Selma and across the Jim Crow South in the historic struggle for racial equality, and who then carried a mantle of moral authority into Congress, died on Friday. He was 80.

headline: John Lewis Risked His Life for Justice
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: His willingness to do so was essential to the quest for civil rights.
lead_paragraph: Representative John Lewis, who died Friday at age 80, will be remembered as a principal hero of the blood-drenched era not so long ago when Black people in the South were being shot, blown up or driven from their homes for seeking basic human rights. The moral authority Mr. Lewis exercised in the House of Representatives — while representing Georgia’s Fifth Congressional District for more than 30 years — found its headwaters in the aggressive yet self-sacrificial style of protests that he and his compatriots in the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee deployed in the early 1960s as part of the campaign that overthrew Southern apartheid.

headline: Quotation of the Day: To City’s Alarm, Federal Officers Police Portland
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 18, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “I feel like I’m being hunted for no reason.”

headline: Corrections: July 18, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 18, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the relationship between China and Iran misstated the location of the academic institution where an Iranian energy researcher is based. The researcher, Ali Gholizadeh, is at the University of Science and Technology of China in Hefei, not in Beijing.

headline: Praise for John Lewis Pours in From Nation’s Political Elite
abstract: Mr. Lewis, who died on Friday at 80, was instrumental in the historic struggle for racial equality in the United States. “He risked his life and his blood” for his country, former President Barack Obama said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A giant. A legendary leader. A civil rights icon. A human saint.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Father Soldier Son’ and the Dance on Camera Festival
abstract: Stream a documentary about a family shaped by war, and catch a festival that celebrates all the ways dance can be represented onscreen.
lead_paragraph: FATHER SOLDIER SON Stream on Netflix. This documentary, which was directed by the New York Times journalists Catrin Einhorn and Leslye Davis, has been 10 years in the making. Though much has been reported about the hardships some soldiers and their families face upon returning home from combat, this film focuses on one family and chronicles its changing dynamic. It begins in 2010, when Master Sgt. Brian Eisch, a single father, leaves two young sons for a yearlong deployment in Afghanistan. He then returns home following a serious injury, which requires his leg to be amputated below the knee. His experience at war and back at home — where he not only struggles physically, but with a loss of identity — ultimately affects what his sons hope for their own futures. “Life, in ‘Father Soldier Son’ does not move in a circle," Jessica Kiang wrote in her review for The New York Times, “but in an incrementally decaying orbit around the values that, in making us what we are, also keep us from being anything else."

headline: How PG&E Is Racing to Improve Safety as Fire Season Approaches
abstract: The utility, which recently emerged from bankruptcy, is upgrading power lines, trimming trees and making other changes to prevent another big fire.
lead_paragraph: NAPA, Calif. — Atop an electrical pole overlooking grapevines, Pacific Gas & Electric recently installed a piece of equipment that will allow it to quickly turn off power to this part of California’s wine country when conditions for a wildfire are just right.

headline: Long Waits for U.K. Hospital Treatment as N.H.S. Fights Coronavirus
abstract: With routine operations in England curtailed, some patients have experienced a significant deterioration.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After nine months of waiting for surgery, Ruth Fawcett’s knee muscles wasted away, causing her joint to come loose in its socket and leaving her unable to walk without assistance.

headline: Lost and Now Found, Leeds Returns to the Premier League
abstract: After 16 years away from English soccer’s top division, an era marred by sporting and financial batterings, Leeds United finally claimed a spot in the Premier League on Friday.
lead_paragraph: LEEDS, England — On the touchline, a member of the coaching staff had leapt into the arms of the defender Stuart Dallas, and was hanging onto him for dear life. Andrea Radrizzani, the team owner, was standing by the tunnel, embracing every player who approached him. In the stands, Victor Orta, the technical director, was pumping his arms and screaming into the sky.

headline: Hardcore Cyclists Head for the Hills … Mexico City’s
abstract: With new bike routes and the pandemic pushing more people to cycle, the mountains outside one of the world’s megacities are drawing new and veteran enthusiasts.
lead_paragraph: Among Mexico City’s bicycling enthusiasts, the mountain road that twists up through the canyon in Los Dinamos National Park on the outer edge of the city is a rite of passage.

headline: Battle in the Himalayas
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Satellites', 'International Relations', 'Territorial Disputes']
abstract: China and India are locked in a tense, deadly struggle for advantage on their disputed mountain border.
lead_paragraph: China and India are locked in a tense, deadly struggle for advantage on their disputed mountain border.

headline: The Horror Novel Lurking in Your Busy Online Life
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Social Media']
abstract: The genre relies on solitude and isolation to generate fear. But virtual connection is an illusion that cyber-horror writers are beginning to exploit.
lead_paragraph: In early April, at the height of the pandemic lockdown, Gianpiero Petriglieri, an Italian business professor, suggested on Twitter that being forced to conduct much of our lives online was making us sick. The constant video calls and Zoom meetings were draining us because they go against our brain’s need for boundaries: here versus not here. “It’s easier being in each other’s presence, or in each other’s absence,” he wrote, “than in the constant presence of each other’s absence.”

headline: Trump Promotes Caricature of What Conservatives Want
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: A series of events during his White House tenure has made clear that Mr. Trump views the voters he calls “my people” through the lens of what he imagines they like.
lead_paragraph: Standing in the White House colonnade this week, President Trump told an interviewer that he’s “comfortable” with “freedom of speech” extending to the Confederate flag.

headline: Exploring Their Own Paths Together
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Marriages']
abstract: Bonnie Brescia and Jeanette Poillon remain each other’s lifelines, even though both admit that they are polar opposites.
lead_paragraph: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In It’s No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned, revealing their secret to making it work. (Answers are edited for context and space.)

headline: Race Takes Center Stage as Rashida Tlaib Faces Primary Challenge
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Some of Detroit’s most prominent Black leaders are backing a challenger to Ms. Tlaib, a Palestinian-American who has gained celebrity status since winning her seat in 2018.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich. — Representative Rashida Tlaib, one of Congress’s most famous members, is perhaps best known for her membership in the progressive group known as “the squad” and her strident attacks on President Trump.

headline: Sing Figaro’s Aria and Diagram Your Garden
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Opera']
abstract: This week, watch Rossini’s ‘The Barber of Seville,’ learn the history of the ballot and chuckle at stand-up comics.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Why Trump’s Attacks on John Roberts Aren’t Working With Some Conservatives
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The Supreme Court has faded somewhat in importance as frustration with the president grows, according to Republicans in the Indiana county where the chief justice grew up.
lead_paragraph: LA PORTE, Ind. — Mitch Feikes is one of many conservatives who disagreed with some of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s recent decisions, including striking down a restrictive Louisiana abortion law and ruling against the White House in its effort to undo an Obama-era immigration program.

headline: What Is a Travel Columnist’s Role When Travel Stops?
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Rebates and Refunds', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Sarah Firshein, who writes a consumer advice column for The Times, found that her writing became more urgent after the coronavirus upended everything.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: For Families of 9/11 Victims, Virus Further Slows the Pace of Justice
abstract: With proceedings at Guantánamo Bay upended, chances are growing that the 20th anniversary will pass without the trial of the men accused of plotting the attack getting underway.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: Mistrust of a Coronavirus Vaccine Could Imperil Widespread Immunity
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Billions are being poured into developing a shot, but the rapid timetable and President Trump’s cheerleading are creating a whole new group of vaccine-hesitant patients.
lead_paragraph: Almost daily, President Trump and leaders worldwide say they are racing to develop a coronavirus vaccine, in perhaps the most urgent mission in the history of medical science. But the repeated assurances of near-miraculous speed are exacerbating a problem that has largely been overlooked and one that public health experts say must be addressed now: persuading people to actually get the shot.

headline: A Covid-19 Lesson: Some Seriously Ill Patients Can Be Treated at Home
abstract: To ease pressure on hospitals, Northwell Health brought medical workers, oxygen tanks and intravenous equipment into patients’ homes. Now Florida is taking cues.
lead_paragraph: Joan Murray had been home with Covid-19 for about a week when she ran into trouble. She had a fever of 103 degrees and chills that sent shivers up and down her spine. Her oxygen levels were dropping, and the tightness in her chest felt “as if somebody had bound up my lungs with string.”

headline: He Kept a Community’s Bears in Check, but He Won’t Anymore
keywords: ['Bears', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-animals', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Steve Searles, known as the ‘bear whisperer’ of Mammoth Lakes, Calif., quit his post after the coronavirus epidemic led to cuts in the town’s budget.
lead_paragraph: You can’t teach a misbehaving black bear a lesson through a Zoom conference call.

headline: Fire Hits Cathedral in French City of Nantes
abstract: The images of smoke pouring out of the Gothic building were a painful reminder of the fire that mauled Notre-Dame in Paris, but the authorities said the damage would not be as serious.
lead_paragraph: A fire broke out inside the cathedral of the western French city of Nantes in the early hours of Saturday, but the authorities quickly said there was no comparison with the blaze that engulfed Notre-Dame in Paris last year, despite ominous images of flames and smoke coming from the building.

headline: Someone Tore Down a Union Army Statue in Saratoga Springs. Why?
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Vandalism']
abstract: The monument in a New York park was dedicated to men who volunteered to fight for the Union during the Civil War. It is unclear who toppled it, and for what reason.
lead_paragraph: Early on Thursday morning, the police in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., found a cast iron and zinc statue torn down from its stone pedestal in Congress Park and scattered in pieces on the grass.

headline: ‘Our Role Is to Reduce Their Grief’
keywords: ['Cemeteries', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: None of Iraq’s existing graveyards wanted the bodies of Covid-19 patients. So Shiite leaders created a burial ground for them that is also open to Sunnis and Christians.
lead_paragraph: THE DESERT WEST OF NAJAF — There are no signs to signal the way to the New Valley of Peace, or, as the Iraqis call it, the “Corona cemetery.” But it’s not hard to find: Just follow the cars. It’s the only place they are headed on the rough desert road.

headline: Trump Administration Aims to Block New Funding for Coronavirus Testing and Tracing
abstract: The resistance to a funding proposal drafted by Senate Republicans has angered several members of the president’s party on Capitol Hill. The F.D.A. has issued emergency approval for pooled testing, a method that allows for much faster tracking of new infections.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of coronavirus cases and deaths globally.

headline: China Is Dismantling the Empire of a Vanished Tycoon
abstract: Three years after Xiao Jianhua was snatched from a luxury hotel in Hong Kong, Beijing is making it clear that his style of freewheeling finance is a thing of the past.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Xiao Jianhua was once a trusted financier to China’s ruling elite who came to represent an era of unbridled capitalism.

headline: This Border Town Was on the Rise. Then the Pandemic Hit.
abstract: How the closure of the U.S.-Canada border in March devastated the economy of a Washington town.
lead_paragraph: BLAINE, Wash. — Over the past couple of years, Mike Hill poured more than $3.5 million into renovating his Chevron gas station and opening a Starbucks next door. People from British Columbia were crossing the border in droves to buy cheap gas and milk in Blaine, Wash. It seemed like a slam dunk investment.

headline: How to Kill a Vampire: Not With This Kit, Apparently
abstract: The kit, complete with three crucifixes and a pistol, goes up for auction next week. Experts say it might not save you from the undead, but that’s beside the point.
lead_paragraph: Vampires, beware.

headline: Can I Stop Paying for Amenities That Closed Because of the Pandemic?
abstract: Gyms, playrooms and other commons spaces may be off limits, but that may not relieve your financial obligations.
lead_paragraph: Q: The gym, billiards room and children’s playroom in our apartment building have been closed for months, with no prospect of reopening anytime soon. We paid a premium for this apartment partly because of the amenity package. Now, we can’t use it. Should we get a credit for loss of services?

headline: Finally Write That Short Story
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)']
abstract: It’s time to stop talking about writing and write. The best-selling author of “Prep” and “Rodham” offers a plan.
lead_paragraph: Though some people have knocked out an entire short story in a single sitting, it’s more realistic to see writing a story not as an inspiration-fueled creative binge but as a multiweek project. It’s one you’re a lot likelier to finish if, rather than waiting for the muse, you create the possibility for inspiration by planning a time and setting up the circumstances that will allow you to write regularly. It also should be fun! The act of constructing plots, developing characters and creating dialogue can be challenging, even frustrating, but I never find it boring, and it just might allow you to escape from your daily life at the same time that you access the most imaginative parts of your own brain.

headline: As Seasonal Rains Fall, Dispute Over Nile Dam Rushes Toward a Reckoning
abstract: After a decade of construction, the hydroelectric dam in Ethiopia, Africa’s largest, is nearly complete. But there’s still no agreement with Egypt, which calls the structure a national security threat.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Every day now, seasonal rain pounds the lush highlands of northern Ethiopia, sending cascades of water into the Blue Nile, the twisting tributary of perhaps Africa’s most fabled river.

headline: The Crispiest Tofu Sandwich
abstract: Make Superiority Burger’s sandwich, or David Tanis’s black bean burger.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include Superiority Burger’s fried tofu sandwich (above), David Tanis’s black bean burger with a fried egg and Genevieve Ko’s crispy rice with shrimp, bacon and corn. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: Federal Officers Deployed in Portland Didn’t Have Proper Training, D.H.S. Memo Said
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: Rather than tamping down persistent protests in Portland, Ore., a militarized presence from federal officers seems to have re-energized them.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The federal agents facing a growing backlash for their militarized approach to weeks of unrest in Portland were not specifically trained in riot control or mass demonstrations, an internal Department of Homeland Security memo warned this week.

headline: Nicaragua’s Ruling Sandinistas Fall Victim to Covid-19, Highlighting the Disease’s Spread
abstract: The haphazard, politicized response to the pandemic by the country’s leaders has put the government’s own officials and supporters at particular risk.
lead_paragraph: A string of recent deaths across Nicaragua — including mayors, judges, police officials, sports figures, university rectors and government bureaucrats — is pointing to the chilling reality that the coronavirus is devastating this Central American country, although the government is not publicly acknowledging it.

headline: Republicans Keep Flunking Microbe Economics
abstract: Getting other people sick isn’t an “individual choice.”
lead_paragraph: Governor Ron DeSantis of Florida said something remarkably stupid the other day. I know, I know: it’s probably harder to find a day on which DeSantis didn’t say something stupid than a day on which he did. But this particular piece of thickheadedness, I’d argue, helps us understand why America’s response to the coronavirus has been so disastrous compared with other wealthy nations.

headline: A More Liberal Supreme Court? Not When It Comes to Voting Rights
keywords: ['Ex-Convicts', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Twenty-Sixth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Absentee Voting', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In four rulings in a row, the court has refused to ease voting restrictions.
lead_paragraph: For the fourth time since April, the Supreme Court this week made it harder for Americans to vote. The ruling, Justice Sonia Sotomayor wrote in dissent, was part of “a trend of condoning disfranchisement.”

headline: Officer Who Pressed His Knee on George Floyd’s Neck Drew Scrutiny Long Before
abstract: In more than 19 years on the Minneapolis police force, Mr. Chauvin had a reputation as a rigid workaholic with few friends. He sometimes made other officers uncomfortable.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The four teenagers drove around playing a game of Nerf Gun Assassin on a May evening before graduation in 2013. One of them randomly fired an orange dart out the window.

headline: London Police Urged to Apologize After Officer Knelt on Man’s Neck
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: In a video, the detainee, who is Black, can be heard repeating, “Get off my neck,” as a white officer pins him. His lawyer said the encounter mirrored the treatment of George Floyd in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The lawyer for a Black man who repeatedly asked a white officer to “get off my neck” as he was pinned to the sidewalk during an arrest in London told a court on Saturday that the encounter echoed the treatment of George Floyd in the United States and called for a police apology.

headline: The Doctor Versus the Denier
abstract: Anthony Fauci’s at the pool, but Donald Trump’s in deep.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Never mind Johnny Depp and Amber Heard.

headline: I Won’t Return to the Classroom, and You Shouldn’t Ask Me To
abstract: Please don’t make me risk getting Covid-19 to teach your child.
lead_paragraph: SEDRO-WOOLLEY, Wash. — Every day when I walk into work as a public-school teacher, I am prepared to take a bullet to save a child. In the age of school shootings, that’s what the job requires. But asking me to return to the classroom amid a pandemic and expose myself and my family to Covid-19 is like asking me to take that bullet home to my own family.

headline: Learning to Heal, With a Little Fur Machine
abstract: In Joan Bauer’s “Raising Lumie,” training a future guide dog helps a newly orphaned girl navigate loss.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows you’re not supposed to judge a book by its cover, but many of us do it anyway. In the case of Joan Bauer’s 14th novel, RAISING LUMIE (Viking, 288 pp., $16.99; ages 10 to 13), you might see the jacket photograph of a fuzzy yellow Labrador retriever puppy and assume you’re in for a cozy, heartwarming tale. You would be wrong. Sort of.

headline: Creating a More Equitable Economy
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Campaign Finance', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Readers react to policy recommendations on the pay gap, inequality, education and more in a special Sunday Review issue called “The Economy We Need.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Family-Friendly Movies Made by Diverse Filmmakers
abstract: These 8 movies were written, directed by and star people of color, and depict complex stories that can spark conversation.
lead_paragraph: For parents trying to figure out how to talk to their children about racism, film can be a useful tool for generating empathy. But many family-friendly movies with diverse casts are told from a white perspective, for a white audience. That can rob people of color of their turns as the hero, nullifying their voices. And the stories are usually about racism, presenting the issue as a problem to be solved, wrapping up in a neat resolution.

headline: Breathe Better With These Nine Exercises
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Nose', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Oxygen', 'Lungs', 'APNEA (SLEEP DISORDER)']
abstract: “You can’t be truly healthy unless you’re breathing correctly.”
lead_paragraph: Breathe. We do it roughly 25,000 times a day, but until recently few of us gave much thought to this automatic bodily function.

headline: Frans Nieuwendam, Who Knew Style and Had It, Dies at 60
abstract: He was a quiet force in fashion, though others knew him as the guy to try to impress on the rope line. He died of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Defying Kremlin, Protesters Stage Biggest Rally Yet in Russian Far East
abstract: Despite pleas and threats from Moscow, tens of thousands gathered peacefully in Khabarovsk and other cities to protest the arrest of a popular regional governor.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Ignoring pleas from the Kremlin for calm after more than a week of unrest, protesters in the Russian Far East on Saturday staged their biggest display of defiance yet, with tens of thousands of people pouring into the streets to protest the arrest of a popular regional governor.

headline: Travel The World With Your Ears
abstract: Podcasts can drop you anywhere on the map, without having to leave the comfort of your own couch.
lead_paragraph: At this point in the summer — and the pandemic — the desire to escape to a place far away might be overwhelming. Even with so many borders closed, podcasts can transport you elsewhere, making them a good alternative to real, out-of-the-house travel. Here’s a collection of immersive audio experiences that are almost as immersive as exploring the great wide world out there.

headline: The First Time John Lewis and I Integrated the Buses
abstract: We just got on and sat in the front row. The bus driver insisted that we move to the back. But we didn’t move.
lead_paragraph: John Lewis, the civil rights icon, died on Friday. He had announced in December that he had Stage 4 pancreatic cancer.

headline: Inside Trump’s Failure: The Rush to Abandon Leadership Role on the Virus

abstract: The roots of the nation’s current inability to control the pandemic can be traced to mid-April, when the White House embraced overly rosy projections to proclaim victory and move on.

headline: Inside the Failure: 5 Takeaways on Trump’s Effort to Shift Responsibility
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Disease Rates']
abstract: President Trump and his top aides sharply shifted their pandemic strategy in mid-April after seizing on optimistic data suggesting the virus would disappear, a Times investigation found.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and his top aides decided to shift primary responsibility for the coronavirus response to the states during a critical period of weeks in mid-April, eagerly seizing on overly optimistic predictions that the pandemic was fading so the president could reopen the economy and focus on his re-election, a New York Times investigation found.

headline: Trump Weighs In on the Death of John Lewis, One of His Most Vocal Critics
abstract: The president, who once described Mr. Lewis’s district as “crime infested,” expressed his condolences on Twitter a day after the congressman’s death.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican governor of Georgia said that the country will “never be the same” without Representative John Lewis, who died Friday at age 80. The Democratic speaker of the house called Mr. Lewis “a titan of the civil rights movement.” The House minority leader said that Mr. Lewis “never stopped working to improve the lives of others.”

headline: Brigid Berlin, Socialite Who Joined Warhol’s World, Dies at 80
abstract: Born into privilege, she rejected her upbringing to become a fixture on the New York underground art scene of the 1960s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Here is one way to make a first impression.

headline: Doing Schoolwork in the Parking Lot Is Not a Solution
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Rural Areas', 'Quarantines', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Buses', 'Law and Legislation', 'Wireless Communications', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: In a pandemic-plagued country, high-speed internet connections are a civil rights issue.
lead_paragraph: When Autumn Lee, a pre-med junior at the University of New Mexico, needs to download lectures or class assignments, she hops in her car and drives 45 minutes to the McDonald’s nearest to her town of Sanders, Ariz., to connect to reliable Wi-Fi from her car. After the university sent students home because of the coronavirus pandemic, Ms. Lee grew frustrated with what she said is expensive and data-restricted internet service in Sanders, an unincorporated village of fewer than 1,000 people in eastern Arizona. Relying on her smartphone data plan wasn’t much of an alternative. “It took one or two hours to watch a 20-minute lecture,” she said. “I just got so frustrated, I figured there had to be another way.” So she made the 40-mile trek several times each week — and she’ll likely have to keep doing it now that the school has canceled nearly all in-person classes for the fall.

headline: Older Children Spread the Coronavirus Just as Much as Adults, Large Study Finds
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantines', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Children and Childhood', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Research', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: The study of nearly 65,000 people in South Korea suggests that school reopenings will trigger more outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: In the heated debate over reopening schools, one burning question has been whether and how efficiently children can spread the virus to others.

headline: The Real White Fragility
abstract: Does the white upper class feel exhausted and oppressed by meritocracy?
lead_paragraph: In 2001, when I was still attending college, David Brooks wrote an essay for The Atlantic called “The Organization Kid,” in which he spent a lot of time with young Ivy Leaguers and came away struck by their basic existential contentment. Instead of campus rebels, they were résumé builders and accomplishment collectors and apple polishers, distinguished by their serenity, their faux-adult professionalism, their politesse.

headline: ‘They Didn’t Just Love Him. They Knew Him.’ Young Atlanta Activists Mourn John Lewis.
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Mr. Lewis, who died on Friday, served as a connective tissue linking the lions of the civil rights movement to a new generation of activists in the city.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — By the time the Rev. James Woodall came to know John Lewis, Mr. Lewis was already a longtime congressman and a towering figure in the civil rights movement, one whose legacy loomed large over Atlanta.

headline: Oakland Will Pay $32.7 Million to Settle Ghost Ship Fire Lawsuits
abstract: The 2016 fire, which consumed a converted warehouse that had housed an artist colony, killed 36 people. It was the nation’s deadliest structure fire in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: The city of Oakland, Calif., has agreed to pay nearly $33 million to settle lawsuits filed on behalf of the victims of a fire that killed 36 people in a two-story converted warehouse in 2016.

headline: Remembering John Lewis, a Civil Rights Icon
abstract: Readers pay tribute to a man one calls “this nation’s conscience.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The New Rules of Dating
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Online Dating', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: Some people are single and ready to mingle (or … more than that), even amid a global pandemic. Here are some tips for doing so safely.
lead_paragraph: Dating is a complicated and often clumsy dance even in the best of times. Add in mask-wearing directives, social distancing and fear of a highly contagious virus for which there is no cure, and you get… well, an awful lot of people going out and doing some version of it anyway. A survey conducted by Everlywell — a company that makes at-home health tests — found that nearly one in four Americans ages 20 to 31 broke quarantine to have sexual contact with someone in April, when stay-at-home orders were at their peak.

headline: Doubles Play
abstract: We’re all made redundant in Wyna Liu’s Sunday debut.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I often marvel at the number of clean theme entries a deft constructor comes up with for a Sunday grid (especially when I can’t come up with a single one, as often happens). When I figured out the trick today, I went in the opposite direction and briefly imagined how fun a giant mega-puzzle would be, with 26 examples, if that would even be possible. It’d certainly be over the top, maybe even in excess!

headline: Blue Jays Can’t Play Games in Canada Because of Pandemic
abstract: Canada’s immigration minister said repeated cross-border travel among players and staff members posed a health risk. The team is likely to play the regular season in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball’s plan to use all 30 home ballparks for a shortened, 60-game season met an immovable obstacle on Saturday: the Canadian government. The Toronto Blue Jays, the only team in the league that is based outside the United States, will not be allowed to stage home games during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: From the Archive: ‘Forgiving George Wallace’

headline: 2 Republican Senators Post Photos of Elijah Cummings in John Lewis Tributes

lead_paragraph: Like thousands of other Americans, Senators Marco Rubio and Dan Sullivan took to social media on Saturday to mourn the death of Representative John Lewis, a venerated figure of the civil rights movement.

headline: Who Were the Freedom Riders?
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Discrimination', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Buses']
abstract: Representative John Lewis was among the 13 original Freedom Riders, who encountered violence and resistance as they rode buses across the South, challenging the nation’s segregation laws.
lead_paragraph: Representative John Lewis, who died on Friday at 80, was an imposing figure in American politics and the civil rights movement. But his legacy of confronting racism directly, while never swaying from his commitment to nonviolence, started long before he became a national figure.

headline: Amid a Pandemic, Supporters Hope John Lewis Can Still Lie in State in the Capitol
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: More than 40 people have lain in state in the Capitol after their deaths. Some in Congress want the civil rights icon and 17-term congressman to receive the honor, even as the building remains closed to the public.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Elijah E. Cummings became the first Black lawmaker to lie in state in the Capitol last fall, the public poured into Statuary Hall, a choir from Morgan State University sang and admirers cried and hugged.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Tests (Medical)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has balked at providing billions of dollars to fund coronavirus testing and shore up federal health agencies as the virus surges across the country, complicating efforts to reach agreement on the next round of pandemic aid.

headline: Death of John Lewis Fuels Movement to Rename Edmund Pettus Bridge
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The bridge became a flash point on March 7, 1965, as protesters, led by Mr. Lewis and other civil rights leaders, were stopped and beaten by state troopers as they marched to Alabama’s capital.
lead_paragraph: The death of Representative John Lewis on Friday has renewed interest in a campaign to rename the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala., the site of a turning point in the fight for civil rights.

headline: 3 Dead After Glacier Tour Bus Rolls Over in Canadian Rockies
abstract: The vehicle, with 27 people on board, was specially designed to carry visitors onto one of North America’s largest glaciers, in Jasper National Park in Alberta.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A popular tourist outing in the Rocky Mountains in Alberta turned into a scene of chaos after a glacier tour bus rolled on Saturday afternoon, killing three passengers and injuring 24 others on board, according to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 19, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “This feels and looks so different. It is so much more massive and all inclusive. There will be no turning back.”

headline: Southern Europe Opens Its Doors to Tourists. Not Many Are Coming.
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Quarantines', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Most tourist beds are empty in Spain’s Canary Islands. Bookings are down in Italy despite government incentives. And ferries to the Greek islands are carrying less than half the load they once did.
lead_paragraph: ADEJE, Spain — Music blared from a beachfront cafe along the normally bustling southwestern coast of Tenerife, the largest of Spain’s Canary Islands. But several tables sat empty, a month after a Covid-19 lockdown had ended, and the doors to many resorts remained shut.

headline: India Rounds Up Critics Under Shadow of Virus Crisis, Activists Say
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Quarantines', 'Politics and Government', 'Hinduism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Political Prisoners', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']

headline: Corrections: July 19, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 19, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about artists in Newark amid the pandemic and protests misstated the name of a museum. It is the Newark Museum of Art, not the Newark Museum.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘The Last Dance’ and ‘United Shades of America’
abstract: Stream all 10 hours of Michael Jordan’s documentary series, and catch a new season of W. Kamau Bell’s CNN show.
lead_paragraph: THE LAST DANCE Stream on Netflix. After debuting on ESPN in May, all 10 hours of this Michael Jordan documentary are available to stream. The series, which was produced by ESPN Films, Netflix and Jordan himself, chronicles the athlete’s legacy and time with the Chicago Bulls, including the team’s storied 1998 season. As Wesley Morris wrote in his Critic’s Notebook for The New York Times, “The series is this ocean of archival game clips, dunk montages, smack talk, mea culpas, cigar smoking, backstabbing, frontstabbing, manfully restrained tears, endorsements of the triangle offense” and “interviews with anybody who even blinked at the N.B.A. from 1984 to 1998.”

headline: They Came From Moose Jaw and Kapuskasing. They Were the New York Rangers.
abstract: The team’s move to Canada to train and finish the N.H.L. season recalls a time in the 1960s and ’70s when training up there was standard. And most of the team was Canadian.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic has forced the N.H.L. to finish its season at two hubs in Canada, Edmonton and Toronto.

headline: Roger Stone Denies Using Racial Slur on Radio Show
abstract: Though the audio suggests otherwise, Mr. Stone said he did not use a slur in referring to his interviewer, who is Black. He also contended that the word was not offensive.
lead_paragraph: Roger Stone, the political operative who was spared a prison sentence this month by his friend President Trump, denied on Sunday that he had uttered a racial slur on a radio show the night before, calling the accusation a “smear” while also contending the word was not offensive.

headline: ‘One Day While I Was Shopping at Macy’s, I Lost Track of the Time’

headline: The Tokyo Olympics Will Open a Year From Now. Maybe.
abstract: Japan has largely controlled the coronavirus. Large parts of the rest of the world, especially the United States, have not. A year before the rescheduled Games, that is still a major problem.
lead_paragraph: A year from now, the world will begin to gather in Japan to celebrate the opening of the Tokyo Olympics, which were originally supposed to begin this week.

headline: ‘Demagogue’ Remembers a Vintage American Bully
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Larry Tye talks about his new biography of Joseph McCarthy, the senator whose name is synonymous with reckless accusation and fear-mongering.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not often that a man’s name becomes an ism,” Larry Tye writes in his new biography of Joseph McCarthy, the senator from Wisconsin whose crusade against Communism ensured that his name would endure as “a synonym for reckless accusation, guilt by association, fear-mongering and political double-dealing.” Tye writes in his preface that while the book focuses on McCarthy’s life, it’s also about a particularly American strain of demagogy that has existed from the country’s earliest days to Huey Long to George Wallace to the “astonishing ascension of President Donald J. Trump.” Below, Tye discusses McCarthy’s fanaticism, his enablers, his military experience and more.

headline: Why Intellectuals Support Dictators
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Politics and Government', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Anne Applebaum’s “Twilight of Democracy” examines the role of thinkers and writers who back modern authoritarians.
lead_paragraph: TWILIGHT OF DEMOCRACYThe Seductive Lure of AuthoritarianismBy Anne Applebaum

headline: How Buying Beans Became a Political Statement
abstract: The boycott and counter-boycott of Goya come as the major political parties seek to energize Hispanic support ahead of the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: For years, the Goya brand was synonymous with the Latino-American dream. The sheer number of products that lined the grocery store aisles — from refried pinto beans to sazón con azafran seasoning — spoke to the growing number of Hispanic immigrants who bought them. Goya, the nation’s largest Hispanic food company, has sponsored Dominican art shows, mariachi contests and soccer programs.

headline: During Coronavirus Lockdowns, Some Doctors Wondered: Where Are the Preemies?
abstract: Hospitals in several countries saw dips in premature births, which could be a starting point for future research.
lead_paragraph: This spring, as countries around the world told people to stay home to slow the spread of the coronavirus, doctors in neonatal intensive care units were noticing something strange: Premature births were falling, in some cases drastically.

headline: Why a ‘Do No Harm’ General Election Strategy Could Work for Joe Biden

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Make a meal with what you have on hand, whether it’s chicken and rice soup, or a chickpea salad with herbs and scallions.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Family meal is what restaurant people call the dinner served to the staff before service, which is the term they use to describe when the restaurant is open to customers. Family meals are generally made by a line cook, someone who works a particular station in the kitchen — the grill, say, or the stove. A line cook is not the restaurant’s chef, but answers to one or to the chef’s lieutenant, who is known as a sous chef. This is all in keeping with the system by which the French first organized the professional kitchen: a brigade de cuisine.

But now that the coronavirus has left Midtown Manhattan largely deserted, it is facing a $4 million budget shortfall that may threaten its ability to pay its bills.

headline: Which Country Will Triumph in the Post-Pandemic World?
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Hint: It’s not the United States or China.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a country, a major Western economic power, where the coronavirus arrived late but the government, instead of denying and delaying, acted early. It was ready with tests and contact tracing to “flatten the curve” swiftly and limited its death rate to orders of magnitude lower than that of any other major Western industrial nation. Containing the virus allowed for a brief and targeted lockdown, which helped limit unemployment to only 6 percent. Amid a shower of international praise, the country’s boringly predictable leader experienced a huge spike in popular approval, to 70 percent from 40 percent.

In this martial arts film Ip Man (Donnie Yen), a real-life Wing Chun master who inspired the series, leaves Hong Kong for San Francisco, where he finds that the popularity of his student, Bruce Lee (Chan Kwok-Kwan Danny), has stirred tensions in the city. Some members of the local Chinese community are opposed to sharing martial arts secrets with non-Chinese students. headline: Businesses Are Supposed to Cut Debt in a Downturn. Why Not Now?

headline: A Stadium at Iowa State Says His Name: Jack Trice
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Football', 'Football (College)', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Names, Organizational', 'Sports Injuries']

headline: Jackie Robinson’s Inner Struggle
abstract: Books by an American icon tell the story of his battle against bigotry from the inside.
lead_paragraph: It was Tuesday, Sept. 30, 1947 — Game 1 of the World Series between the New York Yankees and the Brooklyn Dodgers — and Jack Roosevelt “Jackie” Robinson was making history. The Dodger first baseman was standing in a packed Yankee Stadium about to hear the national anthem. From a distance, the tableau can seem an inspiring inflection point: the first Black major leaguer in the 20th century playing in the first televised World Series. “There I was,” Robinson recalled in his 1972 memoir “I Never Had It Made: An Autobiography,” “the Black grandson of a slave, the son of a Black sharecropper, part of a historic occasion, a symbolic hero to my people.” So far, so good: The safe narrative of Robinson-as-stoic-hero is intact. “The band struck up the national anthem,” he wrote. “It should have been a glorious moment for me as the stirring words … poured from the stands.” Yet if we see the scene through Robinson’s eyes — and hear the anthem through his ears — we encounter an altogether different story. Writing a quarter of a century after the 1947 World Series, Robinson observed, “I cannot stand and sing the anthem. I cannot salute the flag; I know that I am a Black man in a white world. In 1972, in 1947, at my birth in 1919, I know that I never had it made.”

headline: How to Identify Flawed Research Before It Becomes Dangerous
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'News and News Media', 'Research', 'Academic and Scientific Journals', 'Newspapers', 'Crowdsourcing (Internet)']

Yet what goes around can come around. Legal strategies that have derailed pipelines can also be turned against clean energy projects urgently needed to combat climate change.
