lead_paragraph: The debate about reopening schools seems to pit parents and their employers against teachers. But there is actually a solution that would let grown-ups go back to work, educate kids and keep everyone safe at the same time.

headline: A Timely Case on Police Violence at the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Search and Seizure', 'Immunity from Prosecution', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The justices will hear arguments in October over whether excessive force claims against the police are barred when the people they shoot get away.
lead_paragraph: Early on a summer morning in Albuquerque in 2014, two state police officers in dark tactical gear arrived at a housing complex to serve an arrest warrant. In the parking lot, they came upon Roxanne Torres, sitting in her car with the engine running.

headline: With a U.N. Veto, Russia and China Add to Syria’s Misery
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Moscow and Beijing are callously restricting humanitarian aid to Syria’s suffering civilians as part of their campaign to prop up Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month in the United Nations Security Council, the world saw a preview of what Russian and Chinese global “leadership” looks like: a world order where the most vulnerable suffer for the political gains of those at the top.

headline: The Link Between Parkinson’s Disease and Toxic Chemicals
keywords: ["Parkinson's Disease", 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Pesticides', 'Chemicals', 'Water Pollution', 'Smoking and Tobacco']
abstract: A new book calls the increasing prominence of Parkinson’s “a man-made pandemic.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Richard Clifford, a 66-year-old retired astronaut living in Cary, N.C., learned before his third spaceflight that he had Parkinson’s disease. He was only 44 and in excellent health at the time, and had no family history of this disabling neurological disorder.

headline: Downsizing From a Two-Bedroom to a Studio
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: A couple moved from a two-bedroom to a studio late last fall. But even after four months of quarantine, they don’t regret the decision.
lead_paragraph: Cooped up at home these last four months, many New Yorkers have found themselves longing for larger apartments. But Kayla Oberlin and her partner Inbar Madar, who moved from a two-bedroom in Bushwick to a studio apartment in a Williamsburg high-rise late last fall, are not among them.

headline: Would the Prophet Muhammad Convert Hagia Sophia?
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Mosques', 'Churches (Buildings)', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: Turkey’s decision to change the former cathedral into a mosque flies against the pluralist instincts of Islam’s founders.
lead_paragraph: The recent decision by the Turkish government to reconvert the majestic Hagia Sophia, which was once the world’s greatest cathedral, from a museum back to a mosque has been bad news for Christians around the world. They include Pope Francis, who said he was “pained” by the move, and the spiritual leader of Eastern Christianity, Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew, who said he was “saddened and shaken.” When contrasted with the joy of Turkey’s conservative Muslims, all this may seem like a new episode in an old story: Islam vs. Christianity.

headline: The Pandemic Has Pushed Aside City Planning Rules. But to Whose Benefit?
keywords: ['Urban Areas', 'Zoning', 'Income Inequality', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: As bike lanes and cafes sprout on streets, marginalized residents wonder when their priorities will get attention.
lead_paragraph: One month into the coronavirus crisis this spring, Oakland, Calif., began to restrict car traffic on some streets — ultimately on 21 miles of them — to create outdoor space for residents who suddenly had nowhere else to go.

headline: Building Accessibility Into America, Literally
abstract: Thirty years on, the Americans With Disabilities Act has reshaped the way designers and the public have come to think about equity, civil rights and American architecture. But it’s only a start.
lead_paragraph: The Capitol Crawl, it came to be called. In March 1990, several dozen activists, cheered on by supporters, left their canes and wheelchairs and pulled themselves up the steep stone steps of the United States Capitol.

headline: A Rush to Use Black Art Leaves the Artists Feeling Used
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Art']
abstract: Black creative professionals say they have been used to lend legitimacy to diversity campaigns while being underpaid and pigeonholed.
lead_paragraph: The streets of New York were crowded with protesters when Shantell Martin received an email from an ad agency last month.

headline: N.Y.C. Enters Phase 4, but Restaurants and Bars Are Left Behind
abstract: As the city reaches what should have been a momentous day, a wild weekend in Astoria shows the risks that bars can pose.
lead_paragraph: For the 25,000 restaurants and bars in New York City, Monday was supposed to be a day of celebration — the turning point when the city would enter Phase 4, the final phase of reopening after the coronavirus outbreak.

headline: ‘If It’s Here, It’s Here’: America’s Retirees Confront the Virus in Florida
abstract: As cases spike across Florida, the virus appears to have caught up with the residents of the Villages.
lead_paragraph: THE VILLAGES, Fla. — For months, many of the residents at one of America’s biggest retirement communities went about their lives as if the coronavirus barely existed. They played bridge. They held dances. They went to house parties in souped-up golf carts that looked like miniature Jaguars and Rolls-Royces.

headline: Yankee Stadium Area Is Hurting, and Baseball’s Return Won’t Help
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Unemployment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Small Business']
abstract: Merchants and vendors around the ballpark are struggling to survive in a summer devoid of the usual crowds.
lead_paragraph: By this point in a normal summer, the New York Yankees would have drawn more than 1.8 million fans to their palatial stadium in the South Bronx. On game days, the bars and souvenir shops around the ballpark would be overflowing with customers.

headline: The Black Sanitation Workers Who Are Saying, ‘I Am a Man’
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Organized Labor', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: A determined handful of men in New Orleans carry on the cause Dr. King died defending in Memphis.
lead_paragraph: “All labor has dignity,” the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. told striking sanitation workers in Memphis more than 50 years ago.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Elections, Senate', 'Campaign Finance']

headline: Without Music, Tanglewood Is Empty, Eerie and Beautiful
keywords: ['Tanglewood Music Festival (Lenox, Mass)', 'Music', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Classical Music']
abstract: The usually tourist-packed Berkshires confronts a season without the music festival that anchors its summers.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — André Bernard was three months old when he attended his first concert at Tanglewood: Benny Goodman playing Mozart’s Clarinet Concerto, in 1956. For nearly every one of the next 63 years, he has made a pilgrimage to the lush, sprawling lawn of this summer music mecca here in the Berkshires.

headline: A Glimpse Inside the Workshops of the World’s Finest Panama Hat Makers
abstract: Creamy as silk and costlier than gold, a Montecristi superfino Panama hat is as much a work of art as it is of fashion.
lead_paragraph: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Roff Smith shares a collection of photographs from the workshops of hat artisans in Ecuador.

headline: New York City’s Phase 4, Explained
abstract: It's a landmark in the reopening process, but with bans remaining on indoor dining, cinemas and museums, life is hardly back to normal.

headline: With Tourists Gone, Bali Workers Return to Farms and Fishing
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Unemployment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Many resort workers have gone home to villages and small towns, taking up traditional ways of earning a living to feed themselves and their families.
lead_paragraph: LALANGLINGGAH VILLAGE, Indonesia — Ni Nyoman Ayu Sutaryani, a mother of three, made a steady living for two decades working as a masseuse and yoga instructor at Bali’s luxury hotels and spas. Now at 37 she finds herself back on the farm of her childhood village here, standing precariously at the top of a tall bamboo ladder, picking cloves.

headline: Death and Testing
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: President Trump gave a confrontational interview to Chris Wallace of Fox News yesterday that included numerous untruths about the coronavirus. Trump claimed that the United States had the lowest death rate in the world; that new cases were surging here mostly because of the large number of tests; and that his virus response had saved “millions of lives.”

headline: REI’s response to virus cases angers employees.
abstract: The outdoor equipment co-op REI is facing a backlash over its handling of coronavirus cases among its employees, with some nervous workers pushing for more transparency as stores reopen.

abstract: A militarized crackdown raises an outcry from local leaders: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Armed federal agents are patrolling the streets of Portland against the wishes of local leaders, and the president refuses to guarantee that he won’t contest the official results of the election. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Delta says passengers who don’t wear masks face a health screening.
abstract: Delta Air Lines said it would require passengers unable to wear face masks because of health conditions to undergo a medical clearance at the airport before boarding — or the passengers should “reconsider travel” altogether.
lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines said it would require passengers unable to wear face masks because of health conditions to undergo a medical clearance at the airport before boarding — or the passengers should “reconsider travel” altogether.

abstract: Corporate leaders are increasingly gloomy about the economic recovery, citing the fight over masks and the prospect of renewed lockdowns.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong, considered an exemplar of coronavirus containment, is seeing a surge in infections — a warning for the rest of the world. And a new study in South Korea suggests that children older than 10 can spread the virus as readily as adults, which could complicate school reopenings. More on that below. (Want this delievered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)

headline: ‘I Have to Go in and Decolonize’: Europe’s Black Theater Makers Discuss the Scene
abstract: Kwame Kwei-Armah, Julia Wissert and Eva Doumbia met online this week to talk about challenging the establishment, Black Lives Matter and the issue of white universality.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This summer, a coalition of American theater artists issued a statement, “We See You, White American Theater,” calling for an overhaul of the country’s theater landscape. There should be term limits on theater industry leaders to improve representation, it said, and at least half of casts and creative teams should be people of color.

headline: A Retelling of American History — in Neon
abstract: Maya Stovall, known for her dance performances in public spaces, shares a new artwork.
lead_paragraph: In this new series, The Artists, an installment of which will publish every day this week and regularly thereafter, T will highlight a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist, putting the work into context. First up is a piece by Maya Stovall, who is best known for her dance performances in public spaces, as documented in her “Liquor Store Theater” video series, which will screen this summer as part of the citywide digital-art exhibition “Art Mile Detroit.”

headline: Top Democrats Send Letter on Possible Foreign Meddling in November Election
abstract: Georgia Democrats named Nikema Williams as successor to John Lewis. President Trump threatened to send federal troops to cities run by the “radical left” to temper unrest. And the Jacksonville sheriff said the city was not ready to provide security for the Republican convention.

headline: In a Time of Crisis, Is Art Essential?
abstract: T’s 2020 summer art issue coincides with a breakdown of the status quo, both in the art world and the real one. Not for nothing, we’ve titled it “True Believers.”
lead_paragraph: For the last two summers, T has published an online art issue in which we celebrate artistic freedom in the face of overwhelming odds. Traditionally, these odds have revolved around an international supply chain largely fueled by greed: The small but powerful ecosystem that we refer to as “the art world” has always exploited artists to protect its profit margins.

headline: American Fashion Nominates the Designers of the Year. They Really Make You Think.
abstract: But not in a good way. The Oscars of fashion reflect exactly what the industry needs to change.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus prompted the Council of Fashion Designers of America to postpone the 2020 CFDA Fashion Awards, the annual “Oscars of the Fashion World” (industry prom) originally scheduled for June 8, it seemed like another glittering evening of voyeurism and celebration had fallen to the pandemic.

headline: Once a Model City, Hong Kong Grapples With a New Coronavirus Wave
abstract: Doctors are seeing more cases a day than they had in previous outbreaks, and a number of infections with unknown origin have made the outbreak harder to contain.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong once seemed like a model for how to control the coronavirus. Schools were open. Restaurants and malls buzzed with crowds. Buses and trains operated as usual, with residents dutifully wearing face masks on board.

headline: What You Get for $2.4 Million in California
abstract: A Tudor Revival house in Los Angeles, a contemporary home in Menlo Park and a Craftsman-style bungalow in Carpinteria.
lead_paragraph: A Tudor Revival house in Los Angeles, a contemporary home in Menlo Park and a Craftsman-style bungalow in Carpinteria.

headline: $2.4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Tudor Revival house in Los Angeles, a contemporary home in Menlo Park and a Craftsman-style bungalow in Carpinteria.
lead_paragraph: This house, in the Hollywood Dell section of the Hollywood Hills, was built in the Tudor Revival style popular in 1920s Los Angeles. The actor David Niven, who once lived here, wrote about it in his memoir, “The Moon’s a Balloon.”

headline: H.I.V. Survivors Confront Painful Memories and New Risks in Pandemic
abstract: Monday: Around Palm Springs, survivors of the AIDS crisis found community, but old fears are returning. Also: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced school reopening rules.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘A Place Where Everybody Can Shop’ Is Closing Its Doors
abstract: The famed department store Tati is shutting. And a lot of people are very sad.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Tati is a ghost of what it once was, and soon it won’t even be that. Shelves that were crammed with dish-scrubbers and brassieres for $1.50 and plaster figurines of smiling bunnies are now bare. Exits are still numbered — how else to find your way out through the crowds — but the aisles are empty. There are no crowds.

The Japanese-American Sculptor Who, Despite Persecution, Made Her Mark
abstract: Seven years after her death, Ruth Asawa is finally being recognized as an American master. What can we learn from this overdue reappraisal?
lead_paragraph: IN 2009, THE New York City auction house Christie’s received an unsolicited query: A woman named Addie Lanier had a painting by Josef Albers, the midcentury abstract artist who pioneered modern arts education. Could Christie’s help her sell it? It wasn’t uncommon for a major auction house like Christie’s to get cold calls. News generated by large sales can create curiosity and spark interest; people often approach auction houses in the hope of confirming that they have been sitting on priceless works of art. Jonathan Laib — then a senior vice president and senior specialist of postwar and contemporary art at Christie’s — was excited to hear of an Albers.

headline: Here’s the business news to watch this week.
abstract: More than 90 companies listed on the S&P 500 report their latest earnings this week. So far, 73 percent of blue-chip companies that have released second-quarter results beat analyst expectations, according to FactSet. Can they keep it up?
lead_paragraph: More than 90 companies listed on the S&P 500 report their latest earnings this week. So far, 73 percent of blue-chip companies that have released second-quarter results beat analyst expectations, according to FactSet. Can they keep it up?

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Fix yourself a sandwich, whether it’s Melissa Clark’s garlicky interpretation, full of juicy tomatoes, or one of your own making.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. My pal Ricky turned me on to a breakfast sandwich of the sort I used to order in delis or bodegas or bagel shops, back when I frequented them daily: toasted sesame bagel with butter and Swiss cheese. That’s a great sandwich: simple, salty, vaguely sweet, with a tang from the cheese. If you ask for it with ham, stipulate one slice only. Any more than that, and it’s a lunch sandwich, better consumed with mayonnaise and mustard, sliced pickles, a side of chips.

headline: U.K. Suspends Extradition Treaty With Hong Kong Over Security Law
abstract: Several foreign governments have criticized the new law, which gives China broad powers to crack down on political crimes in the territory.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In an escalation of tensions with China, Britain on Monday suspended an extradition treaty with Hong Kong to protest a new security law that gives China sweeping powers and is seen by critics as imperiling basic freedoms in the former British colony.

headline: ‘Total Bellas’ Refuse to Be Knocked Out by Quarantine
abstract: The twin reality stars and retired WWE champions Nikki and Brie Bella are both pregnant and making TV.
lead_paragraph: When Nikki and Brie Bella, twin sisters who are also reality stars and recently retired WWE champions, found out they were both pregnant last November, they were most excited about the pizookies.

headline: From Good Wine, a Direct Path to the Wonders of Nature
abstract: For this city dweller, wine provided the opening to a greater understanding of food and agriculture, and their precarious balance.
lead_paragraph: Last year a friend asked me a question I had never considered before: Over the many years I had been writing about wine, what was the greatest thing this job had given me?

headline: There Are Wasps in the Yard. You’d Better Get to Know Them.
abstract: They buzz. They hover. Sometimes they sting. But how much do you really know about these insects that can menace our summers?
lead_paragraph: Wasps get a bad rap. And sometimes, they deserve it. Bumblebees don’t swarm your barbecue the moment you pour the lemonade. Butterflies won’t nest by the hundreds in your rafters, then sting you for the crime of walking by.

headline: ‘Anti-Feminist’ Lawyer Is Suspect in Killing of Son of Federal Judge in N.J.
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Roy Den Hollander had openly seethed against the judge, Esther Salas. After the shooting at her home, he was found dead in an apparent suicide.
lead_paragraph: Roy Den Hollander was a self-described “anti-feminist” lawyer who flooded the courts with seemingly frivolous lawsuits that sought to eliminate women’s studies programs and prohibit nightclubs from holding “ladies’ nights.”

headline: Global Warming Is Driving Polar Bears Toward Extinction, Researchers Say
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Polar Bears', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Research', 'Ice', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: By century’s end, polar bears worldwide could become nearly extinct as a result of shrinking sea ice in the Arctic if climate change continues unabated, scientists said.
lead_paragraph: Polar bears could become nearly extinct by the end of the century as a result of shrinking sea ice in the Arctic if global warming continues unabated, scientists said Monday.

headline: Georgia Democrats Choose Nikema Williams to Fill John Lewis’s Seat in Congress
abstract: Ms. Williams, a state senator, is considered the overwhelming favorite in the general election this fall.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Nikema Williams, a state senator from Atlanta, emerged from a conclave of Georgia Democratic officials on Monday as the appointed successor to Representative John Lewis, taking his place on the November ballot and very likely inheriting the seat he occupied in Congress for 17 terms.

headline: For Some Artists, Election Season Means ‘Enough of Trump’
keywords: ['Art', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: More than a dozen artists including Carrie Mae Weems, Ed Ruscha and Shepard Fairey have contributed art to an advocacy campaign aimed at inspiring voters in November.
lead_paragraph: Voters heading to the polls this election season in battleground states like Michigan and Pennsylvania may find themselves facing billboards, projections and even cornfield cutouts designed by the country’s leading artists with a simple refrain: “Enough is enough.”

headline: In 5 Minutes, You Can Have a (Slightly) Tidier Bedroom

headline: New Treatment for Covid-19 Shows Promise, but Scientists Urge Caution
abstract: A small study of an inhaled form of a commonly available drug, interferon beta, suggests it could reduce the odds of patients becoming severely ill.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British drug company said Monday that an inhaled form of a commonly used medicine could slash the odds of Covid-19 patients becoming severely ill, a sliver of good news in the race to find treatments that was met by scientists with equal measures of caution and cheer.

headline: Big Polling Leads Tend to Erode. Is Biden’s Edge Different?
abstract: As his advantage endures well into its second month, it becomes harder to assume that it’s just another fleeting shift.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden’s commanding advantage in the race for the White House shows no sign of abating. He led by 15 percentage points in an ABC News/Washington Post survey of registered voters on Sunday, and he has held a nearly double-digit lead in an average of polls for more than a month.

headline: Marcella Hazan’s Tomato Sauce Trilogy
abstract: Subtle changes in method yield completely different results in these three simple and delicious tomato sauces from the cookbook author, who would have been 96 this year.

headline: Google Promises Privacy With Virus App but Can Still Collect Location Data
keywords: ['Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Global Positioning System', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Bluetooth Wireless Technology', 'Mobile Applications', 'Privacy', 'Android (Operating System)', 'iOS (Operating System)', 'General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)']
abstract: Some government agencies that use the software said they were surprised that Google may pick up the locations of certain app users. Others said they had unsuccessfully pushed Google to make a change.
lead_paragraph: When Google and Apple announced plans in April for free software to help alert people of their possible exposure to the coronavirus, the companies promoted it as “privacy preserving” and said it would not track users’ locations. Encouraged by those guarantees, Germany, Switzerland and other countries used the code to develop national virus alert apps that have been downloaded more than 20 million times.

headline: Hotels Nix Mints and Breakfast Buffets. Hand Sanitizer, Anyone?
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: “Shellshocked” by the pandemic and the drop-off in business, hotels are rethinking amenities and trying to allay travelers’ concerns.
lead_paragraph: Those hotel amenities you took for granted, like throw pillows, turndown service and free coffee in the lobby? They’re gone. Housekeeping is by request or eliminated during your stay. And don’t even think of finding a self-serve breakfast buffet.

headline: The Federal Crackdown on Portland Protesters

headline: Juice WRLD’s ‘Legends Never Die’ Earns the Year’s Biggest Debut
abstract: The album is the second posthumous release in a row to top the chart this year, after Pop Smoke’s last week.
lead_paragraph: Juice WRLD, the rapper and singer from Chicago who died in December at age 21, has landed the biggest opening week of the year so far with a posthumous release, “Legends Never Die.”

headline: A Navy Veteran Had a Question for the Feds in Portland. They Beat Him in Response.
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The veteran said he wanted to ask the officers whether they felt their actions violated the Constitution. Video shows them tear-gassing him and smashing his hand with baton blows.

headline: Trump Announces He Will Resume Virus Daily Briefings

headline: Trump Says He ‘Aced’ a Cognitive Test. What Does That Really Mean?
keywords: ['Tests (Medical)', 'Memory', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Dementia', "Alzheimer's Disease", 'Elderly', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-health', 'your-feed-elections']
abstract: Experts say one popular test that the president might have taken is by no means definitive, or even diagnostic.
lead_paragraph: In recent interviews, President Trump has been boasting about a cognitive test that he took recently and “aced.” It’s not the first time — he made similar remarks in January 2018. But he once again has not said what test he took, or what his score was, making it difficult to know what to make of his claims.

headline: At Least 60 Migrants Killed in Turkish Boat Disaster
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Drownings']
abstract: Rescuers continue to pull the bodies of victims from Lake Van, in eastern Turkey, more than three weeks after the fishing boat carrying them sank.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkish rescue teams have retrieved the bodies of 60 migrants after their boat sank in a lake in the east of the country, Turkish media reported on Monday, in one of the worst disasters involving migrants in Turkey in recent years.

headline: Jailed Soccer Official Contracts Coronavirus in Florida Prison
abstract: Juan Ángel Napout, a former FIFA vice president convicted in a corruption case, said he had tested positive at a federal facility that is struggling to contain an outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Juan Ángel Napout, a former vice president of soccer’s governing body FIFA serving a nine-year sentence for corruption, has tested positive for the coronavirus inside a Miami federal prison. The positive result came days after a federal judge denied his appeal for compassionate release.

headline: ‘It’s a Risk for Everybody’: Why a Jazz Pianist Chose to Perform
abstract: More than four months after his last public performance, the Grammy-winning artist Bill Charlap played at a storied Pennsylvania club, a glimpse into what may be the new normal for musicians.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, four months and 10 days since his last public performance, the Grammy-winning jazz pianist Bill Charlap came out to play.

headline: On-Demand Webinar: Give Students a Voice by Incorporating Contests in Your Curriculum
abstract: In this webinar learn how to use one or more of our 10 student contests as unit projects or enrichment opportunities this school year.
lead_paragraph: For 11 years now, The Learning Network has been running contests that offer students a chance to share their ideas and opinions with the world. Through photography and editorials or personal narratives and podcasts, our contests give students a voice and the opportunity to write for an authentic audience. Each year tens of thousands of students participate.

headline: Sheldon Silver, Former N.Y. Assembly Speaker, Will Finally Go to Prison
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Money Laundering', 'Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: Mr. Silver receives a sentence of 78 months after two trials. He had asked for home confinement, arguing that he was vulnerable to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Silver, the once dominant New York State Assembly speaker who for nearly five years fended off prison after being convicted twice on corruption charges, lost a final bid for freedom on Monday when he was sentenced to 78 months in prison.

abstract: Nina Kapur was a passenger on a scooter rented from Revel, whose Vespa-style rental vehicles have become popular in New York City. It was believed to be the company’s first fatality.
lead_paragraph: A local television journalist died over the weekend, the police said, after she fell from a scooter that had been rented from Revel, a moped-sharing company whose Vespa-style vehicles have become a familiar sight on the streets of Brooklyn and Queens.

headline: Baseball in Middle America: Fans Are In, Autographs Are Out

lead_paragraph: FARGO, N.D. — Forget about everything else for a moment and take a look at this:

abstract: An artist battles anxiety by trying to stay present.

headline: For Women in Afghan Security Forces, a Daily Battle
abstract: A new generation of women is moving to take up leadership roles in Afghanistan. The price is a daily barrage of abuse, and the fear that not much has changed.
lead_paragraph: KHOST, Afghanistan — Motivated, educated and fresh from finishing police academy in Turkey, Second Lt. Zala Zazai had stellar qualifications for the job she took in eastern Afghanistan in June. It all mattered little once she started.

headline: 3 Friends ‘Massacred’ During Florida Fishing Trip, Police Say
abstract: One of the victims called his father, asking for help, officials said.
lead_paragraph: On a dirt road, near cow pastures, orange groves and lakes, a Florida sheriff said he encountered one of the worst crime scenes in his career last week: Three close friends appeared to have been beaten and shot to death during a nighttime catfishing trip.

headline: Danny Meyer’s Restaurants Will End Their No-Tipping Policy
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Minimum Wage', 'Tips and Tipping', 'Restaurants', 'Income Inequality', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: Union Square Hospitality Group, which helped lead the move away from tips, changes course as its restaurants reopen.
lead_paragraph: One of the country’s best-known restaurateurs, Danny Meyer, announced five years ago that his Union Square Hospitality Group would gradually eliminate tipping. The group’s decision began an industrywide examination of the age-old practice, but adopting it proved complicated, especially in New York State, where laws governing tip distribution are strict.

headline: Chevron Deal for Oil and Gas Fields May Set Off New Wave of Mergers
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Shale', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Company Reports', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: With a $5 billion play for Noble Energy, the oil giant is set to acquire properties around the world for a relative bargain. Other companies might make similar moves.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In the first big deal since oil prices crashed four months ago, Chevron agreed on Monday to buy Noble Energy for roughly $5 billion in what many experts consider the beginning of a sweeping consolidation in the U.S. oil industry.

headline: This Chicken Salad Comes With a Kick
abstract: A tahini-wasabi dressing finishes this any occasion recipe inspired, in part, by a Taiwanese-Chinese dish.
lead_paragraph: The next time you get delivery or takeout, don’t throw away those condiments. Use them in your next dinner.

headline: You’ve Heard of Boxed Wine. Enter the Boxed Negroni.
abstract: St. Agrestis, a Brooklyn spirits company, now sells a 1.75-liter version of its bottled cocktail, enough for about 20 quarantine drinks.
lead_paragraph: Cocktails on tap? From your fridge? St. Agrestis, the Brooklyn spirits company specializing in Italian-style aperitivos and digestivos, has introduced Negronis in a box, 1.75 liters (almost two quarts) of premixed cocktail. Like St. Agrestis’s bottled Negroni, the drink consists of the company’s Inferno Bitter spirit, their own vermouth and Greenhook Ginsmiths Gin for a properly complex and forceful drink (24 percent alcohol). A splash of water or soda won’t hurt; it’s not included so you can add your own. Keep the box in the refrigerator, ready to pour.

headline: Ranch Dressing, but Make It Greek
abstract: Williams Sonoma is selling the seasoning mix for Souvla’s popular “Granch,” a Greek yogurt ranch dressing.
lead_paragraph: Souvla, a chain of casual Greek restaurants in San Francisco, created a Greek yogurt-based version of ranch dressing six years ago, calling it Granch. They even trademarked it. Now the seasoning it depends on is being packaged and sold nationwide by Williams Sonoma. The mixture of buttermilk powder, herbs and spices, along with your lemon juice and salt, is designed to transform plain Greek yogurt into a tangy dressing. You might want to add less salt than they suggest, especially if you’re tossing a Greek salad with olives and feta. The dressing works as a topping for lamb burgers, a marinade for chicken or a garnish for cold cucumber soup. It comes in a little metal mug — a miniaturized version of an old-fashioned Greek wine carafe.

headline: Smorgasburg Returns, With Some Covid-19 Changes
abstract: Fans of the Williamsburg, Brooklyn, food fair will be able to order takeout from a rotating lineup of 10 vendors.
lead_paragraph: Smorgasburg has reopened in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, but for now, the chance to graze from a buffet of food vendors, is off the table. Smorg To Go only allows preordering through its new website for takeout from a weekly rotating list of 10 vendors. There are three new ones in the starting lineup: #Gogi for Korean beef barbecue; Mai Bpen Rai, a Thai papaya salad stand; and the Whole Bowl, a Portland, Ore., transplant serving rice and beans. They join stalwarts like Berg’s Pastrami, Lobsterdamus and Mao’s Bao. The week of July 27 will welcome Groundlings Pizza, Ring Ding Bar and Yakitori Tatsu, among others. There is no outdoor seating. Through its website, Smorg To Go is raising funds for Rethink, which fights food insecurity in many neighborhoods.

headline: Vegan Ice Creams With Cheffy Flavors
abstract: Eclipse Foods has collaborated with chefs around the country on plant-based ice cream flavors, with some proceeds going to charitable causes.
lead_paragraph: A scoop of Eclipse blackberry-tarragon ice cream devised by the chef Greg Baxtrom comes topped with support for his restaurant Olmsted’s food bank, active in Brooklyn. Toasted almond thyme ice cream by Nicole Krasinski, an owner and the pastry chef at State Bird Provisions in San Francisco, benefits Black Earth Farms, a Black and Indigenous farming collective in the East Bay of San Francisco. These are just two of the options from Eclipse, a company that is collaborating on flavors with chefs, who designate charities that will receive the proceeds. Though there’s chocolate and vanilla, most of the flavors in the “chef series” are unusual. In fact calling any of these ice creams, despite their rich mouth feel and texture, is something of a misnomer since they’re entirely plant-based, using ingredients like cassava and corn to deliver the creaminess. The company, which began selling its confections late last year, has now made them available nationwide.

headline: A Cinnamon Bun From Aquavit
abstract: These tempting sticky buns from the chef Emma Bengtsson are now available for takeout in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Spices like cinnamon and cardamom bring alluring fragrance to all sorts of Scandinavian foods, most notably baked goods like a classic swirled bun to pair with your morning coffee. The soft, slightly chewy and well-burnished breakfast pastries, showered with pearl sugar, from the chef Emma Bengtsson at Aquavit are heavenly scented with cardamom, too. And now they’re available retail for the first time.

headline: Remembering Ennio Morricone, the Film Score Maestro
abstract: His music was dynamic, bold and idiosyncratic, setting a high bar for composers connecting sound and vision.
lead_paragraph: Ennio Morricone, who died this month at 91, was for decades the most innovative and irreverent composer of film scores working. Best known for his collaborations with Sergio Leone on his spaghetti westerns, Morricone scored approximately 500 films, working with a who’s who of landmark directors: Bernardo Bertolucci, Pier Paolo Pasolini, Terrence Malick, John Carpenter, Quentin Tarantino and many more.

headline: Trump Plans to Deploy More Law Enforcement Officers Amid Protests
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: On Monday, President Trump said he would send more federal law enforcement officers to Democratic-run cities after weeks of civil unrest, including protests over the death of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, President Trump said he would send more federal law enforcement officers to Democratic-run cities after weeks of civil unrest, including protests over the death of George Floyd.

headline: Celebrate the Catskills in Your Kitchen
abstract: Regional ingredients are put to delicious use in this bright new farm-to-table cookbook.
lead_paragraph: “The Catskills Farm to Table Cookbook,” a seasonal, brightly photographed survey of the area’s foods and farms, hews closely to what is produced in the region’s five counties in southern New York State. Spring brings nettles, ramps, fiddleheads, garlic scapes, pea pods and even milkweed buds to compelling recipes, like scalloped potatoes in a stinging nettle sauce. Summer adds corn, tomatoes and zucchini; fall offers squash and apples; and in winter there are roots and cabbage. Meats, mainly pork, show up from time to time, and desserts amount mostly to pies, crisps and crumbles. Some ingredients are not listed in order of use, but the recipes work, though the cacio e pepe with greens is better if the greens are chopped first. For the two upside-down apple desserts, a cake and a pie, the author never nods to tarte Tatin, the obvious antecedent, nor does she use the more common name, Dutch babies, for the puff pancake.

headline: What Is It That Keeps Most Little Kids From Getting Covid-19?
keywords: ['Pediatric Inflammatory Multisystem Syndrome (PIMS)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Disease Rates']
abstract: Young children have consistently been slow to catch and spread Covid-19. Experts have a few hunches why.
lead_paragraph: On the way home from a jog one afternoon in early July, Dr. Silvia Chiang noticed her husband and 2½-year-old daughter playing outdoors with a handful of neighborhood kids and their moms in face masks. As someone who specializes in pediatric infectious diseases and has helped care for dozens of children with Covid-19, Chiang said she felt uneasy at one point.

headline: What the A.D.A. Means to Me
abstract: We asked the disability rights activists Judy Heumann, Alice Wong and Haben Girma to reflect on the 30th anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act. They said the work of a civil rights activist is never done.
lead_paragraph: This essay is based on an interview of Judy Heumann by Kaitlyn Wells. Ms. Heumann is the co-author of “Being Heumann: An Unrepentant Memoir of a Disability Rights Activist,” with Kristen Joiner, and is featured in the award-winning Netflix documentary “Crip Camp: A Disability Revolution.”

headline: Exploring What Disability Means Today, and Could Mean Tomorrow
abstract: Thirty years after the passage of the A.D.A., a Times project featuring more than two dozen articles looks at the many facets of the law’s impact and the work that still lies ahead.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Black Children Are More Likely to Die After Surgery Than White Peers, Study Shows
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Research', 'Hospitals', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: A large study, published in the journal Pediatrics, suggests that disparities exist in surgery outcomes, even among healthy children.
lead_paragraph: Black children are more than three times as likely to die within a month of surgery as white children, according to a study published in the journal Pediatrics on Monday.

keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Quarantines', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Disease Rates', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: “Slow the testing down,” he said, and it’s happening.
lead_paragraph: We’re now at the stage of the Covid-19 pandemic where Donald Trump and his allies are trying to suppress information about the coronavirus’s spread — because, of course, they are. True to form, however, they’re far behind the curve. From a political point of view (which is all they care about), their disinformation efforts are too little, too late.

abstract: The Oscars’ social media strategy — and by extension their relevance to younger viewers — underlies the action brought by the producer Michael Shamberg.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Tension within the stately Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences spilled into public on Monday when a prominent producer sued the organization over a procedural matter and in the process attacked officials over the troubled state of the Oscars.

abstract: The president said he would resume the pandemic briefings that he called off in April, a tacit acknowledgment that the public health crisis he had hoped to put behind him was still ravaging much of the country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time he canceled the show midseason, even President Trump had grown weary of his televised coronavirus briefings. Angry at the reviews, he declared the briefings “not worth the time & effort,” a conclusion shared by his own advisers and allies who had come to see them as hurting more than helping.

headline: Facing a Season of Uncertainty, Max Scherzer Is Still Tinkering
abstract: “I don’t come to the park for all the other hoopla; I come to the park because I want to win another World Series with my teammates,” Scherzer said days before opening the 2020 season.
lead_paragraph: The last competitive game Max Scherzer pitched was the biggest of his life. And he was not about to let the designated hitter rule disrupt his routine before Game 7 of the World Series.

headline: Opera Foundation Removes Trustee Over Offensive Comments
abstract: The Richard Tucker Music Foundation, which gives prestigious awards to young singers, removed Richard Tucker’s son from its board.

Mr. Tucker, a son of the distinguished tenor for whom the foundation is named, was removed after an uproar over comments that he made on a Black singer’s Facebook page.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)']

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Names, Geographical', 'Vetoes (US)']

headline: Stay Safe, Justice Ginsburg
abstract: This summer has been hard enough.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The only word to describe life here right now is this: hell.

headline: Ailey II Drops Director, Citing ‘Inappropriate’ Communications
abstract: Troy Powell, who has led the dance company as artistic director since 2012, was let go after an inquiry by an outside investigator hired by the organization.
lead_paragraph: Troy Powell was dropped as the artistic director of Ailey II, the junior troupe of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, after an outside investigation concluded that he had engaged in “inappropriate communications” with adult students in the company’s training program, a spokesman for the company said on Monday.

headline: Emitt Rhodes, 70, Dies; Singer-Songwriter Vanished After a Splash
abstract: He resurfaced a decade ago, after having built a fan base that compared him to Paul McCartney.
lead_paragraph: Emitt Rhodes, a singer and songwriter who earned a cult status among fans of Beatles-like power-pop for a handful of albums he released in the early 1970s, then gave up recording for decades, has died at 70.

headline: Jets and Giants Are N.F.L.’s First to Say They’ll Play Without Fans
abstract: Following New Jersey’s restrictions on public gatherings, the two teams announced they would not admit fans for regular-season games at MetLife Stadium. Rutgers will cap spectators at 500.
lead_paragraph: The Jets and Giants will play their regular-season games without fans at MetLife Stadium this fall, the teams announced in a joint statement Monday, nearly three weeks after Gov. Phil Murphy of New Jersey issued an executive order limiting social gatherings to 500 people. The teams are the first in the N.F.L. to decide to forego fans, and the revenue they bring, when the season begins in September.

keywords: ['Firearms', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police']

abstract: The @NBABubbleLife Twitter account has amassed more than 100,000 followers in less than two weeks with quirky commentary on the social media posts of basketball’s biggest stars.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two weeks, the Twitter accounts @NBABubbleLife and @WNBABubbleLife have anonymously chronicled the world’s best basketball players shotgunning beers, dancing with their teammates, failing at fishing and going about everyday activities, like getting haircuts and eating pancakes.

lead_paragraph: Gavin Brown’s Enterprise, one of the most consistently provocative contemporary art galleries in Manhattan, will close after 26 years. Its founder, the British artist-turned-dealer Gavin Brown, will become a partner in Gladstone Gallery, which announced the new affiliation.

headline: Raring to Go
abstract: It’s great to see Zhouqin Burnikel back in the race again.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I was taught in school that, when it came to math, there could only be a single answer to a given problem. There might be different ways to get to that answer, but one answer there would be. That was supposed to be the good thing about numbers, the very thing that attracted people who like one answer per problem to the science.

headline: Corrections: July 21, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, July 21, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the effects of the Nicaraguan government’s response to the coronavirus outbreak misstated the name of a top police official who died in May. He was Olivio Hernández Salguera, not Olivio Salguera Hernández.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Landless’ and ‘Frontline’
abstract: Camila Freitas’s documentary embeds with Brazil’s Landless Workers’ Movement. And the latest “Frontline” installment examines a lack of coronavirus protections of agricultural workers.
lead_paragraph: LANDLESS (2019) Stream on Mubi. This summer, Mubi has been featuring movies from both up-and-coming and established Brazilian filmmakers as part of its New Brazilian Cinema series, including Camila Freitas, who directed this documentary. The film focuses on a faction of the country’s Landless Workers’ Movement, a land reform group. Freitas chronicled its activities over four years while members occupied land owned by a sugar cane processing plant that had filed for bankruptcy. As its members work the land and discuss utopian solutions for a better future, the film offers an inside look at activists that Brazil’s right-wing president, Jair Bolsonaro, has likened to a terrorist organization.

headline: Coronavirus Threatens the Luster of Superstar Cities
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Urban Areas', 'Telecommuting', 'Productivity', 'Innovation', 'Relocation of Business', 'Epidemics', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Urban centers, with a dynamism that feeds innovation, have long been resilient. But the pandemic could drive a shift away from density.
lead_paragraph: Cities are remarkably resilient. They have risen from the ashes after being carpet-bombed and hit with nuclear weapons. “If you think about pandemics in the past,” noted the Princeton economist Esteban Rossi-Hansberg, “they didn’t destroy cities.”

headline: This Hospital Cost $52 Million. It Treated 79 Virus Patients.
abstract: Red tape and turf battles marked the race to create temporary hospitals for the coronavirus onslaught in New York.
lead_paragraph: The Queens Hospital Center emergency department has a capacity of 60, but on its worst night of the coronavirus pandemic, more than 180 patients lay on stretchers in the observation bays and hallways. Alarms rang incessantly as exhausted doctors rushed from crisis to crisis.

headline: Trevor Noah Praises Fox News Host for Actually Questioning Trump
abstract: “Chris Wallace did two things right there that Trump absolutely hates: He proved him wrong, and he made him do homework,” Noah said of the president’s “Fox News Sunday” interview.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: China Uses W.H.O. Inquiry to Tout Coronavirus Response
abstract: The global health agency sent two experts to China, but it is unclear how much access they are getting. They must first complete a two-week quarantine.
lead_paragraph: Chinese officials are hailing a visit by a team of experts sent to Beijing by the World Health Organization to investigate the source of the coronavirus as evidence that the country is a responsible and transparent global power. But the investigation by the W.H.O. is likely to take many months and could face delays.

headline: The Lonely Goalkeeper

lead_paragraph: Arsenal legend Bob Wilson on the loneliest role in soccer.

headline: 1920: Police Retaliate After Killings in Ireland
abstract: The town of Tuam was ransacked by the police, with buildings looted and set alight, in response to the shooting of two officers.
lead_paragraph: (By Special Leased Wire.) LONDON, Tuesday. — Following the shooting of Constables Craig and Burke, the cathedral town of Tuam went through a “perfect hell,” in the words of a resident, during the early hours of to-day. The police, having viewed the dead bodies of their comrades at the station, appear to have got completely out of hand. Fully armed they marched into the streets, smashed saloons, looting their contents, dragged young men out of bed and threatened to shoot them. Then they set fire to some of the most valuable properties in the township, causing damage to the extent of £100,000.

headline: There Is No Lonelier Job in Soccer Than This

lead_paragraph: Is there any lonelier position in sports than goalie?

headline: Quarantine and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
keywords: ['Quarantines', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Parenting', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: My 13-year-old son wasn’t engaged in online learning, but rebuilding an engine in the garage let him discover his “ferocious force.”
lead_paragraph: The morning after the governor of Wisconsin shut down schools in an effort to prevent the spread of Covid-19, my 13-year-old son, Hayden, gave himself a project. He would watch, in order of their release, every movie in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Starting with “Iron Man,” he worked his way through nearly two dozen movies in all. He finished in four and a half days.

headline: Should We Cancel Aristotle?
abstract: He defended slavery and opposed the notion of human equality. But he is not our enemy.
lead_paragraph: The Greek philosopher Aristotle did not merely condone slavery, he defended it; he did not merely defend it, but defended it as beneficial to the slave. His view was that some people are, by nature, unable to pursue their own good, and best suited to be “living tools” for use by other people: “The slave is a part of the master, a living but separated part of his bodily frame.”

headline: New & Noteworthy, From Free Speech to True Crime

lead_paragraph: DARE TO SPEAK: Defending Free Speech for All, by Suzanne Nossel. (Dey Street, $28.99.) The chief executive of PEN America revisits recent debates, arguing that “concerns of diversity and inclusion can — and must — be reconciled with robust protections for speech.”

headline: To Get People to Wear Masks, Look to Seatbelts, Helmets and Condoms
abstract: The ways we built habits around other routine safety measures can inform mask-wearing, experts say.
lead_paragraph: In the pediatric clinic where I worked for many years in Boston, each room held a clear plastic bowl full of brightly colored condoms. They were there on display, vivid and eye-catching, and part of my job — every provider’s job — was to offer them cheerfully and matter-of-factly and above all non-judgmentally to adolescents at every visit.

headline: Elizabeth Warren: To Fight the Pandemic, Here’s My Must-Do List
abstract: The Senate needs to act now. There is no time to waste.
lead_paragraph: Americans stayed at home and sacrificed for months to flatten the curve and prevent the spread of the coronavirus. That gave us time to take the steps needed to address the pandemic — but President Trump squandered it, refusing to issue national stay-at-home guidelines, failing to set up a national testing operation and fumbling production of personal protective equipment. Now, Congress must again act as this continues to spiral out of control.

headline: Intimacy Is Overrated: Concerts in the Livestream Era
keywords: ['Music', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: What’s lost when audiences can’t be close to musicians, applause is virtual and over-the-top artists are crammed into screens? So much.
lead_paragraph: So many good intentions, so little joy.

headline: When China Met Iran
abstract: A growing partnership between America’s main Middle East adversary and Asia’s rising superpower bears careful watching in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Leaked news this month that China and Iran had come to the verge of signing a 25-year trade and military partnership agreement struck like a geopolitical storm in Washington — a rising rival of America and a longtime foe joining forces to threaten the United States’s predominant position in the Middle East.

headline: Trump, Unleashed
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Dogs', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Masks', 'Quarantines', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: What could possibly go wrong?
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi Gail. Have I ever mentioned the fact that I’m a big fan of the film “Gladiator?” It has so much that’s relevant to the Trump era: a mad emperor; his terrified female companion; a cowed Senate; bread and circuses and blood sport; and an eerie resemblance between the Proximo character (the great Oliver Reed) and Steve Bannon.

headline: New Emails Show How Energy Industry Moved Fast to Undo Curbs

headline: 10 Best Quarantine Concerts Online
keywords: ['Music', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: With in-person shows still mostly on hold, musicians are finding new ways to insert life into livestreams.
lead_paragraph: Some livestreamed concerts emulate the one-time-only experience of live shows — they’re webcast just once in real time, then disappear from the web. Others recognize that anything that’s digitized can be recorded and replayed. Here, alphabetically, are 10 of the best virtual concerts that have stayed online.

headline: Nature’s Noisiest Liars Carry Secrets in Their Calls
abstract: Many mammals that have loud calls to deceive other animals seem to have a particular learning style in common.
lead_paragraph: A beast calls in the distance. Hearing a low rumble, you might imagine the source will be an unholy cross between a wild boar and a chain saw. The message is unmistakable: I’m here, I’m huge and you can either come mate with me or stay out of my way.

headline: Concerts Aren’t Back. Livestreams Are Ubiquitous. Can They Do the Job?
keywords: ['Music', 'Social Media', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: With no return date for shows in sight, fans and artists are adapting to a new way of experiencing music together. Whether it’ll keep everyone satisfied — and paid — is still unclear.
lead_paragraph: On April 10, Phoebe Bridgers sat in her Los Angeles apartment in her pajamas, with a guitar across her lap and her head cocked quizzically to the side, staring into her phone’s camera. “I’ve never done this before,” the 25-year-old singer-songwriter said, strumming her Danelectro. “How are you guys? Is this, like, a normal angle? Is this good? Can you hear me?”

abstract: When the Covid-19 shutdown hit the music industry, an artist who has never taken the conventional route started rethinking how she’d produce, play and interact with fans at concerts.
lead_paragraph: Erykah Badu has always been a boss, but now she’s closer to a CEO. When the Covid-19 pandemic halted concerts and the music industry scrambled to adapt, the iconoclastic neo-soul singer and songwriter created a new artistic and business model, creating her own interactive streaming network less than two weeks after the country began shutting down this spring.

headline: ‘The Grand Unified Theory of Howard Bloom’ Review: A Career Rewritten
abstract: This documentary looks inside the life of a high-powered music publicist who became a techno-age philosopher.
lead_paragraph: For the past 20 years, in his second career as a best-selling author, Howard Bloom has been grappling with the big questions, all of which can be boiled down to, as he puts it here, “What does the universe want from you and me?” Bloom has, in the pre-Covid-19 world chronicled in this documentary about him, a strict routine that helps him in this discipline.

headline: Cities have survived pandemics before. What about this one?

headline: Google’s virus-tracing apps can allow it to track some users’ locations.
abstract: When Google and Apple announced plans in April for free software to help alert people of their possible exposure to the coronavirus, the companies promoted it as “privacy preserving” and said it would not track users’ locations. Encouraged by those guarantees, Germany, Switzerland and other countries used the code to develop national virus alert apps that have been downloaded more than 20 million times.
lead_paragraph: When Google and Apple announced plans in April for free software to help alert people of their possible exposure to the coronavirus, the companies promoted it as “privacy preserving” and said it would not track users’ locations. Encouraged by those guarantees, Germany, Switzerland and other countries used the code to develop national virus alert apps that have been downloaded more than 20 million times.

headline: American corporations are bingeing on debt in the downturn.
abstract: Since the 2008 global financial crisis, American corporations have taken advantage of historically low interest rates to gorge themselves on debt. Then came the pandemic and the sharpest economic downturn in history, which resulted in an odd solution for the companies that did all that borrowing: more debt.
lead_paragraph: Since the 2008 global financial crisis, American corporations have taken advantage of historically low interest rates to gorge themselves on debt. headline: A More Inclusive View of MoMA’s Sculpture Garden
abstract: Carrie Mae Weems, known for her powerful images of African-American identity, shares a piece from her new project.
lead_paragraph: In this new series, The Artists, an installment of which will publish every day this week and regularly thereafter, T will highlight a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist, putting the work into context. Today, we’re looking at a piece by Carrie Mae Weems, known for her powerful images of African-American identity, whose new project, “Resist Covid Take 6!,” of which this work is a part, uses the mediums of advertising and photography to raise public awareness of Covid-19 among people of color.

headline: The Virus Found a Crowded Houston Neighborhood, Sparing One Nearby

headline: Lianne La Havas Traces the Arc of a Romance
abstract: With supple guitar and a freewheeling voice, the English songwriter delves into matters of the heart on her self-titled third album.
lead_paragraph: The English songwriter Lianne La Havas has always been an outlier, working a decidedly personal amalgam of rock, pop and R&B. Her music revolves around the lithe interplay of her syncopated guitar patterns and her freewheeling voice, which leaps and curls and wriggles with an insouciant vibrato. Her guitar parts echo and rival the ambiguous, unresolved chords and supple rhythmic games of Joni Mitchell and Radiohead, while her voice moves from low, sultry insinuations to open-throated declarations.
