lead_paragraph: The artist speaks of living in 1970s Amsterdam, where she visited a Rembrandt painting at the city’s Rijksmuseum at least weekly.

headline: Where the Wild Things Play
abstract: The animal world is full of games. And tucked in among wrestling monkeys, belligerent birds and wily coyotes are lessons for us all.
lead_paragraph: As a sophomore in college I interned at a lab that studied dolphin behavior. The animals spent most of the year doing back flips and spraying water onto tourists at a theme park, then called Marine World Africa USA, just north of San Francisco. In their off months, they hung out with behavioral scientists who did experiments with them.

headline: The Rembrandt Self-Portrait That Has Long Captivated Pat Steir
abstract: When she lived in Amsterdam, the New York-based artist went to see this painting at least once a week.
lead_paragraph: Rembrandt van Rijn painted and etched his own image dozens of times over the course of his life, but it’s one of his earliest self-portraits, from around 1628, that haunts the New York artist Pat Steir. In this work, simply titled “Self-Portrait,” the 22-year-old Dutch master in the making renders himself in heavy chiaroscuro, his gaze obscured and light bouncing off his jaw to illuminate an earlobe and the edges of a helmet of frizzy hair. It’s an oddly dispassionate depiction. “He painted it the way he would paint a model, without personifying it,” observes Steir. “It’s letting go of imparting wisdom to the figure. Brilliance, scale, beauty — letting go of all that. That’s what’s hard to do.”

headline: 12 Artists On: The Financial Crisis
keywords: ['Art', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: As the pandemic continues to derail the global economy, artists share works that reflect on uncertainty, capitalism and racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 virus has sent the global economy spinning into a state of profound disturbance, casting the livelihoods of individuals and small businesses into doubt and leaving entire industries devastated. The financial impact of the pandemic on local communities, as cities and states slash budgets, and on the world at large will continue to play out in the months and years to come. For the fourth installment of our series T Agitprop, we asked 12 contemporary artists, including Torkwase Dyson, Tomashi Jackson, Isaac Julien and Agnieszka Kurant, to contribute works, most of them new and created exclusively for T, in response to this global emergency. Here are their pieces and statements.

headline: A flurry of activity suggests that deal-making isn’t dead.
abstract: There may be a pandemic and a recession. But in the past day, there has also been plenty of action among deal makers, as reported in the DealBook newsletter.
lead_paragraph: There may be a pandemic and a recession. But in the past day, there has also been plenty of action among deal makers, as reported in the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Trump’s Briefings, ‘The Apprentice’ and the Perils of the Second Season
keywords: ['Television', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: President Trump seems to think there’s no such thing as too much of him on TV. He’s been wrong about that before.
lead_paragraph: The pinnacle of Donald J. Trump’s TV career lasted one night, and he has never stopped trying to relive it.

headline: Three Decades After His Coup, Sudan’s Former Ruler Is Held to Account
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Omar Hassan al-Bashir, ousted in mass protests last year, is on trial for his role in the military coup that propelled him to power in 1989. He faces the death penalty if convicted.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Three decades ago, a little-known army officer named Omar Hassan al-Bashir seized power in Sudan, ushering in a long period of brutal rule that would push the sprawling African country into a series of destabilizing wars, cripple its economy and result in humiliating international isolation.

headline: Andrew Gillum and the Long Shadow of the Florida Governor’s Race
abstract: The magnetic former Democratic nominee for Florida governor went from being a breakout political star to checking into rehab.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Andrew Gillum sounded like a prophet. His words quick, his tone urgent, the man who nearly became Florida’s governor predicted in a podcast interview that the coronavirus would cripple the state’s tourism industry, hide in nursing homes and proliferate amid rampant misinformation.

headline: Chaotic Scenes in Portland as Backlash to Federal Deployment Grows
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Looting (Crime)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: The street demonstrations that have shuddered through Portland for 54 consecutive nights have drawn out a complicated mix of emotions and grievances.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — With a ski helmet and goggles on her head, Allison Hyder recounted how she had told relatives that she planned to stand at the rear of protests in downtown Portland. But, in the early hours of Tuesday, the grandmother of five found herself right up front, locking arms with other mothers dressed in yellow.

headline: Officer Details Killing of Police Partner in Trial of Americans in Rome
abstract: The killing of Deputy Brig. Mario Cerciello Rega last year has attracted significant media attention in Italy and the United States.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The long-awaited appearance in court of Andrea Varriale, a crucial witness in a murder case against two young American men accused of killing an Italian law enforcement officer last year, played out in a Rome courtroom this month.

headline: Michael Cohen Claims in Suit He Was Imprisoned to Stop Trump Book
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: President Trump’s former lawyer said in court papers that officials returned him to prison to prevent him from finishing a book that paints the president as a racist.
lead_paragraph: Michael D. Cohen says it was no secret that he was writing a jailhouse tell-all book about his former boss, President Trump. He spent hours at a stretch working on his manuscript in a prison library before he was released on furlough in May because of the coronavirus.

headline: After Death of John Lewis, Democrats Renew Push for Voting Rights Law
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Discrimination', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Elections', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Democrats and activists who have long sought to update the Voting Rights Act say the proper way to honor the fallen civil rights icon is to pass it and name it in his honor. Republicans are opposed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell took to the Senate floor Monday to lament the death of Representative John Lewis, a civil rights icon whom the Republican leader called a “monumental figure” who made “huge personal sacrifices to help our nation move past the sin of racism.”

headline: Here’s What I Saw on the Streets of Portland Last Night
abstract: Our reporter spent the night in Downtown Portland, witnessing the growing protests in response to the presence of federal troops.
lead_paragraph: Our reporter spent the night in Downtown Portland, witnessing the growing protests in response to the presence of federal troops.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 4: On ‘Many Latinos Couldn’t Stay Home. Now Virus Cases Are Soaring in Their Communities.’
abstract: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Marcella Rodio, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
lead_paragraph: Thank you to the 1,033 teenagers who participated in the fourth week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest, and congratulations to Marcella Rodio, our winner, as well as to our many runners-up and honorable mentions.

headline: Planned Parenthood in N.Y. Disavows Margaret Sanger Over Eugenics
keywords: ['Names, Organizational', 'Sterilization (Reproductive)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', "Women's Rights", 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Women and Girls', 'Disabilities', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Ms. Sanger, a feminist icon and reproductive-rights pioneer, supported a discredited belief in improving the human race through selective breeding.
lead_paragraph: Planned Parenthood of Greater New York will remove the name of Margaret Sanger, a founder of the national organization, from its Manhattan health clinic because of her “harmful connections to the eugenics movement,” the group said on Tuesday.

headline: Michael Bennett, a Protest Pioneer, Retires From the N.F.L.
keywords: ['Football', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'United States National Anthem Protests (2016- )']
abstract: The defensive end announced his retirement on Instagram after an 11-year career in which he won a Super Bowl with the Seattle Seahawks and became a leading voice on race and police brutality.
lead_paragraph: Michael Bennett, the standout defensive end who spoke out forcefully against racial injustice during his career, said he was retiring after an 11-year N.F.L. career, primarily with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Seattle Seahawks.

headline: Coronavirus Infections Much Higher Than Reported Cases in Parts of U.S., Study Shows
abstract: Data from antibody tests in 10 different cities and states indicate that many people with no symptoms may be spreading the virus.
lead_paragraph: The number of people infected with the coronavirus in different parts of the United States was anywhere from two to 13 times higher than the reported rates for those regions, according to data released Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Zizi Jeanmaire, French Star of Ballet, Cabaret and Film, Dies at 96
abstract: She was celebrated for her artistic range, androgynous sexiness and husky-voiced charm.
lead_paragraph: Zizi Jeanmaire, the ballerina, cabaret singer and actress whose gamine haircut, corseted costume and charismatic, erotic performance made an indelible impression in the 1949 ballet “Carmen,” died on July 17 at her home in Tolochenaz, Switzerland, overlooking Lake Geneva. She was 96.

headline: They’re Used to Tapping. Now They’re Talking.
abstract: In Ayodele Casel’s video series, “Diary of a Tap Dancer, v. 6: Us,” performers talk about what’s on their minds — and dance a little, too.
lead_paragraph: Ayodele Casel is a top-shelf tap dancer, as generous of spirit as she is precise in technique. But years ago, she discovered that even appreciative audiences didn’t always grasp all that she was trying to communicate with her feet.

headline: Photos: Federal Forces Clash With Demonstrators in Portland
abstract: Thousands gathered downtown to protest as the conflict with law enforcement intensified overnight.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Fueled by a wide array of grievances, including against police brutality, protests have rocked Portland for eight weeks, persisting even as demonstrations have waned in many other parts of the country since the killing of George Floyd in police custody in Minneapolis.

headline: Zooming In on Bill Buford’s Latest Obsession
abstract: The author spent more than a decade seeking the heart of French cuisine for his new book, “Dirt.” But in quarantine, he just wants to make the perfect chicken.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the writer Bill Buford attempted to teach me, using Zoom, how to bone, stuff, tie and poach a chicken. It was something like one of those MasterClasses that everybody is watching these days, except that those run for 20 minutes, and my lesson lasted more than six hours. It may not have been the longest Zoom call in history, but I suspect it set a record for Zoom calls with a strong focus on boneless poultry.

headline: Beyond the Law’s Promise: 30 Years Since the Passage of the Americans With Disabilities Act
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Discrimination', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: This series explores how the Americans With Disabilities Act has shaped modern life for people with disabilities in the 30 years since it was passed.
lead_paragraph: This series explores how the Americans With Disabilities Act has shaped modern life for people with disabilities in the 30 years since it was passed.

headline: We Searched for Covid-19 Data. Here’s What We Couldn’t Find.
abstract: Fifteen things we need to know about the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Doctors caring for patients track vital signs of temperature, blood pressure, breathing and pulse. Public health doctors fighting epidemics do something similar — they track the most important indicators of the spread of a disease and attempts to control it.

headline: Patient, Can You Spare a Dime?
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Doctors', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Hospitals']
abstract: Hospitals are increasingly soliciting donations from patients, and the patients don’t much like it, a new survey finds.
lead_paragraph: Should your doctor ask you to make a donation to help the medical center where you were treated? If you are a generous donor, should you be rewarded with a better room — or your doctor’s cellphone number?

headline: Works by Sir John Richardson’s Many Friends in Sotheby’s Sale
abstract: The art historian John Richardson collected art by his pals Pablo Picasso, Lucian Freud and Andy Warhol. The works will be sold in New York and London in the fall.
lead_paragraph: John Richardson, the art historian and Picasso biographer who died last year at 95, was a collector. He collected friends — Picasso, Georges Braque, Francis Bacon, Lucian Freud and Andy Warhol, to name only a few. He also collected images of friends, by friends. He had a portrait of Mick Jagger by Warhol and an etched self-portrait of Freud.

headline: What Do Sweden and Mexico Have in Common? A Feminist Foreign Policy
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Six years after Sweden adopted a feminist foreign policy, several other countries are following its lead, raising pressure on the U.S. to do the same.
lead_paragraph: — Ann Linde, Foreign Minister of Sweden

headline: When the Bake Sale Goes Global, Millions Are Raised to Fight Injustice
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Restaurants', 'Chefs', 'Philanthropy', 'Women and Girls', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Online sales have become blockbuster events as long-sidelined pastry chefs lead a charge toward activism.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of 13-year-olds, Daniella Senior loved to bake, and thought she might become a pastry chef.

headline: Congressional Republicans Are Close to Revolt Over Stimulus Aid
keywords: ['Stimulus (Economic)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Several Senate Republicans, in a closed-door lunch, railed against the prospect of another sweeping spending bill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders labored on Tuesday to avert a party revolt over the next round of coronavirus aid, announcing that they planned to provide $105 billion for schools, direct payments to American families and more aid for struggling small businesses as rank-and-file lawmakers balked at the proposal’s cost.

headline: A Land Art Pioneer’s Adventures in Time and Space
abstract: Nearly 50 years after Charles Ross began working on “Star Axis,” the artist’s gargantuan work in the New Mexico desert is nearing completion.
lead_paragraph: THROUGH THE WINTER months, Charles Ross’s existence befits an established New York multimedia artist of a certain vintage: whitewashed SoHo loft with a comfortable studio in the back; a pair of sweet, shaggy dogs that he and his wife, the painter Jill O’Bryan, walk up Wooster Street in the chill, past the wrought iron storefronts that were little more than scrap metal when he first came to the city in the mid-1960s after studying math and sculpture at the University of California, Berkeley, but now are outposts of Chanel and Dior. Evenings, they may drop into a Chelsea gallery opening or two, then linger over dinner at Omen, the Japanese restaurant that’s been on Thompson Street since the ’80s, nodding to the fellow stalwarts of a downtown scene that long ago ate its young: the 92-year-old portraitist Alex Katz sharing a sake with the Abstract Expressionist David Salle, 67; the musician Laurie Anderson, 73, at the bar, her spiky hair stippled with gray.

headline: U.S. Accuses Hackers of Trying to Steal Coronavirus Vaccine Data for China
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Research']
abstract: Two suspects in China targeted companies working on vaccines as part of a broader cybertheft campaign to enrich themselves and aid the Chinese government, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department accused a pair of Chinese hackers on Tuesday of targeting vaccine development on behalf of the country’s intelligence service as part of a broader yearslong campaign of global cybertheft aimed at industries such as defense contractors, high-end manufacturing and solar energy companies.

headline: Trump’s Threat to Send Federal Forces to More Cities
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers urge President Trump to use federal resources to fight the coronavirus rather than citizens.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Angela Merkel Guides the E.U. to a Deal, However Imperfect
abstract: With her long experience as German chancellor, she shapes a necessary compromise on virus aid for the battered European south. But it’s consensus at a cost.

headline: Ukraine Police Surround City Bus Seized by Armed Man
abstract: A man with an automatic weapon seized a city bus in Lutsk, Ukraine, and took about 20 people hostage in the town of Lutsk, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man with an automatic weapon seized a city bus in Lutsk, Ukraine, and took about 20 people hostage in the town of Lutsk, the police said.

headline: Disney Cuts Ties With ABC News Executive Over ‘Racially Insensitive’ Remarks
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'News and News Media', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Discrimination', 'Television']
abstract: The executive, Barbara Fedida, has left the company after an investigation supported complaints about her workplace comments.
lead_paragraph: The Walt Disney Company said in an internal memo on Monday that it had cut ties with a top ABC News executive after an investigation backed complaints that she had made racist remarks in the workplace.

headline: Your Kid Doesn’t Need to Be LeBron or Serena
abstract: Focusing on fun and exposure to new games helps build skills and interest.
lead_paragraph: The sound of the basketball repeatedly smacking the parquet floor echoed across the empty community center gymnasium as I attempted to teach my 5-year-old son how to dribble.

headline: How Play Energizes Your Kid’s Brain
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Babies and Infants', 'Children and Childhood', 'Memory', 'Research']
abstract: Scientists have long studied play to gain insights into the developing human mind.
lead_paragraph: Swiss psychologist Jean Piaget, one of the founding fathers of developmental psychology, spent hours each day observing his children as they grew. He recorded his observations in a raft of notebooks. Lore has it that his wife even carried a notebook on her necklace to jot down observations that Piaget himself missed.

headline: No, My Toddler Doesn’t Need to Learn to Code
keywords: ['Toys', 'Science and Technology', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Education (K-12)', 'Mathematics', 'Youth', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: Sales in educational toys are booming, but often there isn’t much weight to their claims of teaching kids science and math.
lead_paragraph: Botley is a small plastic robot that makes a big claim. According to toymaker Learning Resources, Botley can teach children as young as 5 how to program computer codes. In fact, “he’ll have kids coding in minutes,” the company promises on Amazon.

headline: The Way We Used to Play
abstract: A mother compares her childhood freedom to her kids’ playtime, filled with structured dates, piano lessons and tablet games.
lead_paragraph: As kids, my seven siblings and I would run around outside under the night sky, the summer-hard soles of our bare feet the only shoes we needed, playing a game we made up called “War”.

headline: Beware the ‘But China’ Excuses
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Just because U.S. politicians and tech giants are blaming China, doesn’t mean we should be scared.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Risky Play Encourages Resilience
abstract: Lacking the usual scheduled activities and adult supervision, children are finding the space to play freely.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic lingers like a hangover, many parents are still struggling to work from home and take care of their children at the same time. And for some kids, that brings a special kind of freedom: the ability to play like nobody’s watching.

headline: When Playtime and the Coronavirus Collide
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Parenting', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Children are incorporating Covid-19 into pretend play.
lead_paragraph: Last month, I popped into one of my favorite local restaurants. The place is known for its eccentric menu, created daily according to the chef’s whim. Pizza ice cream is a staple. But before I entered, the chef scolded me and instructed me to put on my mask.

headline: Play Therapy Can Help Kids Speak the Unspeakable
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Toys', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Parenting']
abstract: Play is the language of children — which is why play therapy can help kids speak the unspeakable.
lead_paragraph: Dee Ray doesn’t learn how children feel by listening to their words. Ray, a researcher and counselor in Texas, learns by watching them play.

headline: The Magic of Black Girls’ Play
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Women and Girls', 'Games', 'Quarantines', 'Music', 'Jump Rope', 'Parenting']
abstract: Game-songs created and passed down by Black girls are full of sophistication, power and cultural meaning.
lead_paragraph: Even as an only child, I learned the hidden musicianship performed by girls, for girls, in the 100-year-old Black neighborhood outside Washington, where I was raised. For nearly 30 years, I have written about the sophisticated culture of Black girls’ embodied musical play. From backyards to schoolyards, their game-songs predate Emancipation. Their musical blackness has much to offer once we unpack the magic in the rhythms and rhymes that animate their torsos and release their tongues with laughter.

headline: A Paleontologist’s Guide to Playing with Your Dinosaur-Obsessed Kid
abstract: Paleontologists say parents should nurture children’s romance with playing with dinosaurs, for “Paleontology is the gateway to science.”
lead_paragraph: Every time Cheri Johnson, a senior analyst at the Chicago Transit Authority dropped off her son, Evan, at day care, he would throw a tantrum because he didn’t want her to go. Certainly, she thought, the 20-month-old would not scream all day. So one morning she spied on Evan from behind the day care’s glass door. As he was hollering and kicking his feet, she watched the other children try to console him.

headline: The State of Play
abstract: The act of playing shapes how our children see the world.
lead_paragraph: The first weekend of quarantine, my daughters took sidewalk chalk, made a hopscotch board in our building’s courtyard, and spent over an hour in blustery March weather jumping with glee, their hair whipping in the wind. Over the last few months, they have climbed on rocks and around jagged fences in abandoned parks; built hospitals for their ailing American Girl dolls, Blaire and Nanea, who were struck down by a mysterious illness that kept them in bed for weeks; and chucked a whole lot of rocks into a lake.

headline: Trump’s Tulsa Rally Drew Sparse Crowd, but It Cost $2.2 Million
abstract: New campaign filings show that President Trump’s campaign paid more than $2.2 million for the event, which last month had a lower-than-expected turnout that disappointed his campaign.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has held only one campaign rally since the pandemic swept across the country in March. It not only failed to fill the arena in Tulsa, Okla., but it was also very expensive.

headline: ‘It’s Terrifying’: Federal Agents Confront Portland Protesters
abstract: Military-clad agents arrived under the Trump administration’s executive order to protect U.S. monuments. Oregon’s governor called it “a blatant abuse of power.”
lead_paragraph: Military-clad agents arrived under the Trump administration’s executive order to protect U.S. monuments. Oregon’s governor called it “a blatant abuse of power.”

headline: Cosmas Magaya, Musician and Teacher of African Traditions, Dies at 66
abstract: A virtuoso of the mbira, a plucked instrument, he shared his knowledge with the wider world to preserve wisdom handed down orally. He died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Five Takeaways From the Report on Russia’s Interference in Britain
abstract: A report released on Tuesday depicts the failure of successive British governments to combat Russian interference despite ample evidence of meddling.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A long-awaited report into Russian influence in Britain was finally published on Tuesday, painting a damning picture of the failure of successive British governments to combat a series of threats and interference in its affairs, ranging from disinformation to the purchase of influence.

headline: Some Vaccine Makers Say They Plan to Profit From Coronavirus Vaccine
keywords: ['Clinical Trials', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Moderna, which is receiving $483 million from the U.S. government, told lawmakers it would not sell its vaccine at cost. Pfizer has said it would also profit, but has so far taken no government money.
lead_paragraph: Executives from four companies in the race to produce a coronavirus vaccine — AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson, Moderna Therapeutics and Pfizer — told lawmakers on Tuesday that they are optimistic their products could be ready by the end of 2020 or the beginning of 2021. All four companies are testing vaccines in human clinical trials.

headline: A Kangaroo Got Loose in Florida. Now Its Owner May Face Charges.
abstract: The kangaroo, named Jack, was corralled by the police last week after he was spotted hopping down a street in Fort Lauderdale.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Last week, a kangaroo bounded out of a backyard in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and hopped for about three blocks with the police in pursuit. Now its owner may be charged for allowing the animal to escape and for not having the records to show how he acquired it, the authorities said Tuesday.

headline: Shelton Clears Senate Committee, Moving Closer to Fed Board
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: President Trump’s two Federal Reserve nominees, including the hot-button pick Judy Shelton, will proceed to a vote in the full Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judy Shelton, an unorthodox economist with close ties to the Trump administration, moved a step closer to a seat on the Federal Reserve Board after the Senate Banking Committee voted along party lines on Tuesday to advance her nomination to the full Senate.

headline: Vivienne Westwood Climbs Into Cage to Support Julian Assange
abstract: The fashion designer Vivienne Westwood dressed like a canary to show her support for Julian Assange, the Wikileaks founder fighting extradition from Britain to the United States.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer Vivienne Westwood dressed like a canary to show her support for Julian Assange, the Wikileaks founder fighting extradition from Britain to the United States.

headline: McDonald’s Joins Walmart and Dozens of Other Chains With Mask Mandates
abstract: As coronavirus cases surge, major retail chains are insisting that customers wear face coverings, even in places where local governments do not require it.
lead_paragraph: Large retail chains have started requiring customers to wear masks inside all of their stores, as coronavirus cases surge across the country and politicians and public health experts clamor for widespread use of face coverings to stem the spread of the disease.

headline: Deciding Who Should Be First in Line for the Coronavirus Vaccine
abstract: Readers discuss using race, geography, age and other factors. Also: Working parents; subway riders in the pandemic; the disappearance of a Thai activist.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Americans Hunker Down, Threatening the Self-Storage Industry
abstract: What once seemed like one of the few recession-proof parts of commercial real estate looks as vulnerable as many other businesses.
lead_paragraph: For years, the self-storage industry in the United States has relied on what insiders call the Four D’s: death, divorce, displacement and disaster. But the coronavirus pandemic, combined with aggressive competition and brash overexpansion, has made what once seemed like one of the few recession-proof parts of the commercial real estate industry look as vulnerable as many other businesses.

headline: Trump Seeks to Stop Counting Unauthorized Immigrants in Drawing House Districts
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Census', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Critics described the move as unconstitutional and a transparent attempt to help Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump directed the federal government on Tuesday not to count undocumented immigrants when allocating the nation’s House districts, a move that critics called a transparent political ploy to help Republicans in violation of the Constitution.

headline: Review: Reliving ‘Private Lives,’ This Time Mostly Women’s
abstract: Eight short plays take cues from the 1930 Noël Coward comedy — but now the stakes are different.
lead_paragraph: An unlikely hodgepodge of names gets dropped in the course of Red Bull Theater’s Short New Play Festival: Virginia Woolf, Rachel Dolezal, Troilus, Cressida, Cervantes, Trump. But the name that gets dropped hardest — dropped in the sense that it all but disappears — is that of the production’s touchstone, Noël Coward.

headline: Tapestry C.E.O. Resigns, Acknowledging Past Relationship
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Tapestry, which owns Coach and Kate Spade, had hired a law firm to look into the claim against Jide Zeitlin, one of only five Black chief executives in the Fortune 500.
lead_paragraph: Jide Zeitlin, the chief executive of Tapestry and one of only five Black chief executives in the Fortune 500, resigned on Tuesday and later said the unexpected move, less than a year into his tenure, was related to a past relationship. The company’s board had been made aware of a misconduct allegation involving Mr. Zeitlin and hired a law firm to investigate, according to a person familiar with the situation who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Big Tech Has a Big Climate Problem. Now, It’s Being Forced to Clean Up.
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Apple said on Tuesday its devices would be carbon-neutral by 2030, making it the latest tech giant to ramp up voluntary climate targets.
lead_paragraph: The titans of the tech industry like to think of themselves as solvers of big world problems, and, lately, they’re tripping over themselves to show that they are working to solve a problem for which they, too, are culpable: climate change.

headline: Even More Notes From Our Homes to Yours
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'News and News Media', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Suggestions, lists, distractions and quarantine diaries from our reporters, critics and editors.
lead_paragraph: Suggestions, lists, distractions and quarantine diaries from our reporters, critics and editors.

headline: In Alex Trebek’s Reluctant, Moving Memoir, Life Is All About the Next Question
abstract: The longtime “Jeopardy!” host writes about his struggle with pancreatic cancer in “The Answer Is...,” but saves most of the room for gratitude and enthusiasms.

headline: Pompeo Praises Britain for Getting Tough on China
abstract: The secretary of state praised the British government for recent actions on China as the Trump administration tries to build a global coalition against Beijing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Tuesday cheered the hardening British posture toward China and appealed for a global coalition against the country, blaming the Chinese Communist Party for what he described as exploitation of the coronavirus pandemic “to further its own interests.”

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Monogamous Birds of N.Y.C.’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Pigeons arrived on our fire escape, grooming one another. A couple. Affectionate. But they weren’t pigeons. There was something un-pigeonly about them. My wife called them “generic birds.” Search: “generic, monogamous birds of N.Y.C.” We discovered: “Morning doves!” No, actually: “Mourning doves,” named after their gray feathers and melancholy song. I play a recording of their plaintive call. One cocks its head in recognition. (My wife thinks he was looking at a tree.) We sit inside. They sit outside. Bonded pairs waiting out this storm, listening to ambulance sirens mix with the sound of mourning. — Scott Illingworth

headline: The New York Times Has Shared a File With You
abstract: What happens when you invite staff members to make a Google Doc, write about what they’re thinking and doing during the pandemic, and make it public? “Notes From Our Homes to Yours” brings journalists and readers closer.

headline: Take the Next Step Toward Racial Justice
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: This incipient movement risks being reduced to a fleeting instant of heightened consciousness.
lead_paragraph: Since George Floyd’s murder, America has begun a remarkable reckoning with racial injustice. People of every race and generation have come together in largely peaceful protests across the nation to halt police brutality, which is disproportionately directed at people of color. But many Americans are demanding much more — that we finally redress the systemic racism that persists in this country, understanding that it diminishes us all.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Amadeus’ and ‘The Last Full Measure’
abstract: London’s National Theater is streaming a recorded production of “Amadeus.” And a fact-based film about a fallen Air Force medic hits Hulu.
lead_paragraph: AMADEUS Stream on nationaltheatre.org.uk. Nearly four decades after its debut, Peter Shaffer’s “Amadeus” was reborn at the theater that spawned it — the National Theater in London — in this 2016 production, which dropped an actual orchestra onto the National’s Olivier stage. Directed by Michael Longhurst, this telling of the rivalry between the composers Antonio Salieri and Amadeus Mozart pairs the Southbank Sinfonia with the actor Lucian Msamati, who plays Salieri. Msamati stars opposite Adam Gillen, who plays Mozart. This production “sounds different from any previous ‘Amadeus’ and, perhaps more important, feels different,” Matt Wolf wrote in a review of the production for The New York Times. He called it “a vibrant staging.”

headline: Andrew Mlangeni, Ally of Mandela in Anti-Apartheid Struggle, Dies at 95

headline: I’m a Lip Reader in a Masked World
abstract: There are ways to accommodate people like me. But if our collective pandemic experience has taught us anything, it’s that small sacrifices to help others are not exactly America’s strong suit.

headline: The Lightness of Being a Couch Potato May Work to Keep Us Fat
abstract: Sitting may confuse cellular sensors into thinking we are lighter than we are, prompting the body to put on weight.
lead_paragraph: In an interesting new study of overweight adults, those who donned a weighted garment for three weeks dropped pounds, without consciously changing their diets, moving more or otherwise altering their lives.

headline: His Name Is Joseph Boulogne, Not ‘Black Mozart’

headline: Gretchen Whitmer: What if Trump Made Everyone Wear Masks?
abstract: It would save many lives — and save the economy, too.

As a result, we took some of the most aggressive measures in the country in the fight against the disease, and our hard work paid off. Our actions saved thousands of lives.

headline: A Director Brings Cerebral, Sexy Style to Opera Classics
abstract: Krzysztof Warlikowski, who is staging “Elektra” at the Salzburg Festival, gives ancient myths a contemporary flavor.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — On a recent afternoon here, Krzysztof Warlikowski sat on a roof terrace, tousling his mane of hair and drawing deeply on a vape pen. Behind him were the spire of a church where Mozart prayed and the hills made famous by “The Sound of Music.”

headline: Portland Clashes Converge on Courthouse Named for an Antiwar Republican
abstract: The site where federal officers have fired tear gas and projectiles at protesters is named after a senator, Mark O. Hatfield, who described himself as “close” to being a pacifist.
lead_paragraph: At the federal court in Portland, Ore., the action usually takes place inside sleek, wood-paneled courtrooms. That is where an imprisoned C.I.A. spy admitted to smuggling notes to Russia through his son, where a judge upheld Oregon’s landmark assisted-suicide law, and where a jury acquitted seven people who participated in the armed takeover of a federal wildlife sanctuary.

headline: The Latest in School Segregation: Private Pandemic ‘Pods’

abstract: If they become the norm, less privileged kids will suffer.

Pods are supervised either by a hired private teacher or other adult, or with parents taking turns.

Because I canceled my reservation a week before Cunard itself canceled the sailing, I was not given the opportunity to get a refund.

headline: U.S. Northeast, Pummeled in the Spring, Now Stands Out in Virus Control

While the kids cannonballed into the saltwater pool and my wife sped through several novels, I spent my time in the sun doing exactly the sort of thing you’d imagine an opinion columnist might do on summer vacation: I read two hot new books about macroeconomics.

headline: Vampire Bats Self-Isolate, Too
abstract: When these mammals are ill, they have fewer interactions with family and friends, a new study suggests. “It’s like us,” said one researcher.
lead_paragraph: Vampire bats, those bloodsucking, flying critters with razor-sharp teeth, are rather social beings. They love grooming one another and sharing food supplies, which consists of regurgitated blood from some other unfortunate mammal. These bats also call out to one another when they’re apart from their group.

headline: How to Actually Talk to Anti-Maskers
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Medicine and Health', 'Social Media']
abstract: You cannot force public trust; you have to earn it.
lead_paragraph: As the Ebola epidemic raged in 2014, some West Africans resisted public health guidance. Some hid their symptoms or continued practicing burial rituals — like washing the bodies of their dead loved ones — despite the risk of infection. Others spread conspiracies claiming the virus was sent by Westerners or suggested it was all a hoax. In Conakry, Guinea’s capital city, an imam was arrested for violating his quarantine, and residents protested by not letting health officials check for fevers.

headline: M.L.B.’s Marathon Has Become a Sprint. Who Will Benefit Most?

Back then, in March, teams were preparing for business as usual: a 162-game schedule, fans in the stands, the pitcher hitting in National League parks — and if you were signed to play, you had to play.

headline: Still Time to Make Things Right

In our earliest days in our living room, my mother taught me about the joy of words and, from this, I learned about the power of the pen, and that getting a tricky clue or figuring out life’s puzzles is always better with someone else.

Photographers, after all, make the eye of the beholder literal, placing the subject consistently at their mercy to be idealized, stripped down or otherwise interpreted for the world as they see fit.

headline: Four Artists on the Future of Video Art
abstract: Hito Steyerl, Rachel Rose, Isaac Julien and Lynn Hershman Leeson talk about how they’ve been spending quarantine and just where, in this era of never-ending screen time, their work should live.
lead_paragraph: When coronavirus shuttered just about every gallery in the United States and confined many to their homes, museum curators and dealers had to improvise. Overnight, the only way they could show art was digitally. In some cases, this meant posting photos of paintings or using cameras to offer 360-degree virtual tours of exhibitions — to varying degrees of success. But then there were the works that were designed to be viewed on a screen, which have enjoyed a sort of a renaissance.

headline: Your Trusty Maps App Can Help You Navigate the Pandemic

Here are a few things you can do.

headline: $500,000 Homes in New York, New Mexico and Wisconsin
abstract: An 1814 Federal-style manor in Sackets Harbor, a renovated 1944 house in Albuquerque and an 1890 farmhouse outside Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: Known as Elisha Camp Manor, this house on the National Register of Historic Places was built by Elisha Camp, an industrialist, lawyer and soldier, who settled in Sackets Harbor on Lake Ontario, near the Canadian border, in 1804. The village is 68 miles north of Syracuse, N.Y., and 129 miles southwest of Ottawa. An early naval shipyard and War of 1812 battlefield — as well as a popular summer destination in Victorian times — it has evolved into a tourist center and gateway to the Thousand Islands region.

Exhibit A: Zoje Stage’s mind-bending, trippy second novel, WONDERLAND (Mulholland, 358 pp., $28). It begins with the most realistic of desires: more living space. Orla, a retired ballet dancer, and Shaw, an artist, leave New York City for a house upstate, their two young children in tow. Shaw has his own studio; the kids won’t have to share a room.

headline: 12 Forgotten Classics by Women-Led New Wave Bands
keywords: ['Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Listen to lesser-known songs by Nervus Rex, Josie Cotton, the Waitresses and more that arrived in the early 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Punk began as a reaction to both the blandness and bombast of rock’s ruling class. And the shrapnel from its mid-70s explosion struck more than just a nerve, triggering a flare-up of creativity colored by a spectrum of textures, styles and ideas. The Ramones and the Sex Pistols may have led the way, but it took bands like the Police, the Cars and Talking Heads to usher elements of punk aesthetics into the mainstream. While these new wave bands couldn’t help but sand down most of the rough edges, some of the spikiness and spirit of ’76 remained.

headline: Annie Ross, Jazz Vocalist of ‘Twisted’ Renown, Dies at 89
abstract: She rose to fame with the vocal group Lambert, Hendricks and Ross and, after personal struggles, found success as both an actress and a cabaret mainstay.
lead_paragraph: Annie Ross, who rose to fame as a jazz singer in the 1950s, struggled with personal problems in the ’60s, faded from the spotlight in the ’70s, re-emerged as a successful character actress in the ’80s and finished her career as a cabaret mainstay, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

abstract: New research has sharply narrowed the range of outcomes.

headline: ‘It’s just like gambling’: China’s bustling stock market echoes the 2015 crisis.
abstract: In a global economy troubled by the coronavirus pandemic, China’s recovery has offered a glimmer of growth. Chinese stocks rose by nearly a trillion dollars in the span of a few short weeks, shocking even the most sanguine of financiers.

headline: Do You Really Want That Wedding Cake a Year Later?
abstract: Experts weigh in on how to freeze your cake and have some other suggestions for commemorative treats to savor on your one-year anniversary.

The cake-freezing ritual stems from a 19th-century convention in which partners saved the top tier for their first child’s christening (with some believing it to be an omen of good luck).

headline: Know Your Food
abstract: It’s affirming to cook for yourself. Try to do it as much as you can.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. A few summers ago, long before the pandemic came to upend our lives and economy, my friend and colleague Tejal Rao wrote a beautiful column for The Times about how she met the man who would become her life partner. The story was about how he enjoyed oysters — “keenly and quietly, without fetish or hyperbole.” I think that’s probably the best way to enjoy oysters.

headline: Museum Directors Fear Permanent Closure, an Alliance Survey Shows
keywords: ['Museums', 'Finances', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: The American Alliance of Museums says that the Paycheck Protection Program “has served as a lifeline for many museums” during the pandemic, but they need more.
lead_paragraph: In an American Alliance of Museums survey published Wednesday, 16 percent of American museum directors who responded to it said there was a high risk that their museums could close in the next 16 months if they do not find additional funding.

headline: The Man Who Brian Eno Called ‘the Daddy of Us All’
abstract: La Monte Young, the composer who quietly shaped much of contemporary Western music, reaches his last act.
lead_paragraph: THE COMPOSER LA MONTE YOUNG held his 84th birthday party on a drab, rainy Sunday afternoon last October inside the Church Street building where he has lived with his wife, the 80-year-old artist Marian Zazeela, since 1963. That people like Young and Zazeela can still be found in TriBeCa in 2020 is nothing short of remarkable. Young is certainly the lone musician alive today who can claim to be no more than two degrees removed from three of the greatest icons of 20th-century modern music: Igor Stravinsky (who taught Robert Stevenson, the musicologist who was Young’s mentor in college), Charlie Parker (who played with the saxophonist Lee Konitz, with whom Young himself played as a session musician in Los Angeles) and Lou Reed (who co-founded the Velvet Underground with one of Young’s bandmates, John Cale). He is often considered the founder of minimalist music, having stripped composition down to its bare elements of rhythm, sound and tempo as early as the late ’50s. His compositions can alternate between abrasive (the 30-minute-long “Day of Niagara,” recorded in 1965 with Zazeela, along with Cale and sometime Velvet Underground collaborators Tony Conrad and Angus MacLise, is a loud score that sounds not unlike an airplane engine and predated the noise rock of Reed’s “Metal Machine Music” and other staples of early punk by about a decade) and hauntingly beautiful (such as 1958’s “Trio for Strings,” a three-hour piece that effectively created the language of minimalist music through the use of sustained tones punctuated by brief gasps of silence). In the 1960s, he introduced generations of musicians to the concepts of drones and sustained repetition and began incorporating Indian classical music into his work, about five years before George Harrison had ever heard of the sitar.

It wasn’t even the bullet shot through his leg by an Israeli soldier — a mistake, he was told later — after his Palestinian police squad had risked their lives to rescue a Jew from an attempted lynching.

headline: ‘Amulet’ Review: A Man in Dark Times and Deep Trouble
abstract: In this spooky tale, a soldier discovers a strange female talisman and meets some far more enigmatic women.

Students of the cinematic supernatural will know better, given the fantastic objects scattered throughout the horror genre, with its demonic dolls, cursed videotapes and enchanted fetishes. The object here is worn and pale as bone, with breasts and a shell-like disc fanning above its head like a mantilla.

headline: Pods, Microschools and Tutors: Can Parents Solve the Education Crisis on Their Own?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'E-Learning', 'Children and Childhood', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Income Inequality', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: As school openings remain in flux, families grapple with big questions about safety, money and politics.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, many parents have realized the agonizing truth about school this fall: If it happens in person, it might not feel safe. And if it happens remotely, it will be inadequate, isolating and unable to provide the child care many working parents need. Desperate for a better solution, parents around the country have started organizing “pandemic pods,” or home schooling pods, for the fall, in which groups of three to 10 students learn together in homes under the tutelage of the children’s parents or a hired teacher.

headline: ‘The Pull of the Stars,’ by Emma Donoghue: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “The Pull of the Stars,” by Emma Donoghue
lead_paragraph: Still hours of dark to go when I left the house that morning. I cycled through reeking Dublin streets that were slick with rain. My short green cape kept off the worst, but my coat sleeves were soon wet through. A waft of dung and blood as I passed a lane where livestock were waiting. A boy in a man’s coat shouted something rude at me. I pedalled faster, past a motor car creeping along to eke out its petrol.

headline: Charles Evers, Businessman and Civil Rights Leader, Dies at 97

abstract: Changing the secular space back into a religious one is a risk for the World Heritage Site.

To Turkish Islamists, the conversion marks the fulfillment of a long-held dream of restoring a symbol of Ottoman grandeur. For many others around the world, the change is a dismaying setback for one of the world’s greatest architectural and cultural landmarks.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Tokyo Olympiad’ and ‘Greatness Code’
abstract: Revisit Kon Ichikawa’s portrait of the 1964 Summer Olympics, or stream a new short-form sports documentary series on Apple TV+.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO OLYMPIAD (1965) Stream on Criterion Channel and HBO Max; rent on Google Play, iTunes and YouTube. Athletes and aesthetes alike can appreciate this documentary by the Japanese filmmaker Kon Ichikawa. “Tokyo Olympiad” covers the 1964 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, exploring glory and defeat at the games through a free flowing collage of meticulously framed wide-screen footage. Ichikawa pays more attention to the athletes and their emotions than to the competitions themselves — a decision that helped the movie stand out and become influential. Criterion Channel is streaming it along with a number of other artful films about the Olympics — including Claude Lelouch and François Reichenbach’s 13 DAYS IN FRANCE (1968) — that offer a high brow alternative to the postponed 2020 Tokyo Olympics, which were originally scheduled to open this week.

headline: Jacob Soboroff Saw Kids in Cages. Then He Started Talking — and Writing.
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Family Separation Policy (US Immigration)']
abstract: In his new best seller about the practice of family separation, the NBC News correspondent does not mince words.
lead_paragraph: EYEWITNESS On June 13, 2018, Jacob Soboroff, a correspondent for NBC News and MSNBC, prepared to visit Casa Padre, a former Walmart in Brownsville, Texas, where nearly 1,500 migrant boys, ranging in age from 10 to 17, were living after being apprehended at the U.S.-Mexico border. Hundreds of them had been separated from their parents as a result of the Trump administration’s zero tolerance immigration policy. Journalists were not allowed to bring cameras inside the facility, so Soboroff stopped at Walgreens to buy a small blue spiral-bound notebook (along with a car charger, dry shampoo and yellow Gatorade, which calms his nerves).

headline: Welcome to the Great Indoors: Museums Beckon in the Berkshires
abstract: At Mass MoCA and the Clark, there are timely new exhibitions, but our critic finds as much relevance in a still life by Manet, or an Ingres drawing.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — Museums that seemed on the brink of reopening in New York are staying shut after Gov. Andrew Cuomo modified the state’s reopening plan last week. In California, arts institutions that had briefly reopened have had to padlock their doors once again. As the coronavirus epidemic continues to intensify across the country, museums have had to recalibrate their plans for renewed engagement. Remember when you thought your “first” museum visit would feel like a payoff as the pandemic abated?

headline: Landlords Jump the Gun as Eviction Moratorium Wanes
keywords: ['Evictions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The CARES Act temporarily protects millions of renters from being kicked out of their homes for nonpayment. Filings aren’t supposed to resume until after Friday.
lead_paragraph: The four-month pause that has protected millions of Americans from eviction cases is set to expire at the end of this week. But that hasn’t stopped landlords across the country from trying to get a head start forcing renters out.

headline: In Picking Up Work Here and There, Many Miss Out on Unemployment Check
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: For millions of people, making a living is a cobbled-together proposition. That leaves a hole in the safety net when things turn bad.
lead_paragraph: Annie Frodeman often worked 40 hours a week or more — full time by most lights. She just worked them at two jobs.

headline: How This N.Y. Island Went From Tourist Hot Spot to Emergency Garden
abstract: Governors Island had a charming teaching farm that was a field trip destination. Now it’s producing hundreds of pounds of fresh produce every week.
lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be the busiest summer yet for Governors Island. After 15 years of careful redevelopment, a semi-abandoned isle off the southern tip of Manhattan had blossomed into a lush day-trip destination.

headline: The Blessing and Burden of Being John Lewis
abstract: During a reporting assignment in 2013, I received a rare glimpse of both the legend and the man. Neither one disappointed.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Red vs. Red in Texas, With Republicans Battling One Another After Mask Order
abstract: The virus has heightened long-simmering friction in the largest Republican-led state in the country, with Gov. Greg Abbott under attack from within his own party.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Texas Republicans have long sparred with one another, with feisty internal disputes in recent years over gun rights, bathroom bills and other culture-war issues. But since the spring, as the coronavirus began to take hold across the state, it has been an all-out battle of red versus red.

headline: Reopening Schools Is Way Harder Than It Should Be
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'E-Learning', 'Quarantines', 'Families and Family Life', 'Education', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Parenting', 'Child Care', 'Lunch and Breakfast Programs']
abstract: So is leaving them closed. Now what do we do?
lead_paragraph: Of all the American institutions the pandemic has shut down, none face pressure to reopen quite like schools do. Pediatricians exhort schools to open their doors wherever possible or risk developmental harm to kids. Working parents, particularly mothers, are in crisis, worried about having to leave the work force altogether in the absence of a place to send their young children each day. And President Trump is campaigning for schools to reopen, threatening to withhold funding if they don’t.

headline: An Artist Who Reanimates Extinct Species
abstract: In an age of uncertainty, the mysterious, highly imaginative work of the sculptor Marguerite Humeau embodies the precariousness of contemporary life, with an eye to the distant past.
lead_paragraph: ON A RECENT April afternoon, Marguerite Humeau set out to see some dinosaurs.

headline: The Great Climate Migration Has Begun
keywords: ['Migrants (Environmental)', 'Global Warming', 'Drought', 'Food Insecurity', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: New research suggests climate change will cause humans to move in unprecedented numbers. The Times Magazine partnered with ProPublica and data scientists to understand how.
lead_paragraph: New research suggests climate change will cause humans to move in unprecedented numbers. The Times Magazine partnered with ProPublica and data scientists to understand how.

headline: Where an American Passport Doesn’t Work: The World, and Irish Pubs
abstract: Will the coronavirus finally show Americans how much privilege they’ve enjoyed?
lead_paragraph: You know how countries have slogans, like Thailand is “The Land of Smiles”? That seems like a lot of pressure on citizens and tourists alike. An entire land of constant smiles? Even when you have lower back pain or you’ve just been served surprise divorce papers: Smile!

headline: Crowd Catches 2 French Children Who Leapt From Burning Apartment
abstract: The boys, aged 3 and 10, landed safely after people gathered below to break their fall.
lead_paragraph: As a plume of thick black smoke billowed from their burning apartment, a 10-year-old boy dangled a younger child from an open third-floor window, grasping on to the back of his shirt. The apartment’s balcony was engulfed in flames, and the two children appeared trapped.

headline: How the Police Ousted ‘Occupy City Hall’
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: After a pre-dawn raid with officers in riot gear, tarps were torn down and graffiti was scrubbed off, shutting down a monthlong protest.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Global Coronavirus Cases Surge, Stinging Even Places That Seemed to Have Control
abstract: Troubling resurgences have hit places around the world that were seen as models in the virus fight. In the U.S., known cases surpassed four million.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of coronavirus cases and deaths globally.

headline: Popular Chinese-Made Drone Is Found to Have Security Weakness
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Android (Operating System)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Privacy']
abstract: Researchers found a potential vulnerability in an app that helps power the drones, highlighting U.S. officials’ concerns that Beijing could get access to information about Americans.
lead_paragraph: Cybersecurity researchers revealed on Thursday a newfound vulnerability in an app that controls the world’s most popular consumer drones, threatening to intensify the growing tensions between China and the United States.

headline: The Showdown in Portland
abstract: Why have militarized federal forces been deployed to an American city?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Going Topless, Turning Heads
abstract: Station wagons outsell them, but convertibles hold a special place in the hearts of drivers, and automakers still offer a smorgasbord of models.
lead_paragraph: When Hollywood needs an allusion to freedom, romance or rebellion, it puts its hero in a convertible: Dustin Hoffman carving up traffic in an Alfa Romeo Duetto Spider, racing to bust up a wedding in “The Graduate.” The 1966 Ford Thunderbird in “Thelma and Louise,” frozen in flight above the Grand Canyon in the title pair’s climactic act of outlaw defiance. And Grace Kelly, in white gloves and a signature coral scarf, driving Cary Grant to distraction in a Sunbeam Alpine in “To Catch a Thief.”

headline: Storage Units Are Standing By
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Storage', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Moving and Moving Industry']
abstract: When it was time to quarantine with parents, or give up a lease, renters often had to make quick decisions on what to do with all their stuff.
lead_paragraph: Before Tiffany Shu, 23, left New York in late March, she spent two days in her East Village apartment frantically boxing up clothing, accessories and kitchen items, and preparing her mattress and a mirror for storage.

headline: Former Nazi Guard Is Convicted in One of Germany’s Last Holocaust Trials
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The 93-year-old defendant was convicted of 5,230 counts of accessory to murder — one for each person’s death while he was at the Stutthof camp — but was tried in juvenile court, because he was 17 at the time.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A German court convicted a 93-year-old man on Thursday for helping the Nazis murder thousands of people while he served as a concentration camp guard more than 75 years ago, in what might be one of the last verdicts to be handed down to a living participant in the Holocaust.

headline: Remote Learning? No Thanks.
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus is so widespread in the U.S. that many schools are unlikely to reopen anytime soon. Already, some large school districts — in Atlanta, Houston, Los Angeles, Phoenix, suburban Washington and elsewhere — have indicated they will start the school year entirely with remote classes. Yet many parents and children are despondent about enduring online-only learning for the foreseeable future.

headline: ‘The Rental’ Review: High Infidelity
abstract: Dave Franco’s directing debut puts four friends in peril at a vacation property.
lead_paragraph: Whether “The Rental” will injure the Airbnb industry is debatable, but its impact on moviegoers will otherwise barely be noticed. Featuring one of the most dissatisfying, anticlimactic endings in genre memory, this paranoid thriller (the directing debut of Dave Franco) turns an isolated seaside villa into a slaughterhouse.

headline: ‘Helmut Newton: The Bad and the Beautiful’ Review: Man With a Camera
abstract: This cheery, chatty overview of the life and work of the photographer Helmut Newton prioritizes gossip over critique.
lead_paragraph: Any artist who visibly raises the hackles of Susan Sontag deserves a closer look, and Gero von Boehm’s “Helmut Newton: The Bad and the Beautiful” is eager to oblige. Yet this brisk documentary, steered by the fond recollections and admiring voices of famous beauties — Charlotte Rampling, Catherine Deneuve, Isabella Rossellini, Grace Jones — is as averse to analysis as its irrepressible subject.

headline: ‘Yes, God, Yes’ Review: Sin and Sensuality
abstract: A naïve Catholic teenager explores her sexuality in this gentle indie comedy.
lead_paragraph: In the masturbation comedy “Yes, God, Yes” — a title that begs for an exclamation point — Alice (Natalia Dyer), a 16-year-old virgin and naïve Catholic high schooler, embarks on the road to solitary orgasm with more persistence than luck.

headline: ‘Retaliation’ Review: To Suffer Silently or Take Revenge?
abstract: Orlando Bloom takes on a tough role as an abuse survivor confronting his trauma.
lead_paragraph: “Retaliation” isn’t the violent revenge picture its title promises. When this movie, directed by the brothers Ludwig and Paul Shammasian, had its premiere three years ago, it was called “Romans.” Anyone who expects Orlando Bloom in Charles Bronson mode will instead get a serious-minded, if heavy-handed, British drama about a man coping with the trauma of having been sexually abused as a child by a priest.

headline: Bloomberg’s Gun Control Group Pours $15 Million Into Races in 8 States
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Political Advertising', 'State Legislatures', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: The group, Everytown for Gun Safety, hopes to help Democrats flip three Senate seats, win control of state legislatures and lift Joe Biden to victory in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg’s gun control organization will focus its political advertising spending this fall on eight states where it aims to help Democrats flip three Senate seats, wrest control of state legislatures and lift former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to victory in Florida.

headline: ‘Fisherman’s Friends’ Review: A Tale of Unlikely Chart-Toppers
abstract: This movie about singing seafaring working men hums a familiar tune.
lead_paragraph: This is one of those “based on a true story” movies that rather undercuts its veracity by having every character talk like they’re in a movie. In 2010, in Port Isaac, Cornwall, a quartet of loutish music industry execs throwing a stag weekend for a colleague hear the singing of the local fisherman. Described by one character as “the rock 'n' roll of 1752,” it sure has some heavenly harmonies, and one of the louts hears the sound of money.

headline: Southwest Airlines and American Airlines report deep losses.
abstract: Southwest Airlines and American Airlines on Thursday reported deep losses in the second quarter of the year, as a meek rebound in travel slowed in recent weeks with the spread of coronavirus infections and travel restrictions nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines and American Airlines on Thursday reported deep losses in the second quarter of the year, as a meek rebound in travel slowed in recent weeks with the spread of coronavirus infections and travel restrictions nationwide.

headline: Tesla turned a surprise profit despite a plant shutdown and lower sales.
abstract: The result was achieved “despite tremendous difficulties,” said the chief executive, Elon Musk, including a plant shutdown and lower sales.
lead_paragraph: Tesla on Wednesday reported a profit of $104 million, a result that surprised analysts, who were expecting the electric carmaker to lose money as the coronavirus pandemic squeezed the company on two fronts.

headline: Twitter’s user count surged but its revenue fell in the second quarter.
abstract: Twitter’s daily users surged to 186 million in the second quarter, up 34 percent from a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s daily users surged to 186 million in the second quarter, up 34 percent from a year ago.

headline: Trump Sends In More Federal Agents
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Chicago’s mayor cautiously agrees to receive help: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: When Biden said Trump was our first racist president, he might’ve been forgetting a few people. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet.

headline: Elon Musk Delivers a Big Surprise
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: An unexpected profit pushed Tesla’s turbocharged shares even higher. Will the electric-car maker join the S&P 500 soon?
lead_paragraph: Join us today at 11 a.m. Eastern for a timely discussion about the deteriorating relationship between the U.S. and China, and the implications for Huawei, TikTok, 5G and more. Our special guest for the DealBook Debrief conference call is David Sanger, The Times’s national security correspondent, who has been covering the “New Tech Cold War” between the world’s two largest economies. R.S.V.P. here. (Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)

headline: A Work in Progress That Explores Our Collective Ignorance
abstract: Pope.L, known for exploring themes of endurance alongside the history of race in America, shares a recent piece.
lead_paragraph: In this new series, The Artists, an installment of which will publish every day this week and regularly thereafter, T will highlight a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist, putting the work into context. Today, we’re looking at a piece by Pope.L, who’s known for his paintings, performances and installations that often explore themes of endurance alongside the history of race in America.

headline: John Lewis, Civil Rights Icon and Congressman, Will Lie in State at the Capitol Rotunda
abstract: In a stark reversal, President Trump said he was canceling the Jacksonville component of the G.O.P. convention. A new Quinnipiac University poll of Florida voters showed Joe Biden leading Mr. Trump by 13 percentage points.
lead_paragraph: [Follow the DNC Live: Biden’s speech, schedule, start time, streaming and more.]

headline: Owner of Ann Taylor and Lane Bryant Files for Bankruptcy
keywords: ['Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'E-Commerce', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Bankruptcies']
abstract: Ascena Retail is the latest retailer to fall during the pandemic. The disappearance of 1,600 of its 2,800 stores is a fresh blow to shopping malls.
lead_paragraph: The owner of Ann Taylor and Lane Bryant, which just a few years ago was one of the country’s largest clothing retailers for women and girls, filed for bankruptcy on Thursday, after declining sales and high debt were exacerbated by store closures mandated by coronavirus lockdowns.

headline: Angels and Artisans
abstract: And lots of ambition at Valentino and Dior, the last of the pandemic-designed digital shows.
lead_paragraph: You know something is wonky in the state of Denmark when a designer tells you he wanted to do something radical for a show so he decided to focus on … dresses. Dresses?

headline: Introducing: Nice White Parents
abstract: A new five-part series about building a better school system, and what gets in the way. New episodes of “Nice White Parents” are available here, brought to you by Serial, a New York Times Company.
lead_paragraph: We know American public schools do not guarantee each child an equal education. Two decades of school reform initiatives have not changed that. But when Chana Joffe-Walt, a reporter, looked at inequality in education, she saw that most reforms focused on who schools were failing: Black and brown kids. But what about who the schools are serving? In this five-part series, she turns her attention to what is arguably the most powerful force in our schools: White parents.

headline: ‘Tag-team parenting’ as jobs, joblessness and schooling take a toll on couples.
abstract: Daniella Knight called it “tag-team parenting.” She worked part time at a property-management company during the day while her husband took care of their three children — 3, 5 and 9 years old. She took over during his 4 p.m.-to-midnight shift as a litigation data analyst. After kissing the children good night, she worked her second job as a pediatric sleep consultant.
lead_paragraph: Daniella Knight called it “tag-team parenting.” She worked part time at a property-management company during the day while her husband took care of their three children — 3, 5 and 9 years old. She took over during his 4 p.m.-to-midnight shift as a litigation data analyst. After kissing the children good night, she worked her second job as a pediatric sleep consultant.

headline: California Reports More Coronavirus Cases Than New York
abstract: Thursday: But New York has recorded far more deaths. None of it is good.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Well-designed puzzles, natural bug sprays, Paul McCarthy — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Google Takes Aim at Amazon. Again.
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Search Engines', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The company is unveiling another initiative to compete more effectively with Amazon’s e-commerce business.
lead_paragraph: Google is getting serious about competing with Amazon in online shopping — just as it did in 2013, 2014, 2017 and 2019.

headline: How Well Is the Real Estate Market Recovering?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Record-low interest rates and a shortage of listings have produced a fast-paced seller’s market, but many areas are still lagging.
lead_paragraph: Coronavirus restrictions brought the U.S. housing market to a near standstill. Now it’s beginning to recover, if unevenly, as states enact their reopening plans, according to a report by Realtor.com.

headline: How New York’s Jewish Museum Anticipated the Avant-Garde
abstract: A string of adventurous curators made a quasi-religious institution a leading arbiter of mid-20th-century American art.
lead_paragraph: IN AMERICA IN the 1960s, the museum that showcased the latest and best contemporary art was located, predictably enough, in New York, but it wasn’t the Guggenheim, the Whitney or the Museum of Modern Art. Instead, the epicenter of the shock of the new was the modestly endowed upstart that art-world insiders affectionately called “the Jewish.”

abstract: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom in Pleasantville, N.Y., and an eight-bedroom in Stamford, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom in Pleasantville, N.Y., and an eight-bedroom in Stamford, Conn.
