headline: Beijing’s Tightrope: Stand Tough, but Avoid a Full Rupture With the U.S.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: After the closure of the Houston consulate and other actions, Chinese officials are trying to respond without endangering the economy or inviting further global isolation.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Two weeks ago, China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, pleaded with the United States to step back from the brink and find ways to work together. Just days later, he complained to his Russian counterpart that the United States had “lost its mind, morals and credibility.”

headline: What Changes in the First Year of Marriage?
abstract: For some millennial couples, not too much.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, young newlyweds are dealing with a host of new challenges and anxieties brought on by the coronavirus pandemic. Many have lost jobs or are worried about the possibility of losing work. Others are dealing with the stress of loved ones falling ill. And some — if they are lucky enough — are learning how to spend 24 hours a day with their new spouses, living and working together under quarantine.

headline: ‘Egregious Overreaction’: Portland Mayor Is Tear Gassed by Federal Officers
keywords: ['Tear Gas', 'Mayors', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: Federal officers tear-gassed Mayor Ted Wheeler of Portland, Ore., when they sprayed protesters he had joined outside a federal courthouse.
lead_paragraph: Federal officers tear-gassed Mayor Ted Wheeler of Portland, Ore., when they sprayed protesters he had joined outside a federal courthouse.

headline: Analysts worry about the top-heavy stock market.
abstract: The five largest stocks in the S&P 500 now account for 22 percent of the index’s market capitalization, according to Goldman Sachs. The soaring share prices of Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Microsoft — which all set new highs this month — has led to this record degree of market concentration, which makes some analysts nervous, notes the DealBook newsletter.
lead_paragraph: The five largest stocks in the S&P 500 now account for 22 percent of the index’s market capitalization, according to Goldman Sachs. The soaring share prices of Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Microsoft — which all set new highs this month — has led to this record degree of market concentration, which makes some analysts nervous, notes the DealBook newsletter.

headline: ‘Almost Famous’: The Oral History of a Golden God’s Acid Trip
abstract: As the coming-of-age rock tale turns 20, the cast and crew remember how a star’s badly aimed jump and other near-misses became a standout scene.
lead_paragraph: The writer-director Cameron Crowe was already a beloved voice in cinema for high school tales like “Fast Times at Ridgemont High” and “Say Anything.” Then came “Almost Famous” (2000). Also a coming-of-age story, it gave audiences a backstage pass to the 1970s rock ’n’ roll scene and in the process became a classic.

headline: A Decade of Puppets in Organized Chaos
abstract: Manual Cinema, a Chicago arts collective, is highlighting four of its productions — vivacious hybrids of film and theater — in a virtual retrospective.
lead_paragraph: A Manual Cinema show can often feel like two performances at once.

headline: Taylor Swift and Kanye West Will Tangle Again, With Dueling Albums
abstract: The two pop stars, who have been linked since the MTV Video Music Awards in 2009, are both set to release new records on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift and Kanye West, the most reliably combustible pair of stars in pop music, may well face off yet again on Friday.

headline: ‘It’s Like Groundhog Day’: Coronavirus Testing Labs Again Lack Key Supplies
abstract: Just weeks after resolving shortages in swabs, researchers are struggling to find the chemicals and plastic pieces they need to carry out coronavirus tests in the lab — leading to long waiting times.
lead_paragraph: Labs across the country are facing backlogs in coronavirus testing thanks in part to a shortage of tiny pieces of tapered plastic.

headline: Large DNA Study Traces Violent History of American Slavery
abstract: Scientists from the consumer genetics company 23andMe have published the largest DNA study to date of people with African ancestry in the Americas.
lead_paragraph: More than one and a half centuries after the trans-Atlantic slave trade ended, a new study shows how the brutal treatment of enslaved people has shaped the DNA of their descendants.

headline: Why Some Mosquitoes Prefer Humans
abstract: A few species find us irresistible; the rest are unimpressed. A three-year-long experiment offers an explanation for the difference in taste.
lead_paragraph: Mosquitoes have been called the deadliest animal in the world: tiny creatures so dangerous that genetic engineering may be necessary to win the battle against them. But not all mosquitoes are equally responsible for devastating the human population by spreading disease. Out of thousands of species, only a few like to bite humans — and even within the same species, mosquitoes from different places can have different preferences. Why do some find us irresistible, while others remain unimpressed?

headline: How Trump’s Use of Federal Forces in Cities Differs From Past Presidents
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Urban Areas', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Legal scholars fear the president is trying to take on a job that the Constitution did not give the federal government.
lead_paragraph: Federal forces went into Los Angeles to control the Rodney King riots. They entered Washington, Chicago and Baltimore in the days after the killing of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968. They went into Detroit during a race riot in 1943, and then again in 1967. They were in Little Rock, Ark., during school integration. For the Pullman Strike of 1894 in Chicago, and across numerous cities during the Great Railroad Strike of 1877, they were there, too.

headline: Video Surfaces of Execution of Aid Workers and Others Abducted in Nigeria
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Politics and Government', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: Five men — three aid workers, a government employee and a security worker — were abducted in June. A group aligned with the Islamic State is believed to be behind the killings.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A Nigerian terrorist group has executed five men — three of them aid workers — who disappeared while providing assistance in the northeastern state of Borno last month. A video surfaced on Wednesday showing the men kneeling and blindfolded. They were then shot.

headline: A Grandmother Offered Poetry and a Tween Found His Voice
abstract: As a widow living alone, I needed company, even virtual. His parents needed relief.
lead_paragraph: “Remote learning isn’t working out,” my daughter says on one of our regular family FaceTime sessions. My older daughter chimes in, “Have Mom work with Will.”

headline: The Tax Cut That Trump Wants, but Few Others Do, Explained
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Payroll Tax', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: How a temporary reduction in payroll taxes became the president’s go-to proposal to stoke the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump badly wants to cut the payroll tax. Hardly anyone in Congress shares his enthusiasm.

headline: ‘Finish the Fight’: A Special Digital Theater Performance Celebrates 100 Years of Women’s Right to Vote
abstract: The New York Times marks the centennial of the suffrage movement with an original play from some of the brightest young voices working today.
lead_paragraph: “Finish the Fight” premiered on Aug. 18, 2020 — the 100th anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment. A recording of the performance is available to stream for free.

headline: Barack Obama and Joe Biden Join Forces in Video Targeting Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Masks']
abstract: The former president and vice president released a new video Thursday meant to cast President Trump as unbefitting of the office, while trumpeting the credentials of Mr. Biden.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

headline: Viewing Party! Let’s All Watch ‘Love & Basketball’
abstract: Before she saved the summer with “The Old Guard,” Gina Prince-Bythewood proved that she had cinematic game with her debut feature.
lead_paragraph: For those seeking summertime movie fun, this has been an interminable season of discontent. With many theaters closed and the industry on effective hold, audiences have been streaming and often yawning the hours away. So thank the goddess for Gina Prince-Bythewood, whose Netflix action-adventure “The Old Guard” — with its mysteries, kinetic action, tight set pieces and pensive superheroes — has delivered the transporting pleasures we need.

headline: Teachers’ Fear of Returning to the Classroom
abstract: An Op-Ed writer said she will refuse to teach in person if that is required. Readers sympathize but also suggest that she should do her “civic duty.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tropical Storm Gonzalo Expected to Become 2020’s First Atlantic Hurricane
abstract: Gonzalo is the earliest named “G” storm since the satellite era began in 1966, according to the National Hurricane Center. In the Pacific, Hurricane Douglas is advancing toward Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Gonzalo is expected to strengthen into the first hurricane of the 2020 Atlantic season as early as Thursday, forecasters said.

headline: Saudi King Is Said to Have Successful Gallbladder Surgery
abstract: Days after King Salman was hospitalized, renewing rumors about his health, the royal court announced that the 84-year-old monarch had undergone an operation.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — King Salman of Saudi Arabia had surgery on Thursday to remove his gallbladder, days after being hospitalized, according to a statement from the royal court carried by the official Saudi Press Agency.

headline: Should 5-Year-Olds Start School This Year?
abstract: Faced with remote learning or socially distanced classroom options, some parents of rising kindergartners are considering holding their kids back.
lead_paragraph: Alka Tripathy-Lang’s 5-year-old son is supposed to start kindergarten this fall, but her district in suburban Phoenix has already delayed its start and announced that classes, when they do start, will be online for at least the first couple of weeks.

headline: Judge Orders Cohen Released, Citing ‘Retaliation’ Over Tell-All Book
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A judge agreed that federal officials had returned Michael D. Cohen to prison because he wanted to publish a book this fall about President Trump.
lead_paragraph: When Michael D. Cohen, President Trump’s one-time lawyer and fixer, met with probation officers this month to complete paperwork that would have let him serve the balance of his prison term at home, he found a catch.

headline: Shot Twice in the Back: A Case Tests the ‘Fleeing Felon’ Defense
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Fugitives', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: In August 2019, a man stood on a highway bridge over the Colorado River in Rifle, Colo., and pointed a gun to his chest as two police officers urged him not to kill himself.

headline: ‘Days of the Whale’ Review: A Battle Between Art and Power
abstract: Teenage graffiti artists have to confront the pleasures and pains of adolescence in this noteworthy new film from Colombia.
lead_paragraph: For all the stress and strife endured by the teenage protagonists of “Days of the Whale,” a drama set in Medellín, Colombia, the movie also puts across the bright beauty of its urban environs. After all, Medellín is known as a “city of eternal spring.”

headline: Read a Summary of the Republican’s Draft Proposal for More Virus Aid
abstract: The White House and Senate Republicans neared agreement on Thursday on a proposal for the next round of virus relief.
lead_paragraph: The White House and Senate Republicans neared agreement on Thursday on a proposal for the next round of virus relief.

headline: Do We Need to Tell Our Son That His Dad Has Coronavirus?
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: He is 8 years old and very afraid of us getting sick.
lead_paragraph: My husband, 8-year-old son and I live in a city that has become a Covid-19 hot spot. From the beginning of the pandemic, even when infections were low in our area, my son was fearful of the virus. He’s a little withdrawn (though happy to play with friends on Zoom) and worries that precautions like masks and social distancing are not enough to keep us safe. The problem: My husband just tested positive for the virus, but he has no symptoms; my son and I tested negative. Should we tell our son the truth or fib and say his dad is traveling for work while he quarantines at his parents’ house?

headline: The W.N.B.A. Is Out to Reclaim ‘Tremendous Momentum’ in New Season
abstract: A dramatic free agency period, a new collective bargaining agreement and a leading voice on social justice have set the stage for the W.N.B.A.’s players to capture the spotlight.

keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Wills and Estates']

lead_paragraph: The palatial mansions in New York City and Florida owned by Jeffrey Epstein, where the notorious financier was accused of running an elaborate sex-trafficking scheme involving underage girls, will be listed for sale for a combined $110 million.

headline: Ronald L. Graham, Who Unlocked the Magic of Numbers, Dies at 84
abstract: He was pre-eminent in the field of discrete mathematics, coming up with “some really pretty cool stuff.” (He was also a world-class juggler.)
lead_paragraph: Ronald L. Graham, who gained renown with wide-ranging theorems in a field known as discrete mathematics that have found uses in diverse areas, ranging from making telephone and computer networks more efficient to explaining the dynamics of juggling, died on July 6 at his home in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 84.

headline: These Women Are in the Running to Be Biden’s Vice President Pick

headline: Obama and Biden Discuss Health Care Legacy in Campaign Video
abstract: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. released a video conversation with former President Barack Obama, covering several topics including health care and the economy.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. released a video conversation with former President Barack Obama, covering several topics including health care and the economy.

headline: Suggestions, Distractions and Diaries. Our Staff Is an Open Book.
abstract: Worry is a drumbeat. Above it, though, there’s a melody: a craving for distraction and joy, for intimacy, for serendipity.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. It’s a funny thing, what’s happening with us, with this growing community of ours at home and At Home. We’re anxious about the coming months, about what happens when schools start or don’t, when the sun stops coming up early and falling late, when the temperature drops and we can’t be outside so much, can’t eat on a sidewalk, can’t loll around in a park. Will we be back at work, will we be still working or looking for work at this tiny desk in the corner of the bedroom, in the attic, in the living room, in the garage? Will we still be alone, or alone together? Will we be safer, or less safe?

headline: Big Tech Versus Climate Change
abstract: How tech companies and all of us can help slow global warming.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Gerald Williams, Poet, Essayist and Editor, Dies at 85
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Bronx-born and Boston-educated, he also worked as a translator in Paris and Amsterdam before settling in New York in the late 1960s. He died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Eight Artists on the Influence of Tom of Finland
keywords: ['Art', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Leather and Leather Goods', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Touko Valio Laaksonen, who would have been 100 this year, transformed depictions of queer eroticism in art through his hyper-real, hypermasculine style.
lead_paragraph: Tom of Finland’s influence is so vast that it can be hard to calculate. Through sheer force of imagination, the artist was able to manifest a hyper-real, hypermasculine style of queer erotic illustration that would end up inspiring not just legions of visual artists but entire subcultures. Any time a stylist puts a young pop star in a leather biker cap for a magazine shoot, the impact of Tom of Finland is not far-off.

headline: South Korea’s Most-Wanted Man Is Seized in New York
abstract: Yoo Hyuk-kee, whose family controlled a shipping company that ran a South Korean ferry that sank, faces charges of embezzlement. Prosecutors say embezzlement helped lead to unsafe conditions on the ferry.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — One of South Korea’s most notorious fugitives was arrested in the United States this week on ​ embezzlement charges ​at home stemming from the 2014 sinking of a ferry that killed more than 300 people, many of them high school students.

headline: 12 Summer Sparkling Wines, Because Who Needs a Reason
abstract: Beyond Champagne, excellent bubbly now comes from all over in a diversity of styles. You don’t require a special occasion to enjoy them.
lead_paragraph: The world may not offer much to celebrate right now. Nonetheless, it’s a great time to drink sparkling wine.

headline: ‘I Am Someone’s Daughter:’ Ocasio-Cortez Condemn’s Yoho’s Remarks

headline: Senators Say N.C.A.A. Needs Broad Reform
abstract: As the N.C.A.A. appealed for a federal policy for name, image and likeness rights, senators criticized the organization’s handling of amateurism rules and the return of sports amid the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: That the N.C.A.A. bars athletes from receiving compensation isn’t the only issue Congress has with the organization.

headline: A Hedge Fund Bailout Highlights How Regulators Ignored Big Risks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Government Bonds', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The Dodd-Frank financial law succeeded at making banks safer, but empowered shadowy corners of finance that nearly wrecked the system in March.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the coronavirus began shuttering the global economy in March, critical parts of U.S. financial markets edged toward collapse. The shock was huge and unexpected, but the vulnerabilities were well known, the legacy of risk-taking outside regulatory reach.

headline: ‘David Makes Man’ and the Matters of a Young Black Life
abstract: This quietly brilliant coming-of-age series from 2019 has new resonance with its arrival to streaming in 2020.
lead_paragraph: In the pilot of “David Makes Man,” Dr. Woods-Trap (Phylicia Rashad) is speaking to her gifted middle school class about history and family origins. She talks about the complexities and unanswered questions of the past, then turns the focus to her students: “What is your story? Will there be one?”

headline: ‘They Pushed Portland Too Far’: How Trump’s Crackdown Strengthened Protests
keywords: ['Federal-State Relations (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: President Trump’s deployment of federal agents is fueling the unrest in Portland, where protests have continued for over 50 consecutive days.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s deployment of federal agents is fueling the unrest in Portland, where protests have continued for over 50 consecutive days.

headline: A Brooklyn Restaurant’s Answer to Cabin Fever: Summer Camp
abstract: Olmsted, like many of its New York City peers, is trying to make the most of a strange season by serving up fun and games along with the distancing.
lead_paragraph: The other night a watermelon was brought to my table in the backyard of Olmsted, in Brooklyn. The first thing I noticed was its unusually compact size, slightly smaller than my teenage son’s head. The more unusual thing, though, was the copper spigot sticking out of its midsection. When I turned the spigot, out trickled a stream of cold, pink watermelon punch.

headline: Coming Next Year to the N.H.L.: The Seattle Kraken
abstract: The team’s new name and logo reference a mythical sea monster that has taken on popular appeal in recent years. It is already being met with cheers.
lead_paragraph: Seattle’s expansion National Hockey League team will be known as the Kraken.

headline: With Covid-19, a Seismic Quiet Like No Other
abstract: Coronavirus shutdowns led to “the longest and most coherent global seismic noise reduction in recorded history,” scientists report.
lead_paragraph: The shock waves of civilization travel through rocky ground and, at times, ricochet around the globe, as geologists know from decades of listening for earthquakes with sensitive seismometers. The human pulses come from heavy traffic, football games, rock concerts, fireworks, subways, mine explosions, rock drilling, factories, jackhammers, industrial blasts and other activities. In 2001, vibrations from the collapse of the World Trade Center registered in five states. Seismometers even picked up the impacts of the two airplanes.

headline: Viking Age Smallpox Complicates Story of Viral Evolution
abstract: An extinct version of the smallpox virus dating to 1,400 years ago prompts speculation about viruses becoming more lethal over time.
lead_paragraph: The evolution of the deadliest virus in human history — smallpox — is only partly understood. Like the novel coronavirus and many other disease-causing viruses, smallpox seems to have originated in animals, probably rodents, and spilled over to humans, probably thousands of years ago. In the 20th century alone it killed hundreds of millions of people.

headline: Virtual Encounters With Purring Cheetahs and Curious Penguins
abstract: Zoos are beginning to open, but digital experiences allow visitors to see ecosystems from a different perspective.
lead_paragraph: Wild creatures seem to be experts at social distancing — at least when it comes to humans. Most of the time, you can’t get within six feet of a leopard or a lemur on an ordinary trip to a zoo, which, with many cities’ pandemic-related restrictions, now promises to be far from ordinary. Online excursions to wildlife parks, aquariums and nature centers, however, can offer more intimate and revelatory experiences than on-site visits. How often do you get to see a penguin wandering an aquarium by itself or have your own face-to-face encounter with a cheetah?

headline: ‘Radioactive’ Review: Marie Curie and the Science of Autonomy
abstract: Rosamund Pike plays the pioneering scientist who won two Nobel Prizes while raising two daughters (one won her own Nobel).
lead_paragraph: “Radioactive,” a thoughtful, very watchable fictionalized portrait of Marie Curie, tries hard to nudge the halo off its subject. Given her endeavors and accolades — including two Nobel Prizes — this simple, humanizing effort proves tough but also feels necessary. One of the most celebrated scientists of the 20th century, Curie has long been lauded as a pioneer and is the only woman to win a Nobel twice, having first shared the prize for physics in 1903. Eight years later, she won for chemistry, defying a scandal to pick up her award and remind the world that she merited a claim on history.

headline: Ziwe May Destroy Hamilton
abstract: Welcome to the Age of Discomfort
lead_paragraph: “Hamilton” is back in the mix, but the flavor has changed from beloved historical blockbuster to “wait, that’s what this is?” Elsewhere, in new works like “Baited,” on Instagram Live, and “I May Destroy You,” on HBO, Black women are getting personal in ways that are expanding our palates for discomfort.

headline: The Pleasure of Watching Charlize Theron Throw a Punch
abstract: From her debut in “2 Days in the Valley” to “The Old Guard,” the actress has taken action seriously. Her fight scenes have the heft and emotion of a Gene Kelly dance sequence.
lead_paragraph: “You really wanna do this, kid?”

headline: Samantha Hickey, Nurse With a Gift for Diagnosis, Dies at 45
abstract: Ms. Hickey trained dozens of junior colleagues and exercised rare skills as a diagnostician over more than 20 years as a nurse in southwestern Idaho. She died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Testing Bottlenecks Threaten N.Y.C.’s Ability to Contain Virus
abstract: “Honestly, I don’t even really see the point in getting tested,” said one New Yorker who has waited nearly two weeks, with still no results.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four months after the pandemic’s peak, New York City is facing such serious delays in returning coronavirus test results that public health experts are warning that the problems could hinder efforts to reopen the local economy and schools.

headline: AT&T Signed Up 4 Million HBO Max Customers
keywords: ['Television', 'Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications', 'Company Reports', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Cable Television', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The phone giant saw customer defections across its businesses, but millions signed up to its new streaming service.
lead_paragraph: AT&T reported second-quarter results Thursday, and the numbers showed customer defections across the board, including in its wireless, broadband and satellite TV businesses. But arguably its most anticipated metric was how many people signed up for its new HBO Max streaming service.

headline: With Officials’ Backing, Dubious Virus Remedies Surge in Latin America
abstract: A chlorine solution, particularly popular in Bolivia, is just one of several unproven treatments gaining ground in a region desperate for hope.
lead_paragraph: TARIJA, Bolivia — In Cochabamba, high in the Bolivian Andes, people line up daily outside pharmacies on the central plaza, eager to buy the scarce elixir they hope will ward off Covid-19: chlorine dioxide, a kind of bleach used to disinfect swimming pools and floors.

headline: 8 Things to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Art', 'Music', 'Dancing', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Classical Music', 'Folk Music', 'Museums', 'Jazz', 'Opera', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'Theater', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: How can you get your cultural fix when many arts institutions remain closed? Our writers offer suggestions for what to listen to, read and watch.
lead_paragraph: This year’s edition of Asia Week, the annual convergence of auctions, museum shows and private dealer exhibitions that provides a tour of the artistry of several ancient cultures, was mostly forging ahead despite the coronavirus. But that plan didn’t work out: Gallery shows were cut short, and auctions were postponed. Finally, after some retooling and collaborating with institutions such as Bonham’s to conduct online sales, the cultural-festival-cum-trade-fair has come up with a virtual version (on view through July 31 at asiaweekny.com; click on “Summer Redux”).

headline: Here’s How Congress Might Replace the Extra $600 Weekly Jobless Benefit
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Recession and Depression', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Supplemental checks for laid-off workers are set to expire at month’s end. Republicans and Democrats disagree on what to do next.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An additional $600 per week that has provided a vital financial cushion for unemployed Americans has begun to expire. On Monday, top Republicans had reached agreement on a proposal to reduce a benefit that has helped millions of laid-off workers and been a boon to consumer spending amid a deep recession.

headline: At the British Masters, Empty Fairways, Empty Pubs and a Hole in the Bubble
abstract: A town in northeast England welcomed 70,000 fans for the British Masters three years ago. This year, in so many ways, is different.
lead_paragraph: NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE, England — A reporter walks into a bar with a hotel booking number in her hand and a mask covering her face.

headline: No Longer in Shadows, Pentagon’s U.F.O. Unit Will Make Some Findings Public
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Unidentified Flying Objects (UFO)', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: For over a decade, the program, now tucked inside the Office of Naval Intelligence, has discussed mysterious events in classified briefings.
lead_paragraph: Despite Pentagon statements that it disbanded a once-covert program to investigate unidentified flying objects, the effort remains underway — renamed and tucked inside the Office of Naval Intelligence, where officials continue to study mystifying encounters between military pilots and unidentified aerial vehicles.

keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Spanish Civil War (1936-39)', 'Spanish Language']

lead_paragraph: MADRID — Juan Marsé, one of Spain’s most acclaimed writers, whose novels mostly chronicled the dark years that followed the civil war in Barcelona, his home city, died there on Saturday. He was 87.

lead_paragraph: Washington’s N.F.L. team will retire Redskins branding and adopt a placeholder team name until it can decide on a permanent name, the organization said Thursday, weeks after announcing it would yield to pressure from sponsors and activists and drop the name it has used for nearly 90 years.

headline: A Biden-Obama Reunion Pitches a Campaign as Comfort-Food TV

lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has been a boom time for TV reunions: “30 Rock,” “Parks and Recreation,” “Community” and more. On Thursday, the Joseph R. Biden campaign premiered a reunion of the West Wing — not the NBC drama, but the previous, pointedly low-drama presidential administration.

headline: Why the U.S. Chamber of Commerce Is Suing the Trump Administration
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Foreign Workers', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'United States Economy', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']

lead_paragraph: Over the past few weeks, the Trump administration has decided to close the door to engineers, executives, information technology experts, doctors, nurses and others who come to the United States on work visas. It has attempted to ban international students from attending American colleges and universities that hold classes virtually in the fall. And it has shown an unwavering commitment to canceling the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, or DACA.

headline: Who Gets the Covid-19 Vaccine First? Here’s One Idea
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Shortages', 'Remdesivir (Drug)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']

headline: Keith Sonnier, Playful Sculptor in Neon, Dies at 78
abstract: He tweaked the solemnity of Post-Minimalism with a sense of poetry and fun, using functional everyday materials.
lead_paragraph: Keith Sonnier, who infused functional materials like sailcloth, foam rubber, steel rebar and neon with a sense of poetry and play that tweaked the solemnity of Post-Minimal art in the late 1960s and made him one of the movement’s more unconventional standard bearers, died on July 18 in Southampton, N.Y. He was 78.

headline: Baptist Pastor Is Fired After Coming Out as Transgender
abstract: Junia Joplin, a Baptist pastor in Ontario, asked for acceptance in a sermon: “I want to be the person that God created me to be.” The congregation narrowly voted to terminate her contract.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the Rev. Junia Joplin told her Baptist congregation in a sermon about the importance of telling the truth without fear of the consequences. And then she revealed a secret truth of her own: She is a transgender woman.

headline: Johnny Depp and Amber Heard’s Courtroom Face-Off: An Explainer
abstract: The “Pirates of the Caribbean” star is suing a British newspaper for claiming he was violent toward his former wife. It’s a battle in which both stars could lose.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For the past three weeks, the attention of movie fans has been focused on one place: London’s grand, neo-Gothic Royal Courts of Justice.

headline: Anthony Terlato, Who Brought Pinot Grigio to the U.S., Dies at 86
abstract: In a 60-year career as a wine importer and marketer, he introduced Americans to lesser-known labels and shaped tastes.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Terlato, a visionary wine importer and marketer who introduced Americans to enduringly popular European wines and sought to elevate the wine market in the United States, died on June 28 at his home in Lake Geneva, Wis. He was 86.

headline: TikTok’s Parent Said to Weigh Selling a Majority Stake in the Video App
keywords: ['Social Media', 'United States International Relations', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

headline: Juan Soto’s Positive Test Casts Shadow on Yankees-Nationals Opener
abstract: Hours before the opening game of Major League Baseball’s pandemic-delayed season, one of Washington’s top young stars tested positive for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aaron Judge, the Yankees’ star outfielder, had been waiting for this day for nine months. Even this week, he insisted the Yankees’ season-ending loss to the Houston Astros in Game 6 of last year’s American League Championship Series still bothered him.

headline: Yoga, SoulCycle and Peloton Face Truths About How Black Lives Matter
abstract: Instructor walkouts and motivational messages in a predominantly white industry decimated by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic changed the way we work out, possibly forever, Sarah Levey was among the boutique fitness industry’s fastest-rising stars.  She and her husband, Mason Levey, are the founders of Y7, a yoga company with 14 studio locations in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, with classes costing $25 each, taking place in candlelit rooms with the heat and hip-hop playlists on full blast.

headline: Homeland Security Dept. Admits Making False Statements in Fight With N.Y.
abstract: The surprise admission came as the Trump administration unexpectedly reversed its decision to bar New Yorkers from programs that allow travelers to speed through airports.
lead_paragraph: Homeland Security officials made false statements in a bid to justify expelling New York residents from programs that let United States travelers speed through borders and airport lines, federal lawyers admitted on Thursday.

headline: Why Can’t Trump’s America Be Like Italy?
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Disease Rates', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: On the coronavirus, the “sick man of Europe” puts us to shame.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago The Times published a long, damning article about how the Trump administration managed to fail so completely in responding to the coronavirus. Much of the content confirmed what anyone following the debacle suspected. One thing I didn’t see coming, however, was the apparently central role played by Italy’s experience.

headline: Iranian Civilian Jet Swerves to Avoid American Warplane in Syria

lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. This latest installment is part of a series exploring how the Americans With Disabilities Act has shaped modern life for disabled people. Share your stories or email us at ada@nytimes.com.

headline: London’s West End Comes Out of Lockdown. For an Afternoon.

headline: Tech Is About Power. And These Four Moguls Have Too Much of It.
abstract: A congressional hearing on Monday should address this imbalance.
lead_paragraph: One of the more bizarre cable-show-bro handoffs of late happened this week between Fox News hosts Tucker Carlson and Sean Hannity concerning the $13 billion one-day spike in the Amazon chief executive Jeff Bezos’ fortune.

headline: Canceled Tournaments in China Are a Big Blow to Women’s Tennis
abstract: A move by the Chinese government to cancel international sporting events means the WTA Tour will lose its lucrative championships and six other tournaments.
lead_paragraph: In a season full of foiled plans and economic peril, the WTA Tour suffered its biggest blow on Thursday when it was forced to cancel its remaining tournaments in 2020 in China, including its lucrative tour championships: the WTA Finals in Shenzhen.

headline: The Future of Nonconformity
abstract: Where freethinkers go to fight.
lead_paragraph: Like other realms, American intellectual life has been marked by a series of exclusions. The oldest and vastest was the exclusion of people of color from the commanding institutions of our culture.

headline: In Afghan Attacks, Facts Are Murky. But It’s Clear Deaths Are Piling Up.
abstract: With peace talks stalled, the details of intensifying strikes across the country, and their toll on civilians, are increasingly hard to pin down. But there’s one certainty: Afghans are dying.
lead_paragraph: HERAT, Afghanistan — For a full day after airstrikes on a remote village in western Afghanistan on Wednesday, the only certainty was that people had perished.

headline: M.L.B. Expands Playoffs for 2020 Season
abstract: The new playoff format, which increases the postseason to 16 teams instead of 10, will help the league add broadcast revenue as it loses out on ticket sales.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The United States surpassed four million cases.
lead_paragraph: Grim milestones keep coming. The total U.S. case count surpassed four million on Thursday, with one million infections added in the last two and a half weeks alone. Virus-related deaths and hospitalizations are also rising at alarming rates.

headline: House Democrats Advance New Checks on Presidential Pardon Power
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Law and Legislation', 'Constitution (US)', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: The measures face major political and constitutional hurdles, but amount to the most substantial attempt by Congress in recent history to put guardrails around such powers.
lead_paragraph: Outraged by President Trump’s commutation of the sentence of Roger J. Stone Jr., House Democrats pushed forward legislation on Thursday that would give lawmakers new authority to scrutinize uses of executive clemency involving presidential family members or crimes against Congress and explicitly outlaw presidents from pardoning themselves.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: We dig deep into personalities in several of this week’s recommended books, and we start at the top, with the president. Mary Trump’s “Too Much and Never Enough,” about her uncle Donald and her extended family’s dysfunction, sits atop The New York Times’s best-seller list. Lacy Crawford’s “Notes on a Silencing” recounts her experience of sexual assault at an elite boarding school and the decades-long institutional cover-up that followed. The graphic novelist Adrian Tomine traces memories of neuroses and humiliations in the autobiographical “Loneliness of the Long-Distance Cartoonist.” And in “Desert Notebooks,” Ben Ehrenreich writes about life near Joshua Tree National Park and in Las Vegas.

With little chance of an imminent economic rebound, millions of Americans who have lost their jobs during the pandemic are now in grave danger of losing their homes, too.

It was held by coaches and players from both the Washington Nationals and the Yankees, all spaced out, as a message recorded by the actor Morgan Freeman played over the stadium speakers.

headline: A Half-Century Later, Police Identify a Homicide Suspect and His Victim
keywords: ['Forensic Science', 'Genealogy', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Missing Persons']
abstract: Using DNA evidence, the district attorney’s office in Orange County, Calif., said it had identified a 1968 homicide victim as Anita Louise Piteau and the suspect as Johnny Chrisco.
lead_paragraph: The last time Anita Louise Piteau’s family heard from her was in February 1968, when she sent a letter and a postcard home to Maine saying she had visited Hollywood and taken a tour of stars’ homes. Ms. Piteau had gone to California just a few months earlier, eager to see a new part of the country. In her letter, she said she planned to return to the East Coast in May.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Jim Gaffigan: The Pale Tourist’ and ‘The Kissing Booth 2’
abstract: A pair of new Jim Gaffigan specials debut on Amazon. And Netflix premieres the sequel to its rom-com hit “The Kissing Booth.”
lead_paragraph: JIM GAFFIGAN: THE PALE TOURIST Stream on Amazon. Jim Gaffigan jokes about poutine in Canada and paella in Spain in this two-part comedy special, which were filmed in Ontario and Barcelona. Among the other highlights of the site-specific sets: A bit about Spain’s many autonomous communities (“Do some of these regions even know they’re part of Spain?”) and an anecdote about showing up early to a Las Vegas nightclub to see Drake, the famous Canadian. “All these Drake fans were waiting to go in,” Gaffigan recalls. “They looked at me like, ‘Oh my gosh, there’s Drake’s accountant!’”

headline: A Chinese Tycoon Denounced Xi Jinping. Now He Faces Prosecution

lead_paragraph: China’s ruling Communist Party has expelled an outspoken and prominent property tycoon who denounced the country’s authoritarian leader, Xi Jinping, paving the way for his criminal prosecution and escalating its efforts to quash dissent among the elite.

headline: H.G. Wells and George Bernard Shaw Fight Over Socialism
abstract: In his latest installment of The Literati, Edward Sorel illustrates the epic battle for control of the Fabian Society, an elite group of socialists, at the turn of the last century.
lead_paragraph: In his 1901 book, “Anticipations,” H.G. Wells offered his predictions for the future and his belief that only an elite group of enlightened scientists and technicians could save humanity. The book caught the attention of London’s Fabian Society, a small group of accomplished men and women whose aim was to bring about socialism peacefully through the “permeation” of socialist ideas into universities and government. Some members thought that having Wells in their midst would make Fabianism interesting again, and in 1903 the red-bearded George Bernard Shaw, chair of their executive committee, led a group who put up the mustachioed Wells for membership.

headline: Divisions, Decency and ‘The Plague’
abstract: What should we do about the uneven distribution of pandemic consequences?
lead_paragraph: There’s a point early on in “The Plague” when a journalist stuck in the sickened city of Oran tries desperately to get out — beyond the walls, to the rest of healthy, happy French Algeria.

headline: Late Night Isn’t Impressed with Trump’s Cognitive Dissonance
abstract: “It was impressive until they asked Trump what he ate for lunch that day and he said, ‘Person. Woman. Man. Camera. TV,’” Jimmy Fallon joked after the president once again bragged about his cognitive test results.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Refugee and Author Long Detained by Australia Gets Asylum in New Zealand
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Books and Literature', 'Kurds']

lead_paragraph: CAIRNS, Australia — Behrouz Boochani, a Kurdish-Iranian refugee and writer who documented abuses under Australia’s tough immigration policies during his yearslong detention on a remote Pacific island, has been granted asylum in New Zealand.

headline: Michelle Wie West on Motherhood, Pain and a Possible Return to Golf
abstract: “I used to think my wrist was hurting during a round until I went through labor,” the former L.P.G.A. star says. Her competitive days might not be over.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Wie West’s eyes were not hollowed by exhaustion, as one might have expected of a first-time mother of a 1-month-old. Her face was not streaked with tears, as it was 13 months ago after her injury-plagued body failed her yet again, lending a hint of finality to a golf career that had once seemed limitless.

headline: ‘The Kissing Booth 2’ Review: Another Dose of Prep School Drama
abstract: A high school senior juggles college applications and a slippery, long-distance beau in this Netflix sequel to the popular teen rom-com.
lead_paragraph: Carnival smooching takes a back seat in “The Kissing Booth 2,” a treacly Netflix sequel that finds Elle (Joey King), alongside her best pal Lee (Joel Courtney), returning for more prep school escapades. Before senior year is up, Elle must juggle college applications, a cagey beau, friendship woes and, most absurdly, a high-profile dance video game competition held inside a colossal arena. The director Vince Marcello leans heavily on montage to get us through this deluge of invented drama which, mercilessly, unspools over more than two hours.

headline: ‘Animal Crackers’ Review: Of Hamsters and Men
abstract: For a movie about magical snack cookies, this animated adventure takes its sweet time laying out a basic premise.
lead_paragraph: In this children’s animated feature, magical animal crackers transform munchers into circus animals. Want to be a lion, elephant or hamster? Simply dig out the corresponding cookie.

headline: Thailand Drops All Charges Against Red Bull Heir in Deadly Crash
abstract: Vorayuth Yoovidhaya, grandson of the energy drinks inventor, had fled the country after striking a police officer with his car in Bangkok in 2012.

headline: A Spellbinding Debut Leaps Across Genres to Recreate the Confusion of Trauma
abstract: Kate Reed Petty’s “True Story,” focuses on the rippling, decades-long impact from a high school sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, in her powerful and galvanizing victim impact statement, Chanel Miller recalled the horror she had felt upon hearing the testimony offered by Brock Turner, the Stanford swimmer who had sexually assaulted her while she was unconscious. Initially, Turner had portrayed the evening as an anonymous drunken hookup. But at trial, a startling narrative emerged, one in which the events unfolded like a “poorly written young adult novel with kissing and dancing and hand holding and lovingly tumbling onto the ground,” and culminated in consent.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘The Memory Police’ and ‘Fleishman Is in Trouble’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: CHANCES ARE ..., by Richard Russo. (Vintage, 320 pp., $16.) The author of “Nobody’s Fool” and “Empire Falls” mines the “reminiscences and regrets” of three former college roommates gathered on Martha’s Vineyard more than 40 years after a young woman they all loved took off and disappeared. The novel “unfolds as a mystery” and builds to the men’s realization, as our reviewer, Alida Becker, put it, that “they might not know one another as well as they thought.”

headline: What’s Fair in Work and Pay: A Conversation About the Economy We Need

headline: Oh, So We’re Doing Random Video Chat Again?
abstract: Omegle, a precursor to Chatroulette, has grown in popularity during this indefinite period of social isolation.
lead_paragraph: First there was the Zoom boom, followed quickly by Zoom fatigue. Then everyone became a gamer, inviting visitors to their virtual islands and sending friends digital gifts. There were raves, meetings, meditations and movie nights, all of which took place on the internet.

headline: A Life Full of Meaning
abstract: The diabetes camp that gave us hope had an unlikely connection to my father, a former priest who would have delighted in being our guardian angel.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I received a handwritten letter in the mail from a person I didn’t know. The writer was the executive director of a summer camp. He had read my father’s obituary in the local newspaper.

abstract: Interviews with those who are risking the unknown — taking the train, commingling with strangers — to grab some fresh air and space.

In a news conference, the local sheriff, Grady Judd, described the aftermath as one of the worst crime scenes he had ever encountered — a massacre.

lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Road Trips are Great. Except for the Driving.
abstract: I wasn’t looking for an exotic vacation, just a temporary reprieve from compulsive news-watching and a dose of in-person fun with family and friends.
lead_paragraph: I am in the Catskills in a charming, tucked-away treehouse of an inn. My room, walking distance to hiking trails, overlooks a waterfall. Morning coffee and evening vodka-tonic are taken on the deck where the temperature clocks in at a marvelous 75 degrees. Owls hoot. Birds chirrup. Wind tickles my legs.

headline: The Art of the Cookie Drop
abstract: My Cookie Dealer, a bakery that delivers and ships orders placed through Instagram, has fared well in the time of socially distant dining.
lead_paragraph: Juan Morel, a 38-year-old professional bodybuilder, has several nicknames. One is “Diesel,” for his resemblance to the similarly smooth-headed and muscled actor Vin. Another, “King of New York,” he earned for winning his second New York Pro competition last May.

headline: That Flour You Bought Could Be the Future of the U.S. Economy
keywords: ['Grain', 'Flour', 'Commodities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Local Food', 'Small Business', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Keep baking bread. Small grain companies may suggest a better path for American business.
lead_paragraph: By the established logic of the business world, Maine Grains, a small miller of flour in a rural part of the state, should not exist. With some 20 employees, it mills about 2,000 tons of flour a year in an industry where larger companies can mill more than 20,000 tons a day. Grain has long been a commodity business, and milling is driven by size and scale. Yet tiny mills like Maine Grains and small brands like King Arthur Baking Company and Bob’s Red Mill are thriving. They raise a bold question: Could flour, of all products, suggest a better path for more of the U.S. economy?

headline: How to Dress for the Protest
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Graphic Novels', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Creativity', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: “On a daily basis I think about what I’m wearing.”

headline: Will It Take a Clever Acronym to Stop Racially Motivated 911 Calls?
abstract: A San Francisco politician thinks a new bill — named the “CAREN Act” — could be what it takes to get people’s attention, and limit potential harm.
lead_paragraph: The stories showed up in Shamann Walton’s social media feeds with alarming regularity: An eight-year-old selling water to raise money to go to Disneyland. A family barbecuing food on a charcoal grill near Lake Merritt. A man bird watching in Central Park. A woman sitting, leisurely, on a public bench in Manhattan. All of these activities — and several more like them — had been reported to law enforcement, often by strangers passing by.

headline: Did New York Just Get the Nation’s Most Liberal Legislature?

headline: W.N.B.A. Preview: The Seattle Storm Are Ready to Run the West

headline: There Is a ‘Great Silent Majority.’ But It Stands Against Trump.
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Whites', 'Suburbs']
abstract: And the minority he represents.
lead_paragraph: President Trump believes he represents the “silent majority” of the country against a dangerous, radical minority. He says as much on Twitter, frequently yelling “SILENT MAJORITY” at his followers. Accordingly, his campaign for re-election has tried to appeal to this “majority” with displays tailored to its perceived interests.

headline: Meet the New C.D.C. Director: Walmart
abstract: Why are big corporations requiring masks when many states still do not?
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention opened branch offices in Bentonville, Ark., and Seattle this month. Not officially. But with the president trying to distance himself from responsibility for the coronavirus crisis, and Southern governors amplifying the damage with their flawed reopening strategies, the nation’s retailers have become the first line of defense against the pandemic.

headline: How One of America’s Whitest Cities Became the Center of B.L.M. Protests
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Whites', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: In a state with a brutal racist history, the Black Lives Matter protests in Portland, Ore., have been overwhelmingly attended by white demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Seyi Fasoranti, a chemist who moved to Oregon from the East Coast six months ago, has watched the Black Lives Matter protests in Portland with fascination. A sea of white faces in one of the whitest major American cities has cried out for racial justice every night for nearly two months.

headline: So You’re Thinking of Moving …
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Moving and Moving Industry', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Road Trips']
abstract: But you’re scared about doing it during a pandemic. Here’s our F.A.Q. on changing homes (and cities) safely.

headline: Just How Far Will Joe Biden Go?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: He’s not listening to Twitter. So who does have the candidate’s ear?
lead_paragraph: For months, President Trump’s re-election team has been trying out possible lines of attack against Joe Biden: He’s sleepy. He’s creepy. He’s corrupt. He’s soft on China. He’s soft in the head. So far, nothing has stuck. Which may explain why one theme Mr. Trump and his supporters have latched onto is that, whatever you think of Mr. Biden personally, he is “a helpless puppet of the radical left.”

headline: The Star of This $70 Million Sci-Fi Film Is a Robot
abstract: Meet Erica, an android believed to be Hollywood’s first fully autonomous artificially intelligent actor. Can she overcome the uncanny valley?
lead_paragraph: The strangest part of Matthew Helderman’s video call came when he bit into an apple.

headline: How a Waiter, With Over 30 Years at the Same Restaurant, Spends His Sundays
abstract: John Roney has worked at J.G. Melon since the 1980s, but he’s not averse to change: the outdoors suit him just fine.
lead_paragraph: John Roney has been a waiter at J.G. Melon, the old-school burger joint on Manhattan’s Upper East Side, since 1986. He has worked through plenty of urban disasters, including Black Monday, Sept. 11 and Hurricane Sandy. But the coronavirus outbreak posed new challenges.

headline: Living With Edmund White
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']

lead_paragraph: There’s a lot you could say about Edmund White: He is the paterfamilias of queer literature, he witnessed the Stonewall riots, he literally wrote the book on gay sex. Not for nothing, his autobiography is called “My Lives.”

headline: 3 Great Mysteries About Life on Mars
abstract: How habitable was early Mars? Why did it become less hospitable? And could there be life there now?
lead_paragraph: Mars is the most explored planet in the solar system other than Earth. With all of our robotic visitors there, we’ve discovered that it is a world far too dry, cold and irradiated to support the scheming humanoids or tentacled invaders once imagined by science fiction.

headline: Tyler Mitchell: ‘Black Beauty Is an Act of Justice’
abstract: His debut photography monograph, “I Can Make You Feel Good,” suggests an Edenic timeline for Black American life, but also shows its inherited traumas.

headline: A Climate Plan in Texas Focuses on Minorities. Not Everyone Likes It.
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hurricane Harvey (2017)', 'Floods', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: For years, money for flood protection in the Houston area went mostly to richer neighborhoods. A new approach prioritizes minority communities, and it’s stirring up resentments.
lead_paragraph: Pleasantville, a few square miles of bungalows and industrial sites stuck between Houston’s railways and freeways, resembles a shallow bowl — quick to flood, like much of the city. But like other neighborhoods with large Black and Hispanic populations and low property values, it never qualified for the pricey flood-control projects that protect wealthier parts of Houston.

headline: Big Tech Funds a Think Tank Pushing for Fewer Rules. For Big Tech.

keywords: ['Track and Field', 'Swimming', 'Olympic Games (1948)', 'Women and Girls', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Athletics and Sports']

But in May, Ms. Fischer, her husband, Elliott Upton, and their 22-year-old son, Jack, picked up and moved to their weekend home in Southampton.

headline: A Busy Year and One to Remember

headline: Adding to the Sweeter Moments of Life
abstract: When the coronavirus forced them to change their plans, Bruktaweit Addis and Tif Slama were married on the same lookout point where they got engaged.

headline: Caring for Each Other, and Many Others

headline: A Four-Ring Ceremony (2 Wooden, 2 Golden)
abstract: Christian Willmes carved two rings from a fallen tree in Oxford, England, which were at the ready if the gold bands did not come through for his wedding to Lily McElwee.
lead_paragraph: Christian Willmes surprised Lily Clare McElwee on May 7 with two wooden rings he hand carved from a tree that had fallen near their house during a rainstorm earlier this year in Oxford, England. They were symbols for the date they started dating in 2017 at Oxford University and the date they were supposed to get married at Merton College Chapel before the coronavirus lockdown.

headline: Always an Open Table for Each Other
abstract: Rachel Lindstrom and Zach Sawyer met in a restaurant where both worked in Austin. Then they moved to Maine to take on another restaurant together.
lead_paragraph: Zach Sawyer and Rachel Lindstrom both ended up in Austin, Texas, on a whim. In 2015, Mr. Sawyer, now 33, had gotten out of a serious relationship on the East Coast and had a friend in Austin who offered him a couch. Ms. Lindstrom, also 33, had opted out of grad school for health care administration and had no idea what was next. She just knew she had to experience something different from Minneapolis, her hometown. A friend was heading to Austin and Ms. Lindstrom “kind of just piggybacked” on her move.

headline: Iraqi Security Forces Free Abducted German Arts Advocate
abstract: Hella Mewis was rescued after she was kidnapped near her offices in Baghdad on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Iraqi security forces have rescued a German arts advocate, just days after her early-evening abduction near one of Baghdad’s busiest streets, Iraqi and German officials said on Friday.

headline: Erdogan Fulfills Cherished Goal, Opening Hagia Sophia to Prayers
keywords: ['Religion-State Relations', 'Mosques', 'Politics and Government', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Byzantine Civilization', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Ottoman Empire', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: The Muslim faithful celebrated the decision by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, even as it generated dismay among Christians and architectural conservators.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan sealed his long-stated desire to restore the historic Hagia Sophia as a working mosque on Friday, opening the magnificent Byzantine structure built in the sixth century as the world’s largest cathedral to thousands of Muslim worshipers for the first time in nearly nine decades.

headline: A More Accessible World
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: When Judy Heumann was growing up in the 1950s, the New York City school system barred her from attending school and instead gave her only two and a half hours a week of home instruction. Why? She was in a wheelchair, as a result of polio, and school administrators refused to accommodate her in a classroom.

headline: Dave Franco Realizes His Worst Vacation Fears in ‘The Rental’

headline: Benjamin Mkapa, Ex-President of Tanzania, Dies at 81

keywords: ['Taxation', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'States (US)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

headline: My House Has Not Kept Up With the Pandemic

headline: Luis Barragán’s Forgotten Works, Revisited
abstract: After moving to Mexico City in 1935, the architect set about designing a series of obscure functionalist residences that he would later disown.
lead_paragraph: LUIS BARRAGÁN’S INCLUSION in the pantheon of the 20th century’s most influential architects rests on a strikingly limited output: foremost his own house and studio in the west of Mexico City, a UNESCO World Heritage site, followed by a handful of standout residences created after 1945 for wealthy clients. The reception of Barragán’s work is similarly reduced to a concise class of qualities: In the global imagination, his architecture became synonymous with evocatively vague notions of silence, mystery, serenity and thick walls in sensual colors considered to be redolent of some absolute sense of Mexican tradition.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Get inspired in the kitchen again. Make yourself a spumoni ice cream cake to go alongside a pan pizza, or grill your first corn of the season.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I caught a fat porgy on a home-tied fly the other day, a blind cast into clear ocean water, streaming past boulders on an outgoing tide. It wasn’t the striped bass I was looking for, but I thought it might be good for a few tacos for dinner and that hauled me out of the rut I’ve found myself in these last few weeks. It’s been freestyle mapo tofus with ground beef and chile crisp; skillet pastas with Italian sausages and plenty of kale; crema-marinated chicken grilled and doused in lime; repeat. It gets boring, frankly.

headline: Yoshitomo Nara Paints What He Hears
abstract: Ahead of a major retrospective in Los Angeles, the Japanese artist discusses his musical education.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the far northern reaches of Honshu, Japan’s largest island, Yoshitomo Nara discovered the outside world through his ears. This was many years before he’d leave to study painting at the prestigious Kunstakademie Düsseldorf in the late ’80s, and decades before Sotheby’s would sell his work “Knife Behind Back” (2000) for $25 million in 2019. Back then, in the 1960s and ’70s, he was a latchkey kid who whiled away the afternoons playing in an abandoned ammunition depot on a former Japanese Imperial Army site. At night, he’d listen obsessively, either using the family radio or one he’d built himself at age 8, to the Far East Network, an American station that served the area with news and tunes. Over these airwaves, he found Western music. Folk music. Rock music. He heard voices in a strange foreign language — English — and because he couldn’t understand the lyrics, these voices became just another sound alongside the guitars. And so he became an improbable, insatiable witness to Western pop’s evolution from the flower-child bliss of the mid-60s to the ecstatic thrash of late ’70s punk.

headline: When a Bookish Girl’s Imagination (Truly!) Takes Flight
abstract: With nods to Narnia, Hogwarts, E. Nesbit and Frances Hodgson Burnett, Hilary McKay’s “The Time of Green Magic” is a love letter to the literary canon.
lead_paragraph: If you read your way through childhood, you’ll feel a flash of recognition when you meet Abi, the 11-year-old heroine of Hilary McKay’s utterly enchanting new novel, THE TIME OF GREEN MAGIC (McElderry Books, 240 pp., $17.99; ages 8 to 12). Abi is “hunched over her book like a diving bird on the edge of a pool, poised between worlds,” so immersed in an old copy of “The Kon-Tiki Expedition” that she can taste the Pacific’s salt spray from her perch in North London. Then something uncanny happens. Her 6-year-old stepbrother, Louis, enters the room and sees a flicker of green — a glimpse, “no more than a wing tip,” of the parrot that flew alongside the Kon-Tiki.

headline: 10 Streaming Movies to Keep Your Summer Interesting

So, once again, it’s time to recommend a few out-of-the-box selections from your subscription streaming services — the offbeat biopics, quirky comedies, gritty dramas and cuckoo documentaries worth digging around for.

They often feature bleak, snowy settings and what seem to be rather morose police detectives. If you’re looking for a dark, chilly read, pluck one from this list.

headline: Love Letter: Breaking the Cycle of Abandonment
abstract: Plus: The new rules of dating.
lead_paragraph: By the age of 3, Kacey Vu Shap had experienced unthinkable loss, and in the next two years he would experience so much more. His mother and his younger brother died when he was 2, leaving his maternal grandmother to be his only caregiver. When he was 5, his older sister drowned in a river near their home in Vietnam, and he then learned that his father had died, too. That same year, his grandmother asked him to pack for a trip, which he would later find out was to an orphanage, where he would stay for two years before being adopted by a family in America.

headline: Nadine Taub, Early Leader in Women’s Rights Law, Dies at 77
abstract: Along with other feminist lawyers like Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Ms. Taub made legal history in cases that argued that the Constitution protected women’s rights.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1970s, Nadine Taub was one of a cadre of young female lawyers breaking new ground by fighting gender discrimination. Along with Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Nancy Stearns and others, she made legal history in cases that successfully argued that equal rights for women were protected under the Constitution. She litigated cases for rape victims, for women seeking access to abortion and for employees battling workplace discrimination and sexual harassment.
