abstract: At one of the eight pools to reopen, a swimmer almost forgot to remove his mask before making a cannonball jump. So, he placed it on his flip-flops and then — splash.
lead_paragraph: Watching the heavy rain from inside her car, Barbara Young considered going back home. Ms. Young, 52, had arrived at Fisher Pool in East Elmhurst, Queens, at 9:30 a.m. — an hour and a half before the pool had been scheduled to reopen for the summer — just to be one of the first people inside. The downpour looked ominous.

headline: ‘Pure Instinct’: The Extraordinary Rescue of 2 French Boys From a Fire
abstract: The story of how two brothers, 10 and 3, were saved from a burning apartment: “There were maybe five or six of us,” said one of the rescuers. “We did not plan anything.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Both the rescuers and the rescued refused accolades for bravery. But both were saluted across France on Friday for coming together in an extraordinary act that saved the lives of two small children threatened by a raging fire this week in a third-floor apartment in Grenoble.

headline: Kimberly Guilfoyle’s Fund-Raising for Trump Draws Scrutiny
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: Ms. Guilfoyle has raised money from donors and has made inroads with some who have rejected calls from others. Yet Trump supporters inside and outside the campaign say the operation she’s built hasn’t lived up to expectations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kimberly Guilfoyle’s popularity with major donors caught the attention of President Trump last year, as she traveled the country appearing at fund-raisers for his re-election campaign with her boyfriend, Donald Trump Jr.

headline: Pelosi Rejects Short-Term Extension of Unemployment Benefits, Again
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Pushing for broader aid, Nancy Pelosi, the House speaker, again rejected the prospect of passing of a short-term extension of the $600-a-week unemployment benefits on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Pushing for broader aid, Nancy Pelosi, the House speaker, again rejected the prospect of passing of a short-term extension of the $600-a-week unemployment benefits on Friday.

headline: Baseball Embraces the Weird and Hopes for the Best
abstract: There were cardboard fans, stars benched by the virus, and a last-minute playoff shuffle. While M.L.B. got its season off the ground, much remains out of the league’s control.
lead_paragraph: It was the most polite crowd in the history of New York baseball. Early in the Mets’ season opener on Friday, Jeff McNeil slid safely into second base, but the umpire blew the call. When the scoreboard showed the replay, the fans didn’t howl. They didn’t even make a peep.

headline: As He Woos Drugmakers on Virus, Trump Demands Drug Price Controls
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: President Trump is trying to revive a 2016 campaign promise to control the rising price of medicines, but new executive orders are coming when he needs drugmakers to deliver coronavirus treatments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump signed a slate of executive orders on Friday targeting the high price of prescription drugs, including a still tentative plan to tie the price that Medicare pays for some drugs to the low prices that foreign countries pay.

headline: U.S. Warns Russia, China and Iran Are Trying to Interfere in the Election. Democrats Say It’s Far Worse.
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Absentee Voting']
abstract: The government statement was short on details, reminiscent of the vague warnings in 2016 that, in retrospect, failed to seize the attention of officials and voters before the last presidential election.
lead_paragraph: American intelligence officials issued a public warning on Friday that China was “expanding its influence efforts” in the United States ahead of the presidential election, along with Russia and Iran, but Democrats briefed on the matter said the threat was far more urgent than what the administration described.

headline: Rene Carpenter, Astronaut’s Wife Who Broke NASA Mold, Dies at 92
abstract: The last living member of the Mercury 7 couples who helped define America’s early space program, she went on to become a writer and television host.
lead_paragraph: Rene Carpenter, the last surviving member of the much-glorified cohort of Mercury 7 astronauts and their wives, whom Tom Wolfe immortalized in his best-selling 1979 book “The Right Stuff,” died on Friday in Denver. She was 92.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The C.D.C.’s package on school reopenings included mixed messages.
lead_paragraph: In the anguished battle over reopening America’s schools, the nation is divided into distinct, sometimes overlapping groups. There are those who want schools to fully reopen in the fall in order to restore normalcy for children or to help reopen the economy or both, and others who are much more concerned that in-person instruction could seed broader outbreaks.

headline: Wary of Other Leagues’ Battles, N.F.L. and Players Agree on Terms to Return
abstract: As training camps get underway, the two sides finalized plans to reduce the salary cap and scrap preseason games, an agreement that paves the way for the regular season to begin as scheduled on Sept. 10.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. and the N.F.L. Players Association have finalized the last key financial issues related to this season, paving the way for an on-time start to the regular season on Sept. 10.

headline: Feeling Hopeless? Embrace It.
abstract: And then take action.
lead_paragraph: I attended a program several years ago at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis that was part of an exhibition called “Hippie Modernism: The Struggle for Utopia.” The event was a celebration and reunion for some local countercultural civil rights and antiwar activists from the late ’60s and ’70s. One of the speakers, a young Native American man, caught my attention when he said: “You baby boomers have forgotten who you are. It’s time to step back up and finish what you started.”

headline: Cracking Open a Bottle of Calgary’s Past
abstract: One man’s social media post of archived 19th-century newspaper ads has revived interest in a long forgotten drink.
lead_paragraph: For part of each week, I help put together The Times’s live briefing on the pandemic, which continues to ravage the United States and cause worrying outbreaks in Canada, where things are otherwise significantly better.

headline: Inside Trump’s About-Face on the Republican Convention in Jacksonville
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Republican National Convention', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Faced with a surging pandemic, resistance from local officials in Florida and deadlines for items like hotel payments, Mr. Trump chose to cancel the convention in an effort to cast himself as putting safety first.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

headline: Judge Rejects Challenge to Federal Agents Targeting Portland Protesters
abstract: Oregon’s attorney general had sued to prevent federal agents from patrolling the city in unmarked vehicles and detaining protesters.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — A federal judge in Portland on Friday rejected Oregon’s legal bid to restrict the operations of federal agents who have been battling protesters nightly in the city.

headline: Woody Johnson Was a Loyal Trump Supporter in 2016. As an Ambassador, He May Be Too Loyal.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'British Open (Golf)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In the view of some American diplomats, Mr. Johnson’s willingness to carry out President Trump’s request to seek the British government’s help in moving the British Open to his golf resort in Scotland was only the latest example of the envoy’s poor judgment.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Playing host at a small dinner on Tuesday night in honor of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, the American ambassador to Britain, Robert Wood Johnson IV, told his guests that the wine was from President Trump’s vineyard in Virginia. He was serving it, he joked, even though it might be ethically improper.

headline: What Arizona’s Tenuous Virus Plateau Could Teach Us
abstract: Is it possible to stabilize coronavirus infections without going into full lockdown? The hardest-hit Sun Belt states are offering a real-time experiment.
lead_paragraph: As the United States surpasses four million known coronavirus cases, far more than any other country, new outbreaks are sending thousands of seriously ill people to hospitals and driving a new wave of funerals. But there are also initial signs that new infections may be leveling off in some places, including in some of the worst hot spots.

headline: Trump Signs Orders to Reduce Cost of Prescription Drugs
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump on Friday signed a series of executive orders intended to lower the cost of prescription drugs in the United States.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Friday signed a series of executive orders intended to lower the cost of prescription drugs in the United States.

headline: ‘Mugged by Reality,’ Trump Finds Denial Won’t Stop the Pandemic
keywords: ['Masks', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: A president who once claimed that “the worst days of the pandemic are behind us” now acknowledges that it has surged through much of the country and will “get worse before it gets better.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He insisted that it was safe, that people could go back to work, that schools could reopen, that he could hold packed indoor campaign rallies, that he could even hold a full-fledged, boisterous, bunting-filled nominating convention as if all were well.

headline: Washington Post Settles Lawsuit With Student in Viral Protest Video
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Newspapers', 'Libel and Slander', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: A $250 million defamation suit over coverage of an encounter with a Native American elder came to a confidential end.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Post settled a defamation lawsuit filed by the parents of a Kentucky teenager over the paper’s coverage of his encounter with a Native American protester in Washington last year, an event that set off a national debate.

headline: The Two China Fires
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Is America prepared for a Cold War with China?
lead_paragraph: We’ll probably never know exactly what sorts of documents were incinerated at China’s Consulate in Houston in the days before the United States forced it to close on Friday, after accusing it of being a hub of espionage. We may also never know what caused this month’s catastrophic fire aboard the U.S.S. Bonhomme Richard, a massive amphibious assault ship that was being fitted out to double as a small aircraft carrier, in the port of San Diego.

headline: Split 5 to 4, Supreme Court Rejects Nevada Church’s Challenge to Shutdown Restrictions
keywords: ['First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Quarantines', 'Casinos']
abstract: The church said it was subject to more severe limits than casinos and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday rejected a request from a church in Nevada to block enforcement of state restrictions on attendance at religious services.

headline: American Catastrophe Through German Eyes
abstract: Trump says he wants to protect law-abiding citizens. In 1933, Hitler issued his ‘Decree of the Reich President for the Protection of People and State.’
lead_paragraph: PARIS — No people has found the American lurch toward authoritarianism under President Trump more alarming than the Germans. For postwar Germany, the United States was savior, protector and liberal democratic model. Now, Germans, in shock, speak of the “American catastrophe.”

headline: Clash of the Historians: Paper on Andrew Jackson and Trump Causes Turmoil
keywords: ['History (Academic Subject)', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A paper accusing scholars of “historical malpractice” upended an academic society and stirred arguments about racism, history and the limits of debate.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Jackson has been no stranger to rough-and-tumble conflict. In his own time, he upended the established political order and helped spearhead the violent expansion of America’s borders. In ours, he has become a toxic figure for many, as even the Democratic Party he helped found has distanced itself from his legacy of slaveholding, Indian removal and populist demagogy.

headline: For Whose Sake?
abstract: Royce Ferguson sets up our weekend stacks.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle punished my hubris and gave me a workout — I made a couple of wrong assumptions in those triple stacks — talk about pell-mell behavior — and got stymied. This is Royce Ferguson’s second puzzle for The Times, after an inventive Sunday debut that had little tunnels hidden everywhere — remember that? Feels like a decade ago to me, but it’s actually been three months.

headline: ‘Home-Schooling Won’t Kill Us. Covid-19 Might.’
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'E-Learning', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Parents and teachers struggle with how to reopen schools safely this fall.
lead_paragraph: “Of all the American institutions the pandemic has shut down, none face pressure to reopen quite like schools do,” Sarah Darville writes in this week’s Sunday Review.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Charities Fall in Need of Aid to Stay Afloat
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 25, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “People who used to donate to nonprofits are now standing in line to receive services, which tells you while demand is soaring the resources are plummeting.”

headline: The Coronavirus Unleashed Along the Amazon River
abstract: As the pandemic assails Brazil, the virus is taking an exceptionally high toll on the Amazon region.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic assails Brazil, the virus is taking an exceptionally high toll on the Amazon region.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Surviving Joe Exotic’ and ‘Days of the Whale’
abstract: Animal Planet follows some of the big cats transferred from Joe Exotic’s zoo. And two Colombian graffiti artists clash with a local gang in a New York Times’ Critic’s Pick.
lead_paragraph: SURVIVING JOE EXOTIC 10 p.m. on Animal Planet. The Netflix series “Tiger King” took viewers on a wild ride inside the world of exotic-animal breeders by following the lives and rivalries of its many colorful characters. But according to some critics of the show, its conservationist message was drowned out by the drama. This special, however, focuses on the stories of some of the animals who were transferred from G.W. Zoo, the Oklahoma wildlife park formerly owned by Joseph Maldonado-Passage, a.k.a. Joe Exotic. Among them are two visually impaired tigers whose vision is restored at the Exotic Feline Rescue Center in Indiana, and two lions who are relocated to the WildCat Ridge Sanctuary in Oregon. The special also includes interviews with former G.W. Zoo employees, as well as footage that Maldonado-Passage filmed in 2018 as part of Animal Planet’s “Wolves and Warriors” show, before he was arrested.

headline: Thanks to Trump, Jacksonville Becomes Political Roadkill
abstract: Successfully hosting a Republican National Convention during a pandemic could have been a big moment for Florida’s biggest city. But the coronavirus got in the way.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For Jacksonville, it wasn’t all that fun while it lasted.

headline: The F.B.I. Pledged to Keep a Source Anonymous. Trump Allies Aided His Unmasking.
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: After a Russia expert who had collected research on Donald Trump for a disputed dossier agreed to tell the F.B.I. what he knew about it, law enforcement officials declassified a road map to identifying him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long after the early 2017 publication of a notorious dossier about President Trump jolted Washington, an expert in Russian politics told the F.B.I. he had been one of its key sources, drawing on his contacts to deliver information that would make up some of the most salacious and unproven assertions in the document.

headline: How to Talk to Your Friends About Money
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Content Type: Service', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Friendship']
abstract: New financial hardships may be hitting those closest to you. It doesn’t have to be awkward.
lead_paragraph: When the 2008 recession hit, Emma Connelly was in fourth grade. The mass layoffs hit close to home. “My dad was unemployed off and on for basically six years, so he became a stay-at-home dad,” Ms. Connelly, 22, said. “We got very close.”

headline: President Trump Bows to Reality: This Week in the 2020 Race
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: Mr. Trump tried to convey a measure of seriousness about the coronavirus pandemic, backtracking on previous positions and behavior. How long will it last?
lead_paragraph: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.

headline: Me, My Relationship and PTSD
keywords: ['Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Past and present find their place as a couple wades through what their future holds. And it’s all OK.
lead_paragraph: Sam and I began the conversation partly in jest. His co-worker had just eloped in Hawaii, and as we scrolled through their photos I gave him an elbow to the ribs and said in a singsong voice, “Well, maybe we should go to Hawaii, too!”

headline: Comic-Con Is Online, and So Is the Artist Alley
abstract: Indie artists who make a significant portion of their income at fan conventions are hoping virtual attendees will be willing to spend.
lead_paragraph: Like most large events, fan conventions including San Diego Comic-Con, WonderCon and Dragon Con, have shifted gears this year as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. Some have been postponed or canceled; others have moved their programming online.

headline: In Era of Sickness, Doctors Prescribe Unusual Cure: Voting
abstract: As the pandemic curbs in-person voter registration, a growing number of doctors and nurses are registering their patients to vote.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The sign is easy to miss in the waiting room of the emergency department at Massachusetts General Hospital, next to the reception desk and a hand sanitizer pump. “Register to vote here,” it says, above an iPad attached to a lectern.

headline: Federal Agents Push Into Portland Streets, Stretching Limits of Their Authority
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: Federal agents are venturing blocks from the buildings they were sent to protect. Oregon officials say they are illegally taking on the role of riot police.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — After flooding the streets around the federal courthouse in Portland with tear gas during Friday’s early morning hours, dozens of federal officers in camouflage and tactical gear stood in formation around the front of the building.

headline: Anatomy of an Election ‘Meltdown’ in Georgia
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting Machines', 'Absentee Voting', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Computer Security', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: New voting machines and the pandemic exacerbated distrust of the state’s oversight of elections and voter access. What does this mean for November?
lead_paragraph: Last month, Daryl Marvin got his first taste of voting in Georgia.

headline: Don’t Throw Out That Corn
abstract: You can use kernels and cobs in creative ways.
lead_paragraph: When buying fresh corn, the old rule of thumb is to get one for each person and “one for the pot,” or maybe two, and it still applies, now that farm stands and markets are piled high with moist, green, just-picked ears. And it’s worth the added pocket change even though some farms are selling corn for as much as $1.25 an ear: There is so much you can do with extra cooked corn-on-the-cob you might as well plan to have some on hand. A single ear will yield from three-fourths to a cup of kernels. And don’t forget to keep the cobs. Collect them in a plastic bag in the freezer and you have the goods to enhance a quick vegetable stock.

headline: True Crime Podcasts at the Intersection of Race
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'Serial Murders', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Indigenous People', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Sex Crimes', 'Pulitzer Prizes', 'Minorities']
abstract: True crime is the lifeblood of podcasting. Here’s a list of shows that make racial justice their focus.
lead_paragraph: When people think of true crime podcasts, they inevitably think of “Serial.” But the genre is vast, and the podcasts listed here represent that diversity: a mother who investigates the death of her own son, a journalist recovering the lost history of a nearly forgotten race massacre, two friends telling each other stories about their favorite serial killers of color. They all have one thing in common: These stories are also about how racism and inequality intersect with the deeply flawed systems of criminal justice.

headline: ‘Online School Is Not the End of the World’
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'E-Learning', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Students tell us how they feel about the prospect of returning to the classroom.
lead_paragraph: We’ve heard from the adults about reopening schools: Teachers have presented safety concerns, politicians have presented political concerns, health experts have presented health concerns, parents have presented parenting concerns, and so on.

headline: The Retirement Savings Coach You Already Know
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Mentors', 'Retirement', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Workers who have learned how to manage their finances and sock away some money are teaching colleagues and friends.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic was declared in March and the U.S. stock market plunged, Dr. Bryan T. Whitlow was surprisingly sanguine about his retirement investments. Unlike many Americans, he didn’t radically cut his spending, didn’t check his balances constantly and didn’t yank money from the market.

headline: How Rob Manfred Navigated a Summer of Peril for Baseball
abstract: “We cannot be the one sport that doesn’t figure out how to play,” M.L.B.’s commissioner repeatedly told himself during months of contentious negotiations.
lead_paragraph: As Major League Baseball’s commissioner, Rob Manfred, boarded a private jet in Phoenix in June, he was convinced he had finally put his sport’s season on track. He had just met with the head of the players’ union, Tony Clark, and had hashed out what he thought was a framework to play an abbreviated season, seemingly ending weeks of an ugly back-and-forth between team owners and the players.

headline: What Do Portland Protesters Want, and How Have the Police Responded?
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Reform', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: Eight weeks after the death of George Floyd, here’s a look at why longstanding protests in the city have recently intensified.
lead_paragraph: When a video showing George Floyd’s death in police custody spread across social media, cities and towns nationwide soon erupted in protests against systemic racism and police brutality. But while protests in many places subsided after a few weeks, Portland, Ore., has been holding demonstrations every night since May 29.The arrival of federal forces in the city this month — and concerns they were exceeding their authority and violating protesters’ rights — drew the ire of local officials and reinvigorated nightly demonstrations. With renewed force, marchers have spray-painted the walls of the U.S. District Court building, demanding that federal agents go home. Groups of mothers have banded together, locking arms and chanting: “Feds stay clear. Moms are here.”

headline: Travel the World Through These Dance Tutorials
abstract: Here are eight cultural dances that you can learn at home through online tutorials or mobile dance apps.
lead_paragraph: Do you have itchy feet after all these months of lockdown? Now could be the time to do a little homework on the world of dance. And dance does span the globe, with genres found all over that are historically integral to their communities, cultures and regions.

headline: Trump’s Covid Failures Reshape Race and Lift Biden
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Republican National Convention', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: President Trump’s cancellation of the convention in Florida and sudden embrace of masks may signal his acceptance of a political landscape transformed by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: For months, President Trump belittled Joseph R. Biden Jr. as an opponent cowering in the basement in a mask as he sought to dismiss the seriousness of a pandemic threatening the nation’s health — and his re-election prospects.

headline: Mothers’ Power in U.S. Protests Echoes a Global Tradition
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Whites', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: When mothers take to the streets — particularly those from privileged groups — governments take note. The “wall of moms” in Portland has taken up the cause against police violence.
lead_paragraph: Wearing matching shades of white or yellow, the women of the “Wall of Moms” in Portland, Ore., have become instant icons of the city’s protests, though the mothers nightly gatherings only began last Saturday and the city’s protests have been going on for more than a month.

headline: Elon Musk, Blasting Off in Domestic Bliss
abstract: The billionaire space oddity on life with Grimes and Baby X, Trump, Tesla, tunnels, short shorts, stock surges, Facebook fumbles and everything else under the sun.
lead_paragraph: So how do the King of Mars, his Galactic Princess and their newborn son, X Æ A-Xii, spend a Saturday night holed up in their Los Angeles pad?

headline: As N.F.L. Fights Racism and Sexism, Team Owners Undercut the Message
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Football', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Women and Girls', 'Minorities', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The league has often focused its progressive efforts at employees, players and public displays. But the actions of team owners have undermined attempts at change.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has taken strides to repair its image as being insensitive to issues facing women and people of color. But the league continues to be confronted by an uncomfortable reality: Its efforts can be undercut by reports of toxic behavior at the tops of its franchises.

headline: Tailors Know New Yorkers’ Pandemic Secret: ‘Everybody Got Fat!’
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Weight', 'Dry Cleaning', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Small Business', 'Seamstresses and Tailors']
abstract: Tailors across New York City are expanding waistlines and moving buttons to accommodate the “Quarantine 15.”
lead_paragraph: With weddings postponed and offices shut, business was bleak at Woodside Tailor Shop in Queens during the long months of pandemic lockdown. There was no need for party dress alterations, or any pressure for slacks to be hemmed.

headline: The Great Au Pair Rush
keywords: ['Child Care', 'Foreign Workers', 'Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Visas', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: When the Trump administration shut the borders to many new au pairs, those already in the country found they had something new: options.
lead_paragraph: When the au pair decided to change families, she feared she was taking a major risk.

headline: Corporate Insiders Pocket $1 Billion in Rush for Coronavirus Vaccine
abstract: Well-timed stock bets have generated big profits for senior executives and board members at companies developing vaccines and treatments.
lead_paragraph: On June 26, a small South San Francisco company called Vaxart made a surprise announcement: A coronavirus vaccine it was working on had been selected by the U.S. government to be part of Operation Warp Speed, the flagship federal initiative to quickly develop drugs to combat Covid-19.

headline: These Monkeys Were Once Revered. Now They Are Taking Over.
abstract: The monkeys of Lopburi, Thailand, were once a draw for tourists and pilgrims who would feed them. But with few recent visitors, the monkeys are getting hungry — and aggressive.
lead_paragraph: LOPBURI, Thailand — The customers waiting outside a bank in Lopburi, Thailand, left their jewelry at home and kept other treasures out of sight. But danger lurked anyway.

headline: Compensation for Embassy Bombing Victims Could Imperil Thaw With Sudan
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A settlement to compensate victims of the 1998 attacks in Kenya and Tanzania would award more money to American embassy employees than the Africans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Riz Khaliq and Doreen Oport were both working at the American Embassy in Nairobi on Aug. 7, 1998, when a truck bomb tore through the compound. Both were bloodied. Mr. Khaliq was knocked unconscious and Ms. Oport trapped beneath fallen rubble.

headline: Why the ‘Super Weird’ Moons of Mars Fascinate Scientists
abstract: What’s the big deal about little Phobos and tinier Deimos?
lead_paragraph: Mars is the darling of many planetary scientists, who continue to visit it through increasingly advanced robotic explorers. But don’t forget that our planetary neighbor is adorned with two moons: puny Phobos, a lumpy mass 17 miles across; and diminutive Deimos, just 9 miles long. Their names in ancient Greek may mean “fear” and “dread’, but the aesthetics of these Lilliputian space potatoes inspire anything but.

headline: Vietnam, Lauded in Coronavirus Fight, Has First Local Case in 100 Days
abstract: A 57-year-old grandfather in the city of Danang, with no history of travel, tested positive and has been hospitalized. Health officials are tracing his contacts.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Vietnam, which had gone 100 days without reporting a case of local transmission of the coronavirus, said on Saturday that a 57-year-old grandfather in the central city of Danang had tested positive. How he got the illness remains a mystery.

headline: What’s in This Deep ‘Blue Hole’ Off Florida? They’re Working on It
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Exploration and Explorers', 'Submarines and Submersibles']
abstract: There are hundreds, perhaps thousands, of such holes on the ocean floor. Scientists are planning a mission to the one they call the “Green Banana.”
lead_paragraph: Sprinkled across the ocean floor, invisible from the surface, are hundreds — or maybe thousands — of sink holes. These “blue holes,” as scientists call them, do not swallow up everything incapable of fighting their gravitational force, like their black hole cousins. But to those who study them, they are still nearly as intriguing.

headline: A Viewer Spotted a Lump on Her Neck. Now, She’s Having a Tumor Removed.
abstract: Victoria Price, an investigative reporter in Tampa, Fla., said she was grateful that a viewer sent her a terse email suggesting that she get her thyroid checked out.
lead_paragraph: When an eagle-eyed viewer noticed something on the broadcast journalist Victoria Price’s neck during a televised segment last month, the woman sent her a short, cryptic email.

headline: Hurricane Hanna Hits Texas Region Struggling With Coronavirus
abstract: Some of the communities in the storm’s path have seen a sudden spike in Covid-19 cases and hospitalizations as Texas has become one of the largest hot spots in the country.
lead_paragraph: CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — Already battered by the coronavirus pandemic, southeast Texas faced a new but no less frightening foe on Saturday, as Hurricane Hanna slammed the coast with heavy rains and powerful winds.

headline: Breanna Stewart Is Ready for Her Old Normal: Winning Championships
abstract: The Seattle Storm forward played in her first W.N.B.A. game in almost two years since rupturing her Achilles’ tendon. She returns in a season like no other.
lead_paragraph: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Stewart’s previous installments here and here.

headline: To Learn to Draw, Start With Your Shoe
abstract: Drawing depends first on really seeing what’s in front of you, contour drawing can help train your hand to follow your eyes.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, people develop a manner of “seeing” that relies heavily on their brain telling them what’s there without really looking, because it saves time. Drawing depends on the opposite — bypassing the brain and really seeing what’s in front of you.

headline: Protests Swell in Russia’s Far East in a Stark New Challenge to Putin
abstract: Demonstrations in the city of Khabarovsk drew tens of thousands for the third straight weekend. The anger, fueled by the arrest of a popular governor, has little precedent in modern Russia.
lead_paragraph: KHABAROVSK, Russia — Watching the passing masses of protesters chanting “Freedom!” and “Putin resign!” while passing drivers honked, applauded and offered high-fives, a sidewalk vendor selling little cucumbers and plastic cups of forest raspberries said she would join in, too, if she did not have to work.

headline: Shed Your Quarantine Skin (and Hair and Nails), Safely
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Beauty Salons', 'Hair', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Spas', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: If you venture out for a treatment or trim, you might encounter plexiglass barriers, tons of cleaning supplies, fewer clients at a time and higher prices.
lead_paragraph: As areas around the country reopen following months of lockdowns, people are emerging from their homes with shaggy hair, translucent skin and claw-like fingernails — and then rushing to make self-care appointments. “The bathhouse has been booked out every day that we’ve been open,” said Andrew Nehlig, the owner of Sauna House, in Asheville, N.C., which reopened last month.

headline: U.S. Coronavirus Cases Soar as 18 States Set Single-Day Records This Week
abstract: Friday was the fourth day running that the United States reported over 1,100 deaths. New research sheds light on male vulnerability to severe Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read the latest updates here.

headline: Your Used Mask Needs to Make It to the Trash Can
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Masks', 'Pollution', 'Water Pollution', 'Plastic Bags', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Plastics', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: They’re on beaches, in parking lots and on sidewalks. You probably won’t catch the coronavirus from a discarded mask, but the litter poses a risk to the environment.
lead_paragraph: Helen Lowman looks at litter a lot. It’s her job. But while walking her dog in Westport, Conn., in March, she noticed an alarming trend. First she passed some dirty wipes on the ground. Then there were gloves. And finally a mask. Four months later, she said the litter of personal protective gear has only gotten worse.

headline: A.O.C. and the Jurassic Jerks
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For the Cave Man President and his party, clubbing women is not a path to victory.
lead_paragraph: President Trump is oh so proud of having mastered the ability to intone, “Person. Woman. Man. Camera. TV.”

headline: My Co-op Is Letting Workers in Again. How Do I Know They’re Doing It Safely?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Content Type: Service', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Cooperatives', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: Although the city and state have broad requirements in place, apartment buildings are enacting their own rules for residents. The key is to make sure you know what they are.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a large Manhattan co-op where, before the pandemic, apartment renovations happened almost constantly, with crews of workers showing up early in the morning and spreading out to different floors in the building. Now that workers are returning again, I’m concerned about my health and safety. How can we be certain that someone won’t bring Covid-19 into the building? Does our co-op really have to allow all this work to happen again?

headline: This Summer’s #1 Zucchini Recipe
abstract: Make seared zucchini, an heirloom tomato tart, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include Colu Henry’s seared zucchini (above) inspired by cacio e pepe, Vallery Lomas’s heirloom tomato tart and Sue Li’s carrot tart with ricotta and feta. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: A ‘Wall of Vets’ Joins the Front Lines of Portland Protests
abstract: Military veterans said they banded together to protect the free speech of demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — A week after federal officers in Portland, Ore., brutally struck a Navy veteran who said he had approached them simply to ask a question, a group of military veterans on Friday joined the front lines of the city’s growing protests.

headline: Officials Push U.S.-China Relations Toward Point of No Return
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Top aides to President Trump want to leave a lasting legacy of ruptured ties between the two powers. China’s aggression has been helping their cause.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Step by step, blow by blow, the United States and China are dismantling decades of political, economic and social engagement, setting the stage for a new era of confrontation shaped by the views of the most hawkish voices on both sides.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Anything goes in Sam Ezersky’s spicy variety puzzle.
lead_paragraph: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — This puzzle is a quintessential “PandA,” cute as heck but stubborn and hard to run with. PandAs are where pun clues that are too loosey-goosey for a disciplined cryptic crossword go to live. Sam Ezersky, who’s one of the foxes guarding the Times puzzle henhouse, sets a flurry of anarchic honks upon us. No more animal references, promise! Thank goodness, as always, for anagrams and crosses — some of today’s clues are really out there.

headline: Who Gets to Be a ‘Naked Athena’?
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Whites', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: On weirdness, whiteness and federal agents in Portland.
lead_paragraph: “Naked Athena.” Have you heard of her? She’s the woman who was so christened after she strolled into a recent Portland protest — one that was ostensibly, crucially, about Black lives — stark naked, save a mask (kudos to that) and skullcap. She sat down with her legs wide, and proceeded to do some yoga poses. Some say she was putting herself between protesters and police, that she was turning the cultural sacredness of a white (or at least a white-passing) woman’s body into a shield against rubber bullets and tear gas.

headline: A ‘Safety Net’ That’s a Kafkaesque Mess
abstract: The Supplemental Security Income program, on which millions of disabled Americans depend, is daunting by design.
lead_paragraph: In July 1988, a crowd of roughly 40 protesters gathered outside the Los Angeles Federal Building. As they chanted, their leader, Dr. Paul Longmore, a visiting scholar at Stanford, set fire to a biography of George Washington on a small barbecue grill.

headline: Once a Source of U.S.-China Tension, Trade Emerges as an Area of Calm
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: The trade deal is providing a rare point of stability as relations between the United States and China fray over Hong Kong, the coronavirus and accusations of espionage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the better part of three years, President Trump’s trade war with China strained relations between the world’s largest economies. Now, the trade pact the two countries signed in January appears to be the most durable part of the U.S.-China relationship.

headline: A 2020 Question 100 Days Out: Will the Elections Be Free and Fair?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Absentee Voting', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: President Trump baselessly rages about voter fraud, while Joe Biden warns of foreign interference.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

headline: Congress Was Already Broken. The Coronavirus Could Make It Worse.
abstract: A new report says that a sweeping change in institutional culture is needed for Congress to regain public trust. The challenges of the coronavirus are feeding the dysfunction.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A conservative Republican House member profanely accosts a Democratic congresswoman as she strides up the Capitol steps to do her job during multiple national calamities.

headline: A.O.C. and the Daughter Defense
abstract: Sorry, Ted Yoho. Having daughters doesn’t get you a sexism free pass.
lead_paragraph: Brett Kavanaugh invoked it. Mitch McConnell used it too. Matt Damon and Ben Affleck have each talked about it, and this week, Representative Ted Yoho joined their ranks: He, too, is now a member of the having-a-daughter-makes-me-an-ally-to-women — or at the very least, should-excuse-my-bad-behavior — club.

headline: Inequality and Our Capitalist System
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers discuss whether inequality, as one writer puts it, is “a logical, even necessary outcome of the capitalist system itself.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dive Into D.I.Y.s and a Variety of Summer Books
abstract: This week, tie-dye with veggies, listen to Michelle Obama’s new podcast and celebrate the singer and activist Mavis Staples.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: ‘Enough Is Enough’: A ‘Wall’ of Veterans Joins Portland Protesters
abstract: A group of military vets formed a wall on the front lines of protests in Portland, Ore., a week after federal officers struck a Navy veteran who said he approached them to ask a question.
lead_paragraph: A group of military vets formed a wall on the front lines of protests in Portland, Ore., a week after federal officers struck a Navy veteran who said he approached them to ask a question.

headline: Live Hurricane Hanna Tracking Map
abstract: The storm made landfall Saturday afternoon on the southern coast of Texas.
lead_paragraph: The storm made landfall Saturday afternoon on the southern coast of Texas.

headline: Misogynistic Lawyer Who Killed Judge’s Son Had List of Possible Targets
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: The list was found after the lawyer killed himself and had more than a dozen names, including three other judges and two doctors.
lead_paragraph: An openly misogynistic lawyer who is believed to have killed the son of a female federal judge in New Jersey had a list of more than a dozen other possible targets, including three other judges and two doctors, three people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: Richard Gelles, Scholar of Family Violence, Is Dead at 73
abstract: He believed in reuniting families even if parents had abused their children — until he saw how often that approach threatened children’s safety.
lead_paragraph: Richard Gelles, a prominent sociologist, had been one of the nation’s foremost defenders of family preservation, the practice of reuniting biological parents with their children even if they had abused them.

headline: Milos Jakes, Czech Communist Leader, Is Dead at 97
abstract: In 1987 he was made general secretary of the country’s Communist Party. Two years later he was swept aside by reform.
lead_paragraph: Milos Jakes, the head of the Communist Party in what was then Czechoslovakia during the tumultuous two years that ended Communist domination of the country and resulted in the election of the playwright Vaclav Havel as president in December 1989, has died. He was 97.

headline: David Sackoff, 71, ‘Survivor’ Who Battled Mental Illness, Dies
abstract: He lived on the streets, in prison and in psychiatric facilities, but in the end achieved independence. He died of complications of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Tom Thibodeau Nearing Agreement to Become Knicks Coach
abstract: Thibodeau, a defensive-minded coach who most recently led the Minnesota Timberwolves, had been an assistant coach for the Knicks from 1996 to 2003.
lead_paragraph: Tom Thibodeau, a defensive-minded coach who most recently led the Minnesota Timberwolves, is nearing an agreement to take the reins of the Knicks, a source with knowledge of the negotiations said on Saturday. Thibodeau, who had been an assistant coach for the Knicks from 1996 to 2003, will become the team’s eighth coach since 2012.

headline: In Portland’s So-Called War Zone, It’s the Troops Who Provide the Menace
abstract: If President Trump is actually trying to establish order, he is stunningly incompetent.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — To watch Fox News is to learn from Sean Hannity that the “Rose City” of Portland is “like a war zone” that has been, in Tucker Carlson’s words, “destroyed by the mob.”

headline: Donald Trump Is the Best Ever President in the History of the Cosmos
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: That’s no more fantastical than the rest of his re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: It’s no longer interesting, or particularly newsworthy, to point out that Donald Trump lies. It stopped being interesting a long time ago. He lied en route to the presidency. He lied about the crowd at his inauguration. His speech itself was one big lie. And the falsehoods only metastasized from there.

headline: The Ghost of Margaret Sanger
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Planned Parenthood and the complexities of anti-racism.
lead_paragraph: This week, Planned Parenthood of Greater New York announced that it would remove Margaret Sanger’s name from its Manhattan Health Center. The grounds were Sanger’s eugenic ideas and alliances, which for years have been highlighted by anti-abortion advocates and minimized by her admirers. Under the pressures of the current moment, apparently, that minimization isn’t sustainable any more.

headline: A Visit to the Classrooms the Kids Left Behind
abstract: School administrators confront what one called “the greatest challenge of my career.”
lead_paragraph: Over a million New York City students and teachers are still unsure of when and how they might return to school this fall. Their classrooms are capsules of those panicked final days in March, when schools abruptly shut down to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: ‘We Will Be a Voice for the Voiceless’: The W.N.B.A. Season Is Dedicated to Breonna Taylor
abstract: The Seattle Storm, with the league’s career assists leader, Sue Bird, and its 2018 M.V.P., Breanna Stewart, back in action, beat the Liberty’s seven-rookie squad in the season opener.
lead_paragraph: The W.N.B.A. season started with 26 seconds of silence and an empty court.

headline: John Lewis, Son of Alabama, Makes His Last Journey Home
abstract: Days of memorials for the congressman and civil rights figure began in Troy, the small Alabama town where he was raised. “Rest well,” one of his sisters said.
lead_paragraph: TROY, Ala. — In the coming days, John Lewis will be brought to the halls of power. He will lie in state in the Capitol in Washington, as well as in the statehouses in Alabama and Georgia. He will be mourned by lawmakers and governors and the many other influential figures he came to know during more than 30 years in Congress.

headline: Rich New Yorkers, How’s That Census Coming?
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Census']
abstract: Some neighborhoods where wealthy residents skipped town during the pandemic have among the lowest response rates in the city.
lead_paragraph: You’re a wealthy New Yorker who fled the city during the coronavirus pandemic, and you haven’t yet filled out the census.

headline: The Pandemic Could Make Political Conventions Less Terrible
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Republican National Convention', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Democratic National Convention']
abstract: The president did America a favor, in more ways than one, by canceling much of this year’s Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: President Trump announced on Thursday that, in deference to the pandemic, he was canceling the portion of the Republican National Committee’s nominating convention scheduled to take place in Jacksonville, Fla., late next month.

headline: Brazil’s Bolsonaro, Leading Virus Skeptic, Says He’s No Longer Infected
abstract: President Jair M. Bolsonaro of Brazil said on social media that he had tested negative for the coronavirus, more than two weeks after confirming his infection. Then he went for a motorcycle ride.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil said Saturday that he had been cured of the coronavirus, appearing to have suffered only mild symptoms from a scourge he has repeatedly downplayed even as it rippled through the country, killing more than 86,000 people.

headline: Regis Philbin, TV’s Enduring Everyman, Dies at 88
abstract: With patience, determination and folksy, spontaneous wit, Mr. Philbin climbed to pre-eminence relatively late in life on talk and game shows.
lead_paragraph: Regis Philbin, the talk- and game-show host who regaled America over morning coffee with Kathie Lee Gifford and Kelly Ripa for decades, and who made television history in 1999 by introducing the runaway hit “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,” died on Friday night. He was 88.

headline: From Alabama to the Capitol, the Journey to Honor John Lewis
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Family and friends gathered to remember the civil rights figure.
lead_paragraph: Representative John Lewis, the congressman and civil rights figure who died July 17, began his long journey home this weekend.

abstract: Trenton Charlson’s puzzle asks us to line up properly, please.
lead_paragraph: Note:  The Times is working on an issue with downloadable puzzle pdfs.  We will make them available here.

headline: As the World Gets Tougher on China, Japan Tries to Thread a Needle
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Tokyo has not confronted Beijing as the United States and other allies have, mindful of its neighbor’s economic might and its own limited military options.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Earlier this year, as it became clear that the coronavirus pandemic was not going to pass quickly, the Japanese government delayed plans for what would be the first state visit by a Chinese leader to Tokyo since 2008.

headline: North Korea Declares Emergency After Suspected Covid-19 Case
abstract: The country locked down a city near its border with South Korea. It was the first time North Korea has admitted that it might have a coronavirus case.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Sunday that it had locked down a city near its border with South Korea and declared a “maximum” national emergency after finding what its leader, Kim Jong-un, said could be the country’s first case of Covid-19 there.

headline: Small Plane Crashes Into Backyard in Utah City, Killing 3
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Private Aircraft', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: Three people died in the crash, including a 9-month-old, an official said. Four others were injured.
lead_paragraph: A small plane with six people aboard crashed into a backyard in a residential section of a city in Utah on Saturday afternoon, killing three people and sending a fireball hundreds of feet into the air, officials said.

headline: Fires and Pepper Spray in Seattle as Police Protests Widen Across U.S.
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: From Los Angeles to New York, protesters marched in a show of solidarity with demonstrations in Portland, Ore. In Seattle, they smashed windows and set fires. A shooting at a protest in Austin, Texas, left one man dead.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Weeks of violent clashes between federal agents and protesters in Portland, Ore., galvanized thousands of people to march through the streets of American cities on Saturday, injecting new life into protests that had largely waned in recent weeks.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Wynonna Earp’ and a Manson Docuseries
abstract: The fan-favorite Syfy show returns for a fourth season. And “Helter Skelter: An American Myth” revisits the Manson murders.
lead_paragraph: WYNONNA EARP 10 p.m. on Syfy. This fantasy western series, based on the comic books by Beau Smith, has been described by its showrunner as “a combination of ‘Buffy the Vampire Slayer,’ ‘Justified’ and ‘Frozen.’” It follows the adventures of Wynonna Earp (Melanie Scrofano), a distant descendant of Wyatt Earp, who is tasked with protecting the remote plains town of Purgatory from demons. Wynonna does this using Wyatt’s enchanted gun, the Peacemaker, and with a little help from her sister Waverly (Dominique Provost-Chalkley) and Waverly’s girlfriend, Nicole Haught (Katherine Barrell), a Purgatory sheriff’s deputy. As the series enters its fourth season, the Earp curse has been broken, but Wynonna still has to rescue everyone she loves.

headline: Corrections: July 25, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 25, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about a large DNA study that traced the violent history of American slavery referred imprecisely to some historical research. Historical records do exist showing that enslaved people were shipped directly from Nigeria to the United States, but not to the extent indicated by the new genetic evidence.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Federal Agents’ Aggression in Portland Stretches Legal Limits
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 26, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “This is not creeping authoritarianism. The authoritarianism is here.”

headline: Corrections: July 26, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 26, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 5 about the director Krzysztof Warlikowski, who is staging “Elektra” at the Salzburg Festival, misspells the surname of a Polish actor. He is Jacek Poniedzialek, not Pondiezialek.

headline: Yes, Fake News Is a Problem. But There’s a Real News Problem, Too.
abstract: In “Ghosting the News,” Margaret Sullivan writes about the consequences of local newspapers closing across the country.
lead_paragraph: What do you call it when a hedge fund buys a local newspaper and squeezes it for revenue, laying off editors and reporters and selling off the paper’s downtown headquarters for conversion into luxury condos or a boutique hotel?

headline: ‘We Were Somewhere in the 50s When We Noticed a Brass Quartet’
abstract: A face in the crowd, how to carry a rocking chair and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Virus Turns Midtown Into a Ghost Town, Causing an Economic Crisis
abstract: 7,500 workers are missing from a famous building. A food cart sells 10 hot dogs a day. The virus’s effect on one block could be an omen for the city’s future.
lead_paragraph: Editors and account managers at the Time & Life Building in Midtown Manhattan could once walk out through the modernist lobby and into a thriving ecosystem that existed in support of the offices above. They could shop for designer shirts or shoes, slide into a steakhouse corner booth for lunch and then return to their desks without ever crossing the street.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: Your Coronavirus Antibodies Are Disappearing. Should You Care?
abstract: Declining antibody levels do not mean less immunity, experts say. Besides, two widely used tests may detect the wrong antibodies.
lead_paragraph: Your blood carries the memory of every pathogen you’ve ever encountered. If you’ve been infected with the coronavirus, your body most likely remembers that, too.

headline: Don’t Ban TikTok. Make an Example of It.
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Censorship']
abstract: There is plenty the U.S. government could do to ensure that TikTok acts responsibly without getting rid of it altogether.
lead_paragraph: For a while, it seemed that TikTok might dodge the techlash. After all, what could be problematic about a short-form video app featuring a bunch of teenagers and 20-somethings doing choreographed dances, roller skating, hanging out in influencer mansions and cutting into photorealistic cakes?

headline: Slimmed-Down Baseball on TV Has Broadcast Workers Worried
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Television', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Cameras', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: Could changes to telecasts made during the coronavirus pandemic become permanent?
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball’s abbreviated 60-game season will look a bit different on television this year.

headline: Everlane’s Promise of ‘Radical Transparency’ Unravels
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Organized Labor', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Start-ups', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: Employees past and present are challenging management, saying the company’s ethical image was an illusion.
lead_paragraph: Michael Preysman, a founder and the chief executive of Everlane, a fashion brand that targets the ethically minded with minimalist basics, stood onstage in May 2019 at the Copenhagen Fashion Summit and preached the gospel of his company.

headline: ‘Disabled People Love Clothes Too’
abstract: But #disabledandcute influencers say the fashion industry has been slow to embrace them.
lead_paragraph: I have always believed that fashion is the window to the soul. As a Black disabled woman with cerebral palsy, a neurological disorder that affects movement on the right side of my body, I have gone through what I call the stages of fashion grief.

headline: Sledding Athletes Are Taking Their Lives. Did Brain-Rattling Rides and High-Speed Crashes Damage Their Brains?
keywords: ['Sports Injuries', 'Skeleton (Sport)', 'Luge Racing', 'Bobsledding', 'Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy', 'Concussions', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Brain', 'Traumatic Brain Injury']
abstract: Not long ago, Pavle Jovanovic was among the world’s top bobsledders. In retirement, he battled mental illness and substance abuse. Were brain injuries the cause of his demise and that of others in his sport?
lead_paragraph: On May 3, Pavle Jovanovic, a former bobsledder, rigged a chain to a crane he and his brother kept in the shop of their family’s metal works in Toms River, N.J. He tied the loose end around his neck and hanged himself.

headline: How Coronavirus Ravaged One Houston Family
abstract: Coronavirus numbers have shot up across the country. A family in Texas, a virus hot spot, describes how the illness quickly spread among them and hospitalized both parents.
lead_paragraph: Coronavirus numbers have shot up across the country. A family in Texas, a virus hot spot, describes how the illness quickly spread among them and hospitalized both parents.

headline: ‘You Do the Right Things, and Still You Get It’
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Masks', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Hospitals']
abstract: A Texas family tried to ward off the virus. But as cases in the state soared and debates about masks and distancing raged, there was only so much they could control.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Elaine Roberts, a longtime bagger at a supermarket, tried to be so careful. She put on gloves and stopped riding the bus to work, instead relying on her father to drive her to keep their family safe. She wore masks — in space-themed fabrics stitched by her sister — as she stacked products on shelves, helped people to their cars and retrieved carts from the parking lot.

headline: The Week in Business: Goodbye, Extra $600 a Week
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Federal aid programs will expire this week, but jobless numbers are rising again. It’s a perfect storm.
lead_paragraph: It’s a big week ahead in Washington, where Congress will hash out the fate of jobless benefits for over 30 million people as the coronavirus rages on. Here’s what else you need to know in business and tech as we roll into Monday.

headline: Testing Results Take Too Long, U.S. Official Concedes
abstract: Florida has now recorded more cases than New York. Britain orders travelers from Spain into 14 days of isolation, upending vacation plans for thousands.
lead_paragraph: Read our live Coronavirus Pandemic coverage here.

headline: As a Teenager, I Hated Johnny Carson. Then Came the Pandemic.
abstract: As a teenager, I thought his ‘Tonight Show’ was a bland, uncool relic. Now I appreciate his deadpan humor and the loose weirdness of his interviews.
lead_paragraph: In the last few months, at the end of news-packed days, as the noise of my cooped-up children gives way to the calmer sounds of sirens and fireworks, I have found myself uninterested in seeing any of the current late-night hosts transform the horrors of the world into jokes. I get my fill on Twitter.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Accusation’
abstract: An examination of the truth, in a moment when facts can seem malleable.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Strange Bedfellows: Iran’s Ex-President Woos Saudi Crown Prince as Pen Pal
abstract: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, known in the West for his Holocaust denial and disputed re-election in 2009, writes a warm letter to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, calling him a man of peace.
lead_paragraph: A former president of Iran, known in the West for speeches that assert the Holocaust was invented and that Israel should be erased from the map, has written a chummy letter to his country’s most ardent Arab foe: the crown prince of Saudi Arabia.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Fiery, sweet and salty, Tejal Rao’s fried chicken biscuits are great to eat wherever you might be.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today I’d like to make these fried chicken biscuits (above) that Tejal Rao cooked up a few years ago and brought into the newsroom like a gift, fiery-sweet-salty little picnic sandwiches that brought laughter onto the floor. They’d be great to eat in a park this evening, on a porch or stoop or roof, at the beach or in the forest where the falling sun dapples the pine needles. They’d be great to eat in a tiny apartment with a fan doing overtime. They’d be great to eat anywhere, if chicken you eat. (You don’t? Try this chicken-fried tofu sandwich instead.)

headline: Volunteer Confesses to Starting Fire at Nantes Cathedral
abstract: French prosecutors have charged the man, a Rwandan refugee, with arson. He had been questioned and released earlier in the investigation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A Rwandan refugee who volunteered at the 15th-century cathedral in Nantes, France, has confessed to setting a fire that severely damaged the interior of the church this month, his lawyer said on Sunday.

headline: We’re 20 Percent of America, and We’re Still Invisible
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Group Homes and Supportive Housing', 'Discrimination', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Minorities']
abstract: Disabled Americans are asking for true inclusion.
lead_paragraph: This month as the 30th anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act approached, we asked two prominent figures in the disability rights movement, Judy Heumann and John Wodatch, where they thought the United States stood in its quest to secure full rights for people with disabilities.

keywords: ['Green New Deal', 'Income Inequality', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers caution against radical change, though one disagrees.

abstract: Readers criticize leaders who view mandatory mask-wearing as an infringement on rights. Also: President Trump and Ghislaine Maxwell; online voting for New York City; age and the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Selma Helped Define John Lewis’s Life. In Death, He Returned One Last Time.
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: The body of John Lewis crossed the Edmund Pettus Bridge on Sunday, more than a half century after he helped change American history there.
lead_paragraph: SELMA, Ala. — On a different Sunday in Selma, this one more than five decades ago, John Lewis was a 25-year-old activist wearing a long tan coat and carrying a backpack, helping to marshal hundreds of demonstrators across the Edmund Pettus Bridge. They were bombarded by clouds of tear gas and swarmed by state troopers wielding clubs, one of which fractured Mr. Lewis’s skull.

headline: Hurricane Douglas Grazes Hawaiian Islands With Strong Winds and Rain
abstract: Forecasters predicted three to six inches of rain on the main islands, possibly contributing to flash flooding and landslides.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Douglas moved north of Hawaii early on Monday, sparing the islands the direct hit that forecasters had feared.

headline: Olivia de Havilland, a Star of ‘Gone With the Wind,’ Dies at 104
abstract: She built an illustrious Hollywood career punctuated by a successful fight to loosen the studios’ grip on actors.
lead_paragraph: Olivia de Havilland, an actress who gained movie immortality in “Gone With the Wind,” then built an illustrious film career, punctuated by a successful fight to loosen the studios’ grip on contract actors, died on Sunday at her home in Paris. She was 104 and one of the last surviving stars of Hollywood’s fabled Golden Age.

headline: Taylor Swift, a Pop Star Done With Pop
abstract: On “Folklore,” a quarantine album made largely with Aaron Dessner from the National, she swerves away from her last few releases, embracing atmospheric rock — and other characters’ points of view.
lead_paragraph: The song that catapulted Taylor Swift from too-cool-for-country phenom to the-world-is-not-enough pop supernova was “We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together,” the debut single from her fourth album, “Red,” in 2012. The first of her songs to top the Billboard Hot 100, it deployed country references as a tease on the way to an ecstatically saccharine, unmistakably pop hook — a universal anthem of I’m over it.

headline: ‘The Persians’ Review: Aeschylus’s Ancient Portrait of Defeat
abstract: This staging by the National Theater of Greece was broadcast live on Saturday from the amphitheater of Epidaurus.
lead_paragraph: There is not much action, barely even a plot, in “The Persians.” People just mill about, talking (admittedly rather intensely) about events (admittedly of the tragic kind) that happened far away.

headline: Peter Green, Fleetwood Mac’s Founder, Is Dead at 73
abstract: One of England’s finest blues guitarists, he wrote most of the group’s early songs. But he left the group after taking LSD, saying he wanted to change his life.
lead_paragraph: Peter Green, the English guitarist and singer who founded Fleetwood Mac, died on Saturday. He was 73.

headline: Upsides for Some Remote Workers; Lost Pay and Security for Others
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Telecommuting', 'Workplace Environment', 'Outsourcing']
abstract: Working from home creates economic winners and losers. It can benefit highly skilled employees but depress others’ wages and make it hard to organize.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic hit and tens of millions of American workers suddenly redeployed to their basements and living rooms, it was easy to imagine that their workdays would unfold roughly as before, with communication tools like Slack and Zoom substituting for face-to-face interactions (and maybe with slightly greater multitasking opportunities).

headline: Garrett Foster Brought His Gun to Austin Protests. Then He Was Shot Dead.
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The police in Austin, Texas, have not identified the motorist who fatally shot a protester after driving his car in the direction of marchers.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — It was not unusual for Garrett Foster to be at a protest against police brutality on a Saturday night. And it was not out of character for him to be armed as he marched.

headline: ‘In These Uncertain Times’ Review: Love, Loss and Zoom
abstract: Source Material presents a postmodern approach to talking about grief and isolation in quarantine.
lead_paragraph: “You OK?”

headline: Mason Gaffney, Who Argued for Taxing Only Land, Dies at 96
abstract: He was at the forefront of a tax-policy movement based on the ideas of Henry George, which helped spark the Progressive movement in the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: As Mason Gaffney bicycled to a Boy Scout meeting in 1940, a chauffeur-driven car clipped him, leaving him with injuries that kept him bedridden for months. During his convalescence his mother, appreciating his restless intellectual curiosity, gave him books to read, including complex tax policy textbooks in which he learned about Henry George, whose late-19th-century ideas helped spark the Progressive movement.

headline: Fighting False News in Ukraine, Facebook Fact Checkers Tread a Blurry Line
keywords: ['Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Propaganda']
abstract: Facebook hired a Ukrainian group battling Russian disinformation to flag misleading posts. But critics say the fact checkers’ work veers into activism.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — To understand the complexity of policing online disinformation, consider the small Ukrainian fact-checking group StopFake.

headline: The Premier League Calls It a Year, 352 Strange Days After It Began
abstract: A remarkable year in England ended with Aston Villa saved, Watford and Bournemouth relegated and the big clubs pretty much where everyone expected them to be.
lead_paragraph: LEICESTER, England — Those final few minutes, the ones upon which an entire season rests, do something strange to time. The clock seems to slow, each second clawing and scratching for its moment before it yields to the next. But each is so pregnant with meaning, or with the possibility of meaning, that even in these moments that last an age, it can be hard to keep up.

headline: Quarantine Order Blindsides Britons Returning From Spain
abstract: Britain’s sudden decision to make travelers from Spain self-isolate for 14 days caught many vacationers by surprise — including the transportation secretary.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Often criticized for a slow response to the coronavirus, the British government moved quickly this weekend to impose a quarantine on anyone arriving from Spain, after a spike in Covid-19 cases there.

headline: For French-Algerian Families, Virus Disrupts Cherished Summer Ritual
keywords: ['Summer (Season)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Families and Family Life', 'Travel Warnings']
abstract: Holidays in Algeria are a cornerstone of the cross-cultural identity of many French people with roots there. This year, they are stuck at home, and the pain is acute: “It’s sacred for us to leave.”
lead_paragraph: TOULOUSE, France — Sitting around a table strewn with steaming cups of mint tea, a dozen women were sharing memories of their summer holidays in their homeland, Algeria.
