abstract: The C.E.O.s are likely to argue before Congress that their companies aren’t anticompetitive. Here are the facts.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos of Amazon, Tim Cook of Apple, Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and Sundar Pichai of Google are set to testify before Congress on Wednesday to make their case about why their companies actually are not that powerful.

headline: Bored With Your Home Cooking? Some Smoky Eggplant Will Fix That
abstract: These crispy-silky croquettes rise to the restaurant level of cooking we’ve been missing.
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve been worn out by my own home cooking. It’s not the toil that’s getting to me; it’s more that I feel fatigued by the familiarity of it: the predictability of my own kitchen habits, the recognizability of my own cooking voice, the monotony of what I always throw in my cart as I zigzag the aisles at the grocery store on autopilot. Everyone I know has had a similar malaise recently — all of us feeling rather short on enthusiasm for this monogamous intimacy with our three-ingredient tendencies and our everything-shoved-on-a-sheet-pan ways, no matter how beloved and delicious the results have reliably been. And so I’ve begun reaching for new ideas, new paths, new routes to new pleasures.

headline: The Mysterious Life of Birds Who Never Come Down
abstract: Swifts spend all their time in the sky. What can their journeys tell us about the future?
lead_paragraph: I found a dead common swift once, a husk of a bird under a bridge over the River Thames, where sunlight from the water cast bright scribbles on the arches above. I picked it up, held it in my palm, saw the dust in its feathers, its wings crossed like dull blades, its eyes tightly closed, and realized that I didn’t know what to do. This was a surprise. Encouraged by books, I’d always been the type of Gothic amateur naturalist who preserved interesting bits of the dead. I cleaned and polished fox skulls; disarticulated, dried and kept the wings of roadkill birds. But I knew, looking at the swift, that I could not do anything like that to it. The bird was suffused with a kind of seriousness very akin to holiness. I didn’t want to leave it there, so I took it home, swaddled it in a towel and tucked it in the freezer. It was in early May the next year, as soon as I saw the first returning swifts flowing down from the clouds, that I knew what I had to do. I went to the freezer, took out the swift and buried it in the garden one hand’s-width deep in earth newly warmed by the sun.

headline: ‘I May Destroy You’ Is Perfect TV for an Anxious World
abstract: The HBO drama about trauma is possibly the most emblematic show of 2020.
lead_paragraph: The sixth episode of HBO’s “I May Destroy You” opens on a bucolic urban scene: a park under a train overpass, where three young friends are attempting some plein-air spray-painting on canvas. Terry and Kwame have come to support Arabella, whose therapist has recommended painting to help her heal from a recent sexual assault. But Arabella doesn’t paint. She stands apart from her friends, engrossed in her phone. Terry, concerned, points this out to Kwame, but he shrugs: Arabella looks fine to him.

headline: This Great Black Baseball Player Still Isn’t in the Hall of Fame
abstract: John Donaldson died in obscurity, his statistics devalued because he played before baseball was integrated.
lead_paragraph: Most baseball fans have probably never heard of John Donaldson, a hard-throwing pitcher who drew sold-out crowds around the country for an astonishing three decades before he hung up his glove in 1941. His statistics establish him as one of the greatest to ever play America’s pastime. Yet he died in obscurity.

headline: Why Is There No Consensus About Reopening Schools?
abstract: Here’s what we know: With too many variables and too few studies, schools lack the tools and data they need to balance education and health.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible to reopen school buildings in the fall in a way that keeps kids, educators, staff and their families and communities safe from Covid-19? Is it possible not to do so without harming them in other ways? Already, school closures have set children behind academically. More than 20 million children rely on school breakfasts and lunches. Too many parents face the choice between losing their jobs or leaving their children at home unsupervised. Vaccination rates for various dangerous diseases, typically required before students can attend school, have plummeted. Isolating children from their peers exacts social and emotional costs, which differ by age group and are nearly impossible to quantify. And whether schools reopen or remain closed, the risks are borne disproportionately by low-income communities and people of color. “This is really one of the most perplexing and complex issues I’ve ever faced in 40 years,” says Dan M. Cooper, a professor of pediatrics at the University of California, Irvine.

headline: Is Your Blood Sugar Undermining Your Workouts?
abstract: Eating a diet high in sugar and processed foods could dent our long-term health in part by changing how well our bodies respond to exercise.
lead_paragraph: People with consistently high levels of blood sugar could get less benefit from exercise than those whose blood sugar levels are normal, according to a cautionary new study of nutrition, blood sugar and exercise. The study, which involved rodents and people, suggests that eating a diet high in sugar and processed foods, which may set the stage for poor blood sugar control, could dent our long-term health in part by changing how well our bodies respond to a workout.

headline: Secondhand Shoppers Worry About Their Favorite Local Spots
abstract: Sites like Poshmark and Thredup have thrived during the pandemic, but your neighborhood thrift store is not doing so well.
lead_paragraph: For the last four months, Laurie Sigelman, an accountant in her late 40s who lives in the Studio City neighborhood of Los Angeles, has been waiting impatiently for her favorite stores on Melrose Avenue to reopen.

headline: Inside the Iraqi Kleptocracy
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Corruption, as much as violence, makes Iraq unlivable. It helped fuel the rise of ISIS. And America provides the cash to sustain it, at least $10 billion a year in hard currency.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: We Have a Question for Jeff Bezos and Other Billionaires
abstract: Will you finally let your workers unionize?
lead_paragraph: Covid-19 has created strange bedfellows. Six months ago we, a labor leader and an Amazon vice president, would have been on opposite sides in discussing the future of work at Big Tech in general and Amazon in particular. Then on May 1, one of us, Tim, walked away from a senior role at Amazon Web Services, and potentially millions in compensation, in protest over the firing of workers who spoke out about conditions in the company’s warehouses.

headline: How Do You Know a Human Wrote This?
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: Machines are gaining the ability to write, and they are getting terrifyingly good at it.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never really worried that computers might be gunning for my job. To tell the truth, often, I pray for it. How much better would my life be — how much better would my editor’s life be, to say nothing of the poor readers — if I could ask an all-knowing machine to suggest the best way to start this column? It would surely beat my usual writing process, which involves clawing at my brain with a rusty pickax in the dim hope that a few flakes of wisdom and insight might, like dandruff, settle on the page.

headline: Are the Polls Missing Republican Voters?
abstract: Registered Republicans were actually more likely than registered Democrats to respond to the Times/Siena survey.
lead_paragraph: With polls showing Joe Biden holding a commanding lead, one question keeps popping up: Are these polls missing Trump voters?

headline: High Schoolers Across the Country Are Seeking ‘Teenager Therapy’
abstract: A podcast started by five teens from a bedroom has become a lifeline for students.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic has upended school, summer plans, and daily life for millions of teenagers, many are turning to a podcast to cope. “Teenager Therapy,” hosted by five rising seniors at Loara High School in Anaheim, Calif., has become a lifeline for kids and a breakout hit.

headline: Don’t Fear Dying. Fear Violence.
abstract: Why do millions of practitioners of the Jain religion strive to avoid harming even microscopic creatures?
lead_paragraph: This month’s conversation in our series exploring religion and death is with Pankaj Jain (@ProfPankajJain), an associate professor in the department of philosophy and religion at the University of North Texas. He is the author of “Dharma in America: A Short History of Hindu-Jain Diaspora,” “Dharma and Ecology of Hindu Communities: Sustenance and Sustainability” and other works. He is currently translating “Jain Darshan,” a text on the philosophy of Jainism. In 2019, he appeared in the TV series “The Story of God” with the actor Morgan Freeman.

headline: Where George Floyd Was Killed: Solemn by Day, Violent by Night
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: Two months after the killing of Mr. Floyd, a South Minneapolis neighborhood remains a police-free zone.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Still, they come — from all over the country and beyond. From New Mexico, Texas, Massachusetts. From Africa and Europe. One man even said he walked a thousand miles, all the way from Alabama, just to be in Minneapolis.

headline: The Horror of Isolation
abstract: Three new movies show why this cinematic genre is best suited to the Covid-19 era, when isolation has become not just a way of life, but necessary to avoid deaths.
lead_paragraph: The first essential of a good horror film is an isolated place. Any desolate locale will do: cabin in the woods, empty motel, middle of the ocean, Detroit, just somewhere no one can hear you scream. Populate it with potential victims, add a monster and you’ve got everything you need to make things go bump in the night.

headline: I Cured My Pandemic Anxiety by Making Tiny Food Out of Clay
abstract: The subtle pleasures of trying to make one small piece of the world just right.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always hated cooking. My mother thought it was drudgery; her mother felt the same. As for me, a tech worker, I hid in my profession’s disdain for inefficiency. The calculus of exchanging time or money for feeding my family never balanced in cooking’s favor. For a perfectionist like me (another matrilineal inheritance) long recipes looked like baroque forms of self-torture; there wasn’t even time to shop at the good grocery store.

headline: Latin America Is Facing a ‘Decline of Democracy’ Under the Pandemic

keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Deserts', 'Rock and Stone', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Microbiology', 'Research', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: In the Mojave Desert, a translucent crystal offers bryophytes much-needed respite from the heat of the sun.
lead_paragraph: To humans, a desert oasis may conjure an image of a blue pool encircled by a coronet of palm trees. But to certain mosses, an oasis takes the form of a pebble of milky quartz. The cloudy crystal dilutes the sun’s piercing ultraviolet rays and, in the dry desert heat, traps moisture beneath it, creating a microclimate perfect for a moss.

headline: Families Across the U.S. Struggle to Afford Diapers, Wipes and Formula
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Diapers', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Food Insecurity', 'Unemployment', 'Food Stamps']
abstract: Over 56 million families have lost income since March 13, and diaper banks are straining to fill the need.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, Chelsea Murgatroyd turned to her local diaper bank for a supply of diapers and wipes. Murgatroyd, 29, who has a 4-year-old and 8-month-old in Austin, Texas, co-owned a carpet cleaning business with her husband that opened two years ago. They worked mostly with hotels, but as soon as the coronavirus shutdown happened in March, “all our work was gone,” she said, and ultimately they had to shutter the business. Their savings went quickly. Murgatroyd found the Austin Diaper Bank through a Google search. “We needed help,” she said. “I have never used a charity in my life. That was very different and humbling for me.”

Putin last week — apparently his first opportunity to directly confront Mr. Putin about the C.I.A. assessment since its existence became public late last month.

headline: Mysterious Coronavirus Outbreak Catches Vietnam by Surprise

lead_paragraph: In a world plagued by pandemic, Vietnam seemed like a miracle. As months went by without a single recorded coronavirus death, or even a confirmed case of local transmission, residents began leaving their face masks at home.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Make a no-recipe recipe for gochujang spaghetti, or follow some more formal instruction and prepare a sheet-pan baked feta.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’ve been cooking two or three squares a day for 133 days now, surely the longest run of my cooking life, and if it’s sometimes a chore, I still thrill to the possibilities of an improvisatory session — a no-recipe recipe made with what’s on hand. I love those “recipes,” which are really just outlines, notes that others can make into dishes that become entirely their own.

headline: ‘The Hater’ Review: Resentments and Revenge via Digital Disinformation
abstract: In this Polish film from Jan Komasa, a villainous internet troll makes the personal political, and worse.
lead_paragraph: “The Hater,” a new Netflix movie directed by Jan Komasa from a script by Mateusz Pacewicz, does a lot of telegraphing before getting down to jackhammering. Tomasz (Maciej Musialowski), the title character, is first seen as a law student in Warsaw being called to account for plagiarizing a paper. Facing his professors, one of whom he obsequiously flatters, he smirks in a way that suggests he might soon break out into “Tomorrow Belongs to Me,” the Nazi anthem from “Cabaret.”

headline: Paris Beehives Trace Notre-Dame’s Toxic Fallout
abstract: Bees can act as tiny pollution detectors, say researchers, who found higher but still safe lead levels in honey gathered downwind of the cathedral.
lead_paragraph: The hundreds of tons of lead that burned in the April 2019 fire that nearly destroyed Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris created a dangerous dust that landed in parks, buildings and playgrounds, raising health alarms. Now, scientists say, some of that lead has found its way to a surprising place: honey produced by urban beehives.

headline: Bent Fabric, Pianist and Composer Known for ‘Alley Cat,’ Dies at 95
abstract: A simple tune with an old-time feel, it could embed itself in the listener’s ear as if on a continuous loop. In 1962, it became a worldwide hit.

headline: When a Quarantine Comic-Con Keeps Fans at a Distance
abstract: Comic-Con International in San Diego recreated panels and viewing events for its online-only incarnation but left out ways for fans to interact. Our critic asks, what does that spell for the future of fandoms?
lead_paragraph: Every year, for several days in late July, the San Diego Convention Center is usually animated with people taking part in Comic-Con International. During the last few years, more than 130,000 convention attendees — lifelong fans, collectors, artists and culture vultures — swarmed the city for the event. It’s nerd heaven: exclusive panels and screenings from big studios like Disney and FX, interactive fan experiences like gaming centers and meet-ups, vendors with discounts and deals and more.

headline: Video Shows Burning Freight Train on Arizona Bridge
abstract: A freight train derailed and caught fire as it crossed a bridge in Tempe, Ariz., causing it to partially collapse.
lead_paragraph: A freight train derailed and caught fire as it crossed a bridge in Tempe, Ariz., causing it to partially collapse.

headline: Renada McGuire, Resilient Home Health Aide, Dies at 39
abstract: She decided to work with adults with mental disabilities after giving birth to a child with challenges. She died of complications of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Two Women Charged in Attack on Wisconsin State Senator
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: Tim Carpenter said he was punched and kicked after he recorded video of demonstrators at a protest in the capital, Madison, last month.
lead_paragraph: Two women were arrested and accused of beating a state senator who had been recording video of protesters last month, during a night of intensifying violence in Madison, Wis., the authorities said.

headline: The Go-Go’s Made History 38 Years Ago. There’s Still More to Their Story.
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Women and Girls', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: A new documentary about the Los Angeles band explores the punk roots that came before its pop sheen, and the power dynamics that led to its split.
lead_paragraph: In March 1982, “Beauty and the Beat” — that classic, effervescent, catch-a-wave-of-pink-champagne debut by the Los Angeles band the Go-Go’s — made history: It became the first record by an all-female group who wrote its own songs and played its own instruments to hit No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. Thirty-eight years later, it’s hard to decide what’s more of a shock: That it took so long to happen, or that it hasn’t happened since.

headline: U.N. Panel Takes Aim at Heavy-Handed Police Tactics at Protests
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The comments by the United Nations Human Rights Committee come as the Trump administration faces growing criticism for deploying federal agents to confront Black Lives Matter protesters.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Law-enforcement authorities are obligated to protect and facilitate peaceful demonstrations, an influential United Nations human rights panel said on Wednesday, challenging tactics the police have used against anti-racism protests in American cities and around the world.

headline: ‘Shine Your Eyes’ Review: Reimagining São Paulo
abstract: This feature from the Brazilian filmmaker Matias Mariani, finds a distinctive way to tell a familiar immigrant narrative.
lead_paragraph: A man comes to São Paulo to find his brother. What he discovers, however, is a city more alluring than he could have imagined. “Shine Your Eyes,” from the Brazilian filmmaker Matias Mariani, finds a distinctive way to tell a familiar narrative — of immigrants in megacities, of how dreams can pummel you and of the complexity of fraternal bonds.

headline: ‘Gordon Lightfoot: If You Could Read My Mind’ Review: A Troubadour Looks Back
abstract: The singer-songwriter, now 81, is frank about his own work and refreshingly open to today’s music.
lead_paragraph: If you haven’t laid eyes on the singer-songwriter Gordon Lightfoot in a while, you may be stunned at the beginning of this straightforward, engaging documentary about his life and work, directed by Martha Kehoe and Joan Tosoni. Now 81 years old, Lightfoot doesn’t resemble the curly-haired, oft-mustachioed, outdoorsy-looking troubadour of his 1970s heyday. Skinny, his clean-shaven face now long and almost gaunt, his hair straight and combed back, he looks like an aged underground rocker.

headline: Video Shows ‘Umbrella Man’ Smashing Windows in Minneapolis
abstract: The police in Minneapolis said they have linked a man dressed in black, wearing a gas mask and holding an umbrella, to a white supremacy group, and accused him of trying to provoke violence.
lead_paragraph: The police in Minneapolis said they have linked a man dressed in black, wearing a gas mask and holding an umbrella, to a white supremacy group, and accused him of trying to provoke violence.

headline: Freight Train Catches Fire and Derails in Arizona
abstract: The derailment, on a bridge over a lake in Tempe, caused part of the bridge to collapse, the authorities said. No injuries were reported.
lead_paragraph: A freight train derailed and caught fire as it was crossing a heavy rail bridge in Tempe, Ariz., on Wednesday morning, causing the bridge to partially collapse and sending plumes of black smoke billowing over the Tempe Town Lake, the authorities said.

headline: Whence Came Stonehenge’s Stones? Now We Know
abstract: Last year archaeologists pinpointed the origin of many of the ancient monument’s massive stones. A new study identifies the source of the rest.
lead_paragraph: Back in the ’30s — the 1130s — the Welsh cleric Geoffrey of Monmouth created the impression that Stonehenge was built as a memorial to a bunch of British nobles slain by the Saxons. In his “Historia Regum Britanniae,” Geoffrey tells us that Merlin, the wizard of Arthurian legend, was enlisted to move a ring of giant mystical stones from Mount Killaraus in Ireland to what is commonly believed to be Salisbury Plain, a chalk plateau in southern England, where Stonehenge is located.

headline: Federal Reserve Leaves Rates Near Zero as Economic Recovery Sputters
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Federal Reserve officials made clear that they will work to bolster the economy as the pandemic hurts business activity and the job market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve left interest rates near zero on Wednesday and Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, predicted a long road ahead as a recent spike in virus cases saps momentum from the nascent economic recovery.

headline: This Watermelon Salad Is Meant for Hot Days
abstract: You can use any kind of pickled chiles in this refreshing summery dish.
lead_paragraph: I’d never seen a watermelon small enough to fit in my purse until about a decade ago. But lately, they seem to be everywhere, which is a huge boon to my pandemic melon consumption. Because without a large group to help devour the 20-odd pounds of a standard watermelon, it feels a little sad to lug one home. And as practical as those plastic-wrapped wedges may be, they’re never quite as juicy or as satisfying as what you get from hacking into an intact melon yourself and plunging your biggest knife into its dripping, pink heart.

headline: Val Demings Is on Biden’s V.P. List. Will Her Police Career Hurt or Help?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former police chief in Orlando, Fla., Ms. Demings has emerged as a finalist to be Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s running mate. A review of her record shows a complicated history with episodes involving police misconduct.
lead_paragraph: An Orlando police officer shoved a 27-year-old Hispanic woman down a flight of stairs, breaking her ankle. A jury ordered him to pay her medical bills.

headline: Economy’s Path Forward Is ‘Extraordinarily Uncertain,’ Powell Says
abstract: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome H. Powell said a full recovery was unlikely until Americans felt safe to “re-engage in a broad range of activities.”
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome H. Powell said a full recovery was unlikely until Americans felt safe to “re-engage in a broad range of activities.”

headline: A Food Writer’s Sicilian Pasta Dish, and Tips for Sharing It
abstract: Skye McAlpine has made a name for herself serving bountiful meals to large groups of friends. During lockdown, she’s discovered the joy of cooking for just one or two.
lead_paragraph: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.

headline: Watch live: Fed Chair speaks about the state of the U.S. economic recovery.
An Extra $600 a Week Kept Many Jobless Workers Afloat. Now What Will They Do?
keywords: ['Unemployment Insurance', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'United States Economy', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: A supplement to unemployment benefits is at an end, and Congress is deadlocked over new aid. For some, that means hunger, evictions or bankruptcies.
lead_paragraph: For Sara Gard, the government’s safety net moved smoothly into place when the coronavirus pandemic upended her family’s lives. Jobless benefit checks began arriving a few days after she was furloughed in April from an entertainment company in Atlanta. A $600 weekly supplement, part of an emergency federal program, would cover the mortgage until her company resumed operations — probably in June.

headline: MacKenzie Scott Gives $1.7 Billion to Historically Black Colleges and Other Groups
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Philanthropy', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Historically Black Colleges and Universities']
abstract: One year after pledging to give away most of her fortune, Ms. Scott, an author and the ex-wife of Jeff Bezos, announced that she had donated to causes supporting women, L.G.B.T. rights and racial equality.
lead_paragraph: MacKenzie Scott, one of the world’s richest women, pledged one year ago to give away her money “until the safe is empty.”

headline: Bernie Sanders Is Asking for Masks for All
keywords: ['Masks', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: A national campaign to encourage mask wearing, including the distribution of free masks, would help to check the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont introduced legislation this week that directs the Trump administration to send three “high-quality, reusable” masks to every person in the United States, and would provide $5 billion to increase mask production. This is a good idea.

headline: Teachers Are Wary of Returning to Class, and Online Instruction Too
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Organized Labor', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Unions are threatening to strike if classrooms reopen, but are also pushing to limit live remote teaching. Their demands will shape pandemic education.
lead_paragraph: As the nation heads toward a chaotic back-to-school season, with officials struggling over when to reopen classrooms and how to engage children online, teachers’ unions are playing a powerful role in determining the shape of public education as the coronavirus pandemic continues to rage.

headline: Five Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
abstract: Our critic shares accounts that make her feel, think and see in new ways — something that feels especially vital right now.
lead_paragraph: Coronavirus cases in New York are at a reassuring low, and the state is on its way to reopening. That includes art galleries, which are starting to welcome people back, mostly by appointment. I recently visited two, but am mostly remaining cautious and spending the bulk of my time at home. At this point, everything in my apartment looks incredibly uninteresting (except for my cats), so I’m grateful that Instagram continues to provide a small portal of escape.

headline: Proud of the Kids
abstract: A mother recounts what her 12-year-old daughter and her friends are saying about returning to school and notes, “I was awed by them.” Also: The story behind the flour.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Opening Schools Won’t Be Easy, but Here’s How to Do It Safely
abstract: Not all schools will be able to restart. For those that can, the focus should be on more than just the classroom.
lead_paragraph: As we wrestle in the next few weeks over which of the nation’s schools to reopen — and let’s be clear, not all of them will be safe to restart — we need to understand this: Kindergarten through the 12th grade involves more than just the classroom.

headline: Anti-Mask Louie Gohmert Tests Positive, Sending Shudders Through Congress
abstract: The Texas congressman, who frequently refused to wear a mask, said he had probably contracted the coronavirus because he did so. His diagnosis raised questions about the spread of the virus on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: Representative Louie Gohmert, a Texas Republican who has frequently refused to don a face covering in the Capitol, confirmed on Wednesday that he had tested positive for the coronavirus before a planned trip with President Trump on Air Force One, and he blamed his diagnosis on wearing a mask.

headline: Barr Repeats Trump Falsehoods in Congressional Testimony
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The attorney general echoed many of the president’s inaccurate claims on nationwide protests, police shootings and the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General William P. Barr, in a contentious congressional hearing on Tuesday, defended President Trump and the Justice Department on a variety of matters. Here is a fact-check.

headline: U.S. Open Will Play in Westchester Without Fans
abstract: The rest of the PGA Tour events and all men’s golf major championships except the Masters have announced plans to play without spectators.
lead_paragraph: The outlook for fans attending a major men’s golf championship this year grew bleaker on Wednesday when officials for the 2020 United States Open announced the event in Westchester County, N.Y., would be conducted without spectators.

headline: Madeleine Albright on Covid-19, Fascism and Her Dream Superhero Team
abstract: “We are in one of the most crucial periods that I’ve ever seen,” the former secretary of state said.
lead_paragraph: — Secretary Madeleine Albright

headline: Gum Disease Tied to Alzheimer’s Disease Risk
abstract: Severe gingivitis with tooth loss was associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia.
lead_paragraph: Severe gum disease and tooth loss may be linked to an increased risk for developing dementia, a new study has found.

headline: Memers Have a New Campaign Aimed at Getting Trump Out of Office
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Meme 2020, the social media collective that supported Michael Bloomberg’s presidential primary run, is back with a new focus: mail-in ballot registration.
lead_paragraph: Meme 2020, the collective of social media influencers and content creators that posted sponsored content in support of Michael Bloomberg’s Democratic presidential primary run, is back with a new campaign aimed at preventing the re-election of President Donald Trump.

headline: During the Pandemic, More Women Must Miscarry at Home
abstract: Some women who sought surgical treatment for miscarriage were turned away in the spring. Experts worry it could happen again.
lead_paragraph: Elena Castilla learned she was pregnant with twins in early February. Castilla, 32, lives in New Jersey but works as a teacher outside Philadelphia. She and her husband had been trying to conceive for years and were overjoyed to learn she was finally pregnant.

headline: Big Tech Hearings, Vietnam Outbreak, Sheep Shortage: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Help Me Find Trump’s ‘Anarchists’ in Portland
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: The president has his politically driven narrative. And then there’s reality.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — I’ve been on the front lines of the protests here, searching for the “radical-left anarchists” who President Trump says are on Portland streets each evening.

headline: 9 Great Movies to Stream on Peacock
abstract: Dive into the new NBCUniversal streaming service to discover these excellent (and free) options.
lead_paragraph: Peacock has taken wing, and NBCUniversal’s streaming service distinguishes itself from fellow newcomers Disney+ and HBO Max by offering 15,000 hours of film and TV for free, if viewers are willing to tolerate ad breaks. With enough entertainment to stretch to March 2022 without sleeping, where to begin? The Universal monsters, like the Mummy and the Wolf Man, are an obvious start. Other self-celebratory categories on the home page include movies starring “S.N.L.” alums and a salute to Alfred Hitchcock, who was loyal to the studio for 43 years.

headline: Racist Incident From Bronx Zoo’s Past Draws Apology
abstract: The Wildlife Conservation Society apologized for an incident from 1906 when a Central African man was placed on exhibit at the zoo, and for its association with two eugenicists.
lead_paragraph: The Wildlife Conservation Society, which operates the Bronx Zoo, three other zoos and an aquarium in New York, apologized Wednesday for two aspects of its history that the society’s chief executive described as demonstrating “unconscionable racial intolerance.”

headline: The Optics and the Politics of the Protests
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “I worry that protesters destroying property or retaliating against federal forces, however justified, are playing right into Mr. Trump’s hands,” writes a reader.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Belarus Says Russian Mercenaries Planned to Disrupt August Election
keywords: ['Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Elections']
abstract: State media says 33 Russian fighters have been arrested in Belarus, dramatically escalating a feud between longtime allies.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Escalating a simmering feud with Russia, its neighbor and longtime ally, Belarus on Wednesday charged that more than 200 mercenaries from Russia, disguised as tourists, had infiltrated Belarus on a mission to disrupt its presidential election.

headline: It’s Time to Head to the Woods
abstract: Answering a reader’s question about what to do with vacation time when standard travel seems problematic.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. Life at home seems about where it was a week ago, in this age where it seems to be Wednesday every day, though where I stay we are heading into the dog pound of summer, fans whirring everywhere against the heat. It’s hard to stay focused, hard to seek pleasure against the pressures of the work day or the day spent looking for work, when so many of us are still at home as summer beats on.

headline: Even With an Early Outbreak, Baseball Still Has a Path Forward
abstract: The sport is grappling with the wisdom of continuing the season after the coronavirus infiltrated the Marlins’ roster. But many players remain committed to playing.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Katz stopped by the Hall of Fame on Tuesday in Cooperstown, N.Y., where he served three terms as mayor. It was strange, he thought, to see no plaques in the gallery for the 2020 class, headlined by Derek Jeter. The plaques were always in place on the Tuesday after induction ceremonies.

headline: The World’s Greatest Directors Have Their Own Streaming Lists
abstract: A French platform asked auteurs to put together their ideal cinémathèques. It turns out filmmakers with seemingly little in common share favorite movies.
lead_paragraph: To heck with algorithms: Sometimes, you need a human touch.

headline: Bahrain Buys Into Paris F.C., With Plans to Use It as a Billboard
abstract: The kingdom’s investment has made it the latest Gulf country to try to improve its nation’s image by attaching it to a European soccer club.
lead_paragraph: For years, soccer in Paris has been the hub of Qatar’s global ambitions. Through its ownership of the city’s biggest team, Paris St.-Germain, Qatar has dreamed big, spent big and won big. In doing so, the country has also used the sport’s popularity to enhance its profile on the world stage.

headline: Old Vaccines May Stop the Coronavirus, Study Hints. Scientists Are Skeptical.
abstract: Certain vaccines may provide broad protection against infections. But new research doesn’t prove these vaccines can turn back the coronavirus, experts said.
lead_paragraph: Billions of dollars are being invested in the development of vaccines against the coronavirus. Until one arrives, many scientists have turned to tried-and-true vaccines to see whether they may confer broad protection, and may reduce the risk of coronavirus infection, as well.

headline: Titans of Tech Testify in Their Trust-Me Suits
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Suits (Apparel)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Computers and the Internet', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: It’s a tongue twister, but also a strategy. Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg, Tim Cook and Sundar Pichai appeared before Congress and dressed the part.
lead_paragraph: They didn’t look like titans. They didn’t look like masters of the universe. They didn’t look like “emperors of the online economy,” as Representative David Cicilline, chairman of the antitrust subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee and Democrat from Rhode Island, called them. Nor did they look like “cyber barons,” as Representative Jamie Raskin, a Democrat from Maryland, said.

headline: Lou Henson, Final Four Coach With Two Schools, Dies at 88
abstract: A genial “old school” leader, he took New Mexico State and then Illinois deep into the N.C.A.A. tournament. In a 42-year career, he won close to 800 games.
lead_paragraph: Lou Henson, who led New Mexico State and the University of Illinois to the Final Four in a 42-year head-coaching career in which he piled up almost 800 victories, died on Saturday at his home in Champaign, Ill. He was 88.

headline: Coronavirus Deaths, Big Tech, Clay Food: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: National Endowment for the Humanities Announces New Grants
abstract: This round of funding, the final for the fiscal year, totals $30 million and will support 238 projects.
lead_paragraph: The Amistad Research Center’s holdings on African-American history, a new biography of the poet Robert Frost and a traveling exhibition commemorating the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks are among the 238 recipients of new grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Some teachers’ unions are threatening to strike if districts don’t take sufficient precautions.
lead_paragraph: The school year is on the verge of starting in much of the United States, and the country is still deep in a debate over whether, how and when to bring students back. The White House is pushing for a full return to classrooms, school officials are struggling with safety precautions, and concerned parents are becoming increasingly desperate as their children have fallen behind.

headline: U.S. Surpasses 150,000 Coronavirus Deaths, Far Eclipsing Projections
abstract: The national toll shows how difficult predicting the virus — or human behavior — can be. President Trump and leading experts have at times said that deaths would be much lower.
lead_paragraph: The United States’ leading authority on infectious disease expressed hope in April that no more than 60,000 people in the country would die from the coronavirus. A revered research center predicted a few weeks later that the figure would be just over 70,000 people by early August. When the number of deaths shot up in May, President Trump said that anywhere between 75,000 and 100,000 people could die.

headline: Reopening Schools: Senator Patty Murray Says Congress Needs to Step Up
abstract: She isn’t optimistic that Congress will help schools reopen safely in the fall: “There’s going to be a lot of parents in tears.”
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: N.B.A. Restart Preview: The Lakers and Clippers Stare Down the West
abstract: Anticipation built for a Western Conference finals played entirely in one arena. It’s still possible, but in Florida instead.
lead_paragraph: Almost exactly a year ago, on a sticky summer afternoon in Los Angeles, the Clippers staged a news conference for their two new headliners, Kawhi Leonard and Paul George. The duo sat on a platform inside a recreation center gymnasium that was packed with fans, reporters and team employees. For a long-suffering franchise, the event had the feel of a genuine celebration.

headline: Ex-C.I.A. Chief Criticizes Silence of Top Republicans on Russian Interference
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: A new book by John Brennan is another salvo in the political debate over the intelligence community’s investigation of the election interference campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the final days of the Obama administration, intelligence officials laid out evidence of Russia’s 2016 election interference campaign to congressional leaders, prompting Nancy Pelosi, then the House minority leader, to press for Moscow to be punished.

headline: ‘It’s Been a Crazy Couple Days’: The Yankees’ Virus-Scrambled Week
abstract: The Yankees’ plans changed seemingly by the hour this week, part of the ripple effects of the Miami Marlins’ outbreak.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees’ equipment truck was leaving Philadelphia on Tuesday afternoon, and the team buses were scheduled to do the same in about 45 minutes. Their game against the Phillies had been postponed, just like the previous night’s game matchup, so they were headed back to New York to get ready for a Wednesday game in the Bronx.

headline: N.B.A. Season Restart Preview: In the East, Where Do the Bucks Stop?
abstract: Milwaukee led the Eastern Conference before the season was suspended in March, but a few teams could pose challenges as Giannis Antetokounmpo tries to take the Bucks to the finals.
lead_paragraph: Hello, basketball, my old friend. I’ve come to talk to you again.

headline: Trump Plays on Racist Fears of Terrorized Suburbs to Court White Voters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: President Trump painted a false picture of suburbs under siege, saying he was protecting them from low-income housing, as he seeks to win over white voters who were key to his 2016 victory.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump vowed on Wednesday to protect suburbanites from low-income housing being built in their neighborhoods, making an appeal to white suburban voters by trying to stir up racist fears about affordable housing and the people who live there.

headline: Atlanta Mourns John Lewis and Ponders Carrying On With ‘Good Trouble’
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The congressman and civil rights leader preached in support of nonviolent resistance, a message that some say must live on in his absence.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A motorcade on Wednesday led John Lewis on one final tour of Atlanta, the city he represented in Congress for more than three decades and a place he helped establish as the spiritual home of a nonviolent movement to protest racism.

headline: As Trump Undercuts Aid Talks, White House Says Extra Jobless Benefits Will Lapse
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Unemployment Insurance']
abstract: President Trump signaled that he was not interested in a broad economic recovery package that would have to be negotiated with Democrats, saying he preferred a narrower plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The prospects for a quick agreement between the Trump administration and congressional Democrats on a new round of aid for the ailing economy faded on Wednesday, as President Trump undercut his own party’s efforts to negotiate a deal and a top White House official declared that a lifeline to unemployed workers would run out as scheduled at week’s end.

headline: Lawmakers, United in Their Ire, Lash Out at Big Tech’s Leaders
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce', 'Social Media', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: The chiefs of Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook faced withering questions from Democrats about anti-competitive practices and from Republicans about anti-conservative bias.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief executives of Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook, four tech giants worth nearly $5 trillion combined, faced withering questions from Republican and Democratic lawmakers alike on Wednesday for the tactics and market dominance that had made their enterprises successful.

headline: One in Three Children Have Unacceptably High Lead Levels, Study Says
keywords: ['Lead', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Batteries', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: “Children around the world are being poisoned by lead on a massive and previously unrecognized scale,” according to the study, a collaboration of UNICEF and Pure Earth, an advocacy group.
lead_paragraph: Lead contamination has long been recognized as a health hazard, particularly for the young. But a new study asserts that the extent of the problem is far bigger than previously thought, with one in three children worldwide — about 800 million in all — threatened by unacceptably high lead levels in their blood.

headline: Ashley Judd Can Sue Harvey Weinstein for Sexual Harassment, Court Rules
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', '#MeToo Movement', 'Movies', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Sex Crimes', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The ruling reversed a lower court’s dismissal of one of the claims brought by the actress against the now-imprisoned movie mogul.
lead_paragraph: The actress Ashley Judd can proceed with a sexual harassment claim as part of a lawsuit against Harvey Weinstein, the movie mogul imprisoned for sex crimes and a focus of the #MeToo movement, an appeals court ruled on Wednesday.

headline: The Tanned Man Has a Green Monster
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: Dr. Fauci is now in danger of being lumped into Trump’s envelope of envy, the same place in which he has placed Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease specialist and a leading voice in our battle against Covid-19, has gotten under Donald Trump’s skin.

headline: Ashleigh Barty Will Skip U.S. Open
abstract: The No. 1 women’s singles player opted out of the Grand Slam tournament over concerns about traveling to New York amid the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Ashleigh Barty, the top-ranked women’s singles player, has confirmed that she will not play in the United States Open because of concerns about traveling during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Corrections: July 30, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about similarities between the public personas of President Trump and his father described incorrectly the illness that afflicted Donald Trump’s mother when he was two and a half years old. The illness she suffered from, peritonitis, is an inflammation of the peritoneum, a tissue lining the abdominal cavity, not the stomach lining.

headline: Justice Ginsburg in the Hospital Again
abstract: She underwent a “minimally invasive” procedure to repair a bile duct stent and is expected to be released this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who recently announced that she has been undergoing chemotherapy to address a recurrence of cancer, was back in the hospital on Wednesday, this time for what a Supreme Court spokeswoman called “a minimally invasive nonsurgical procedure.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: New Resistance in Remote City Confronts Putin
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “You rabid dog, why don’t you deal with what is under your own nose? Your people are hungry. Look at how your people live.”

headline: Report: N.B.A.’s Academies in China Abused Athletes
keywords: ['Basketball', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The report said athletes were struck by coaches, housed in crowded conditions and not given schooling as promised.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘In My Skin’ and ‘The Birds’
abstract: A coming-of-age comedy series comes to Hulu. And a thriller from Alfred Hitchcock is on TCM.
lead_paragraph: IN MY SKIN Stream on Hulu. Kayleigh Llewellyn, the Welsh writer behind “In My Skin,” had a parent with bipolar disorder and was constantly worried her peers would learn of it. This series is modeled after Llewellyn’s experiences, and it stars Gabrielle Creevy as Bethan Gwyndaf, a 16-year-old girl who is ashamed of her mother's frequent hospitalizations and her father’s alcoholism. But Bethan is an excellent liar. After all, she’s trying to balance an unstable home life with the typical anxieties of a teenager — like friendships and crushes — as best as she can. The first season is available for streaming.

headline: Trevor Noah Thinks Trump Is ‘Oddly Chilled Out’ About Russia
abstract: The president said he didn’t ask Vladimir Putin whether Russia paid to have U.S. troops killed. The “Daily Show” host can see why that talk would have been “super awkward.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: John Lewis: Together, You Can Redeem the Soul of Our Nation
keywords: ['Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Though I may not be here with you, I urge you to answer the highest calling of your heart and stand up for what you truly believe.
lead_paragraph: While my time here has now come to an end, I want you to know that in the last days and hours of my life you inspired me. You filled me with hope about the next chapter of the great American story when you used your power to make a difference in our society. Millions of people motivated simply by human compassion laid down the burdens of division. Around the country and the world you set aside race, class, age, language and nationality to demand respect for human dignity.

headline: ‘Democracy Is Not a State. It Is an Act.’
abstract: Representative John Lewis’s final words.
lead_paragraph: The brief essay that Representative John Lewis sent me two days before his death — to be published today, on the occasion of his funeral — expresses the hope for national healing and reconciliation that guided his life’s work.

headline: How to Convince Phoebe Bridgers to Write a Rock Song
abstract: The 25-year-old singer and songwriter shows us how “Kyoto” transformed from a ballad into a rock song over months, combining a stray lyric, a bare-bones voice memo from tour and shared memories of childhood.
lead_paragraph: The 25-year-old singer and songwriter shows us how “Kyoto” transformed from a ballad into a rock song over months, combining a stray lyric, a bare-bones voice memo from tour and shared memories of childhood.

headline: His Face, Hands and Feet Swelled Up. What Was Going On?
abstract: The young boy’s grandmother saw strange red lines snaking around his body. Could this be an allergic reaction? A rare autoimmune disease?
lead_paragraph: The 5-year-old boy lay in his grandmother’s arms. “My feet, my feet,” he wailed. She smoothed the tangled bangs away from his forehead then reached for her phone. She wasn’t sure what was going on with her grandson, but she had cared for enough children and grandchildren to know that something was really wrong. His feet were swollen and painful and so were his hands. On his legs there was a rash that exploded over the several hours he was at her house into a series of raised red rings. She called her son and daughter-in-law. The little boy needed to go to the hospital.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Having TSA PreCheck When Your Fiancée Doesn’t
abstract: Should you get extra time at the food court or go through the line for regular people?
lead_paragraph: Amber writes: My fiancée has TSA PreCheck. When we travel together, she leaves me in the regular security line while she zips through. Recently while checking in, my partner pointed to me and asked the TSA agent, “Where’s the line for regular people?” Please order her to go through normal security with me.

headline: Pandemic Loneliness in Late Life
abstract: Many seniors comply with the physical distancing and stay-at-home orders, even as we understand that social isolation generates the lethal byproducts of loneliness.
lead_paragraph: By the end of June, when my husband landed in the hospital, its administrators had begun allowing one visitor per patient, much to my relief. At 92, Don had fallen and fractured a hip. He would need an operation and then rehab in a facility that responded to the ongoing coronavirus by extending its ban on all visitors. This last prospect filled me with dread.

headline: Poem: Beatific
abstract: Respect for the other whom you do not know, but with a slightest stretch of mind, imagine you do. A poem that shrinks the distance between us.
lead_paragraph: Attention to the stranger crossing any road in any town or city; patience with the awkward encounter, the unknown intention; respect for the other whom you do not know, but with a slightest stretch of mind, imagine you do. Tracy K. Smith’s unforgettable poem from “Wade in the Water” feels so potent right now. The pedestrian sees himself one way — hears his own music in those engines idling for him — but who doesn’t? Take it easy. I am thunderstruck by the human care of these last lines. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: Coin Shortage? It May Be Time to Use Your State Quarters
abstract: In the midst of reduced coin circulation, the U.S. Mint is winding down its production of novelty quarters. Should they be saved, or spent?
lead_paragraph: Growing up in San Diego in the early 2000s, Kelsey Fehlberg proudly displayed her state quarters in a map with inserts for each coin. Then, she said, sometime in middle school, “I started to be too cool for it.”

headline: The Strange Lure of Other People’s Photos
abstract: When I consider all that these people lived through — world wars, the Depression, epidemics with no medicine — I’m given a far longer view.
lead_paragraph: My phone is so stuffed with photos that it takes me, no lie, 143 vigorous thumb flicks — past 41,407 pictures — to scroll back through time to its very first snap, a ho-hum shot of music-festival fans under a wide Texas sky. I’ve got plenty more elsewhere. Everyone does: on hard drives, backed up in the cloud, hung on walls and perched on shelves, scrambled in shoe boxes, sorted in old-school albums.

headline: New York Love Story: The Submarine Officer and the Beatles Cover Band
abstract: A Columbia grad student, new to the city, lost his lease. So he organized the perfect send-off.
lead_paragraph: On an otherwise quiet pandemic Sunday, the unmistakable songs of the Beatles started blaring from the roof of a building on the Upper West Side. The band was belting out faithful renditions from the 1969 rooftop concert in London — “Get Back,” “Don’t Let Me Down,” “I’ve Got a Feeling” — and people stepped out onto their balconies and fire escapes to listen.

headline: One Middle School, Six Decades and the Complicated Dynamics of Race
abstract: “Nice White Parents,” the first podcast that partners The Times and Serial Productions, looks at the shaping of education from a different perspective.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: How Phoebe Bridgers (Begrudgingly) Writes a Rock Song
abstract: The singer and songwriter prefers a ballad. But collaborators yanked her out of her comfort zone for “Kyoto,” a breakout from her latest acclaimed album. Here’s how she made it.
lead_paragraph: When Phoebe Bridgers, the 25-year-old singer and songwriter from Los Angeles, has the first inklings of a musical idea, it’s usually in the form of a ballad — slow and somber, but with enough wry energy to keep it interesting.

headline: $25,000 Pod Schools: How Well-to-Do Children Will Weather the Pandemic
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Children and Childhood', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: “This is our emergency fund,” said one parent considering a pod school. “And this is our emergency.”
lead_paragraph: One Sunday afternoon in July, around a dozen parents gathered in a backyard in Hastings-on-Hudson, a village about a half-hour north of Midtown Manhattan. Another dozen joined them via Zoom. Folding chairs had been placed at prudent distances, and masks were dutifully worn. An Australian Labradoodle belonging to the home’s owners strutted among the guests.

headline: Why Barr’s Pick for Brooklyn Prosecutor Faces Scrutiny From All Sides
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Attorneys']
abstract: Seth DuCharme returns to Brooklyn as U.S. attorney after serving a Justice Department that faced criticism of increased politicization.
lead_paragraph: When Attorney General William P. Barr announced a new top federal prosecutor in Brooklyn this month, it was a promotion for one of his closest advisers in Washington.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Religious Crusaders Take On the Pandemic Response
keywords: ['Casinos', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: The fight over limits on church attendance divides the justices.
lead_paragraph: I know I should be jaded by now by the persistence of the Supreme Court’s conservative justices in seeking to elevate religious interests over those of secular society. After all, in the closing days of the court’s term, religious employers won the right to withhold from female employees the contraception coverage to which federal law entitled them. Religious schools gained a broad exemption from the anti-discrimination laws that would otherwise protect classroom teachers and soon, no doubt, other employees as well.

headline: Louisville May Become Latest City to Declare Racism a Public Health Crisis
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Discrimination', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Medicine and Health', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: “We must have a new sense of urgency to make this declaration,” Mayor Greg Fischer said. The city has been the focus of protests after the police killing of Breonna Taylor.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Louisville, Ky., where there have been continuing protests over the police killing of Breonna Taylor and where coronavirus cases have begun to rise, said on Wednesday that the city might join a growing list of local governments that have declared racism a public health crisis.

headline: Obama Unleashes on Trump Privately as He Raises $24 Million for Biden
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Barack Obama has spoken candidly about President Trump to party donors, bringing up the sexual assault allegations against Mr. Trump and warning of his efforts to push “nativist, racist, sexist” fears.
lead_paragraph: At fund-raising events where he has pulled in more than $24 million for Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign in the past two months, former President Barack Obama has privately unleashed on President Trump to party donors, bringing up past accusations of Mr. Trump’s “assaulting women” and warning of his efforts to push “nativist, racist, sexist” fears and resentments.

headline: The Reconciliation Must Be Televised
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Television', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Reparations', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: What is the next step as America confronts its racism? A broadcast spectacle, our critic writes, that could look like court, a telethon, therapy, an Oprah show — and more.
lead_paragraph: When someone wants to explain where the country’s been since Memorial Day, they refer to The Moment. “The Moment,” at first, seemed to name a finite period, the killing of George Floyd on May 25, and the moments his death comprised. “The Moment” then proved spongy quick, absorbing the bewildering madness of the deaths of Ahmaud Arbery and Breonna Taylor and expanding into more protests in more corners of the planet than seemed fathomable. (The demonstrations took place during a pandemic; The Moment had swelled inside a Moment.) It appealed to people whose response to such Moments has tended to be less than vociferous — white people. White people marched and chanted. They ate tear gas and pepper spray. White people said “Black Lives Matter,” “systemic racism” and, occasionally, “reparations.”

headline: A Cool Trudeau Rebuffs Conflict Charges. Will Canadians Buy His Story?
abstract: There was no corruption, just a government working to save lives during a pandemic. That’s the message the prime minister delivered to skeptical lawmakers, and to Canadians.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — There was no corruption, no conflict of interest, just a government and prime minister working around the clock to save lives and livelihoods during a pandemic.

headline: Why Trump’s Blunt Appeals to Suburban Voters May Not Work
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Political Advertising', 'Suburbs', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: People living the “Suburban Lifestyle Dream” tend to support recent protests and disapprove of the president’s handling of race.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s latest campaign ads warn of left-wing mobs destroying American cities. His recent White House comments have depicted a rampage of violence and a “radical movement” to dissolve the police. His Twitter feed has sounded alarms over an Obama-era fair housing rule he has framed as a threat to “The Suburban Housewives of America” and the “Suburban Lifestyle Dream.”

headline: A Covid Patient Goes Home After a Rare Double Lung Transplant
abstract: Mayra Ramirez was the first of a small but growing number of people whose only hope of surviving the coronavirus was to replace their lungs.
lead_paragraph: The last thing that Mayra Ramirez remembers from the emergency room at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago is calling her family to say she had Covid, was about to be put on a ventilator and needed her mother to make medical decisions for her.

headline: No Summer Tournaments Means More Recruits Committing to Colleges
abstract: Villanova has already received verbal commitments from enough players to build most of a starting lineup for future seasons.
lead_paragraph: In April, Jay Wright, the men’s basketball coach at Villanova, worried the coronavirus pandemic would hurt his ability to recruit players from next year’s high school class.

headline: A Half-Century After Wallace, Trump Echoes the Politics of Division
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 1968', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: George Wallace’s speeches and interviews from his 1968 campaign feature language and appeals that sound familiar again as the “law and order” president sends federal forces into the streets.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s cities were in flames amid protests against racial injustice and the fiery presidential candidate vowed to use force. He would authorize the police to “knock somebody in the head” and “call out 30,000 troops and equip them with two-foot-long bayonets and station them every few feet apart.”

headline: How Pimco’s Cayman-Based Hedge Fund Can Profit From the Fed’s Rescue
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Corporations', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Hedge Funds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreign Investments', 'Tax Shelters']
abstract: Congress said borrowers in taxpayer-backed rescue programs had to be from the United States. Wall Street has a workaround.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pacific Investment Management Company runs a hedge fund registered in the Cayman Islands, a common structure for avoiding certain U.S. taxes. But when a profit opportunity arose from the ashes of America’s coronavirus crisis, that international location did not stop it from seizing the moment.

headline: Returning From War, Returning to Racism
abstract: After fighting overseas, Black soldiers faced violence and segregation at home. Many, like Lewis W. Matthews, were forced to take menial jobs. Although he managed to push through racism, that wasn’t an option for most.
lead_paragraph: The latest article from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series by The Times that documents lesser-known stories from the war, focuses on the racism and segregation that Black soldiers faced upon their return.

headline: Afraid of Airlines? There’s Always the Private Jet
abstract: Concerned about virus-related safety on commercial planes, many fliers are turning to private jets for the first time. The catch, of course, is the price.
lead_paragraph: Lexi Shangraw, a San Francisco resident, flew to Phoenix in early March for what was supposed to be a brief visit. But when lockdowns started, she ended up staying longer than anticipated in hopes of waiting out Covid-19.

headline: About 20% of N.J. Prisoners Could Be Freed to Avoid Virus
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: Believed to be the first Covid-19 bill of its kind, the legislation could free more than 3,000 New Jersey prisoners who are within a year of release.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey lawmakers are expected to approve legislation that could free more than 3,000 prisoners — about 20 percent of the state’s prison population — months before their release dates in response to the extraordinary threat posed by the coronavirus in tightly packed correctional facilities.

headline: Johnson & Johnson’s Coronavirus Vaccine Protects Monkeys, Study Finds
abstract: It’s the second study in a week to report promising results in monkeys for a vaccine candidate. But the real test will come with human trials that are now underway.
lead_paragraph: An experimental coronavirus vaccine developed by Johnson & Johnson protected monkeys from infection in a new study. It is the second vaccine candidate to show promising results in monkeys this week.

headline: As Covid Has Become a Red-State Problem, Too, Have Attitudes Changed?
abstract: There’s still a persistent partisan gap in the level of concern and in mask wearing.
lead_paragraph: With the coronavirus spreading into red America, policymakers there have been forced to change course.

keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Politics and Government', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Censorship']
abstract: The region’s lawmakers and regulators are taking direct aim at Amazon, Facebook, Google and Apple in a series of proposed laws.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — European Union leaders are pursuing a new law to make it illegal for Amazon and Apple to give their own products preferential treatment over those of rivals that are sold on their online stores.

headline: 13 Books to Watch For in August
abstract: Stephenie Meyer’s retelling of “Twilight,” Isabel Wilkerson’s examination of American racism, a biography of the drug kingpin El Chapo, and plenty more.
lead_paragraph: August is often a quiet month for publishers, but this year there’s a lot to look forward to: new books from Akwaeke Emezi and Daisy Johnson; a timely re-examination of William Faulkner, with a special focus on how he wrote about race; and an astrophysicist’s (surprisingly soothing) guide to the end of the universe as we know it.

headline: The Dictator Who Waged War on Darfur Is Gone, but the Killing Goes On
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The ouster of Sudan’s longtime ruler last year stoked hopes for peace in brutalized Darfur. But violence has surged amid fresh accusations against Sudan’s security forces.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — On camels, horses and motorbikes, dozens of Arab militiamen stormed into the remote village in Darfur, in western Sudan, firing wildly, witnesses said. Houses were pillaged, animals stolen and water tanks smashed. Villagers ran for their lives.

headline: Virus-Driven Push to Release Juvenile Detainees Leaves Black Youth Behind
abstract: After an initial decrease in the youth detention population since the pandemic began, the rate of release has slowed, and the gap between white youth and Black youth has grown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Black youth detained in juvenile justice facilities have been released at a far slower rate than their white peers in response to the coronavirus, according to a new report that also found that the gap in release rates between the two groups had nearly doubled over the course of the pandemic.

headline: Renée Fleming, Songbird in Seclusion
abstract: America’s top soprano will return to the Met stage in 2022, starring in a new opera based on “The Hours,” by Michael Cunningham.
lead_paragraph: McLEAN, Va. — Tim Jessell, a lanky divorced Washington corporate attorney and father of three, had given up on love in 2008 when he was set up on a blind date with a beautiful blond New Yorker who had also given up on love.

headline: China Tries Its Favorite Economic Cure: More Construction
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Building (Construction)', 'Credit and Debt', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Local Government', 'Railroads', 'Machinery and Equipment', 'High-Speed Rail Projects', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Strong sales at China’s biggest construction equipment maker show Beijing’s strategy for recovery after the virus. But while the company, XCMG, is prospering, the rest of the economy is struggling.
lead_paragraph: XUZHOU, China — At a cavernous factory in the Chinese city of Xuzhou, 100 new workers have just been hired to produce giant construction cranes. Nearby, at another sprawling factory, employees toil until midnight to assemble drilling and tunneling machines. A few blocks away, their colleagues at a factory that makes dump trucks have received enough orders to keep them busy well into next year.

keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Masks', 'Research', 'Coughs', 'Air Conditioning', 'Cruises', 'Content Type: Service']

headline: The German economy had its biggest slump in 50 years.
abstract: The German economy shrank 10.1 percent from April through June compared to the previous quarter, the biggest decline since the government starting keeping the data in 1970.

headline: Huawei’s phones outsell Samsung’s, a milestone, report says.

headline: A Protester, an Unmarked N.Y.P.D. Van and a Viral Video

lead_paragraph: The Belgian racing team Heli had an engine problem. Specifically, under race conditions, the manifold of the four-cylinder turbo diesel in its BMW 1-series exploded, bursting along an ultrasonically welded seam that held together the manifold’s two halves.

headline: The Gulf Between Republicans and Democrats on Coronavirus Aid, in 9 Charts
keywords: ['Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
