headline: Hong Kong Bans Eating in Restaurants. And Then It Doesn’t.
abstract: City officials did a quick U-turn in the face of public anger, after viral photos showed workers eating lunch on curbs and bridges in the hot sun.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kongers have rarely seen their government react so swiftly to public opinion.

headline: A Romance Blooms in Nebraska
abstract: Robert Voelte and Ian Rose met at an elementary school in Omaha, where they had both taught.
lead_paragraph: Robert Voelte and Ian Rose call themselves an intergenerational, intercultural, interracial gay couple standing in the center of a blue dot in the middle of a red state. That state is Nebraska, where they met in August 2008 on Mr. Rose’s first day as a vocal music teacher at the Omaha elementary school where Mr. Voelte teaches kindergarten.

headline: Romance Around the Great Lakes
abstract: Adam Schlicht turned himself and A.J. Tindall into X-Men superheros for the cover of a comic book he had custom-made for his proposal.
lead_paragraph: Three of the Great Lakes came into play during Adam Schlicht and Aaron Jefferson Tindall’s relationship — their first date was next to Lake Erie in Cleveland, they were married along the shores of Lake Michigan in Milwaukee and they went on a honeymoon in Bayfield, Wis., steps from Lake Superior.

headline: A Page-Turner of a Proposal
abstract: Phillip Stiller, an equity analyst, proposed to Kerry Ederer, a morning news anchor in New York, with the help of his twins.
lead_paragraph: After three dates with Philip Stiller, Kerry Ederer knew her search, virtual or otherwise, was over.

headline: A Perfect Spot for Running, or Proposing
abstract: Harrison Marks knew just the place to propose to Jennifer Soffen — anywhere along the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lauren Soffen and Harrison Douglas Marks got to know each other walking, running and biking along New York City’s waterfront paths, especially by the Hudson River.

headline: The ‘Right Time’ Came a Decade Later
abstract: A mutual friend made sure Zmira Zilkha and Ward Wolff met at Middlebury College in Vermont, but it was 13 more years before they got together for good.
lead_paragraph: She was from Maine and he was from California, but when Zmira Zilkha and Ward Wolff were both admitted in 2005 to Middlebury College in Vermont, a friend that he knew from high school and that she knew from summers in Prouts Neck, Maine, made sure that the two connected.

headline: Taking a ‘Leap of Faith’ in New England
abstract: The couple met in Miami in 2013, but it took four years and a move to the Boston area for a romance to bloom between the two.
lead_paragraph: The marriage of Ruby Sattar and Frank Romeu on July 24, at City Hall in Quincy, Mass., with just three friends attending, was a far cry from the 150-guest bash the two had planned for February 2021 in their hometown of Miami.

headline: ‘How Lucky We Are to Have Found Each Other.’
abstract: Oliver Cacananta and Danny Wan met singing in the Gay Asian Pacific Alliance Men’s Chorus.
lead_paragraph: For a couple who met in a choir, Oliver Cacananta has a perfect description of the partnership between himself and Danny Wan. “We harmonize,” said Mr. Cacananta (left).

headline: Her Just-Friends Note Was Tossed in a Hurry
abstract: Sophia Bachmann and Iain Coston met, they had dinner, they fell in love.
lead_paragraph: Sophia Bachmann almost broke up with Iain Coston even before their first date in 2018.

headline: Wrong Places at the Right Time
abstract: The Rev. Lydia Wittman and Rafi Ziauddin nearly missed their first chance to connect, but found so many more chances later.
lead_paragraph: If there hadn’t been two Dunkin’ stores on the same road in East Hartford, Conn., then maybe the Rev. Lydia Wittman and Rafi Ziauddin wouldn’t have ended up at different doughnut shops for their first date in 2014. And they wouldn’t have missed the beginning of the University of Connecticut football game or the tailgate party they meant to attend.

headline: From Barbados to Bucharest
abstract: Alicia Arendt, a foreign service officer with the State Department, met Rohan Ford, a businessman, while serving in Barbados.
lead_paragraph: Alicia Arendt, a foreign service officer with the Department of State serving at the United States Embassy in Bridgetown, Barbados, will be soon be transferred to a three-year post in Bucharest, Romania. And she’s taking with her something she did not have when she first arrived in Barbados in September 2018: her husband, Rohan Ford.

headline: How to Navigate the Coronavirus Real Estate Market
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Mortgages', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Recession and Depression', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Interest Rates', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Suburbs', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Community Reinvestment Act']
abstract: Suburbs and fashionable exurbs are hot, but don’t forget that home prices have fallen before, a Nobel laureate warns.
lead_paragraph: There are signs that pockets of the U.S. housing market are heating up, particularly in the suburbs and fashionable exurbs, to which people have been fleeing to escape the coronavirus.

headline: The Pandemic’s Top Sellers
abstract: As we shelter in place, the things we’ve been buying for our homes have shifted a bit.
lead_paragraph: As we shelter in place, the things we’ve been buying for our homes have shifted a bit.

headline: A #MeToo Moment in the Military
keywords: ['#MeToo Movement', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Sexual Harassment', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: What happened to 20-year-old Specialist Vanessa Guillen, and how the United States responded.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: What Are We Buying for Our Homes During the Pandemic?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Furniture', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Cookware']
abstract: Sheltering in place may mean avoiding stores, but online shopping for certain home-related items has increased.
lead_paragraph: Even as parts of the country start to reopen after several months of coronavirus lockdown, many of us are still focused on making our homes as comfortable as possible while we weather the pandemic. We surveyed several furniture and design companies to find out what people have been buying since mid-March.

headline: Catch up: Ford posts a profit, United warns pilots of furloughs and more.
abstract: Here’s some of what happened on Thursday that you might have missed.
lead_paragraph: Here’s some of what happened on Thursday that you might have missed.

headline: Executives are getting together in video games, to bond, brainstorm or rampage.
abstract: With Zoom call fatigue setting in and boozy lunches out of the question during the coronavirus pandemic, housebound executives are finding new ways to meet and bond in video games. The goal is to break up a day that is crammed with get-togethers that generally look, sound and feel identical.
lead_paragraph: With Zoom call fatigue setting in and boozy lunches out of the question during the coronavirus pandemic, housebound executives are finding new ways to meet and bond in video games. The goal is to break up a day that is crammed with get-togethers that generally look, sound and feel identical.

headline: European stocks are looking more attractive to investors.
abstract: Europe has a bad rep with investors. For years, asset managers and bank strategists have characterized the region by its anemic growth rate and shaky political union, and steered investors away.
lead_paragraph: Europe has a bad rep with investors. For years, asset managers and bank strategists have characterized the region by its anemic growth rate and shaky political union, and steered investors away.

headline: Hong Kong Delays Election, Citing Coronavirus. The Opposition Isn’t Buying It.
abstract: Pro-democracy politicians, who had hoped to ride widespread discontent to big gains in the fall, saw the yearlong delay as an attempt to thwart their momentum.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong government said on Friday that it would postpone the city’s September legislative election by one year because of the coronavirus pandemic, a decision seen by the pro-democracy opposition as a brazen attempt to thwart its electoral momentum and avoid the defeat of pro-Beijing candidates.

headline: Outdoors Innovation
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: If you’re looking for a pick-me-up — to be inspired by human ingenuity in the midst of a whole lot of bad news — today’s newsletter is for you.

headline: The Lynn Shelton That Marc Maron Knew
abstract: The comedian and podcaster reflects on his relationship with the filmmaker and TV director who died unexpectedly in May.
lead_paragraph: When the writer-director Lynn Shelton died in May, it was a devastating loss to film, to moviegoers who knew her for intimate low-budget features like “Humpday” and “Your Sister’s Sister,” and to TV audiences starting to discover her work as a director on series like “GLOW” and “The Morning Show.” On Tuesday, she received a posthumous Emmy directing nomination for the Hulu limited series “Little Fires Everywhere.”

headline: Voting by Mail Is Popular. So Is the False Idea That It’s Ripe for Fraud.
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Discrimination', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Americans overwhelmingly support increased access to mail voting, but they also appear to be susceptible to misinformation about it.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.

headline: Sanofi and GlaxoSmithKline Snag Biggest Coronavirus Vaccine Deal Yet
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Public-Private Sector Cooperation', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The arrangement brings the Trump administration’s investment in coronavirus vaccine projects to more than $8 billion. The head of the federal effort is a former GSK executive.
lead_paragraph: The French drug maker Sanofi said on Friday that it had secured an agreement of up to $2.1 billion to supply the U.S. federal government with 100 million doses of its experimental coronavirus vaccine, the largest such deal announced to date.

headline: They Made How Much?
abstract: Big tech companies reported bumper profits in the shadow of congressional scrutiny over their outsize market power.
lead_paragraph: You won’t want to miss our next DealBook Debrief call, where we will discuss racial injustice and corporate America with special guest Nikole Hannah-Jones, The Times’s domestic correspondent and creator of The 1619 Project. What more is needed from the business community to produce lasting change? Join us on Thursday, Aug. 6 at 11 a.m. Eastern to find out. R.S.V.P. here. (Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)

headline: ‘Palm Springs’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Max Barbakow narrates a sequence featuring Andy Samberg and Cristin Milioti.
lead_paragraph: The director Max Barbakow narrates a sequence featuring Andy Samberg and Cristin Milioti.

headline: Kamala Harris Pushes Back on Criticism of ‘Ambition’
abstract: President Trump warned of an “election disaster” with mail-in voting, but cited no evidence of fraud. Joe Biden has postponed his planned announcement of a running mate.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election.

headline: How Andy Samberg and Cristin Milioti Meet Cute in ‘Palm Springs’
abstract: The director Max Barbakow narrates a wedding sequence from his comedy, now streaming on Hulu.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Trump White House Meets Its Match With Barstool Sports
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'News and News Media', 'Social Media']
abstract: Trump admits he regrets some tweets during this fratty, swampy summer, as nostalgia surges for Trump’s first underdog campaign and a more uncertain future looms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During the Clinton presidency, The New Republic billed itself as the in-flight magazine of Air Force One. Former President Obama loved The Atlantic. President Trump prefers Barstool Sports, the sophomoric, in-your-face sports blog beloved by bros of all stripes.

headline: A Momentous First Night Back for the N.B.A.
keywords: ['Basketball', 'United States National Anthem Protests (2016- )', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Close games, social justice protests and a principal role for Rudy Gobert, again.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — When his postgame Zoom interview was over, before making a triumphant exit to the team bus, Rudy Gobert of the Utah Jazz acknowledged that the historic play he was savoring did not go exactly as planned.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Week 8: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 7 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 18.
lead_paragraph: Update: Winners have been announced!

headline: With Security Law as a Cudgel, Beijing Cracks Down on Hong Kong
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The spirit and the letter of the new law has been used to crush Hong Kong’s opposition. In the latest blow to the pro-democracy movement, the government postponed an election, citing the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For weeks, as Beijing quickly drafted and imposed a stringent new national security law for Hong Kong, many in the territory feared the rules would be used to intimidate the opposition, but hoped they would not presage a broad crackdown.

headline: Marines Locate Missing Vehicle and Human Remains After California Accident
abstract: One Marine was killed and eight service members were missing after the amphibious vehicle accident on Thursday. The military is working to recover their remains and to raise the vehicle from the seafloor.
lead_paragraph: An amphibious assault vehicle that took on water and sank last week off the coast of Southern California, killing one Marine and leaving eight service members presumed dead, was located on Monday, according to the authorities.

headline: Should I Travel This Year?
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Travel Warnings', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Travel looks very different in 2020. Here are some questions to help you consider the risks to yourself and others if you take a trip.
lead_paragraph: Travel looks very different in 2020. Here are some questions to help you consider the risks to yourself and others if you take a trip.

headline: How Massage Therapists in California Are Adapting to the Pandemic
abstract: Some counties in California have not allowed personal care businesses to reopen. Other counties have moved them exclusively outdoors.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. You cannot give a massage over Zoom. And that means California’s decisions to declare many massage therapists as nonessential workers has made their lives especially challenging in the pandemic.

headline: Can’t Afford a Birkin Bag or a Racehorse? You Can Invest in One
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Horses', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Horse Racing', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Interest in fractional investments has grown as the pandemic has forced more people to spend time at home, but advisers say the strategy has risks.
lead_paragraph: Antonella Carbonaro, a consultant to financial technology companies, saved up to buy her Birkin bag, a luxury tote made by Hermès that sells new for tens of thousands of dollars. Since getting her bag in 2018, Ms. Carbonaro has stored it in her closet, bringing it out only on special occasions.

headline: Zimbabwe Locks Down Capital, Thwarting Planned Protests
abstract: Three years after the fall of the strongman Robert Mugabe, the country is in free fall and his successor is clamping down by arresting opposition activists — including an author just nominated for the Booker Prize.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — When Robert Mugabe was ousted as president of Zimbabwe in a coup in 2017, many in the country hoped for an end to the repression and mismanagement that had characterized his 37 years in office.

headline: An Artist Having Fun While Waiting for Catastrophe
abstract: Heather Phillipson’s works make viewers smile, but underneath their bright, over-the-top exteriors are dark, urgent messages.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The artist Heather Phillipson’s latest work is a 31-foot statue of a dollop of whipped cream, with a fly on it.

headline: ‘America, What a Country.’ Michael Dell on His Life and Business
abstract: The billionaire tech executive discusses capitalism, immigration, innovation and why 2020 has given us “a glimpse of the future.”
lead_paragraph: The first time I sat down to talk with Michael Dell, the coronavirus had not disrupted life and business around the globe.

headline: Covid-19 Tests Are in Short Supply. Should You Still Get One?
abstract: Public health officials once suggested only people with symptoms should be tested. Now some say getting one is a civic duty.
lead_paragraph: First, health officials said you should not get tested for the coronavirus unless you had symptoms. Then the message shifted: Mass testing was essential to trace and contain the pandemic.

headline: A Native American Coming-of-Age and the Uses of Enchantment
abstract: In James Bird’s “The Brave,” a boy bullied for his numeric mind undergoes a metamorphosis when he’s sent to live on a reservation with his Native American mother.
lead_paragraph: James Bird’s THE BRAVE (Feiwel and Friends, 320 pp., $16.99; ages 9 to 12) is a bighearted book about Collin. Collin has a few problems. The most pressing is his compulsion to blurt out the number of letters in the words spoken to him. This leads to bullying and misunderstandings, and turns a sweet, smart adolescent into a problem child. When the novel opens, Collin has caused one problem too many for his beleaguered father, who sends him to live with his Ojibwe mother (whom he’s never met) on a reservation in Minnesota.

headline: Billie Eilish’s Isolation Awakening, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Laura Veirs, A.G. Cook, Bill Frisell and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Monsters vs. Aliens
abstract: In “Sia Martinez and the Moonlit Beginning of Everything,” a Mexican-American girl lights candles in the desert for her deported mother. Then a spacecraft arrives.
lead_paragraph: Sia Martinez is trying so hard to believe in miracles.

headline: The ‘Wildcat’ Episode, or, Did Broadway Love Lucy?
abstract: With her sitcom over and marriage finished, Lucille Ball fulfilled an old dream: a stint on Broadway. It did not go well.
lead_paragraph: This is the story of how the most famous and talented sitcom star of her era — and maybe of all time — failed on Broadway.

headline: In 1920, Native Women Sought the Vote. Here’s What’s Next.
keywords: ['Nineteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights", 'Law and Legislation', 'Politics and Government', 'Land Use Policies', 'Constitution (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Native Americans', 'Treaties', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: The 19th Amendment did not bring the right to vote to all Native women, but two experts in a conversation said it did usher in the possibility of change.
lead_paragraph: Native women were highly visible in early 20th-century suffrage activism. White suffragists, fascinated by Native matriarchal power, invited Native women to speak at conferences, join parades and write for their publications. Native suffragists took advantage of these opportunities to speak about pressing issues in their communities — Native voting, land loss and treaty rights. But their stories have largely been forgotten.

headline: How Italy Turned Around Its Coronavirus Calamity
abstract: After a stumbling start, the country has gone from being a global pariah to a model — however imperfect — of viral containment that holds lessons for its neighbors and for the United States.
lead_paragraph: ROME — When the coronavirus erupted in the West, Italy was the nightmarish epicenter, a place to avoid at all costs and a shorthand in the United States and much of Europe for uncontrolled contagion.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Let Gabrielle Hamilton’s latest recipe, for eggplant croquettes, give your cooking new life.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here’s the beginning of Gabrielle Hamilton’s Eat column in The Times this week, and I think she’s speaking for a lot of us:

headline: In Britain, the Economic Comeback Is in the Suburbs
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Suburbs', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantines']
abstract: Central London remains “very, very quiet” while shops and cafes outside town centers are seeing a fragile recovery.
lead_paragraph: READING, England — The British economy is facing its worst recession since “The Great Frost” of 1709, a horrifically cold winter. Large retailers are shutting stores, and inconsistent quarantine rules are raising anxiety about a second pandemic wave. And yet Summertown, a suburb north of Oxford, has something to look forward to: Its main shopping street is about to get a new bookstore.

headline: Malik B., Longtime Member of the Roots, Is Dead at 47
abstract: He brought his understatedly gritty lyrics and cadence to the band during its formative years. After he went solo, he dropped in on a few Roots albums.
lead_paragraph: Malik B., the elusive M.C. best known for his work with the Roots, died on Wednesday. He was 47.

headline: St. Louis Cardinals Postpone Game After Two Players Test Positive for Virus
abstract: Baseball’s outbreak spreads to a third major league clubhouse, but Major League Baseball said the Cardinals’ game on Saturday will go ahead as planned.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball’s worrying coronavirus outbreak spread into another clubhouse on Friday when the St. Louis Cardinals’ game in Milwaukee was postponed after two Cardinals players tested positive for the virus.

headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Terminator 2: Judgment Day’
abstract: Killer robots may not seem like soothing fare, but unlike real life, the world’s horrors come to an end when the movie does.
lead_paragraph: Like everyone, I lose track of time these days. Some people react to that kind of limbo with comfort viewing that creates a familiar routine, like detective series or cooking shows. But I turn to a George H.W. Bush-era blockbuster about time travel and killer robots so I can feel a bit better about the world.

headline: I Tried to Live Without the Tech Giants. It Was Impossible.
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Software', 'Social Media', 'Cloud Computing', 'Smartphones']
abstract: As lawmakers debate whether Apple, Google, Facebook, and Amazon are monopolies, a reporter recalls her attempt to avoid interacting with the companies.
lead_paragraph: The chief executives of Amazon, Facebook, Google and Apple were called before a House antitrust committee this week, ostensibly to answer questions about whether they have too much power and whether that hurts consumers.

headline: What Is Randonautica Really About?
abstract: An app that generates coordinates for adventurers claims to turn your thoughts into reality. TikTok and YouTube creators want you to believe it — but you shouldn’t.
lead_paragraph: The app led one person to a friendly dog in the desert and another to a field of wildflowers. One young woman, after making her college decision, followed the app to a field where her school’s initials had been mowed into the grass.

headline: Chewy Meets Crispy in This Summery Salad
abstract: This satisfying bowl gets its bite from farro, its crunch from spiced chickpeas, and its sweetness from roasted corn and slivered fennel.
lead_paragraph: Farro salads have a lot going on in the texture department. Unlike their softer sisters — quinoa, couscous and rice — farro has a hearty, starchy chewiness that’s satisfying even before you start tossing in piles of diced vegetables, dried fruit and toasted nuts.

headline: Italian Fashion Hasn’t Changed Enough, Black Designers Say
abstract: A new letter sent by independent designers to fashion executives demands reform, or at least a serious conversation about race.
lead_paragraph: The designer Stella Jean wanted to make something clear about an impassioned letter she sent to Italian fashion’s governing body: “It’s not a protest,” she said. “I’m not protesting. It’s a proposal.”

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Mourning John Lewis. Advances in Alzheimer’s research. Sheep in Senegal. Ben & Jerry. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend, and welcome to August. It’s the beginning of the end of summer. If you’re like me, the end of the heat can’t come soon enough. If not, don’t worry: There’s still plenty of time to head to the woods, make a watermelon salad or even learn some theater skills (or knife-fighting techniques). Whatever you do, be sure to make time for some amazing journalism.

headline: Embracing the Value in Scarcity
abstract: Major League Baseball is busy worrying that a 60-game season is not long enough. But that hand-wringing might offer an insight into why elite soccer is such a global phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: You could have been enjoying this newsletter hours ago. If you like it, sign up to get it directly, every Friday, at nytimes.com/rory.

headline: Low-Key Cooking
abstract: These recipes are simple and satisfying enough for those sweet and drowsy August days.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Somehow, we have arrived at July 31, the month gone in a flash. Let’s keep things low-key this week: That sweet and drowsy August feeling is about to set in. Ideas? Thoughts? You can find me at dearemily@nytimes.com.

headline: Isaias Tracking Map
abstract: Follow the storm’s path as it moves north along the Atlantic Coast.
lead_paragraph: Follow the storm’s path as it moves north along the Atlantic Coast.

headline: Democrats Decry Fed Push to Ease Capital Requirements for Big Banks
abstract: Senators Sherrod Brown and Elizabeth Warren criticized a Fed-backed effort to slip a change into the next coronavirus relief package
lead_paragraph: Two Senate Democrats sharply criticized the Federal Reserve’s effort to get Congress to help it weaken capital requirements for big banks this week, following a report in The New York Times that Republicans were hoping to include such a provision in the next coronavirus relief package.

headline: Why the Working Class Votes Against Its Economic Interests
abstract: Two new books, Robert B. Reich’s “The System” and Zephyr Teachout’s “Break ’Em Up,” examine the impact of economic inequality in America.
lead_paragraph: THE SYSTEMWho Rigged It, How We Fix ItBy Robert B. ReichBREAK ’EM UPRecovering Our Freedom From Big Ag, Big Tech, and Big MoneyBy Zephyr Teachout

headline: In India, a Gay Prince’s Coming Out Earns Accolades, and Enemies
abstract: Prince Manvendra’s journey from an excruciatingly lonely child to a global L.G.B.T.Q. advocate included death threats and disinheritance.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Born into a royal family that once ruled the kingdom of Rajpipla in India, he was raised in the family’s palaces and mansions and was being groomed to take over a dynasty that goes back 600 years.

headline: Review: A Sci-Fi Classic Featuring a Multiverse of Stooges
abstract: In “The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy,” an experimental theater lab operating from a closet adapts a timely tale about the solitude of cramped quarters.
lead_paragraph: With its freshly color-coded cardigans, my pandemic closet was looking pretty sharp, I thought — until I saw Joshua William Gelb’s. Soon after Covid-19 hit New York, he emptied his, painted it white, reinforced it with plywood, removed its door and turned it into a cross-disciplinary performance lab. (Here’s how he did it.)

headline: Five Argument Starters for More Joyful Disagreements
abstract: Since we’re all stuck together all the time, let’s figure out some new things to argue about.
lead_paragraph: Since we’re all stuck together all the time, let’s figure out some new things to argue about.

headline: Dobby Dobson, Versatile Jamaican Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 78
abstract: Best known for his hit “I’m a Loving Pauper,” he was a significant figure in the evolution of Jamaican music. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Lobbying Intensifies Among V.P. Candidates as Biden’s Search Nears an End
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Two women, Representative Karen Bass and Susan Rice, the former national security adviser, are among the most formidable contenders on Joe Biden’s list.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr. has entered the final stage of his deliberations about choosing a running mate as he prepares to talk one-on-one with the finalists next week, while Democratic leaders lobby him furiously to elevate their allies and sink their enemies.

headline: John McNamara, Red Sox Skipper in ’86 Series Loss, Dies at 88
abstract: He led six big league teams with some success, but he’s best remembered for questionable managerial moves in a crushing (for Boston) sixth game against the Mets.
lead_paragraph: John McNamara, who managed the Boston Red Sox to within one out of a World Series championship against the Mets in 1986 — and whose strategy in the critical sixth game has been questioned ever since — died on Tuesday at his home in Brentwood, Tenn., a Nashville suburb. He was 88.

headline: Hurricane Isaias Rakes the Bahamas on a Track for Florida’s East Coast
abstract: The National Hurricane Center issued a hurricane warning for over 150 miles of the Florida coastline, stretching from Boca Raton to the northern bound of Brevard County.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A hurricane warning was issued for parts of Florida’s Atlantic coast on Friday, hours after Hurricane Isaias raked the Bahamas, parts of Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic.

headline: Amazon Wins Without Even Trying
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'United States Economy', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: As America’s economy suffers, Big Tech does shockingly well.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: U.S. Adds Sanctions Over Internment of Muslims in China
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)']
abstract: The Treasury Department imposed sanctions on a powerful government entity that runs companies and farms in the Xinjiang region, where officials carry out the mass internment of Muslims.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration announced sanctions Friday on a powerful government entity and two senior officials who have helped manage it, citing systemic human rights abuses against predominantly Muslim ethnic minorities in the Xinjiang region in China’s far northwest.

headline: The ‘Seductive Lure’ of Authoritarianism
abstract: Anne Applebaum discusses “Twilight of Democracy,” and Barbara Demick talks about “Eat the Buddha.”

headline: Provincetown: Go for the Mask Compliance, Stay for a Show
abstract: In this gay haven known for its nightlife, the crowds are smaller this summer. And the nightclubs are closed. But by the pool, the show goes on.
lead_paragraph: PROVINCETOWN, Mass. — Varla Jean Merman has a good arm, and when she threw her hairpiece into the swimming pool the other evening at the end of an increasingly frenzied number in her cabaret show, it landed on the surface just right. Then it floated there, inert and disheveled.

headline: Mutual Fund Winners Don’t Stay Ahead for Long
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Research', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: A new study finds that hot mutual funds generally don’t keep outperforming from year to year, overturning an important finding from the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Don’t try to beat the stock market.

headline: Alan Parker, Versatile Film Director, Is Dead at 76
abstract: “Midnight Express” and “Mississippi Burning” brought him Oscar nominations, and many of his other films, including “Fame,” were acclaimed.
lead_paragraph: Alan Parker, who was nominated for the best-director Oscar for the 1978 film “Midnight Express” and again 10 years later for “Mississippi Burning,” died on Friday in South London. He was 76.

headline: Muppet Meta Mania, Revived for the Streaming Era
abstract: The Muppets were made of, by and for TV. Two new shows, “Muppets Now” on Disney+ and “The Not-Too-Late Show With Elmo” on HBO Max, reimagine the media-savvy furry friends for a new age.
lead_paragraph: What is a Muppet made of? One of the first corrections I ever had to make in this newspaper, and still the best, involved my review of the 2015 ABC sitcom “The Muppets.” I referred to the covering that makes up the outside of Jim Henson’s creations as felt; a reader informed me that it was, in fact, fleece. Noted.

headline: Isabel Wilkerson’s ‘Caste’ Is an ‘Instant American Classic’ About Our Abiding Sin
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Caste Systems', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Wilkerson’s new book makes unsettling comparisons between India’s treatment of its untouchables, Nazi Germany’s treatment of Jews and America’s treatment of African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: A critic shouldn’t often deal in superlatives. He or she is here to explicate, to expand context and to make fine distinctions. But sometimes a reviewer will shout as if into a mountaintop megaphone. I recently came upon William Kennedy’s review of “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” which he called “the first piece of literature since the Book of Genesis that should be required reading for the entire human race.” Kennedy wasn’t far off.

headline: Steven Soderbergh and Amy Seimetz Made the Pandemic Movies of the Moment
keywords: ['Movies', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: His 2011 “Contagion” and her new thriller “She Dies Tomorrow” have added resonance now. “Why is this kind of imagery so compelling?” Soderbergh asked.
lead_paragraph: The directors Steven Soderbergh and Amy Seimetz had prepared for a significant spring. Her new film “She Dies Tomorrow” was intended to debut at the South by Southwest film festival in March, after which she’d fly to Detroit to act in Soderbergh’s crime drama “Kill Switch.”

headline: Comfort Viewing: Why I Still Love ‘The Goldbergs’
abstract: The period sitcom about a Jewish family in the ’80s has for seven seasons been a weekly gift of old-fashioned zingers.
lead_paragraph: In the TV business, hit shows inevitably inspire imitators, but ABC’s programming department maybe went a bit too crazy at the copy machine after “Modern Family” became a smash in the fall of 2009. Before long, the network had added “The Middle,” “The Neighbors,” “Trophy Wife,” “Fresh off the Boat,” “black-ish,” “The Real O’Neals,” “Speechless” and “The Kids Are Alright” — all sitcoms about the complications of domestic life, from different perspectives. Black? Asian-American? Catholic? Gay? Disabled? Stuck in the ’70s? From outer space? For much of the 2010s, ABC gave multiple kinds of families a prime-time platform.

keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Say this about President Trump’s approach to Moscow: It’s been consistent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the eve of accepting the Republican nomination for president four years ago, Donald J. Trump declared that he would pull out of NATO if American allies did not pay more for their defense, waving away the thought that it would play into the hands of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who has spent his career trying to dismantle the Western alliance.

lead_paragraph: Nello, an Italian restaurant and celebrity hot spot on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, has long been a showroom for wealthy New Yorkers undeterred by its lofty prices.

headline: Love Letter: Making Room for More Love (and Sheep)
abstract: And, a legacy of “Loving” continued.
lead_paragraph: Living in a picturesque farmhouse on many acres of land may sound like a dream to some. But many couples who live and work on fully functioning farms know it’s anything but glamorous. Tending to the day-to-day demands of a farm, including caring for several different animals, can take a toll on any relationship. In this week’s Modern Love essay, Bethany Groff Dorau, a writer who grew up on a farm, questions whether her city slicker husband is cut out for the rural life. Then they decide to adopt three sheep.

keywords: ['Weather', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Global Warming', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A sweltering 125 degrees Fahrenheit in Baghdad on Tuesday; a record 115 degrees in Damascus on Wednesday. And extreme levels of heat in Israel and Lebanon.

keywords: ['Social Media', 'Foreign Investments', 'Mobile Applications', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — TikTok, the Chinese-owned video app that has been under scrutiny from the Trump administration, is in talks to sell itself to Microsoft and other companies as President Trump weighs harsh actions against the business, including forcing TikTok to divorce itself from its parent company, ByteDance, said people with knowledge of the discussions.

headline: Let’s End the Wait for Coronavirus Test Results. Here’s How.
abstract: States should look to New York’s strategies.
lead_paragraph: It’s been six months since the United States reported its first coronavirus case, and getting a test can still take days. National labs are overwhelmed, leaving people to wait as much as two weeks for results. Every day that testing falls short is another day the virus can spread undetected, costing lives and delaying the reopening of our economy, schools and society.

headline: 5 Things to Know About Shakuntala Devi
abstract: A film about the Indian mathematics genius is now streaming on Amazon Prime Video. Here are five facts to get you more familiar.
lead_paragraph: Shakuntala Devi (1929-2013) was best known as “the human computer” for her ability to perform lengthy calculations in her head, swiftly. One example of this, described in her New York Times obituary, took place in 1977, at Southern Methodist University in Dallas, where she extracted the 23rd root of a 201-digit number in 50 seconds. It took a Univac computer 62 seconds to do the same.

headline: Overlooked No More: Roland Johnson, Who Fought to Shut Down Institutions for the Disabled
keywords: ['Intellectual Disabilities', 'Abuse of the Disabled', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Biographical Information']
abstract: He survived 13 years of neglect and abuse, including sexual assault, at the notorious Pennhurst State School and Hospital outside Philadelphia before emerging as a champion for the disabled.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. This latest installment is part of a series exploring how the Americans With Disabilities Act has shaped modern life for disabled people. Share your stories or email us at ada@nytimes.com.

headline: White House Backs Away from Proposals to Make Voting Secure
abstract: Kayleigh McEnany, the White House press secretary, echoed President Trump’s attacks on mail-in ballots and did not support proposals that would support states in making voting more secure.

headline: Antonio Brown Suspended Eight Games by the N.F.L.
abstract: The All-Pro receiver was penalized for his role in a January dispute at his home and for sending threatening texts to a woman who had accused him of sexual misconduct.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. on Friday suspended wide receiver Antonio Brown for eight regular-season games for his role in a January dispute with a moving company employee, for which he pleaded no contest to burglary and battery charges and received two years probation. Brown was also penalized for sending threatening texts to a woman who accused him of sexual misconduct. The suspension was first reported by The Washington Post and was confirmed in a statement by the league.

headline: Stabbed in the Convent, Murdered in the Yard
abstract: In the newest batch of crime novels, bodies accumulate at a rather alarming rate.
lead_paragraph: Political protest is a sacred rite of passage for the young. In LADY CHEVY (Pegasus Crime, 296 pp., $25.95), John Woods delivers a righteous cause to a high school senior named Amy Wirkner, whose family lives in Barnesville, a bucolic town in the Ohio Valley that’s being chewed up by fracking and strip mining.

headline: Florida Teenager Is Charged as ‘Mastermind’ of Twitter Hack
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The authorities arrested a 17-year-old who they said ran a scheme that targeted the accounts of celebrities, including former President Barack Obama and Elon Musk. Two others were also charged.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — One by one, the celebrity Twitter accounts posted the same strange message: Send Bitcoin and they would send back double your money. Elon Musk. Bill Gates. Kanye West. Joseph R. Biden Jr. Former President Barack Obama. They, and dozens of others, were being hacked, and Twitter appeared powerless to stop it.

headline: Countering G.O.P. on Courts, Democrats Will Call for ‘Structural’ Change
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Elections, Courts and the Judiciary']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Alarmed at Republicans’ success at reshaping the federal courts, Democrats plan to use their forthcoming party platform to push for “structural court reforms” to counter what they describe as a concerted Republican campaign to pack the judiciary with “unqualified, partisan judges.”

headline: The Most Soothing Man on TikTok
abstract: By slowing down and soaking it all in, Larry Scott makes the whole TikTok experience … nice.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most illuminating, purely pleasurable videos on TikTok this month have been Larry Scott’s awed observations of cooking, where the teen from Florida looks on as a meal is lovingly prepared al fresco: hand-rolled pasta dough, spices arranged by color, a knife assuredly having its way with a pepper or onion. The recipe videos have quick cuts, and with each new move, Scott’s eyes widen. His brow furrows just a bit while he tries to suss out what’s being made. He eases into a million-dollar smile when something catches his fancy. “Oh,” he says, with a sparkle of realization. “Nice.”

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix, Amazon and More in August

lead_paragraph: Welcome. We started At Home to help readers lead a full and cultured life during the pandemic, featuring great reads and helpful advice alongside recommendations for things to do and watch and listen to and see.

headline: San Francisco 49ers Look to Increase Stake in Leeds United
abstract: The N.F.L. team, which has owned a piece of the soccer team since 2018, is in talks to increase its investment now that Leeds is returning to the Premier League.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It took the San Francisco 49ers seven years to turn their interest in owning a piece of an English soccer team into reality. Now, two years after buying a 10 percent stake in Leeds United, the 49ers’ owners are looking to increase their investment, and their involvement, in the storied club that two weeks ago won promotion to the Premier League.

lead_paragraph: In April, as the coronavirus was rampaging through the Northeast, Larry Churchill considered what he would do if the pandemic caused medical shortages. Should he, a 75-year-old, direct care to younger people before him if he got sick?

headline: In a 19th-Century Cart House, a Designer Creates a Room of Her Own
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Furniture']
abstract: Harriet Anstruther has transformed a former outbuilding on her farm in the British countryside into a maximalist retreat.
lead_paragraph: When the British designer Harriet Anstruther first moved into the 500-year-old wattle-and-daub West Sussex farmhouse she shares with her husband, the photographer Henry Bourne, in 1998, there wasn’t much of a garden. “It was a nest of brambles and snakes,” she recalls of the square half-acre walled plot that separates the timber-frame home from the property’s roughly 100 acres of pasture, woodland and wildflower meadows. “It was cold and wet,” she says, “but unbelievably idyllic.”

headline: The Unschooled Artists
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Graphic Novels', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Creativity', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting']
abstract: Taking lessons in creativity from my kids.
lead_paragraph: but being home with my kids turned out to be more inspiring than any art school I can imagine. When my wife and I sent them off to school, I worried less about whether the classroom would rob them of their creativity and more about what would happen to my creativity without them around to inspire me.

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Black Is King’: Let’s Discuss
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Movies', 'Dancing', 'Art']
abstract: Six critics on the visual album rooted in her “Lion King”-inspired record “The Gift,” a grand statement of African-diaspora pride and creative power.
lead_paragraph: When Beyoncé took a speaking role as Nala — the eventual queen — in the 2019 remake of “The Lion King,” she decided to delve beyond Disney’s Hollywood version of Africa. She added a new, gospel-charged song, “Spirit,” to the film’s soundtrack, and gathered an international coalition, featuring up-and-coming African songwriters and producers, to join her on a full-length album, “The Lion King: The Gift.” Now she has turned songs from the album into a film of her own, working with various directors as she did on her visual albums “Beyoncé” and “Lemonade.” Here, critics for The New York Times discuss the imagery and implications of “Black Is King.”

headline: ‘The Better I Got in Sports, the Worse the Racism Got’
keywords: ['Indigenous Australians', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Basketball', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Patty Mills, a key reserve for the San Antonio Spurs, said he developed an emotional shield from a lifetime of racial abuse, but he is using the platform of the N.B.A.’s restart to speak out against racism.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — There were a few must-pack accessories for Patty Mills of the San Antonio Spurs for his stay at Walt Disney World. Mills brought a stack of books on Black history in the United States and his native Australia. He made sure to carefully transport his favorite flat-brimmed hat, which bears two flags representing Australia’s Indigenous populations.

headline: William English, Who Helped Build the Computer Mouse, Dies at 91
abstract: He was one of the computing pioneers who “showed what a computer interface could — and should — look like,” a colleague said.
lead_paragraph: William English, the engineer and researcher who helped build the first computer mouse and, in 1968, orchestrated an elaborate demonstration of the technology that foretold the computers, tablets and smartphones of today, died on July 26 in San Rafael, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Despite Historic Plunge, Europe’s Economy Flashes Signs of Recovery

abstract: European countries that have better contained the virus are poised for speedier economic recovery than the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Before the pandemic, a traditional state of play prevailed in the enormous economies on the opposite sides of the Atlantic. Europe — full of older people, and rife with bickering over policy — appeared stagnant. The United States, ruled by innovation and risk-taking, seemed set to grow faster.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: New estimates gauge the risk of returning to classrooms.
lead_paragraph: How risky will in-person education be this fall? Researchers at the University of Texas at Austin have new estimates that provide a rough gauge of the risk that students and teachers could encounter in each county in the United States.

headline: Where to Stream Alan Parker’s Best Movies
abstract: Though he may not have stamped a specific style on his work, he brought an intelligence and professionalism to each film, whether musicals or dark dramas.
lead_paragraph: The British filmmaker Alan Parker, who died on Friday at 76, was not easy to pin down. Many of his contemporaries, particularly in the hyper-commercialized world of 1980s studio moviemaking, settled on a particular style or specialty, and drilled down into it. Parker was closer to the journeymen directors of the old Hollywood studio system, who would take on (and excel at) just about any story or genre they were assigned. Over the course of his 27-year career, Parker made thrillers, dramas, comedies and (especially) musicals, and though many bore little resemblance to one another, they were bound by two common elements: the intelligence of Parker’s approach, and the professionalism of his craft. Here are a few of his must-see works:

headline: The Less Impossible Israeli-Palestinian Peace
abstract: The two-state idea is comatose but not dead.
lead_paragraph: Let’s play the Israel-Palestine impossibility game. It’s timely because the two-state peace for which I have long argued is now widely deemed unattainable. The answer, as one of the most thoughtful observers of the conflict, Peter Beinart, has recently argued, must be one state with equal rights for Jews and Palestinians, “a Jewish home that is not a Jewish state.”
